description:
This restaurant has always been a treat for my family to enjoy during special occasions. Tucked away in a less crowded part of the city, Ozumo created a dining space that makes one feel at home and that is very important to us. 
The food is fantastic..obviously, otherwise why would you even know about this place? 
I look forward to the next time we sit down together at Ozumo.
author: Fran R.

description:
Excellent meal. The service was spot on. Boom was our server and she was awesome at recommending dishes - attentive enough without being over bearing. 

The cod appetizer was heavenly. Melted in your mouth. Each sushi roll was better than the next. And the toro was excellent. 

They also have an amazing selection of sake.

It's definitely pricey - not a cheap sushi experience. But everything is so fresh and well prepared, and great service.
author: Trish B.

description:
Came here with a friend. My friend recommended their sushi as she said other dishes were mediocre. So I ordered the unagi nigari and the spider roll. The ingredients were fresh and the unagi was very warm when I tasted it, what a nice surprise. It was grilled soft with a good amount of sauce - not too sweet. Definitely would like to have it again.
We also had some specialty roll with an appetizer, and these were decent too.
A little bit pricey overall but the sensei who made our sushi was so cheerful and funny. We really enjoyed taking to him! The staff were extremely nice too, with attentive service. The pleasant experience we had make this review got one more star.
author: Tian G.

description:
(1) Food: Exceptionally disappointing food, especially considering the prices and location. The seafood does not seem fresh (lacking flavor and poor texture), and dishes were not cooked or assembled properly.

- Hotate-Yaki ($23): The fingerling potatoes were 75% raw (they were still crunchy), and they were huge for fingerling potatoes - I actually wondered if they used a sliced baking potato. The scallops were cooked through, but I could not taste them past the miso butter, which was very salty and reminded me of Velveeta cheese.
- Shishito peppers ($7): Came out cold, barely grilled, and limp.
- California Roll ($12): The pieces were cut very unevenly - They looked like a mini mountain range sitting on a plate.
- Flight of sakes: Good, but also tiny!

(2) Atmosphere: Very beautiful.

(3) Service: Very fast and friendly, but not particularly helpful with the menu.

(4) Location: In a wonderful location in SOMA.
author: Michelle B.

description:
This would have been a 1-star review had it not been for the positive interaction with the manager of this restaurant. Even then, a more accurate rating would be 1.5.

The service was subpar-- our service was awkward and inattentive, the menu's online pricing didn't not match the menu in person-- the menu online had the steak priced at $75 but it was $90 IRL, and my steak had too much fat on the ends to not be served with a knife and fork but rather just chopsticks (you should have seen my chopstick skills to get the fat removed, as it was definitely a funny sight!) We also ordered the aged tofu which was flavorless.

When we brought up the issue of the fatty steak to our server he said, "well...it was a ribeye and ribeyes have fat" but the amount of fat on this ribeye was unusual. In fact, the manager acknowledged it as soon as she saw the steak. 


I hate complaining in a restaurant and it's also not my favorite thing to do online, but...I guess that's what Yelp is for.
author: Grace P.

description: Quality fish and sushi, but prices ain't cheap here so be prepared to splurge. I would come back for sake and light bite.  Full dinner can easily be $150-$200 per person before drinks.  Lunch bento is a much better value, about $50 including a beer.
author: Edmond T.

description:
Great spot for a work lunch or date night. 

Beautiful interior with killer views of The Bay. 

I'm surprised Ozumo only gets 3.5 stars I think the food is great.  It might be downgraded slightly due to the cost - expect close to $100 for lunch for 2 with no cocktails. 

Gyoza is really good. 

Sushi is awesome - sashimi is even better. 

I love the bento box lunches. 

The gyu don and tonkatsu curry both rock!

The best things at Ozumo...

The happy hour ramen and the Shabu Shabu on the dinner menu. The Shabu Shabu is not cheap but it's insane!

Killer bar scene with lots of pretty people. Wish they poured stiffer cocktails
author: Dave K.

description: Not worth the price what's so ever. The food is not good. The fish was not great either. It's one of those places u have to drown the fish with spicy mayo in other for it to taste ok. The service was good. Our waitress was great and accommodating but for $300 you're better off eating eating at your local sushi shop.
author: Gisselle R.

description: I love this place!  Beautiful decor, great views, friendly waitstaff.  First and foremost, they have happy hour from 4-6.  I enjoyed prossecco/sparkling wine, garlic edamame and ribs from the menu.  We then shared the hamachi sashimi appetizer, the Ozumo roll and the Schacho lobster roll.  They Schacho roll is plated very elegantly and was delish!  We rounded the evening out with desert.  The chocolate bomb was good, but the sushi was definitely the highlight of the night.
author: Yellowbag T.

description:
A friend in the restaurant industry recommended this place to me a while ago, but I didn't try it until a recent business trip landed me in a hotel near here. 

Service was excellent and attentive from the moment I walked through the door. I sat at the bar and had a great time chatting with the chef on a relatively slow night. 

Food was amazing. Chef made me a gorgeous omakase platter! And it was some of the freshest fish I've had in years. Okay, this might reflect that my palate has been acclimated to generally subpar San Diego sushi. But still, the quality dramatically surpasses the average San Diego joint. And the quality actually matches the price(y) tag. I was almost certain there was a built-in location tax, but nope, totally worth it on just the food alone. 

Speaking of location though, it's right by the water. Evening views of the Bay Bridge are so pretty!
author: Anna C.

description:
Excellent food and service. 

It was a busy Saturday night and unfortunately we had to change our reservation time twice, and each time was accommodating graciously. 

We requested booth seating, which was accommodated.

We liked the albacore tuna and the wild salmon sashimi. We also loved the hanabi, which was the yellowtail sashimi/avocado/jalapeño app.

The Ozumo roll was good but we really loved the Bucho roll. 

I was in costume as a vampire and joked with our waiter that I'd like some blood, and he brought a free red drink. 

The restaurant manager came to our table to welcome us and see how our experience was.
author: Mo T.

description: Quality was good but way overpriced. We had a bunch of rolls no drinks and walked out with a $150 check. Still don't know why. I know a few places with even better quality for 50% less. Device was good though. Still, won't be back.
author: Falko H.

description:
Ikura really stood out as being super round firm, yet burst easily, with a nice orange color. Satisfyingly juicy and complex ikura flavor-- salty yet sweet, although this wasn't reminiscent of ocean water, and was more...human like? Not sure quite how to describe it. Lightly vinegared rice and slightly chewy seaweed. Decent meat to rice ratio. 4/5.

The ika (squid) was slightly too thinly cut for my tastes. The knife markings on the top of it were beautiful though. The texture was chewy yet chewable (perfect) without coating the interior of your mouth. This lacked any sort of flavor, however. 3.25/5.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Ranking on service alone. Obnoxious. Unhelpful. Rude. Came in close to closing time with a large group that had a reservation. Server was curt with us and unhelpful with explaining the menu to the sushi novices among us. When I asked how large the $27 lobster tail was I was informed that "it's the size of a lobster tail." Happy to be only visiting the city, and therefore a temporary inconvenience to the snobby staff of Ozumo.

Postscript - If you love grilled lobster, stay away from the lobster tail. It is not what you will expect, and the aroma alone will soil your appetite.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Wow, what an amazing place!!!
The decor is so cool, the bar, the seating and the view of the Bay Bridge is sweet.
Had reservations so I was seated right away. I can only imagine what it would be like on a Friday or Saturday.  
Service was right on, can right away and welcomed us and asked if we had any questions about the menu and took our drink order.  The Sake options are incredible, pick your pleasure.
Take your palette on a journey, the flavors and combinations are over the top.  Each dish a plated with a unique touch and is just as tasty with the eyes as it is in your mouth.
author: David E.

description:
The service was great! I got the Sake Sampler which was really good. And the Wine selections were amazing. We got some nigiri and mako rolls. Though for the amount that we spent, I didn't feel it was worth it. The best rolls there were the Scallop (so fresh!). The tuna tartare was really good as well. 

I'm happy it was on the corporate account because it was good but for the price we paid, it was not worth it.
author: Ryan R.

description:
Ozumo has been around awhile but the quality of the sushi continues to impress. The decor is modern and the view on the water is second to none. 

I ordered a sake tasting and it was crisp and refreshing. For appetizers, the Dohyo is the tuna, avocado and tobiko tower it was light and delicious. The mushroom salad was tasty as well. 

We also ordered Toro (a must!), fatty Salmon Belly (awesome), Shiro Maguro, Tai and Kampachi. It was all so fresh and the rice expertly prepared.

But my favorite was the Gindara, which is the Miso-Black Cod. It's so buttery and delicious it melts in your mouth!

For dessert, we ordered the chocolate flourless cake with green tea ice cream. What a great pairing. I think I devoured the whole thing in just a few bites. 

The Happy Hour is spot on but when you want an amazing experience sitting on the water eating some of the best sushi in the City, Ozumo is the place to go!!!
author: melissa l.

description:
The restaurant is not very well marked from the street. The door is simple.  When entering it is dark and you walk through the bar to get to the restaurant. Once in the restaurant it is noisy, the sushi bar top was very sticky and the waiters were fast talking and slow to return when needing a beverage refill or to serve food.

Oddly enough, I sat at the sushi bar and was never greeted by any of the chefs standing directly in front of me.

Item #1 "dohyo" bigeye tuna tartare, edamame, cucumber, avocado, black tobiko, ponzu, wasabi oil, served with gyoza chips. This dish came and appears it was made in advance or with old avocado. It was served with cold greasy chips. As for flavor my palate is ruined with the taste of greasy chips and ponzu. This Sadly missed my expectations for $18.

Item #2 "Yuzu Maguro Maki" asparagus tempura, cucumber, kaiware roll topped with maguro, shiso, yuzu goma vinaigrette sauce. The presentation is wonderful. The flavor is thrown off by the shiso giving a very woody flavor - not good. I wouldn't order it again, especially for $18.

Item #3 "Sekiwake" spicy tuna roll with tobiko, tempura flakes, salmon and hamachi with a peanut sauce. The peanut sauce is nice but really doesn't go with the dish. I can't tell where the tempura flakes are and the roll is small. The salmon is bitter and fishy the rice is ok. And for spicy - that's got to be a joke as pepper has more spice than this roll it's really bland. I do like the hamachi but my mouth is quite fishy and nasty tasting. Another $18 failure.

After three solid attempts it was a horrible experience not to return.

One person 3 rolls and a 12 ounce beer $82.
author: Chris A.

description: A place to adore. If you want a sublime Japanese meal with a lovely view of the bay bridge from the booths you are in luck. Ozumo has a new look, new menu and is THE PLACE for sushi in San Francisco. The uni is always delicate and buttery, one of the best I have had the pleasure of having. If I sound like I am laying it on thick it because I just left and I am in food heaven... that bit of ecstasy that lingers after a truly lovely meal. My favorite items on the menu are the wagu with fingerling limes, the uni nigiri and summer snow saki. Lastly, as a personal note, this restaurant is free of latex gloves and takes allergies seriously which is a major plus in my book.
author: Ashley G.

description: This place has the best Sushi. Amazing service from all of the staff and a really yummy new menu. They were so accommodating with our 4 year old son. We will be back soon
author: Stef J.

description:
This place is amazing! One of the best sashimi's I have had so far. I'm a sucker for salmon sashimi and everything was so fresh and amazing.

Got the blue fin tuna belly was sooooo yummy, big eye tuna, baby octopus and wild salmon sashimi! My favs was wild salmon sashimi but both the tuna sashimi's were really fresh and just melted in my mouth. The baby octopus was pretty good too, not as chewy as the rest of the spots that I have been to still chewy.

We also got a Sacho roll, which was beyond amazing and took us by surprise. Never tried the jalepeño n mango combination and the plating was fabulous. They had the mayo and the soy sauce as a side n was an amazing combination with the roll. You guys absolutely need to try this dish. 

Also got 2 kinds of hot sake, don't remember the names and not a sake connoisseur so apologies! We ended up spending close to 300 bucks on a low key random night which I felt guilty about but spent 100 bucks on the sake ‍
Did I forget the ambience? Good lord! It has the view of the bay bridge, and we went for dinner and could see the bay bridge all lit up. It was spectacular given my love for the overly underrated bay bridge.
author: Darshana S.

description: My roommate and I came in at a really busy time and were made to feel like we were the only guests in the restaurant. The vibe was amazing and the food was even better . This place made me realize how much I miss Japanese cuisine. And more importantly, how much guest service and experience makes a eirestaurant good or UHMAZING ! Uzumo is UHMAZING! To Kristen , Mel, Royce ,  Marcos , and the rest of the team ! Keep doing what you are doing ! ITS WORKING - BIG TIME .
author: Gabriella D.

description:
Ozumo is a very trendy venue. Nice view of the bay, modern interior, super clean and comfortable. 

The highlights of our meal were: 
Hanabi: there's a reason there are a million pictures of this dish on yelp.  It was my favorite dish of the night.
Shacho: also so good. There's no rice, so it's not your typical sushi roll- but it was delicious and beautifully plated
Black cod: highly recommend. Second favorite dish.  the cod was perfectly cooked- soft moist melts in your mouth and the sauce doesn't overpower the natural flavor of the cod 

The service was impeccable. Our waitress was attentive, knowledgeable of the menu, and very friendly. 

Would highly recommend Ozumo to anyone!
author: Ashley A.

description:
We had the omakase on the table to make things easier for everyone. 

Grill your own pieces of A5 wagyu beef.  Choose how you want it cooked, I was able to cook it seared as much as I like.  I even had one just un-cooked, as rare as you can get.  The green tea salt was a good edition and foi gras butter was just right for the cooking.

The sushi and sashimi meats tasted fresh and good.  The chefs choice of sashimi and sushi were a good combination.

The calamari appetizer was very good as well, grilled and the tentacles had some crispiness light breading as well.
author: Kent H.

description:
This last visit was my 3rd time dining here. Each time has been great, from food to service I left satisfied. 

Only thing I dislike is that the portions are so small. Not filling if you come in super hungry unless you want to order about 10 different plates. Since its a bit pricey for small portions, we usually choose our few options wisely. Definately worth it though
author: Ashley J.

description:
I ate here with my office for lunch. Conclusion - mediocre sushi. If I had to recommend one roll it would be the shacho, but you only get four pieces for $24. In a city with a lot of sushi options, I'd forego Ozumo.
 

The staff was great and the food was aesthetically pleasing. For reasons mentioned above, it's a three star review from me.

I would also like to say that I've lived in Japan and I go back frequently so my standards for Japanese cuisine are a bit higher than average.
author: Melanie E.

description:
Love Ozumo. I am not sure how  I didn't know about it before. Sushi is fantastic. Sake list is huge and the staff super knowledgeable.. 

The restaurant is beautiful and over looks the bay bridge. What a view! But I sat in the Kotatsu room, a really unique and fun experience if you ask me, I felt like I was back in Japan. Our server explained the differences between the sake's and walked us through the process of making it.

We were blown away by the lovely sushi the chefs made for us. We asked to be surprised and then also ordered sashimi. It was beautifully fresh. We also ordered the Dhoyo but with endive, shrimp tempura, mushroom miso, and a few other dishes from the kitchen. We were not disappointed here either (Gindara was a huge hit with my group.)

I noticed people have mentioned the prices, but this is top quality sushi, I expect it to be a little more money than Tokyo Express, lol. 

I will be back and can't wait to try Sunday's handroll's at the bar!
author: Kristan B.

description: Amazing sushi, perfect location, and fun cool upbeat atmosphere. Would definitely check out when in San Francisco.
author: Adisbel H.

description: Excellent sushi. My favourite was the dessert - Choco Choco. I would definitely go here again.
author: Rutika D.

description:
As a weary, burdened traveller in a foreign land, I somehow found myself sitting at the bar of Ozumo on a weekday night. 

Amidst the formal attire of after-hours business parties and spontaneous romantic dates sits this dopey boy in a pink shirt slightly sweat-stained from a half-day spent navigating the streets of SF on foot holding a Snoopy carrying bag for my writing books/journals.

Marcos greets me warmly, enthusiastically. I shared with him my one impromptu mission: I want to find a Sake to show me the light in the world of rice wines. 

Browsing their expansive Sake menu, I came across several options that called out to me. The intrigue of the described tasting notes matched the richly poetic names themselves - brief expressions the beautiful, art-appreciating country where these hidden treasures come from. 

Marcos was eager to help out, answering any and every question I had - most before they had a chance to leave my lips! Suddenly, not being in a rush as I had been up to that point in the day, I was willing to go on a relaxed adventure. Having a case of Schrödinger's Bank Account, I concerned myself not regarding the prices of these world class beverages.  I Instead opted to experience a variety of these liquid blessings from The Land of The Rising Sun. 

Fatigued, I had a frayed filter and was quick to admit that my limited experience up until this point was Sho-Chiku-Bai on sale at CVS. (Heated up in the microwave to help the bargain beverage proliferate my bloodstream.) Without a hint nor shred of dismay, Marcos in his great patience showed his respect that I would be willing to taste of the fruits from greener pastures. 

On that fateful night, I tried three Sake varieties that have forever changed my perspective. Being a craft beer snob (hint: Westvleteren) I was surprised to find myself daydreaming about switching my rainy-day trove of liquid barley for rice. 

This review may seem airy and filled with poetry, and that's exactly what enlightenment Ozumo offers!  A step *away* from the mundane, the on-sale, the bargain selections, and the bland ... a portal *into* a divine expression of Japan that cannot be read about but experienced first-hand. Thank you Marcos & Ozumo staff for making what had been a stressful day so rich, ripe, and meaningful.

Finally. The most significant piece of knowledge I learned that night was *what exact ingredient* made these selections so heavenly. No, I will not share it with you here ...

... because you'll have to take that journey into Ozumo to find out for yourself.
author: Jason P.

description:
Pretty good, but not excellent. I think the three-and-a-half-star consensus here is pretty accurate, especially relative to the price.

I had the chef's sampler for sashimi and nigiri. The fish was generally quite good -- salmon and tuna on the slightly fattier side. It wasn't the richest in flavor I've ever had, but good nonetheless.

I also had some of the black prawn tempura, which was a little awkward in texture because the prawn inside was quite crispy, and the tempura's fried batter would soften after sitting for more than a minute or two. Nonetheless, the flavor was quite good. 

Overall enjoyable. Atmosphere, decor, etc. is quite nice -- a step up from the usual cramped sushi restaurants.
author: John L.

description:
This place is totally going downhill from what it used to be. It used to be not that great but now is even worse.
I came here on Friday night, there were a lot of empty seats.
Service was really really slow.. food was not great but extremely overpriced.
The regular omakase ($50) came with 5 pcs nigiri and 3 kind sashimi. Nothing special but very expensive.
Definitely not coming back.
author: Irene X.

description: Decent, but overpriced. And service usually lacking. Last time the steak was super dry and our server seemed virtually clueless on how to handle. She didn't even offer to take it off the bill. A guest shouldn't have to ask. So we paid for it anyway. The trade off, won't be going to Ozumo again.
author: John R.

description:
We came here maybe 3 years ago and haven't been back since. Me and my 3 friends ordered the omakase/tasting meal and it was so poorly executed, i still remember it.

It was the same night that we saw Hunter Pence eating beside us in the next table, but even that encounter couldn't save the meal! 

Our waitress has long fake press on nails on with glitter detail. She shouldn't have those on and be serving food.  

The food was ALL severely overpriced for what it was. We ordered an appetizer and that SAME appetizer was brought to our table the second time because the Omakase also included that dish. Why would you do that?? Bring something else! Uh duh?

We dropped $450 between the 4 of us and left i satisfied.

The sake flight was disappointing. Small pours and not memorable.

Word on the street is they are closing soon and moving out of SF.

I get it. Rent must be Ridiculously high being by the Embarcadero. But why he in such a huge ass space? So you can pay $30k in rent every month and just rip all your customers a new one?
author: Kay H.

description: Parking is difficult to find here, so valet your car in front of the restaurant for $15. I love the interior ambience of Ozumo. We were seated in the back of the restaurant with the view of the bridge. Our server went above and beyond for our meal. Unfortunately, I forgot his name. My boyfriend specifically chose Ozumo for the omakase. However, they are currently going through something with the head chef and updating their menu, so their previous omakase was unavailable. But our server was amazing and spoke to the head chef about what type of meal we wanted and created an omakase meal for us. We completely trusted our server and the head chef to chose the dishes for us, so we were in for a surprise each time a plate arrived to our table. I don't like surprises, but I loved every dish we received. Everything was delicious and fresh. We've been hesitant to try sushi, sashimi, and nigiri since our Japan trip because nothing can beat what we had in Japan. But some of the cuts of sashimi brought us back to Japan! We will definitely be returning here and hopefully get the same server.
author: Ashley D.

description: Been coming here for over 8 years love their food! Never a bad experience l. Amazing food and ambiance!
author: Ivette S.

description: Life is too short to don't eat at Ozumo! Everything amazing and the service ...perfect
author: Federico S.

description: Ozumo is, without question, one of the most elegant and welcoming dining experiences we have had in SF. The decor, the Chef's choice sushi & sashimi selection, and sake flights were inspired and absolutely wonderful. The beautiful view of the Bay bridge at night enhanced our appreciation of the cuisine. Kudos to our Sake sommelier, Danny Sprague, for his guidance and knowledge as we were navigated through the dizzying array of sublime sakes on the menu. We were educated and delighted by the entire experience. Ozumo is the perfect romantic dinner spot on the Embarcadero. Do not miss this gem on the San Francisco waterfront!
author: Daniel B.

description: I had dinner at Ozumo last Friday night and was extremely impressed. The wagyu Beef with finger limes was a definite stand out. The little tiny lime bubbles sprinkled over the perfectly seared beef, with a sprinkling of salt was absolutely delightful. The service was also great. Our waitress was very charming and attentive and shared her love for Japanese culture with us, which made the dinner all the more fun. The lobster roll was very special. It was wrapped in rice paper and had accents of mango and jalapeño. It was such a delicious combination. The atmosphere was fun and made for a very lovely Friday night outing. It was lively but not so loud that you couldn't have a conversation. We had a great night and will definitely be back again soon. Great date night spot.
author: Jill A.

description:
Ozumo is our go to upscale Izakaya in San Francisco.

Always great fresh fish, a selection of robatayki, and various hot and cold dishes. They have a nice bar out front with a happy hour menu. We are crazy for their garlic edomame.
author: John C.

description:
Why haven't I been here sooner?!  I can't think of one negative thing to say about this place.  

They have a huge space by the Embarcadero, that is beautiful.  As soon as you walk through the door, there are beautiful flowers and statues -- it has a beautiful modern Japanese style.  The front of the restaurant has the coolest decor, and it is more dim and intimate -- but it's also louder because of the bar.  I would recommend sitting in the front section if you're on a date because of the atmosphere and the lighting.  The back has more light, more windows, a big open space with very modern simplistic decor.  I would recommend the back area for a group or a meeting.    

We made a reservation for 5 people, and when we arrived we were promptly seated at the back of the restaurant -- in the section that is more like an upscale sushi bar.  As soon as we were seated, we were greeted by our wonderful server.  

I ordered the "Giddy Geisha" for my cocktail - Smirinoff vodka, lychee juice and passion fruit purée and I ended up getting two of these because they were so good!  They add a lychee in the drink for you to eat too - yum!  My coworker ordered a "Kazan" - Ketel vodka with muddled jalapeño, cucumber and shiso -- holy cow, amazing!  It's a sweet but spicy cocktail that tastes so good!  I would recommend both of these cocktails.  We also shared a carafe of the house hot sake, which was delicious and fun for the group.

To start we ordered the "Edamame" and "Kaki Kaki Kaki" dish, which is a half dozen oysters with momiji oroshi, scallions and ponzu.  The edamame was pretty standard but the oysters were delicious!  Super fresh with great flavors, I would definitely recommend.  Also fun to share with a group.  

I then ordered the "Hanabi" which is sliced hamachi (yellowtail) with avocado and warm ginger-jalapeño ponzu.  This was a beautiful dish.  If it's too spicy you can just pick off the jalapeños. Good, but not my favorite dish of the night.

I highly recommend the "Dohyo," which is bigeye tuna tartare with edamame, cucumber, avocado, black tobiko, ponzu and wasabi oil, served with gyoza chips.  It's so delicious -- definitely one of my favorite items on the menu and a pretty big portion.  You can share with a group as an appetizer or just order it for yourself as your entree honestly.  I will definitely come back for this dish.  Loved!

I recommend the "Gyu Tataki", which is seared washu beef, arugula, thin sliced red onions, shiso, garlic chips, momiji oroshi, and ponzu.  Some at my table that this wasn't the prettiest dish, but let me tell you -- it tasted amazing!  I got to eat one piece, but it left me wanting more.  Great flavor!

I also recommend the "Shacho" if you love lobster and love pretty dishes - lobster, mango, jalapeño and cilantro wrapped in tuna, spicy sesame aioli.  It was the most BEAUTIFUL dish.  You only get 4 pieces of the actual roll but they stick the empty lobster tail in the middle of the dish, and make it look absolutely gorgeous.  Everyone was so impressed when this dish arrived.  Definitely not a huge portion -- but it's lobster, so that's expected.  Loved!

For dessert we got the "Matcha Panna Cotta" - with strawberries and apples and the "Fondue" - warm Belgian chocolate fondue, fresh fruit, matcha sponge cake, and cookies.  The clear winner at our table was the Fondue -- I pretty much ate the Matcha Panna Cotta by myself.  It was good, but not great -- not much flavor.  I found myself using my Fondue chocolate covered spoon because it tasted better!  The Fondue was more of a hit, we loved the matcha sponge cake.   

Overall, I would definitely recommend this spot.  The presentation of the dishes is outstanding -- so it's perfect for IG.  The quality of the food matches its good looks, everything was delicious -- there was not one thing I didn't like.  The space itself is gorgeous and spacious.  The service is wonderful.  The only downside is the price -- but hey you do actually get what you pay for.  Quality food, service, venue -- definitely worth a visit.  I will definitely be back here!
author: Michelle S.

description: I had an excellent experience here last night. We came for dinner to celebrate our anniversary. Everything that we had was amazing. The sushi and sashimi were on point, great quality. They also had some unique dishes that I don't find everywhere, highly recommend the hanabi, which is hamachi sashimi with a twist, and the ribs, so tender and flavorful. The manager and staff there are wonderful, very friendly which made our night extra special. The decor is beautiful and has an amazing view of the bay bridge at night. We had a lovely dinner here.
author: Little one C.

description:
Ozumo has been a favorite for years. Excellent location to pop in after work. The nigiri/sashimi are always fresh and well prepared with a nice variety. I typically stick with the "classic" rolls and I am never disappointed. One of my favorite dishes in SF is the Gindara (black cod).

The cocktails at Ozumo are balanced and well crafted. I always order an Old Fashioned and it comes out perfectly. They have a robust Japanese whisky and sake selection.

Such a fun and lively atmosphere and environment during happy hour.
author: Jason T.

description: This place was amazing. Absolutely delicious food with wonderful and helpful staff. The atmosphere was amazing too, we had a view of the bay bridge light show! My favorite happens to be there namesake the Ozumo Roll, the fresh snow crab, avocado, and tuna were perfectly balanced with the sauce. Thank you for a great night out and the complementary japanese lessons in the bathroom!
author: Tim G.

description:
Steak... sushi... sake... beer... and so much more...

There is so much to choose from.  But it takes a large dip into your wallet.  The meal here can get quite pricey.  And the portions aren't for the hungry.  These were my reasons for the lack of a few stars.

The flavors were good.  The atmosphere is roomy with a gorgeous back drop of Japanese decor.  Location is also pretty nice - right across from the Bay Bridge.

I can't say I crave to be back, but it's a place to try.
author: Julie C.

description:
First, let's start with allllll the good things about this experience: the server.

Now for the rest.

Food is average with the exception of the salmon belly sushi. Worth mentioning I guess. You don't come across those very often and it was a good cut.

Be ware of an outrageous OVERPRICED menu that is far from being worth it. There's no problem paying $100, $200, and even $300 per person for top notch sushi as I did before but it must stand the standards.

They charge $32 for a SMALL bottle of Otokoyama sake (before taxes and tip). A large bottle cost $26 in the store (Berkeley Bowl) so do the math. Any place I've been chargers around $35 a bottle for the large one. Serious ripoff!! Shame in you!

Unkimo nigiri should comes brushes already with ponzo, they need to know that or someone forgot?

7 sushi nigiri, tuna tarter (you can pass), hamachi,, small sake, and tempura will get you to $277.

You can pass. And no, not recommended.
author: Jonathan H.

description: I love everything about ozumo, they've got great quality everything!! It's abut pricey but it's totally worth It.
author: Berlin M.

description: This is excellent traditional sushi in a beautiful modern venue. The food shines...fresh fish, prepared perfectly and served beautifully. The chawan mushy was silky with delightful little morsels of crab, mushrooms, scallops and goodies.  Glad we tried it. Love this restaurant.
author: t d.

description:
As soon as you walk in, your eyes are rewarded by a beautifully streamlined restaurant setup. All the sake bottles decorating the shelves, the immaculately kept cleanliness of the place, it's impeccable.

The drink:
-I went for the Double Barrel cocktail, which was good, however it was essentially an overly glorifed Manhattan (suggest getting it on the rocks, not Up) It was tasty, though.
-My partner ordered the Dewazakura sake flight, with fruit and floral notes - I had some and approved heartily.

The food:
-We started with the Dohyo Osusume (in my haste to consume it, I deigned to take a picture!) It was a great balance of flavors between the lean tuna, fatty avocado, and salty/citrusy sauce beneath it. The gyoza chips are a nice, light, crispy touch as a vessel.
-Second appetizer was the Shacho Makimono. It was served in a beautiful display! The spicy sesame aoli was inspired. I couldn't get enough of it. Mango+lobster is a great combination. Cool, and sweet, with a hint of spice from the jalapeno make the flavors of each ingredient pop.
-Entree was the Umami Braised Duckbreast Ippin-mono and let me tell you, it was scrumptious. Perfectly cooked, served on a tantalizing bed of wasabi pureed potatoes. The combination of umami and wasabi was magical. I wasn't a huge fan of the skin (being all chewy), but the flavors made up for it.

Dessert: Fondue
You can't go wrong with a large pot of chocolate warmed over your own personal clay oven apparatus! I think, however, the selections for dipping could be more inspired. The matcha cake was dry. The cookie was extremely dry. The chocolate almost couldn't make up for the lack of moisture. Perhaps a suggestion for the restaurant to also seek better fruit vendors, as the melons were juicy but tasted plain, and the strawberries and pineapples erred on the sour side. 

Overall I would give a 5 star except for my minimal gripes over small details. I definitely would come back and suggest anyone who hasn't to give it a try. 

Our server was a wonderfully charming girl! If I could recall her name, I would sing her praises. Just attentive enough to not be a bother and very pleasant. 

Clean bathrooms, clean silverware, clean floors - clean everything - are always a plus!
author: Angela S.

description:
This used to be one the best sushi bars in San Fransisco but has went down hill in the past 2 years!

It was some of the worst fish I've ever eaten
Don't eat here if your looking for the highest quality.

Atmosphere is all ways good with lots of people drinking sake and beer down on the lower level and sushi bar is always hopping. Good place for the younger crowds.
Service was good and the best part was the view out the windows to the Bay Bridge that was light up.

Again we have been eating here for 13 years and gave up on it since it costs an average of $400-$600 for 2 people. Sashimi was horrible and nasty tasting. I spent $80 for Toro Sashimi and it tasted like mush. No flavor!!
No freshness to be found in this place. Go to Omakase and you will come away happy but broke
author: Tom N.

description:
This is perfectly mediocre sushi and Japanese food. To be honest, the classy decor and upscale feel of the place doesn't match the meh quality of the food. We sampled from most the menu: appetizers, sushi, ramen, and rice plates. A walkthrough:

- The gyoza had a really nice exterior, but the meat inside was bland and oddly chewy. 
- The tuna tartare was the best thing I tried, with a great citrus sauce at the bottom of the bowl; oddly, we couldn't get the sauce to "cling" to the fish or avocado, so each bite was almost tantalizing. 
- It's possible that we picked the wrong sushi rolls and sashimi. The Hamachi roll and Sekiwake roll were just not great. They were fine. I expected more; they were like rolls you'd get from any cheap sushi restaurant in SF. We also got some salmon sashimi which was, again, just fine. Nothing special. 
- The Gyu Don rice bowl was my biggest disappointment. When you say "sautéed wagyu beef with black pepper sauce" I imagine really tender steak and garlicky, spicy deliciousness. In my case, they ruined the beef with their sautéing; the result were rubbery strands of steak that with minimal flavor. The sauce also was pretty generic and did not burst on my tongue. I wouldn't say the dish was bad, but it wasn't memorable. 

I don't think I'd bother going back here -- there is so much great Japanese food in downtown SF -- but I wouldn't be crushed if I ended up back here again (if someone else is paying).
author: Benjamin G.

description: Consistently one of the best options for sushi in SF. Large open space accommodated large groups...can get quite loud and challenging to hear across the table at busier times. Food is very fresh and menu has a broad selection of staples. There are also an extensive saki list.
author: PJ R.

description:
Take me here again and again, and I'll be your friend. I love the ambiance here, particularly near the bar and lounge just past the front door. It's dimly lit, it's sexy and even when there's a crowd of people inside, it's easy to hear your friends. 

Most extensive sake selection I've seen by far. I'm simple and don't eat too much in one sitting, most of the time. I've ordered my new found favorite item both visits so far. The Hanabi, which is made with sliced hamachi (yellowtail) with avocado and warm ginger-jalapeño ponzu. It can made into a meal for one or split with 2-3 people for an appetizer. Omfg! This is amazing. I even had a similar dish at another sushi place the next day, and it didn't even come close to the exuberant flavor of Ozuma's version. 

All else I've had is their miso soup, edamame, spicy tuna roll and the Tako sashimi. I'm such a noob when it comes to ordering sushi, but I still know a good place from bad. I love this spot and once again it's close to home for me... I would recommend it to any of my friends.
author: Cassandra E.

description:
Unreasonably expensive restaurant..unreasonable because the food isn't that good here. Tried looking for Omakase places around San Francisco on a Friday evening but all the other popular places were already booked so I decided to come here. 

Omakase at this place takes 3 hours (according to my waiter) - so decided not to do this. Instead, tried to conservatively order 2 appetizers and 2 entrees that I could share with a party of 4 but still ended up dropping $100+ each which was too expensive. 

Came out of the restaurant still hungry and regretful that I had spent that much money. rip
author: Brandon L.

description: Had lunch there today. Waited quite a while for waiter to show up. The food is not as good as before (they change the menu). Definitely not worth the money! Overall it seems like it is going downhill fast. Will go somewhere else in the future.
author: William S.

description: Tricked us into edamame to start and afterwards, just forgot about us. Me and my hubby waited for a long time while our waiter had already served the other table 3x!
author: Ruby C.

description:
3.5 stars - cool, trendy Japanese restaurant in FiDi, maybe didn't have the best best dishes

Venue: the space looked perfect for both small and large groups.  Minimalist design with light wood accents.  Front area makes it look more like a bar scene but the back section of the restaurant makes it look more like a restaurant.  

Staff: very friendly and accommodating, though we may have come at a busy time (Tuesday 6:30pm) since it was sometimes hard to grab the waiters' attention.  When we ordered a carafe of sake (Kubota Manju), they didn't realize that they had ran out but were kind enough to bring the last glass of the Kubota Manju with no extra charge and provide a new recommendation for us (Kubota Hekiju)

Food: awesome sushi!!  Note that they price nigiri/sashimi by piece, so you don't need to order 5 pieces of sashimi as is priced on the menu (my friend and I together ordered four of each type of sashimi).  We had toro, mirugai, hamachi, and benitoro.  Toro was quite good, even though it was a bit too soft for my liking (dunno if it was an old piece or not).

We also ordered the Hotate Sarada (scallops, seasonal medley, onion vinaigrette, shiso pesto) and a special Prime New York Tataki (with red onion, truffle oil, and ponzu).  Hotate was good though not particularly spectacular- we were more obsessed with the brussell sprouts than the scallop, which could have been seared more.  The tataki overall was tasty though the meat itself was unseasoned- we both commented how it was almost like the condiments were trying to mask how bland the meat was.

Dessert- we ordered the matcha panna cotta.  I personally liked it, though I can see how matcha lovers (like my friend) would wish that there was more matcha flavor in the panna cotta itself.

All in all, probably a good place to get quality sushi / sashimi in FiDi, maybe with coworkers or for a slightly more trendy date night.  Will need to test out their other menu items and see if I have better luck with their non-sushi dishes in the future.
author: Audrey H.

description:
My fiance and I went in for the sushi omakase last night. What an amazing experience! We were greeted immediately by the friendly hostess and taken to our seats at the sushi counter. The staff all stand at attention when a customer walks in the dining room and they all chant "irasshaimase" (welcome!) just like in Japan! (I am half Japanese and lived in Japan for many years.) Charlie, the (also half Japanese!) sushi chef promptly greeted us with a friendly smile. The manager, Miho-san, also came by to say hello and asked us if we needed anything. We knew we were in good hands! Our server, Ken-san was also extremely polite, friendly and always there when we needed something (but not hovering at all). Now onto the food! 

Chef Charlie started us off with mozuku (a type of seaweed) in vinegar with 2 generous pieces of sweet crab. It was delicious! Next, we were served 2 plump shigoku oysters, one had momiji oroshi & ponzu, the other had ikura on top. OMG! Yum. Next course was sashimi which was akami maguro, hirame and ama-ebi. The maguro was the perfect color and texture, and the ama-ebi was plump and so sweet! After sashimi, we had a palate cleansing carrot salad course, then came some shrimp tempura. Again, the shrimp were perfectly plump and fresh, and the light coating of batter was just right. We were then served a "yamakake" maguro dish, which is like a grated yam over maguro with nori and soy sauce (a Japanese classic). This dish might not be for some Americans (it's a bit slimy) but we loved it. After that we had mirugai sashimi which had the perfect combination of chewy and crunchy textures (kori kori in Japanese), similar to abalone. We started to get full so we asked for some nigiri sushi before we got too full. All the fish was perfect. We finally ended the feast with some grilled buri and miso soup, then satisfied our sweet tooth with the rich & decadent (and SO yummy) rice pudding. Wow! We both needed bigger pants at the end of the meal! Service was top notch, food was excellent quality and the ambiance all made this one memorable dining experience. We will definitely be back again to Ozumo to try their other dishes.
author: lani P.

description:
Originally wanted to try it's ramen but found out that ramen is only served on Sundays, but regardless decided to give it a try. 
Hanabi: warm ponzu sauce really makes this dish popping and hamachi is also pretty fresh, the only downside is that there are too many jalapeños that, in my opinion, are not necessary for both the presentation and overall taste of the dish.
Gindara: this sweet miso black cod is probably my favorite dish of all we've ordered. The cod is crispy on the outside and juicy+tender on the inside. The marinated cod goes along really well with the miso sauce. Would definitely order this dish again.
Futago: definitely my favorite appetizer, the flavor and texture combination of flat iron beef, spinach, cucumber, and eggplant along with miso sesame sauce hits the spot, presentation is also on point.
Toro hand roll: pretty standard roll as how you would expect it to be, although I expected the toro here to be even more fresh based on the price point
2 rolls--Ozumo and hamachi maki: Ozumo gives off a refreshing presentation and taste. The unagi, crab and tuna combination really pulls through with the spicy aioli sauce. The hamachi maki roll, however, is  not the best roll you can order here, the hamachi is a little tough, and there is a slice of jalapeño on each roll which not only doesn't add anything to the overall flavor (as you can tell I'm not a big fan of jalapeños) but the way it's done also makes this dish look kinda cheap, although I do like the plating of this dish. 
Overall, the food, service, and atmosphere here are pretty decent, but I would say I was expecting more given the price. Out of the 5 dishes we ordered, 3 of them have slices of jalapeños somewhere in them, which personally I didn't enjoy. Would maybe come back to try their ramen, but don't have the urge to try its dinner again any time soon.
author: Hannah T.

description:
My friend and I went on a girl's date at Ozumo. I had helped her find her phone and she had offered to take me out to dinner. I felt a little bad we had ended up at Ozumo due to its price but you really can't be too picky without a reservation on a Friday night.

We were able to get seated at the sushi bar right away and started browsing the menu. San Francisco is an expensive city but Ozumo takes it to another level. Rolls for ~$20 here would be available at other (better tasting) Japanese restaurants for ~$14-16. Everything here is about 20-40% more expensive than it should be. 

We tried to be somewhat price conscious (what would be the best bang-for-your-buck?) and decided on the following four items:
-Yasai Tempura ($15): Very nicely cooked tempura and large portion size. This was the best part of the meal. It's a vegetarian dish but we lucked out and somehow got a free shrimp with it. However, when the server noticed the shrimp, he was concerned that it had appeared because if the customer had been vegetarian or allergic to shrimp, this would've been a costly mistake.
-Hanabi ($19): This hamachi and avocado appetizer is supposed to be one of the most popular dishes here. It was presented beautifully but unfortunately, way too salty.
-Jidori ($18): Chicken seemed like a safe bet. This was even saltier than the hamachi and it made us extra thirsty. When the server came to ask us how things were, we mentioned this was too salty and he took it back and took it off our bill. Thank you for that.
-Bucho Roll ($20): Tempura shrimp with avocado and real crab is a combo I can work with. It was solid.

We ended the meal with an order of cheesecake. It was not a "American-style" cheesecake but also denser than a Japanese-style cheesecake. Not bad, but not great.

Overall, the food was mediocre, which definitely does not justify the high prices. There are so many Japanese restaurants in the City; go to a different one.
author: Yi Z.

description: Great presentation, best tasting sushi ever, pleasant staff! I plan to return here every time I visit San Francisco!
author: Linda N.

description:
Came here after happy hour and knew the prices were pricey but wasn't expecting as high. The hostess were a bit uptight with not having any reservations yet there were so many empty tables. So had to sit at the bar, the sake was good but pretty expensive and all of the sushi that I had was great quality but mad money. 

Good place for a date but not after coming from hh.
author: James H.

description:
Absolutely amazing! I came here with a friend for dinner and it just blew me away! I'm still thinking about the Gindara (black cod) a week later. The presentation of all our dishes were really beautiful and intricate. 

The menu is definitely on the pricier side but with the detailed service and amount of effort that goes into the dishes, it's totally justifiable. The service is what you would expect at an upscale restaurant: the waitress introduced herself and smiled all the time, and the food was always announced and arrived in a timely fashion. 

The restaurant itself is quite pretty with a nice atmosphere. It seems like a lot of people also take their clients there for business discussions (both people sitting next to us seemed to be in meetings) which makes sense based on the ambiance of the place! The venue is also quite large and spacious with a full staff; we were seated at the back and we were thanked by at least 4 different employees as we were leaving. 

Overall, I'd highly recommend this restaurant if it is within your price range!
author: Sunny L.

description: I eat sushi regularly in the city and this place is hands down the best!! Delicious food from appetizers to sushi to dessert not to mention the extensive selection of sake. Very friendly attentive staff and an amazing ambiance make this a memorable dining experience. When I have out of town guests this is where I take them!!
author: Robin W.

description:
$$$ for sushi prices, but $$ for everything else.  The host and hostess were snotty and making comments about the people they had just seated, so I can see why people would dock service.  Also, the front dining room has a much different ambiance than the one in back, which is brightly lit and feels more casual.  

Service in the back dining room was friendly and attentive.  It seemed like the Japanese sushi chefs were all back there, while the non-Japanese were up front.  The front dining room, where the bar was, looked dark and hip and classy, but seemed like where you would go to be seen, rather than to eat good Japanese food.  The back dining room was where you could relax and enjoy a nice meal over good conversation and a glass of Japanese craft beer.
author: erika c.

description: The best bar in Santana Row! Lisa & staff always ensures a friendly and fun atmosphere. You can tell the staff always gets along with each other.
author: Simon T.

description:
Wow. Very happy or local friend brought us here. Dark busy and very lucky to have gotten four seats at the bar. Mind you, we have snacked at the View bar, The La Mer ,The Press Club all before we ended up here. I wish we started here! 
We tried: Miso Cod- cooked to perfection and the sauce had a nice flavor but really undereveloped. That was disappointing
steak with mushrooms and asparagus-the boys like it. the steak was cooked perfectly. sauce heavy 
salmon sushi- yum and fresh
hamachi sushi- like butter
uni- more more more
scallop sashimi- fantastic. thinly sliced in a nice ponzu sauce covered with herbs Perfect dish
beer, sake and cocktails-All fantastic. Took a photo of the best beer ever and i;m not a beer person. Echigo Koshihikari perfecture niigata. It is a rice lager and amazing!
author: Valerie M.

description: This was probably one of the best experiences we've had at a restaurant. To start this great experience we were greeted by a very friendly host. She sat us by the window were we had an amazing view. Our waitress was excellent she knew everything on the menu and helped us with our selection. Everything that we had was delicious and the plates got ever each time a new one came out. It is pricy but they don't disappoint. The desert was amazing as well!
author: Fiorella F.

description:
This is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in town ! 

Perfectly assembled and presented sushi.  A menu with an array of dishes.  If you are a meat lover the Gyu Filet is a must.  Great sake selections. 

Service is superb from the Maitre D',  waiters and restaurant manager.  

Great ambiance in both the bar and dinning room.
author: Brenda Z.

description:
Good sushi and excellent service

This was my first time at Ozumo and it was a lunch occasion. I was not going to waste my time, or stomach space, on anything but Nigiri Sushi; however, I started with a Miso Soup and Kaiso (Seaweed salad). The soup was okay, but I did not care too much for the salad; it was kind of tasteless. The Sushi, however, was very good. I tried Benijake (Wild Salmon), Toro ( Bluefin Tuna Belly), Hamachi (Yellowtail) and Hirame (Halibut). They were all fresh and tasty. 

Our server was very good at what he does. He clearly and patiently explained all the specials and was very attentive to our table.

The dinning space is very nice and our group of three felt very comfortable. I would love to try the bar area towards the entrance at some point. It looked very cozy and appropriate for a single person or two having lunch. 

The price tag for all the above was very steep and living in San Francisco, I know that I can get very high quality sushi at a better price, but I must say that the dishes served to other tables looked very good, so I will not hold the high price tag against Ozumo until I try other items on their menu.
author: Afshin A.

description:
I'm hesitant with the overall 4 star rating, but it's given for the grill octopus dish. Every bite of the octopus was satisfying, the char and the chewiness and the roasted fingerling potatoes that came with it were perfect too!

The rest of the items we ordered were average sushi menu items. The hamachi appetizer lacked a little citrus. I asked for an unagi handroll. I was expecting a little more than just rice and eel wrapped in nori for $10. Maybe some avocado or cucumber for added texture? 

The service was great, it wasn't busy. I did expect this place to be busy, but it wasn't.
author: Quyen B.

description: We have had a business dinner here for the last two years  and have walked away both times blown away by both food and service. Each time we have left selection to the staff who have delivered some incredible selections. Located near Embarcadero, it is very convenient to the Moscone. Will be back again!
author: Patrick M.

description:
Stayed at the hotel next door and decided to give this place a try. I looked at their menu online and called for take out. They charged me $4 more for 1 skewer of each instead of 2 without any rice as stated on the menu.

To begin with, they first told me if I would like to order then I have to download grub hub or door dash. Then she told me to hold on and changed her mind. 

After I saw my order was not what I expected nor wanted, I gave them a call and they were telling me that the menu I saw is very "specific" and not accurate even though it was from the hotel's partner advertising with Ozumo. 

The very least you can do is be nice and respectful especially when your food is very mediocre. The combination of mediocre food and poor customer service in the city where there are so many options, I would expect them to make an effort or even a fake apology. 

Hope the manager can take this review and have a coaching conversation with the 2 ladies at the front to help improve the restaurant
author: Davey J.

description: Excellent hamachi appetizer, wine selections, pork ribs, cold sake. Made reservation on open table with no problem. Changed the reservation a few times day of dinner without any problems.
author: Julie F.

description: Came for the Sunday bar seating menu which is one of the best deals in San Francisco. Classy and modern, yet one of the most relaxed sushi bar experiences ever. You'll be hard pressed to find a better bar to eat handroll at while you work on your laptop.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Extensive happy hour menu, large bar area, tasty drinks, average food at high prices. 

Eats: chicken karaage, tempura shishito, spicy tuna roll, california roll, salmon avocado roll. Everything was just ok and wouldn't be a compelling reason to come back. "Happy hour" prices are comparable to the regular prices at other non-SOMA places. 

Drinks: Giddy geisha was delicious! 

Bar service: friendly
author: Judy C.

description: We originally had a reservation, however realized that the seating in the bar area was more of the vibe we were looking for. The inside dining area is brightly lit with views of the bay bridge, but was a little too bright, busy, and not very intimate. We ordered 2 of the saki flights to taste, the 6 piece hand roll, tuna tartar, and shabu shabu to share. The food is phenomenal, the saki is great, the atmosphere is perfect for a date. I would even return with friends, they have great deals on Sunday nights for handrolls and drinks. I loved this restaurant, but I'm not sure if it was the restaurant that was actually good or if it was the date that made it good.
author: Dale D.

description: Yum yum yum. 4 stars for the gigantic slow moving line at lunch, and staff that is talking to each other rather than helping with your order. Also, I'm on the short side and the glass from the counter is very high,  it's hard for them to understand me, Small problems. Otherwise- very good!!
author: Kim K.

description:
Dinner here was pretty good.  

Came here on a Saturday night and it was a bit dead but I guess given the torrential downpour it made sense, who wants to trek to sushi on a rainy night?  Just idiots like ME. 

Anyway, we started with the seaweed salad, the tuna tartar, the spicy tuna roll and then the Cod.  My favorite dish was the tuna.  The chips were yummy and the avocado was a nice balance to the spicy flavor.  

The sushi to me was not mind blowing.  I guess I have really high expectations when I eat fancy Japanese but the quality of the roll was not outstanding.  

The Cod was good, portion was a bit small...literally 75% of the dish was just sauce in a pretty pattern.  

Overall, good spot but I think a bit overrated in my opinion.  Maybe I should come back and try different dishes.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
For the price and food, Ozumo was OK. For the ambiance and service, Ozumo was really great. 

I appreciate our servers as they were very attentive. I thought that the food was over priced for what they were. Sushi was delicious, don't get me wrong, but it wasn't as great as some other (less expensive alternatives) in the city. 

For our party of five, we ordered pretty much every roll, along with the black cod (HIGHLY RECOMMEND) and hamachi sashimi. 

Must get: 
Gindara - sweet miso and sake kasu marinated black cod with grilled shishito peppers ($29). The cod melts in your mouth. Super delicious, light, and flavorful. Texture was perfect. 
Shacho -  lobster, mango, jalapeño and cilantro wrapped in tuna with spicy sesame aioli ($24 for five pieces....not a lot, but delicious). Presentation of this roll was gorgeous. If you want to impress da ladies (or just your friends or yourself), treat them/you with this roll! 

Other rolls we tried along with my thoughts: 
Bucho - typical tempura roll, nothing too special, over priced
Spider - softshell crab, delicious, but portion was very small
Kanpachi Maki - too spicey and zesty and not enough fish. I felt like we had too much rice and other toppings rather than fish, which is what I'd like when I get sushi 
Ozumo - Unagi roll w/ tuna. Pretty standard roll, I thought Ozumo did a pretty good job but again, portion size was too small for the price and ingredients. 

Drink: Double Barrel was delicious! Our whole table loved it (both men and women). It was a great, better alternative to the old fashioned except this one is mixed with 5 different bourbon and served in a martini glass :) I highly recommend this if you're into bourbon. Double Barrel is made with -- Bulleit, Makers Mark, Jack Daniels and George Dickle bourbons aged three months, Carpano Antica Formula, and cherry bark bitters.
author: Dana Z.

description:
Definitely my favorite sushi joint in the area. I live and work nearby, so this was a great find when I first moved here. I always sit in the bar area because it's (generally) always available seating, cool vibe, and Eric is an amazing bartender. Ask him for his wasabi Bloody Mary if he's not too busy. Black Smoke and Kazan are also excellent!

I recommend the mifune box, spicy miso ramen, or the katsu curry rice bowl. My top three favorites for sure.

I'm definitely a regular and plan to be for as long as I live here!
author: Mike W.

description:
Back after 10 years and still great quality.
Great views of the Bay Bridge, stylish decoration and an impressive sake menu.
The toro was fantastic.
author: Pedro R.

description: Excellent Bento box lunch. $22 felt like a solid value.  My niece had miso, a roll and gyoza.  Everything was very fresh as well as beautifully presented. Sauces and even the wasabi were better than what I'm used to on the east coast -- wasabi seemed almost grated in texture -- soy was not as salty as the generic.  Nice option for a downtown with so many choices!
author: Lin Z.

description: I'm only giving them 3 stars due to the portion size to price ratio, and because the takeout order was ready later than quoted. Quality of food is excellent.
author: Andy A.

description: Decided to try out this restaurant because it was next to the hotel I was staying at. I must say the ambiance it's pretty relaxing dark, yet a nice place to eat and have a nice drink. The service was spectacular. The waitress made sure if we had any questions and answered them accordingly. Also took her time with us. The food was full of flavor and delicious. I had the gyu plate and very tender meat full of flavor, and almost like butter. For dessert I had the Okinawa donuts with coffee ice cream. Pretty flavorful! On the pricey side yet it's worth it.
author: Jorge T.

description: Sushi fantasy here. Service was good as we got a bubbly waitress that was caring and helpful. I heard the SF Giants players come here. Not surprised. Sushi was the best I hadZ top notch freshness. $5 for a miso soup. Quite pricey but worth the experience. Not a weekly affair but will be coming back.
author: Steve S.

description:
We wanted to take my brother and his girlfriend out to dinner for a very late Christmas gift. Since my brother likes sushi and Japanese food, I decided to take them to Ozumos since it's just down the street from my house.

First when we were handed the menus we had no idea what anything meant. It was confusing for us to choose so had to rely on Yelp. The waiter recommended how popular the oysters were. Omg! When they came out, I want to order a magnifying glass because they were so small. I was so embarrassed that the four of us had to split 6 crumb size oysters. The waiter also recommended the rock shrimp that was not on the menu. That was a decent size for all of us to share. It was light, crunchy, and delicious! The waiter had said that the tuna tartar was a big hit. I told him that we couldn't get it because my husband is allergic to edamame. He said we can order it without it, so we ordered two. Also, there was a bug in my water.

We ordered a lot of sushi that all of us shared. We ordered 1 Sacho which had lobster, mango, jalapeños, cilantro, and tuna which was gross. It was very chewy and one of the people in our party could not swallow it so he had to spit it out in his napkin. We ordered 2 Buchos which had crab, tempura shrimp, avocado, and tobiko. It was about $8.00 quality, but paid $18 each for it. Then we had 6 different classic rolls which was $10 per roll and the quality was not there. Everyone in my party agreed that this was just a one time thing and will not go back.

Let me talk about the staff now. There is this one older petite Asian woman who kept staring at my husband. She came to our table and didn't even acknowledge any of us and gave my husband his own bowl of chips for the tuna tartar. My husband even made a comment that maybe the old lady will give us a discount because we all notice how flirty she was. Then our waiter who didn't care about my husbands allergies.. Wait! You guys are probably wondering why we thought he didn't care. Well we did mention that my husband is highly allergic to edamame so he said we can get the tuna tartare without it. When it came out we asked him if there was edamame, he said no.. So right after dinner we had to rush my husband to the ER because he had a really bad allergic reaction the the tuna tartare. I should of called the next day to demand a refund, but the hospital suggested we make them pay for our hospital bills. I was just too exhausted to make the phone call. I had to make sure my husband kept up with his benedryl/medication so his throat doesn't close. I will definitely tell people about my experience at this place and how irresponsible and insensitive the staff was with my husbands allergies. Thank God my husband is still alive and breathing. Shame on you Ozumos!
author: Darlene M.

description: It used to be my favorite Japanese restaurant in SF. But I am pretty disappointed after last visit. Sushi were not very fresh, rice was dry on some rolls. Server was not friendly - had an  unpleasant attitude. Very  sad...
author: Dennis L.

description: Fantastic views of the pier and Bay Bridge. Great lunch spot whenever executives come to town! I always get the Mifune bento box, garlic edemame, and whatever their daily juice spritzer is. It's always a fun surprise, and not a single one had disappointed me!
author: Yanni C.

description:
We went to Ozumo for a celebratory work lunch, and my expectations were high due to coworkers' and Yelp hype.

We ordered a few appetizers, including the Hanabi (slices of hamachi and avocado served with a warm ginger and jalapeño ponzu).  I saw it was listed on the Yelp highlights, so I thought it would be a good selection, but it wasn't very memorable.

For my main, I ordered the Kurosawa bento box (comes with tuna, yellowtail and salmon sashimi, and shrimp, inari and unagi nigiri).  Eveyrthing tasted super fresh, but maybe I just don't appreciate sushi as nothing really stood out here.

And finally for dessert, I ordered a chocolate mousse/pudding dessert. The name escapes me, but this was the best part of the meal. It was rich, creamy, and delicious.

I guess I'm more of a hearty Japanese curry guy than a sushi guy, so in the end Ozumo didn't live up to the hype for me.
author: Nadeem A.

description: This sushi here is incredible!!! The sake selection is expansive, everything we ate was delicious, the manager came over to greet us by name and everything was brought in a timely manner. The view of the bay bridge wasn't too shabby either. Full Five Stars here.
author: Laura B.

description: Celebrated my birthday at this amazing restaurant! We reserved the sake tasting room and the food not only was amazing - but the staff was so great and professional and really made the whole evening such a great experience!
author: Lili D.

description:
It's my second time coming here. Once for dinner and yesterday for lunch. I had the bento Sake bento box which had salmon, rice, potstickers and something else with tomato in the top right. I really enjoyed the chocolate pudding at the end for desert that I didn't notice till they were taking my plate away. Also had the Ozumo roll which was good and fresh. 

The view is beautiful here from their big windows but we came when there was construction outside. It's ok cause you can still see the bay bridge. Bar area is spacious as well as the dinning area. Totally recommend coming here for lunch or dinner.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
A member of our party made last minute reservations for 7 thru their hotel concierge for dinner.  Restaurant was great about pushing the time, 2x, because we were stuck in traffic.

Upon arrival, we were seated at a long table in the bar area.  That was disappointing.  It was louder in that area and every time the door opened, you could feel a draft.

Service was inconsistent.  At times very attentive and then missing in action.  I can only guess that they were overwhelmed that evening.  

The food was 4 stars.  Presentation & taste were Very Good.
 
Although presentation was beautiful, it was difficult maneuvering the huge long platters around the table as food was brought out.

My favorite food items:
Garlic Edamame
Tempura Vegetables
Hanabi
Dohyo (this was a big hit at the table)
Rice Pudding

Good:
Futago
Gindara
Spicy Tuna Handroll

Finally, this was the first time I have been with a group that was kicked out of a restaurant after closing.  I was aware that we were beyond closing time; however, there was a bottle of sake still left at the table (that was ordered at last call).  The restaurant turned on their bright lights and shouted it was time to leave.  

I would return if I had a better table & better service.
author: Melissa L.

description:
My mother and I arrived in San Francisco with a craving for sushi and a fun first night out in the city. Immediately, our experience at Ozumo was hampered by the extremely rude hostess at the back restaurant, who insisted we would not be able to sit at a table despite it being past 5:30. After finally getting a seat, we expected to enjoy a delicious and filling meal. Not so! My mother and I ordered edamame followed by two sushi rolls. My mother's entree arrived well before mine, leaving me to wait awkwardly without dinner. When we asked our waiter why hers was brought before mine, she stated that the dishes were brought out as soon as they were prepared and intended to be shared. We have different tastes in food (I enjoy spicy food while my mother does not) and made this clear to the server, so there is no logical reason why she would expect us to have ordered food to share. Additionally, this was not made clear to us, leaving my mother and I annoyed and hungry. 

When my meal was finally delivered over forty minutes later, it consisted of merely three pieces of the sushi roll itself. The rest of the plate was used to construct a beautiful display using pieces of cucumber and fruit that would have been more appropriate for a cooking show than a meal intended for actual human consumption. A+ for design, but we were charged way too much for the small amount of food provided. The final bill came to over $200, and we felt rushed to vacate the table even after the poor service we were provided. We travel to San Francisco regularly and have generally enjoyed the atmosphere and geniality of this city, but will not be returning here. At least the drinks were strong.
author: Jessica G.

description: As soon as we walked in we were greeted kindly and the whole restaurant welcomed us and they were so nice and showing us were we should sit or what we should eat... The food is great I love it! Definitely the place to go if you want to bring the whole family with kids a peaceful date night or a nice night by yourself don't bother what the other reviews say this place deserves a 5 star rating! But most of all is the service its just great!
author: Kyra S.

description: Food is amazing, but SERVICE IS AWFUL! I will not go back.  They took forever and it was a work lunch and we were all so late back to the office. He forgot orders, drinks and condiments. Sad, because I had heart such great things!
author: Ellie J.

description:
Tourist trap. OK quality food but massively overpriced. Ridiculously tiny portions for the price. 
Premium mediocre...

The decor is also sort of ugly. And the place is too large. No sushi place charm. Feels more like a Chinese mega diner. The service is however very good, as are the views of the Bay
author: Sergei B.

description: I came here for my bday on march 25th. This place was just okay. Portions were incredibly small and some had no flavor to them. They were helpful with gluten allergy stuff and accommodating to our vegetarians. I wasnt thrilled with the food and dessert wasnt much better. I wouldnt recommmend or come back. It was also overpriced
author: Ruthe Ann G.

description: Don't expect the same from and drink menu as the one in SF.  Dissapointing.....yatatori came out cold.  Took 45 minutes to get our Sprite.   And why did it take 2 hours to get just half if my order.  For $$$ I'd expect better food presentation as well.  Ambience was nice though, bit it's a restaurant and food should be better.
author: Brandon L.

description:
I would say Ozumo deserves between 3 and 4 stars but slightly closer to 3. 

We sat at the sushi bar and had some decent sushi. The toro and yellowtail we both brilliant (but they usually are) and so was the spicy tuna makis. The rest was nothing special.

The had a great wine list and we ordered the Au Bon Climat which was splendid and some nice Japanese draft beers. 

We sat at the sushi bar and we were hoping for some interaction with the chefs or at least to be able to see them cut or roll some sushi. This would definitely help bump Ozumo up to a 4 stars in my opinion.

The service was also pretty good but nothing special. I would recommend the restaurant if you're in the area.
author: Michael C.

description: I always enjoy coming to Ozumo. The food is top notch and I enjoy the sake. The waitstaff is always attentive and I enjoy their recommendations. The place is on the pricy side but totally worth it if you're in the mood for top-end sushi and Japanese cuisine.
author: Craig P.

description:
Great experience at Ozumo on a company lunch! The ambiance is great and good for large parties. 

I had the miso cod which was a chef special and not on the menu -- amazing! It was the perfect tenderness along with flavoring. I would highly recommend (the portion isn't enough for a full meal alone though). Their bento boxes also looked delicious and sized well portion wise. I will probably try a bento next time!
author: Lucy G.

description:
Came here on my bosses' tab and was pleasantly surprised. We each ordered the $80 osuzukuri / omakase combo of nigiri and sashimi. There were about 7 pieces of nigiri and 8 pieces of sashimi - given the price, it was a little scant on very premium ingredients like uni, but at the very least, it was all extremely fresh. Also, since this is a busy Financial District "expense account" kind of place with a huge hall and 100 diners to serve, the pieces came all at once in one big platter. I'm not sure I myself would pay $80 for this, but if the company's paying, why not!

If I recall:

-scallops (amazing)
-yellowtail (ok)
-tuna toro nigiri (ok)
-tuna sashimi + nigiri (great)
-salmon sashimi + nigiri (great)
-seared whitefish of some sort (great)
-halibut (superb)
-snapper (great)
author: Ken H.

description: Went in for a happy hour drink on a week day. We were seated at the table near the bar, ordered our drinks and asked for water too. But 15 minutes later, there is nothing. The place was not super crowded at around 5pm. I'm sure if we have chosen to sit at the bar, we would have got our drinks right away. So we asked this Asian waitress for drinks. She was like, it took some time. We said then how about our water? She went away. 5 minutes later, she came back with our water. You will be shocked what she said to us "I checked, you only waited for 10 min, that's not long". Will for sure not going back.
author: Lil W.

description:
Super trendy Japanese restaurant in the heart of the Embarcadero. 

Staff was incredibly friendly and inviting upon arrival. My boyfriend and I were on a time crunch because we needed to make a movie, and weren't that hungry either, so all we ordered was the edemame, tuna tartare, spicy tuna roll, and one of their house rolls with yellowtail and jalapeño on it. It ended up being more than enough food for us especially given we had a HUGE lunch hours earlier, however our waitress kept pressuring us into ordering more. It was kind of awkward, but I get it. She works for tips and wasn't getting a huge tip based off our order total ($80). 

The food was good, but nothing to write home about. And given the prices of this place, it was certainly not worth it. I wish that on the yellowtail roll they gave us more of that miso sauce that they put a meager line of along the side of the dish.  Like.. that's good for 2 pieces of sushi and not the other 8. I did like the gyoza chips that comes with the tuna tartare. Maybe we ordered the wrong things, but for a house speciality roll at an upscale Japanese restaurant, I was expecting more.
author: Jin C.

description: This place has really gone downhill. Two stars because it's still a decent happy hour but the regular prices are obscene for the quantity and quality of sushi they are serving.
author: Alex H.

description: The dishes were tasty however the menu was quite confusing. There was a server who explained the menu, but the selection was quite large. I was unsure what to order but luckily my mother ordered a good amount of food. Happy Mother's Day 2018.
author: Brandon L.

description:
Awesome service | Delicious food | Great ambiance
$$$

Garrett and I were staying right next door at the Harbor Court Hotel because we had to film a wedding the next day at Treasure Island. Conveniently, this place is a step away from the hotel so we decided to try this place out after reading positive Yelp reviews :)

We went around 5:30pm; it was pretty quiet on a Saturday night. We didn't have to wait at all! We just sat down at a cozy spot in the front lounge area near the bar. Our waitress, Natalie (sp?), was the best! She was so knowledgeable about the menu and very friendly. 

We thought it was really unique they offer sake flights!! We ended up doing the Richness and Depth flight. Dang. I've never had sake like this before. Natalie told us to try it in a specific order because the sake gets more bold towards the end. The first one was really light and floral. 

Sushi was on our mind, so we ended up getting 3 different types of sushi! 
Sekiwake.
Kitakaze.
