I've been here a couple of times now. Mostly for work lunches...actually exclusively for work lunches. It's close by and we just love our sushi. 

Bento boxes, sushi, and some edamame. That's our normal staples in each the meals. 

The service there is great. Very professional. I've had a great time each time I've gone. I hope to go more often with my coworkers!
author: Nina Y.

description:
I take business clients from out of town here but last night I took my wife for the first time for her birthday dinner. She had the best time and is still talking about it this morning. The food, the drinks, the music, everything is 5 stars. Also Want to give props to Mel who went out of his way to really make my wife feel special on her day. 

This restaurant represents SF!
author: Kyle M.

description:
I came here for my birthday, and it was one of the best sushi meals I have ever had! We lucked out, and got the private room (they weren't using it that night and needed the room to seat us on time). Our waitress was top notch! She was very knowledgeable and personable, and made us all feel very well taken care of. 

The food was absolutely delicious! Everything is made in house - from the ice cream (miso caramel was awesome) to the soy sauce (from his Grandmother's recipe). Some examples of what we ordered ; komimoto oysters, beef tongue (amazing!), scallop rolls (wow!), house special eel roll (amazing!), tempura vegetables (i love japanese sweet potato), tempura shrimp (yum!), rice pudding dessert (you HAVE to try this).

The weakest offerings were the house special hamachi roll (not as much depth as the others) and the peanut butter tart dessert (way too rich / more like fudge) - but overall - this was truly great and exciting food. My compliments to the chef!

Great sake and wine list to - but based on the other reviews - this goes without saying.

I can't wait to come back, and I could not have asked for a better place to celebrate my birthday.
author: Katie G.

description:
This is a really nice spot close to the financial district. I was not expecting much given the location and that I hadn't heard of it. The reviews were not great, but its sushi so I should be safe. The inside was very nice, and busy during lunch with business people having business meetings.... This is what brought me there with a client as well

Ordered one of the sashimi/sushi bento boxes. The sushi and sashimi was quite good, but most of the other included items were a bit strange and sweet generally speaking. I would rate this decent based on the quality.
author: Jonah K.

description:
A friend was in town and had made reservations for Ozumo on Friday night. We loved the ambience and environment. Maybe, we will love the food too? Well, once we walked in, people were sitting at the bars and tables enjoying their happy hours. As we walked further in, we see a wall of sake with more tables. On the other side of the wall of sake was where the sushi bar was. We were excited to try the food there. This week showcased their new spring menu. It included some new items and some old (so says our waitress). I would have to say, we went with our waitresses recommendations and they turned out pretty well. So, let me try and remember these dishes. By the way, some of the dishes were from the omakase selection. Yummy!

Toro Tuna Belly-was delicious!

Anago- a bit dry, but ok.

Artichokes-the artichokes were tasty. Hint: squeeze the lemon over it. It's better with the lemon. It gives the artichokes a kick.

Hanabi-typical slices of hamachi with ponzu. The jalapeno taste in the jalapeno ponzu makes it unique.

Hotate-Seared scallops. They were very tasty!

Yuki?-pork over cabbage. Delicious. The meat was so tender and the cabbage underneath it complemented the pork.

Beef tartare-raw beef? Yum! It had other condiments to add in with the tartare, if you chose to add it in.

Azuki bean beignets with ice cream-I love beignets, but beignets filled with azuki bean. How yummy!

Taro bread pudding with ice cream-this dessert was good, but I love the beignets more!

On top of all this food and dessert, we also had a bottle of sake. Yeah, the bill was expensive, but I suppose you pay for the ambience and the service. Food is better than the average. That's for sure! :O)
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description: The best sashimi!!! Love their food it is oh so quality. A bit loud but I guess that's part of the experience there in the bar area. Go for the hamachi and tuna apps you won't be disappointed
author: Sahra A.

description: Thank you Sarah! Ozuma catered my daughters wedding and it was delicious.
author: Laurie A.

description: We ordered Omakaze Saturday evening.  It was busy, but our wonderful waitress, Veronica, delivered an amazing experience.  We started with a Hamachi sashimi in a wonderful sauce, moved through sushi, sashimi, and beef.  Each step of the way, Veronica checked in on the direction we wanted to go, but she controlled the menu and we were delighted with her selections and the food.  What amazed me was the Sake pairings.  We moved across and wonderful selection of sake from sweet and cloudy to dry and clear.  Each pairing amazed me and really opened my eyes to sake and its complexities.  Five stars for sure and many thanks to Veronica.
author: John S.

description:
The Good:
Pretty much everything. We got the Ozumo, the Bucho and the Red Dragon rolls. All were amazing. The freshest sushi with not a ton of sauces to mask to flavor. I got a drink called 'The Giddy Geisha' and Daniel got 'Rainwater.' My drink was OK, but his was amazing. Really refreshing, could really taste the cucumber and no burn. The service was great. 

As for service, we don't agree with a lot of the other yelpers. Our waiter was super friendly and had a fun personality. We never felt rushed, the food came on time and we never felt it was too loud. 

The Bad:
The price, but that's to be expected when you're eating at a place like this. 

The Ugly:
The restaurant looked gorgeous. For being such a large place, it maintains that small restaurant appeal.
author: Rachel G.

description: The sushi is decent, but I don't feel like it's anything to write home about. I know I'm particularly picky about sushi so I already accounted for that by giving it four stars. Decent means the fish is fresh and the presentation was good but it wasn't special.
author: Grace H.

description:
My boyfriend and I, were giving a $100 gift card to eat here.  So we decided to check it out for lunch time.  Let's just say we were kids in a candy store.  We both ordered the most expensive glass of wine and beer.  Had the most tastiest Garlic Edamame, veggie tempura, sushi and some dessert.  We still have some money left on the card.  Going here for lunch was affordable for the really good food.  

The main seating room has a really gorgeous view of the Bay Bridge.  Super romantic and fancy.  This place is worth checking out at least once.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This is a trendy and fun expense account Japanese restaurants.  The atmosphere is great with a huge central sushi bar that is the focal point of the room.  

Menu is extensive and "Nobu esque" but what keeps me from a higher rating is quite frankly the so so sushi at someone steep prices.  We had a ton of rolls, and the toro was seriously unedible.  Likewise, the spider roll was only so so. Desserts were tasty.   If you are looking for fun atmosphere and a good drink selection, Ozumo is a fine choice.  But I wouldn't pick it for the food.
author: Gloria F.

description: I love this place! I come here about once a month and the food and service is always on point. I have brought several friends, colleagues and family members over the years and we always have an amazing experience. Charlie's skills at the sushi bar are unparalleled and you should request Wes as your server. He is knowledgeable, professional and attentive. Chef Michael is super creative and innovative.
author: Shelley M.

description:
Have been to Ozumo twice, once for dinner and once for lunch. Overall, I was totally unimpressed with the food and its quality versus the price. Seemed like more show than substance.

If you're in need of an OK lunch spot to do business, I think Ozumo works, but if you're looking to be blown away by the sushi experience, look elsewhere.
author: S M.

description: Nice lunch place close to Rincon center. If you don't have reservation you get to sit at the sushi bar. Even though the place is huge.. guess it's popular. I had the sushi bento box which was good. My hubs had the spicy miso ramen which was good. Nothing spectacular (ok the service is prob above average) but worth repeat business.
author: Vol T.

description:
Best service, hands down. My waiter was brilliant - very nice, respectful and understanding. He gave great recommendations in terms of food. I came here soon after my 21st birthday and for the sake of asking on the behalf of my companions, asked about the sake selection. He was understanding to the fact that my we couldn't  afford the high end of a price range. We decided to decline buying sake but we were still offered a small sampling of sake despite that fact. It was much, much appreciated. 

We ordered a dish of salmon sashimi, the sekiwake roll, the shacho roll, the spicy tuna roll and the sumiyaki. The salmon really does melt in your mouth. This is the kind of place that you don't need soy sauce because everything is delicious enough to not need the that flavor to overpower your taste buds. My favorite was the sekiwake roll but both rolls were definitely enough to put you in a mouth-watery state when they came out. The sumiyaki was deliciously smoked and such a unique spin on pork ribs.

Glad I was able to try it once!
author: Ann V.

description:
This is the least "Japanese" sushi place I've ever seen. Rude staff,  total lack of organization,  and nobody there seems to be Japanese or know anything about Japanese culture. Add to that the way, way overpriced food and you have a place I'll never return to. 

The thing is,  it wouldn't matter if the staff didn't know much about Japan -- we are in the US after all. But shouldn't they knew at least a little?   Or at least not butcher the names of all the menu items?  And why do they have to be so rude?  Hostess was snotty, and our waiter messed up our order,  then tried to blame it on the kitchen (when it was obvious he had made the mistakes) and on top of that he was rude about it! 

If it weren't for tourists and guys on expense accounts this place would probably be out of business. Too bad,  it's a beautiful space.
author: Victoria W.

description: I ordered their Spicy Miso Ramen and I loved it! I also ordered the Donburi - Gyu-Don (steak) which was really good. Can't wait to eat my leftovers, but to be honest, sushi is good, but not worth the price they put. To add, staff is super friendly. If work takes you out for lunch, Ozumo is a place I recommend.
author: Joane B.

description:
The food and service were terrific. We made a reservation for 4 and everything was set up and ready for us when we arrived. The maitre d' was professional, well spoken, and knowledgeable about the dishes. We took him up on his honest recommendations and everything was perfect. The toro, sushi, and cooked fish dishes were all high quality, full of flavor, and paired well. 

I only give it 4 stars because it was rather noisy, making dinner discussion a little challenging at times.

Overall great place and plan to go back.
author: Mypinions N.

description: One of the best meal experiences we have had, hands down!  My husband and I came for dinner on a Saturday and were able to get great service throughout. Drinks, appetizers, sushi rolls, and chocolate fondue dessert with herbal tea. We tried it all, and we're pleased. I will say the riceless lobster roll may be an acquired taste. Other than that, loved it all!
author: Linda H.

description: My favorite bar/restaurant in San Francisco and surprisingly it's never too crowded. Friendly bartenders and awesome sushi and garlic edamame. Shout out to Nicole and Marcus
author: Ninaad G.

description:
I have been to Ozumo countless times. It is a wonderful restaurant to go to with friends, but the food is not spectacular. 

The service can range from downright rude to overly friendly. 
There are typically a lot of tourists at this location and they are usually over-dressed and make me feel awkward when I just came to chow down at dinner. To me Ozumo is more of a casual dining establishment. 

My friends love that they offer sake samplers  ( I don't drink, maybe I would enjoy the food more if I was drunk off of sake lol ). 
I can give the uni risotto 5 stars, but it isn't an authentic Japanese dish.

Ozumo is more of a california-japanese fusion type restaurant. If you are looking for perfect sushi ( nigiri and sashimi) this is probably not the place you want to eat at.

It is worth a try if you have never been before, but for me I don't get my sushi "fix" per se. I'm not a roll girl. If you are you would probably love Ozumo!
author: Alexandra C.

description: Went here on a corporate dinner and loved it!  The place was insanely crowded but the service was still good.  The rolls and other choices were imaginative and delicious.  Our server was very knowledgeable with the sake menu so we were able to get something good even though we were a little lost with all the Sake choices.  Everyone really enjoyed the evening and we'll certainly be back!
author: Jonathan A.

description:
I can't believe this place has been open for at least ten years already.  I am OLD.  Anyway...

Spicy hotate - I had high hopes for the spicy hotate.  Unfortunately, it was neither.  It wasn't spicy, and were there even scallops in there?  I feel that if tiny/cute-sized scallops is typically what they serve, perhaps a different preparation or presentation would help in making the scallop the focal point.

Dragon roll - pretty standard

Ozumo roll - better dragon roll.  Seriously.

Hamachi maki - get it.  Fish was delicious, tempura flakes added great texture contrast, the lemon was refreshing, the accompanying sauce was wonderful.  Just so good.

Also of note: check in on Foursquare and get a sizable bowl of edamame (get it with garlic)!
author: Jenn C.

description:
Sushi melts in your mouth. Definitely a hip and trendy place to eat at, but I always feel like i'm eating in the dark there. The few times i've been for happy hour, but it's just OK. I like how the presentation of each dish is like art. Impressive and fresh. Just pricey.

BTW-- you won't walk out of their feeling "full" unless you've spent over $150 for a dinner for two.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
I was attending a wedding across the street at Yang Sing and on the corner of my eye I caught a glimpse of  Ozumo. Curious and eager to try this place out, I patiently waited for it's doors to open.

When I walked in,  the lounge area was dark and had a combination of natural wood and slate feel. Very modern, sleek, and inviting for conversations.

The bartender was very friendly and offered a few seasonal drinks and suggestions. I am a tequila person, however I was okay with stepping out of my comfort zone.  The drinks came in a martini glass which I prefer in a tall glass instead, much more manlier lol.

Can't remember the name of the drink but it was the only spicy one they made that day. The drink was complex and felt like a roller coaster of flavor seas rushing around my taste buds. 

On the other side of the  room and up a few steps was the dining area with a grand sushi bar. It was artfully decorated with empty saki bottles... The was an actual private room separated by walls of saki bottle. 

I will return soon and see what the corner of my eye catches inside  this establishment, cheers!
author: Thomas C.

description: Great sushi, but horrid service at the front bar. Blatantly ignored me as I sat solo for 14 minutes before I had the hostess move me.
author: Chris T.

description:
Had lunch with a client here and had an overall lovely experience.  Nothing too innovative or unique in the way of food items, but everything we had was fresh and tasty.  I enjoyed some excellent unfiltered sake and was treated to the (very cute) bartender's poetic explanation of how it was made.  

In addition, both my client and I were those annoying corporate types and had to take calls, etc, and the restaurant let us stay and drink green tea way past the time they had officially closed after the lunch.  Major props for dealing with us gracefully - I look forward to the time I can come back with friends and explore the sake options in more detail.
author: Joie M.

description:
Well, what can I say.  I made a mistake and I regret it.  Tourist trap Ozumo has second rate sushi at 3 times the price, and 1/2 the service.  Imagine a 300 ml bottle of cold saki (about 10 ounces) for $44!  And that is the low-average price, not the highest.  3 measly gulps and poof, it's gone, and so is $44!  

Sushi rolls are $14 and above, most high teens, some low $20's.  Had a $300 meal for 4 and two of us only had soup, salad and two rolls each.  Major rip off.  There are great sushi places in SF.  Beware.  Stay far away from this overpriced gaudy one!
author: Barry G.

description: Worth every penny!!!! Great service! Every single thing I ate was amazing!!!! Plus the place has a pretty cool atmosphere. Be smart and don't go on Friday or Saturday though.
author: Fredo L.

description:
The dishes were unique and also the server was very knowledgeable. I have to say the fish was very fresh. We made a mistake and ordered the wrong fish so make sure you get the names right.

There are some seats with a view. We were lucky enough to get one of them. It's better than the seating in the inside.
author: Chi-Kit C.

description:
This place looks pretty upscale and the pricing definitely reflects this.

I came here for lunch one day with a co-worker since we were feeling some sushi. I'm sad to say that for the price that we paid, which was ~$18 for a 6 sushi roll, I wasn't very impressed.

First off I will say that I am not a super sushi eater so I probably can't tell the difference between really good and regular sushi or sashimi, so keep that in mind. If you are a real sushi connoisseur, maybe my review won't accurately describe what you taste, but for the average everyday eater, my guess is my sushi tastes will about match yours.

The rolls definitely tasted good and from what I can tell made of pretty good quality fish, but not enough for me to justify the pricing and small portions.

Bottom line:
Modern, sort of upscale sushi place with good quality fish but small portions (for sushi yes, I had thought rolls were standard 8-10 pieces but I guess they come in 6 sometimes too) and higher than average prices for what you would normally expect. 

That being said, I think some people will really love this place for the quality while others will shy away from it because of the pricing and portions. I fall in the latter category since I like to eat quantity with decent quality, but once above a certain threshold quality all tastes very similar to me. However, if you fall into the first category or linger somewhere in between, maybe this place is worth a shot for you. Ya never know until you try. Wise wise wise. So wise. Just like Samwise Gamgee.
author: Eric S.

description:
Solid large scale, upscale modernist Japanese cuisine right by the Embarcadero.  Yelpers and the server agreed mostly on what to order:
- The Gindara - familiar to JP food snobs everywhere, this is your basic, incredible "miso black cod" - $29 worth of it.  Enjoy it, it's amazing.
- Hanabi - ALSO familiar to JP food snobs, it's hamachi, avocado, and ponzu sauce.  I'm sorry, I mean "warm ginger jalapeno ponzu sauce." You can make this at home in about 5 minutes (at least with regular ponzu sauce) but you're not going to because you have to go to a Japanese grocery store (or Basa in the mission)  to get the ingredients.  So just order it here... it's fantastic.
- Shacho Roll - an original!  This one has lobster and mango and has that "fresh, light natural" taste that is so hard to achieve without making it feel like you're eating a garden.  Probably our favorite (yes even vs miso black cod)!
- Choco Can: flourless chocolate cake.  You've probably had it elsewhere, and you know it's the bomb.  Do it.

We also had the Kyojin, which was "just OK" with seared salmon.  Service was a little uneven since we were at the bar.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Very solid choice. Can't go wrong with the rolls, those are very good. Definitely more of a business lunch or dinner type of place but never disappoints. 

Service has always been great and the last couple of times were no exception.

The only slight knock would be the prices.
author: Charly K.

description:
Japanese people believe that we eat food with five senses.Because of that, Japanese food does not only taste good but is also visually appealing. Japanese chefs like to express seasons with food-in Spring food resembles a cherry blossom for instance.

I had a full Japanese cuisine experience at Ozumo-this is where food meets Zen on a daily basis. Appropriately enough, the restaurant itself was inspired by a Zen garden. I should also mention that this was the best Japanese food I had in San Francisco so far. I can't wait to go back.
author: Elma C.

description:
Sushi is great but only if you want to pay a crazy amount.

We had a total of 16 pieces for 100 dollars.

We ordered salmon sashimi and had asked for five pieces. The chef gave us seven.... Thinking this was an act of kindness we were impressed until we saw the bill where they charged us an extra $4 for each extra piece.

Will not be back.
author: Cass H.

description:
My work is such a temptress!  Tempting me with left over food from meetings & the occasional catering order!  There were a handful of left overs from Ozumo one day at work after a meeting & I couldn't resist.  The beef in the flat loin bento was so flavorful & tender.  The sushi though cut a little on the smaller side was tasty & so fresh.  And my favorite...the chocolate flourless cake was to die for!  It was so decadent & one of the best chocolate items I've ever had.  

I can't wait to actually eat at the restaurant next time!
author: Cat C.

description:
My girlfriend and I ordered two starters - the edamame prepared in soy sauce and garlic ( a must order if you go with edamame) and the tuna tartar - which was nicely paired with a avocado and a spicy dipping sauce. It comes with chips to dip as well. 

We also order two rolls: the dragon and the spicy tuna. The Dragon was super tasty and will definitely order again. It comes with tempura shrimp wrapped in tuna and avocado - really good combo. The spicy tuna is plain (still very good) but I think the more specialized rolls are the way to go.

The atmosphere is also great - it is a really big place so the seat you get might come with a slightly different feel: either kinda like a lounge, a sushi bar or just your standard SF view of the bay...pretty great.

Also the service was very quick. Will definitely make this my go to sushi spot in SOMA/Embarcadero.
author: Derek S.

description:
I came here with a Bachelorette party. We had arranged for a private room and a prefix menu. We had reserved our seating for 8:30 but yet at 11:00 we were still waiting for our 4th course. The sushi platter was not even close to feeding the whole table and we had to order another plate just so everyone could have some. After we got the plate, service disappeared. When we asked when the 4th course would be there, the server kinda pulled a snotty attitude and said that they weren't prepared for the night and that they got slammed. Unfortunately, looking around the restaurant they were steady, but not what I would called slammed. Then we just asked to have the food to be boxed (which unfortunately none of us ate and went to waste). When we asked about the 5th course, the snotty waiter said "you can't exactly box up fondue. I guess we can give you cheesecake or something"

Overall really disappointing. Will not be back and no way will I ever book a party here. I paid $100 and I was still starving.
author: Kat W.

description: Not only are the ambiance and food great, but the service is superb. The dining service is pleasant and accommodating. Additionally, I accidentally left behind my wallet at the table with $500 cash inside. When I returned to look for it, the bus boy turned it in, all $500 in tact.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I am a discerning, critical, OCD sushi nut. You certainly can say that this is an expensive sushi spot. And that's about as much as you can say that's critical. Staff is as well-trained and knowledgeable as you will find in the country, let alone SF. They have a massive sake selection, and at least three sommeliers that know it front to back. 

Fish selection?  Please. Only a handful of sushi places have the kind of volume turnover needed to put out such a tremendous selection. 

GM Mel Collins demonstrates an almost military precision in his attention to detail. He always remembers your name, he makes sure to sit you in front of your favorite sushi chef each time. He knows you, and always makes you feel like you are at home in his house. 

My favorite chef, Charlie, never fails to impress, continually serving me something I've never had before --after 25 years, an impressive feat-- and listens to my wife and I and always surprises us.

The best spot in SF consistently. Love it here.
author: John P.

description:
This was my first dining experience at Ozumo.  It is a classy Japanese restaurant with a light feel.  My girlfriend and I had an 8:30pm reservation on a Saturday night and when we arrived at 8:30 we were seated immediately.  The restaurant wasn't full, but there were a good amount of people dining, as well as at the bar.

Our server arrived a few minutes after we were seated with hot towels to clean our hands - a nice Japanese touch that I appreciate and welcome.  There's something about cleaning your hands with a hot towel before a meal that starts the meal off right.  I wish everything restaurant did that.

Our server, Ken, was great and was able to offer some great recommendations.  We ordered the Hanabi, the Dohyo, the Maguro sashimi, Benijake nigiri, Hamachi Maki rolls.  Everything was outstanding and very fresh.  My only disappointment was that they were out of the Toro, which I really wanted to try.

The food came spaced out enough so that we weren't rushing through anything, and nothing was overcrowding the table.  Ken came back to check on us every once in a while and to get us another round of drinks (Old Fashion and another bourbon drink that resembled an old fashion, but was made with mint and a date jam/syrup - which was delicious but I forget the name of it).  

Overall, our experience at Ozumo was a great one.  I would definitely go back there again.  Next time I'm going to try the Black Cod!
author: Francisco A.

description:
I went with my wife there, based on the reviews from foursquare friends!
Food is great, not your commercial style sushi, service is great love sitting deco, great selection of food for all taste buds!

I had the greatest company at the nicest sushi place in SF!
author: M A.

description:
Can I give Ozumo 6 stars? 7 stars? 10 stars?? If I could, I would. This place deserves it. 

The hubby & I were lucky enough to have a gift card (thanks Sandy!) so we came here on Monday night for an early dinner. It was his first time, my second time. When he first looked at the menu, his eyes just about bugged out of his head. Yes, it is pricey, but I assured him it would be worth it. Well, halfway through the meal he was ordering a $70 bottle of sake without any hesitation so I know he was convinced! 

We started with the garlic soy edamame. Wow I had forgotten how amazing these are! I could have eaten 5 bowls. Once they were gone I was still eyeing the sauce at the bottom, wishing I could drink it. But this is a fancy place so I held back. 

Next was the Hanabi, which was slices of hamachi and avo with ginger jalapeno ponzu sauce. Wow! It was heavenly. Things just kept getting better. 

We ordered 2 sushi rolls, one was the Sekiwake (spicy tuna with tobiko, salmon, hamachi and peanut sauce). If you think that peanut sauce & sushi don't mix, well you would be wrong! The other roll was the Akebono (toro, avo, & asparagus). Both rolls were so incredibly fresh & the fish just melted away in our mouths. 

Last but not least came the assorted nigiri (tako, maguro, hamachi) for hubby & salmon sashimi for me. I literally collapsed with every bite. No, really. Have you even eaten something so delicious it makes you swoon? Yep, that was me. I fell in love with the salmon sashimi. I told my hubby I wanted to take it home with me. 

What's a fancy dinner without dessert? We ordered the melon creme brulee. What was interesting about this dish was that the melon slices were actually caramelized with the creme brulee coating. The slices sat in a sweet tapioca broth with some sorbet on the side. Light, refreshing, & a perfect end to an incredible meal. 

Our waiter was more than accommodating & knew the sake menu like the back of his hand. The overall feeling of this restaurant is fancy, yet casual & not pretentious at all. My kind of place.
author: Erin S.

description:
Ozumo is a solid choice for a dinner spot to go to with friends. I have been here a couple times, and have always had a great experience.

The food is fresh and the quality is above average. Although it's on the expensive side, it's worth the money if you are looking to have a great night out.
author: Nitin Y.

description:
Went for a late dinner with a friend on an expense account (thank god). We had some beer and sake, a hamachi appetizer, the squid tempura, and some nigiri. The food was delicious, and the service attentive. But the portions are quite small, and not justified by the prices. 

The bar looks fun, and I can imagine that they have a decent happy hour scene - the space is beautiful. If I ever need to impress someone, I might take them here. Otherwise, I'll stick to a more affordable spot.
author: Andrew M.

description:
lively bar scene at the front,calmer scene in the dining room. 
rolls can be a little pricey, but worth it nonetheless 
Ozumo is by far my fave roll. 
I sat at the sushi bar, and the chefs donned out samples to me. :) YAY
author: Ericka M.

description:
Overpriced. 

Reduce the price by 40% and you have a solid, 3 star joint.

We had 2 bottles of wine and some great sake.  Both were quite above other places in the city. Now part of it is the location and view. 

Our problem with the meal was that of the 3 high end rolls we ordered, 1 was just terrible, one was excellent and the other average.  We also ordered 12 pieces of sashimi.  The fish was fresh, but not as fresh as one would have assumed.   

For three people, our bill exceeded $450 bucks.  

There are better places to go.
author: Anand A.

description: One of our favorite restaurants in SF!  We are moved and miss the sushi here.  Really fantastic!
author: Tamara C.

description:
Took my girlfriend here for her birthday and had a good time. Made a reservation on their website for a Tuesday dinner but it didn't get packed so it wasn't necessary.

They have a big bar separate from the main dining area and had good service. Everything tasted great. You can tell everything was really fresh. Drinks and Sushi rolls were a little pricey but that should be expected in the city. I highly suggest gettin the Calamari. Probably the best Calamari I've ever had.

Hostess and waitress were great. I brought in my own cake and candles and they helped me throughout the night and kept it a secret from my girlfriend. They wouldn't let me light the candles that I brought because they were sparklers (probably some fire hazard) but they supplied new candles for me so it worked out.

Had a good window seat that opened up to the Bay Bridge so the view was nice. Probably wouldn't make it an every weekend place to go because of the prices but I definitely would go back.

Try it out.
author: Bruce W.

description:
My first review. Normally I just check reviews for recommendations but don't post my own but I was so sad at the poor experience my wife and I had at Ozumo that I had to write. I dined here around the 4th of July weekend and was really excited to be back. I have eaten here before and had a really incredible experience. Until a week ago.

My wife, who is Japanese, and I had a few dishes that were ok. Kama which was good, toro sashimi which was ok. But then I ordered some simple sushi - Ikura and Uni, my wife's favorites. The Ikura had the telltale signs being previously frozen and it had no taste or texture. We both commented that it didn't taste right and I trust my wife's taste buds.  The Uni wasn't much better. I'm guessing freshness was the issue.

Finally we had the hot pot and it was just plain bad. Incredibly bland and poorly executed.

To have one dish miss is one thing. But several dishes given the prices is just unacceptable. In the fog of trying to remember a meal I'd rather forget I seem to recall having Agedashi Tofu and the tempura on the tofu felt heavy and overcooked.

Given the abundance of sushi places in San Francisco, I'll drop Ozumo for any number of better places at better prices. Might be time to get the word out to avoid this place.
author: Ted N.

description: Very nice bar! Great selections of wine and sake. First time here, try many if the sushi rolls..good but not the best in that price range.. however, 2nd time here..we try their Robata kitchen foods..that was wonderful! And the beef tataki ..juicy and tender!  The uni Yamabuki soon good, just melt in your mouth and the smell of the fresh uni just unbeatable! Tempura  and Ikakoromo also great！will be back!
author: Betty L.

description: This spot was cool, overpriced, I feel like they have the same specialities over and over again on the menu. The sushi quality wasn't bad, prices were pretty high, and that's about it! Service was good but that's about it, I won't be back!
author: Arman A.

description:
Had to try this spot out knowing how good it was in Los Angeles!

The black cod was as always light and delicious with its hint of miso. The sushi was fresh and I got my usual nigiri - tuna, unagi, yellowfish and salmon. Dessert of chocolate fondue fruit was definitely to my liking.

The ambiance is pretty good - the front was dimly lit with an intimate feel. The back was a little brighter but still had that sense of privacy that we all seek for a nice dinner with warm sake. And their sake menu is plentiful!

Lots of Japanese customers speaking their native tongue - has to be a pretty good sign right?

Great spot close to the bay bridge and Ferry Building. 

Get parking at the valet or street parking if you're lucky.

This seems like it'd be a great spot for a happy hour or cocktail night out with the group! I like it and would come back if the occasion were right.
author: Julia P.

description:
Just ate here for lunch. Wanted to treat my long time gf to a farewell lunch. They were very accommodating as we were in a rush and I called in ahead of time to put in our order. 

The Hanabi was delicious! I would def get this again. 

Minus two stars for the ramen. It was such a disappointment. Egg was flavorless and wasn't soft boiled as directed. The soup lacked flavor. Portion is small and def wasn't worth $16. 

The sushi should be better. Ramen should be skipped.
author: A W.

description: Food is good, sashimi quality is fresh and excellent. This place is a bit pricey though. A bento box lunch with sashimi is between $20-$25. I only eat when someone else pays :-)
author: Tina C.

description: What a great food experience. I highly recommend in their appetizers; grilled octopus and tuna tartare. In their main course; wagyu steak. For an excellent service, ask for Ken. He was our waiter and made our dinner an unforgettable experience. Highly recommend.
author: Edwin A.

description:
Decent sushi, best so far in sf. Came highly recommended. Sushi was very fresh. Flavors lacked a little bit of oomph. Was pretty busy when we were there, so service was a little slow

Great wine list. Desserts were amazing -
Definitely do not skip!!
author: Sam C.

description: One of the most reliable Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area.  Sushi is always high-caliber, and there are always 'non-standard' options available (on my recent visit we had kinmedai and burri-toro- irregular on US sushi menus).  The non-sushi selections are diverse and tasty as well, and their sake selection is as good as any around.  The location is physically gorgeous, settled on the embarcadero with a great bridge view.  Nice bar, great sushi bar, and a cute 'private room' enclosed with sake bottles.  Near the top of my bay area sushi list, I will be back again and again for sure.
author: Andy S.

description: The service is wonderful and it has a romantic setting .I would have a buisness meeting also best food in town
author: Andrea L.

description:
The food: OK.  The tiny edamame croquette appetizer was tastier than anything I got in the mifune bento box.  Their fish was nothing special, and rather scant on the nigiri.  

The service was good, can't complain there.

The price didn't justify the food, however.  $18 for a medicore bento box, and miso soup wasn't included.  Glad this meal was comp'd.
author: Carlin F.

description: Good food and service. Ambiance ok. Some tables have a view to Bay Bridge light show.
author: Mario C.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile and my coworker was nice enough to take me for a goodbye lunch. 

Its pricey, but its also because they're really good and their fish is top of the line - when you're eating sashimi you want to know you're getting the best of the best. I had the bento which gave me a good sampling of their sashimi.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Came here for my birthday week. Best sushi I have ever had. I am originally from DFW area, and man I've been missing out!

the hamachi is the best here.
author: Nikki K.

description:
Food tasted as good as it looked!!! Here's what we ordered:

Hanabi-  BEST quality Hamachi sashimi I've ever had. It was so fresh that the fish melted in your mouth like butter.

Shacho- this is the lobster roll. Most expensive roll there, and you just get 4 pieces. But believe me, it's the taste and aesthetic design makes the dish worth the pretty pennies!

Toro roll-but all I could taste was the chunk of avocado in the middle. I don't recommend this one.

Toro sashimi with vegetable tempura over a bed of avocado - good but too much lime juice! Made the sashimi hard to eat. And they should have left out the seran wrap under the avocado bed. I thought it was some sort of edible rice paper...=/

Togatta Stilleto- sparking white wine, lychee sake, and passion fruit puree...tasted great and makes you feel happy and positive; lol women in the bathroom were all buzzed and we all ended up telling each other how lovely everyone looked. I wouldn't mind trying all the cocktails - they all sound so creative (i.e. Giddy Geisha) and delicious! 

It was loud and crowded on a Sat night, so do make reservations. Lighting is dim and comfortable- great setting for a date! The interior is pretty modern and trendy.
author: Tes Y.

description:
Excellent service, cozy but classy interior, dressy vibe... Great lunch spot. 

The nigiri Bento Box was so fresh and tasty! Definitely tops most of the sushi I've had in the Bay Area. 

Definitely recommend a reservation, even for lunch. The tea is nice and the sushi bar is very clean and open. 

I plan to go back for dinner and drinks for sure.
author: Liz K.

description: We were in San Fran for a little vacation and we knew we wanted to try sushi somewhere where we knew, being right by the ocean, that the seafood would be fresh! Our hotel recommended this place. Great atmosphere! Friendly staff! Fresh sushi! So good! Need I say more?? Everything we tried was delicious! I Can't wait to get back to San Fran to try this place again!
author: Susan S.

description: Plate after plate after plate!  They know how to take care of you! We were celebrating the acceptance of my dissertation and Xeon hooked us up with tasty bites and the smoothest sake any of us have ever had. I'm coming back for my birthday!
author: JP M.

description:
As a wanna-be vegan, I really shouldn't review this place since my view is somewhat askew. However,  I feel compelled to comment on price vs. value...

I was recently here for a wonderful woman's birthday dinner. As a celebration, it was amazing! I wouldn't have missed it for the world! The service was attentive and generally excellent, if a lil' bit robotic and impersonal.  

I LOVE Sushi! Avocado, & cucumber rolls are easy to find @ most Sushi joints. I don't normally go to too many Japanese places that focus on things other than Sushi. The prix fixe menu here was mostly devoid of the art of Sushi. :( There was plenty of food during the (7-8!?) courses but none of it was worth the price of admission. I know the place is puuurty to look at and the food is well presented  but to me it's no more worth the $$$ than Moki's http://www.yelp.com/biz/mokis-sushi-and-pacific-grill-san-francisco I guess I'll take substance over style any day. Or if allowed, I'd prefer to have both @ a reasonable price. As a vegan, I'll stick to Cha-Ya http://www.yelp.com/biz/cha-ya-vegetarian-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco where I can have my Sushi & eat it too.
author: John B.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the food here is good and probably one of the best in San Francisco for freshness and the location is perfect for the business world and travelers alike.  That is also one of Ozumo's downfalls. Bringing in business people and tourists draws a large crowd which brings long waits and makes you feel as if you're either at the hottest restaurant in town or a chain restaurant like Cheesecake.  

Ozumo's can not be compared to any Factory because the food stands out on it's own.  The Dohyo and Hanabi are MUST-HAVEs on the appetizer portion of the menu.  And you can't go wrong with the sushi.  The Tuna Belly is one of my favorites but for a whopping $10/slice it get's expensive.  

Lower your prices a bit more and you'll be more comparative to better sushi restaurants in SF.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I have been to Ozumo several times. I would normally rate this place between three to four stars as the service tends to be great, but the food is greatly overpriced for what you receive. Also, the food is okay, but certainly not near the greatest I've ever had (particularly for a sushi restaurant in SF). 

The ONE STAR is a direct result of how the management handled a particular incident that left both me and my party so highly offended that we will never return. 

To be as brief as possible, my party entered and as we were being shown to our table, another group of patrons were shouting cat-calls and other crass comments at the women in our group. One individual in the group continued to make comments after I calmly (and repeatedly) asked him to "please show some respect & be a gentleman." 

Two managers arrived and the head manager gruffly told me "to be a gentleman [myself] and find my table,' by which I was greatly taken aback. He was defending the lewd behavior of other patrons during a non-confrontational exchange. At our table, he arrived and told me that I should not be offended as they are just a bunch of guys out having fun and that my friends would do the same thing (basically calling me a hypocrite while again defending rowdy, degrading behavior). Although he offered us a free round of Sake, no other real apology was offered and no corrective action was taken. 

I would expect this kind of behavior in a dive bar, possibly, but not a restaurant that bills itself as a, "destination for connoisseurs of libations as well as discerning epicureans." If you're looking for a good restaurant in SF that is more upscale and worth the price, I might recommend trying elsewhere.
author: Erik C.

description: A beautiful place in every way--food, service, and location.  I had the steak tar tar, ankimo, and salmon belly.  The food made my heart sing!  Plus, they have an amazing selection of Japanese craft beers.
author: Jeffrey D.

description:
Ozumo is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Right when you walk inside, you feel like you're in an intimate NYC style lounge with dim lighting and a trendy scene. I would especially recommend this spot to anyone who is new to the west coast from Manhattan. 

The sushi is great, but a bit pricey. If you're willing to drop some coin, definitely try the sake flights; you won't regret it. 

Small recommendation: This place would be better if the TVs in the bar area went off after 8pm. In my opinion, the TVs in the background make Ozumo feel more like a sports bar and take away some of the restaurant's charm.
author: Sachin C.

description: This place might look like a fancy at first sight, but NO. I was going to try the omakase, but it wasn't available, so I had $80 sashimi&nigiri combo with $100 sake. Sake was fine, but the sushi was sub-par. There was no flavor to any of the fishes maybe except for hamachi, which wasn't amazing either. I saw neither of any technique to cover up the poorly prepared ingredients, nor really fresh fish that is just good as is. Never coming back for fish, but maybe for ramen in the future.
author: J S.

description: Used to love this place years ago but its setting of the dining room has changed.  Lounge in the front is still decent to have a cocktail in.
author: Aasanda C.

description: Food was good. Service and management is terrible. We had to split our meal between the bar and restuarant even though we had a table which was given away (by them). Granted we were 5 mins late but we weren't notified. It was clear they preferred their corporate clients over our small party. Will never go back. The one in oakland offers much better service.
author: Terence L.

description: Very fresh sushi, with great preparation and presentation.  While the prices shouldn't throw me off for fresh sushi in downtown San Fran, they did. I could quite get the feel of what the restaurant was trying to go after, but was a nice place to eat at and and have a refreshing and well done meal.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Solid sushi. The uni and yellow tail were honestly awesome. The uni was some of the best I have had. In fact a I ordered more after we finished our first order. 
The rolls were good. 
Service was exceptional - honestly too notch. 
I would return if in SF.
author: Basil M.

description:
I will never EVER return here. 
I went for the first time for a bachelorette party in a private room. We had arranged to have a pre-fixed 5 course meal. We sat down around 8:30. The first two courses were ok and the service was decent. However when the 3rd course came out, there was a very small plate of sushi, but nowhere near enough for all 8 girls. We actually had to order another plate so that everyone could sample some. As the night rolled around, we looked at the clock and realized that it was 11:00pm and we had still yet to receive our 4th course, aka the main course. When we finally tracked down the server, he was rude and said that they were just slammed and were not prepared for the night. 

When we looked around, it was steady, but not what I would say slammed. Sadly, the bride was fading and we were just ready to go home. We asked for the 4th course to be boxed to go. When we asked about the 5th course, which we again, we had already preordered, the server answered snidly and said that "we can't exactly box up fondue, I guess we can box up some cheesecake or something." 

I basically paid $100 and walked out hungry, frustrated and disappointed. It really impacted the vibe of the whole party too. 

There are way too many other sushi restaurants at a better price point, better food and better service in San Francisco. I would highly recommend NEVER plan a private party here unless you want to receive subpar service and walk out unfulfilled.
author: Kat W.

description: I used to love coming here for happy hour and they had an awesome menu but they recently changed it and it's really overpriced
author: F R.

description:
I do not leave a lot of reviews online but feel that I should let others know about my recent experience. I work in the financial district and go to Ozumo regularly. I have been a fan of their food and service is generally delicious. (To give you an idea, I sometimes go 3x a week!) However, my experience today at lunch left much room to be desired. I am seeing a lot of new wait staff and the quality has most definitely declined in the past few years. As a loyal patron for many years, I was beyond disappointed.

We were a party of 2 and were seated promptly, which was great. When our server came to take our drink orders, we told her that we were ready to order food as well, as one of us was on a time constraint today. Our server acknowledged that and took our orders (gyoza, and 2 gyu bentos - one medium rare and one medium well). It was very odd that our server decided to whisper everything. We had to ask her to repeat what she said after every sentence. After she took our orders, she did not show up again until the very end. Never once did she check on us; it wasn't until I had flagged her down to get our check that she actually talked to us again.

After we placed our orders, the gyozas took another 25 minutes to arrive, which was unseasonably slow. The gyozas tasted very bad; the filling was dry and the outside was covered in a ton of oil. After that, it took another 15-20 minutes for our bentos to arrive. My dining companion's medium well order turned out to be completely well done; my medium well was charred on the outside but completely raw on the inside. The meat was simply too raw for my taste and so I sent it back. Another 10 minutes went by and a new bento was brought to me. But wait, I got the same beef that's been thrown back on the grill or something (they were already sliced) and drenched in sauce. Instead of preparing another piece of beef appropriately, it was evident that someone just cooked the sliced beef some more and tried to cover it up by adding a ton of sauce. The amount of sauce was appalling; it literally covered the meat. I was forced to send that back again and my order finally arrived another 10 minutes later, after I had to follow up a couple times. I basically had to scarf down my food and rush back into the office.

The server apologized half heartedly when I told her what happened. And not that I was looking for any monetary compensation, but after I had to send food back twice, and kept longer that I normally would have, I would expect a place like Ozumo to offer some form of gesture to make it right for their customers. But nothing. They did not do anything to make me feel that I am a valued customer and as such, I doubt I will be going back often, and will be taking all my business meetings in neighboring restaurants moving forward, for fear that Ozumo will provide an embarrassing experience.
author: Vivian K.

description: Atrocious.  I was a guest staying at the hotel and when I walked in at 8pm to a half empty restaurant I was told the only option was the sushi bar, not a table.  I had been at work for 10 hours, was on the wrong timezone and didn't want to sit up high without a back to lean against.  I am shocked that the hostess wouldn't seat me, on a holiday Monday with a half empty dining room.  I got welcomed to the restaurant next door, shown a fabulous table with a view of the bridge and had a great meal.  Utter fail
author: Amira G.

description: Fun vibe for drinks. However, the food was very disappointing. From the salads, to the sashimi, to the rolls- each dish was below average. The staff seemed to be rushed and unenthusiastic. I would maybe go back for a drink at the bar but nothing more than that.
author: Christina C.

description: Was staying next door at the Harbor Court Hotel, so figured I'd give it a try. Got a seat at the bar.  Service was a little pretentious, but not bad. Decided to try the Ozumo roll w/ grilled unagi and cucumber topped w/ snow crab, tuna, avocado and spicy sauce - very tasty; and the hamachi maki w/ hamachi, avocado, cucumber, jalapeno in a roasted garlic miso sauce.  A little pricey ($16-$18 each), but very good.  Next time, think I'll try to come during happy hour.
author: Amber E.

description:
We had the sekiwake - fresh ! 
Hamachi - incredible 
Suzuki - awesome. 
Sauvignon blanc - crisp 
Prices - reasonable
author: Ted A.

description:
Enjoyable dinner, nice interior, great service, very good food and average ambiance at least in the section we were in.
We had Edamame (standard), Tempura Yasai (Tasty), Shishito & Asparagus (yum), Tuna and Salmon Sashimi (very fresh) and black cod (large piece, a bit too saucy, generally quite good).
The drink I had with some type of whisky and yuzo (sp?) juice with muddled(haha) mint was basically a glorified mohito and not particularly impressive.
Overall a solid three, the main two issues I had were the big room on the embarcadero side was bland, like an upgraded denny's (sorry it was painful saying that) and the prices seemed high relative to similr places I've been in NYC or Toronto (and this plays a role in my ratings).
Entry side of restaurant looks nice for a pre dinner drink.
Maybe better options
author: Anthony C.

description:
I went here for a team lunch on a Friday. It was extremely packed, but luckily we called ahead and got a table for 6. The hostess was very friendly and accommodating. The place itself is very loud and dimly lit. 

The service left something to be desired. We had a reservation for 12:15pm. We arrived at 12:15pm, seated by 12:25, ordered placed by 12:45... food out by 1:30pm. I get that it's a busy restaurant, but it seemed like we did a lot of waiting around with no updates or attention or water refills. It also felt like we were kind of forgotten about as the waiters and waitresses would just pass on by. 

The food itself was pretty good. Each of us got a bowl of ramen. I tried the Ozumo ramen, which is a pork and seafood broth with egg noodles, fish, fish cake, bamboo. I also added an egg. The broth was quite delicious, everything else was very standard. Not bad at all. The ramen was $17 (plus some extra for the egg, I think). 

Overall, I don't regret it, but I would think twice before picking this place.
author: Mary N.

description:
I came for the sushi, but my boyfriend, who hates sushi, found some menu items that he absolutely loved--Gyu Filet I believe was one.  I loved the Dragon and Bucho rolls.  

Last time I visited, I tried a special, but I've forgotten the name of it - it was squid and it was amazing.  We like to get a big Japanese beer with dinner, but I tried the "Giddy Geisha" cocktail and really liked it.
author: Annie C.

description:
There is a common assessment on foodie boards and blogs that not a single phenomenal sushi restaurant exists in San Francisco. Over the past few years I've been trying to prove this idea wrong, and was hoping that Ozumo would be a case study against this premise. I am sad to say, however, that after dining at Ozumo it is becoming clearer and clearer that SF simply doesn't have it together in the sushi department.

We were seated promptly at 6 p.m. on Friday night. The bar area was super busy, while the rest of the place was about 3/4 full. I was immediately disappointed that all nigiri orders had a 2-piece minimum. It is well known that true sushi connoisseurs order single nigiris, so I immediately filed this place in the "dabbler" category. And after looking at the chefs -- they were all under the age of 30 -- I got the "training day" vibe as it's clear that relative beginners are preparing the sushi at Ozumo.

Those observations aside, it was time for the food. I ordered toro sushi, albacore sushi, salmon belly sushi (one of their specials), sweet shrimp sushi and anago sushi. Of those five varieties, only the salmon belly was delectable. Everything else was good, but nothing stunning, which was a disappointment considering the hefty expense.

In conclusion, I won't be returning to Ozumo. The decor is very nice, and the view of the Bay Bridge is superb. However when it comes to sushi I am seeking a life-affirming experience. You will not find anything close to that at Ozumo, or in San Francisco at all seemingly.
author: Phillip J.

description:
Pretty fancy place.

We were seated rather quickly.  We were a party of 4, we all ordered our drinks first and our sushi afterwords, total of 5 rolls.

The waitress brings out 4 rolls and leaves one persons order out.

We all finish our food because the rest of us were famished and the person was left with no food so told them they can share what we had on the table.

Long story short, any restaurant with these prices should know to bring ALL of the food at the same time. 

Secondly the drinks came after the food, which was a first for me. 

Sushi was nothing of spectacular, rather tasteless and boring, and rather on the smaller side.

3 stars for the decor and ambience. 

1-2 stars for the food.

We ended up getting the last roll compt.
author: Steve A.

description:
Simply, no.

Had it not been for the company of my friends and the fact they were so accommodating in the reservation. It would go zero.

Let's start off by having to take off my shoes to go into your little room. We're not Asian, and we should not have to take off our shoes. I do not eat ANYWHERE with my shoes off. Let me keep my damn shoes on, and  I would have given you a star. In fact, I was so unhappy about this I wanted to move to a different spot, but that compromised our party privacy.

The server, though nice, was including herself in our conversation. No, honey, you are there to serve us, not to party with us. Know your boundaries. Do not give your opinion about our conversation regarding lesbians adopting children. You are simply not invited into our conversation.

For a bill over $500, the best thing might have been...wait, there was nothing to brag about! The sushi was average, the sashimi was flavorless, the $130 bottle of distilled sake didn't taste great, the steak's mustard was simply and flat out a confusion to my taste buds (why sell steak at a sushi restaurant, anyway?)

We also had sparking sake, which was something I hadn't tried before, and chocolate fondue. I'm not even sure how Japanese this was, but at least they threw some mochi in there.

Also, we ordered enough food, and she kept pushing for us to order more. We're not idiots. We know you want to sell. If we want to buy, we will speak up and order more.

Overall, there are a million other not as expensive sushi restaurants in the city where you can have any roll and it melt in your mouth...and have a completely private conversation with just your friends minus your server joining in.

Avoid.


Edit: So, they decided to charge my card a different amount than what I authorized. Just what I needed. Paying more than I ever wanted to for sushi and on top of that getting charged a little more. This server needs a new profession asap!
author: Alexia R.

description: Awesome atmosphere. Awesome staff! Thanks for a great, incredible meal! The Kazan drink was amazing! Can't wait to come back!
author: Amanda H.

description:
Definitely a 3.5 star place/view/decor and yummy food. 

Service is a bit slow because it is always packed up the a$$.  Also, parking REALLY REALLY sucks so consider the valet service. 
 
I celebrated two bdays here and with about 16 people, we paid $170 each. It is a bit on the pricier side so try out their daily HH menu from 4 to 6pm. 

Their are def more japanese restaurant in the city with tastier selections but Ozumo strike me as 'to see or be seen" atmosphere...

Dress up to impress...i guess =]
author: Vee V.

description: Mel the manager is absolutely the best. I am not used to great service some I moved to the bay but Mel changed that. Food was great and service was awesome.
author: Ernie H.

description:
Incredibly overrated.  We were highly disappointed with Ozumo.

Sushi was fishy and not fresh, needed extra soy sauce to wash it down and we truly thought it might be so bad we could get sick.  I've never until now ordered toro that I actually didn't want to eat because it was that bad.  We ordered the hanabi appetizer, toro and salmon nigiri, the four vegetables and a couple of the rolls and both agreed the hanabi was the only item that actually tasted okay.  With the caliber this restaurant is supposed to be, the food should not taste the way it does.  The sushi that I've gotten from Whole Foods market has always been substantially better than everything I ate at Ozumo.  This should not be the case with a restaurant like this. 

The restaurant is incredibly overpriced for food that was truly inedible and not authentic Japanese in any way.   

There are so many great finds in the city that this place is not at all worth it.  Would not come back.
author: Kari F.

description:
In summary, a fantastic evening at Ozumo.

Things that stood out:

- The availability of Taittinger. Practically downed it.
- Our colorful waitress. Super fun. Which brings me to my next point...
- The cheesecake that she recommended. It's made of tofu, she says. Impossible.
- The remarkably fresh uni. I could've had a bowlful.

The roll we ordered was very meh (and same with the crowd). And our evening was pricey ($200 for 2).
author: Jeena C.

description: Very disappointed with the service at the bar. Food was not delivered after waiting for over 30 minutes, manger was extremely rude. When we asked for another drink, we were told we had been "cut off" only after ordering 1 drink prior. Very disappointed with the experience as a whole.
author: Lindsay D.

description:
What's sexy, popular and tasty all over?

As Bay Area Yelpers, you're probably thinking about bacon donuts, ROTDs and Power Exchange.  But what I want you to think about now is:

Warm, low lighting over square tables with square chairs, plotted out over a series of intricately arranged squared off sitting areas, heading surprisingly deep into this space.  Geometry is hot.

Raw fish done right is always sexy and they offer a fair variety of standard sashimi/nigiri/sushi (i.e. tuna, salmon)  to the slightly less familiar (i.e. sea urchin, octopus), for the more adventurous.

Can't handle the raw?  Try the warm and smooth: steamed sea bass or seared dayboat scallops are melting in your mouth.

Your happy ending may feel like an endurance challenge after the above pursuits, but I implore you to keep going.  All of the options look divine, but I can personally recommend the Choco Chan, a flourless chocolate orgasm with mochi and an afterglow side of green tea ice cream.

Go forth, Yelpers, and be sexy.
author: Ravena F.

description:
This. Place. Is. AMAZING.

As we were being led to our table, not only did I notice the beauty of the restaurant itself, but also that every single staff member we passed greeted us with a smile and sincere friendliness. Once we were seated, the superb service continued. So service alone = 5 stars. Every time my wine glass was empty there was a server next to me refilling it.

The food, also 5 stars. The hamachi appetizer was delicious, and the maki rolls had such unique and refreshing flavor combinations. The only slight issue I had was that the fish on the nigiri was not cut well. Besides that, the flavors of the food blew my mind.

Expensive, but so worth it for a date night or special occasion.
author: Sharon F.

description: Beautiful location overlooking the bay, the food was fresh, and a great ambiance. It's a little pricey, but overall it was great! I would definitely recommend this place to anyone. The service was also great!!
author: Melanie R.

description:
The food here is done impeccably but the portions are tiiiiiny for the price. The amount of chicken or salmon you get in a bento is literally like half a deck of cards. Which is cool but if the other items in the bento plate are a tablespoon of potato salad (which is super good), two grapes and half a strawberry and lettuce... It's not worth the price!

That being said their salmon is perfect, their sushi is fukn great and they have THE BEST edamame with soy sauce, garlic and ginger, it's a must get app.

Tip: ask how much the sushi special rolls of the day cost because I ordered one once a few years ago and it was $27.00! WTF?!!! Tell people how much the "special" costs if it's over $15.99!

I'd go here more often if it was cheaper. Also the space is HUGE and not cozy at all.
author: Free P.

description: When I travel for business and stay in the city, I love to entertain my clients at Ozumo.  They have a wonderful Sashimi selection, and the rolls are good.  I love to get the Sake flights and the combination of 3 tastings.  The atmosphere is always lively.  The one complaint would be the very small pieces of sashimi.  I eat all over the Bay Area and Ozumo seems to be a bit light on the serving size.
author: Conan P.

description:
An amazing dinner experience bolstered by a table near the window, great view of the Bay Bridge.

The tuna tartare was on point. The calamari was eh, tasted similar to a TGIF. You MUST order the uni/mushroom risotto! The cod with shishito was ok.  The sushi I was not a fan of. Presentation was great but the taste didn't wow me.

I'll still come back. Best time to go is Wednesdays at 9pm!
author: John M.

description:
Parking was difficult because of an event at ATT Park. I met a large group in one of the private dining rooms (seats up to eight comfortably). The dimmer lighting made the gathering intimate but harder to see the food.

Nice drink menu with specialty drinks. Appetizers served simultaneously by three staff, a nice touch. Fish were excellent: flavorful, distinct, and well presented. Rolls were tasty without excessive sauces that overwhelm most fish. Deserts excellent.

Very pricey with alcohol, easy to go over $100/person but a worthwhile and memorable splurge. I'll return to the sushi bar--I like to see the fish and the sushi man.
author: YearOf M.

description:
Updated February 2007:

$6 for green tea!!!!!!

I initially had Ozumo at 4 Stars, but I'm dropping them to One STAR after being charged $6 for a order of Ocha (green tea).  I asked for green tea, assuming it would be free (our waitress did NOT tell me it would be at a charge).  I started to get worried when each person that asked for tea got their own pot (very nice looking iron pot).  When the bill came, I was shocked that they charged $6.  Can you imagine if a sushi restaurant in Japan charged money for 'agari' (hot tea)?  If you are not familiar with Japanese food culture, you might be thinking, 'why is Toro E. getting so upset about this?'  For me, charging $$$ for green tea at a sushi restaurant is a crime!!! It's not right.

Note that I got this $6 tea treatment during lunch at Ozumo.  I could have had a full meat at The Taco Truck for $6!!!!

-----------------------------
I just learned that the name Ozumo is actually written in Kanji as O-O-Zu-MO, which means Big Sumo.  Which means you need to pronounce it with a long 'O', like OOOZumo.

My math for Ozumo:

+ 1 Star for amazing interior design.
+ 1 Star for fresh seafood, including sushi.
+ 1 Star for excellent appetizer --- try their Hanabi.
+ 1 Star for proximity to my home.
+ 1 Star for offering Kirin and Sapporo beer on draft.
- 1 Star for portion size.
-----------------------------------------------
4 Stars Total

I expected that a nice restaurant like Ozumo would charge high prices on their meals, but most of their menu items were below $20, perhaps to provide a perception that prices are reasonable.  You quickly find out that a $20 doesn't get you much as their portions are extremely small, so you end up getting a bunch of other things.  I know that fresh-quality food isn't cheap, so I just wished they would give you more food and have the prices on the menu reflect that.

LUNCH:  Although it's pricier than lunch at places in Rincon Center, lunch deals at Ozumo is much more reasonably priced than their dinner.  Many items are $12-15 range with some around $20.  Their three course pre-fixe lunch is $22.  Kurosawa bento ($19) came in a box with 5 compartments which included sushi and sashimi.  Their vegetable curry don ($13) was quite unique (which doesn't mean good) with yellow colored rice with mild curry with lots of vegetables.  I could see some people liking it, but it won't be ranked high in my top Japanese Curry List.  Tonkatsu Bento ($15) came with pork, which was on the thin side, with higiki, boiled veggi, salad, and for some reason, edamame.
author: トモ T.

description:
I'm not sure how accurate this review would be. My boyfriend's parents love this restaurant, and every time they're in town, they would take us here, and treat us to dinner. I've been here pretty often in the last several years, and since I've never paid for these meals, I am not accounting price in my review.

The food is always spot on. Fresh, flavorful, & creative. Their sashimi is always fantastic, but last time we got a local albacore tuna (on their daily special), and it was amazing. I always prefer albacore or fatty tuna over round eye, but this albacore was like stuff made from butter. It was soft, slightly sweet, and so fresh. 

We always order a couple of sushi rolls too, but their rolls are so-so. It's good, but there are more interesting things to get on the menu.

We also always get their four small plates of vegetables. They're usually okay, but last time we were their, their egg plant dish was seriously lacking. It was tough and still had a bitter undercooked flavor. My boyfriend's mother loved their okra. 

The boyfriend ordered a black cod entree, which was seared. It was just done, maybe even a very slight tinge under down. It was really good, but the boyfriend claims that "it is the best first [he's] ever eaten."

I'm sure our bill is always a few hundred dollars because there's wine, drinks, way too much food, and desserts. We get amazing service. Water and tea is always flowing. The server is very attentive and checked on us constantly (in a good way) and gave really good recommendations. He was very helpful with recommendations and handled our questions very courteously.
author: H. L.

description:
Is Ozumo expensive? Yes. Is it worth it? YES. We brought mom for Mother's Day and everything was exceptional. 

The restaurant itself is gigantic and pretty awesome. SF industrial meets customary Japanese architecture with a legit bar, lots of marble, a private room made out of sake bottles and even Japanese language lessons playing in the bathroom...  yes, really. Our server even looked like Clark Kent. Andrew (Andy?) was genuinely nice, made some great recommendations and won my mom and sister over pretty quickly *GROANS* But really cool ambiance, feels upscale without being stuffy.

Now the FOOD: Everything was insanely good! All of the sushi was delicious and super fresh. Food presentation was on a different level, more art than plating. The rolls were also really good without being overly sauced. All in all, we had a great experience, my mom left happy, good-son-duty completed. Oh, we were also in a little bit of a hurry to get to the airport but the food came out pretty quickly. We were in and out with ample time to get my mom to her flight. I will definitely be coming back.
author: Jeff G.

description: Wow.  This place just sucks.  I'm sorry - I love sushi, and everything about this place was awful.  The cooked food was incredibly bland.  The sushi rice was mushy.  The fresh fish was middling.  (Although I have to say the uni nigiri we ordered was delicious).  How is this place still in business?  No amount of half-dressed knockouts hanging out in the bar area (of whom there were a few) makes enduring this food worth it.
author: A B.

description: Came here with my boyfriend while on a trip to SF. We ordered the calamari which was some of the best I've ever had! We then got 2 orders of nigiri (yellowtail / Scottish salmon)  both pretty good. We also got a shrimp tempura roll and the Ozumo roll the portion sizing of the rolls is really small which is why this restaurant lost a star. The Ozumo roll was amazing!! Just wish they'd give you a little more for what you're paying for. All and all great meal and amazing ambiance and interior design in the restaurant. Great younger crowd.
author: Lauren M.

description: This is my fourth time dining at Ozumo. They have a wonderful selection of Sake and wines by the glass. Try the Sake tasting flight to get a good idea of the huge selection of flavors. The sushi is fresh and beautifully prepared. Very creative rolls. My wife is not a sushi eater and they had a good selection of cooked dishes. However, the made my wife a shrimp tempura roll with crab and topped with cucumber. She said it was the very best she has ever had. Why not 5 stars, it is a bit expensive. Lastly, the service is exceptional and to be commended on their creativity and suggestions. We will certainly be back.
author: John H.

description: This place is all around delicious.  The sake, everything on the menu and the food is amazing.  I had the cod which was out of this world good.  The lovely server picked out some great sake's.  We had the hamachi crudo as well and some different sushi - all awesome.  I look forward to coming back again.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Sushi was just okay...not close to some of the other establishments in the area. Service started off fine, but then completely dropped off to virtually non-existent for the second half of the meal. Think:
- asking for more more water
- pouring your own bottle of wine
- asking someone to clear your empty plates. 
We will not be back. 
#fail
author: Kirk P.

description:
My friend had a birthday party last week. We have total 44 people
They serve like family style (couple dish put on the table and you guys share)
I though they charge us $95/person and we should have individual plates (not share)
Very disappointed
For ambience is ok, but for food with that kind of price, sorry I won't go there again.
author: Raymond C.

description: Some of the best Japanese food I have had on the west coast. Went there for a business function and our tip was $1000 bit well worth it considering service and quality.
author: Benjamin K.

description: Service was awesome. Atmosphere fun. Sushi ...ehh...less than average. I'm from Broomfield Colorado and the sushi there is better. Still not perfect but better. Had the Toro, Buritoro, Shrimp tempura roll and their house specialty roll. Just didn't do anything for me. Bland and generic.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Found it disappointing for the price and hype. Bland bento bowls. Desserts were incredible.
author: Ipsita B.

description:
I LOVE Ozumo. I specifically need to give them a shout out because my wallet fell out of my tote bag at a large reception we were having. I was a wreck of course and called them when I got home. They found it, called me, were so helpful.

The food was fantastic as ever and the staff was awesome!

Thank you!
author: Julie T.

description:
Left here with such disgust. Came here to celebrate my friend's acceptance to Med school. So we got a Sake bottle and Sapporo to celebrate. My other friend and I were hungry, so we wanted to order some food. I ordered Shacho Rolls because it sounded amazing. My friend got his food, but I never got my roll. One simple order, and never got it. And it was a Tuesday night! It's not like it was busy or super packed. One thing i expect from restaurants is to have adequate service and have my food come in a timely manner, otherwise what is the fucking point?! 

So the waiter comes and notices I am still waiting for my roll (My friend already finished his two plates at this point). The waiter then tells me that the rolls will be complimentary since we were about to wrap up the bill. So then when he comes back to take the bill (like literally 20mins later), we asked him about the roll. Then he says "Oh did you still want it?" UM yeah I still wanted it because it sounds awesome to eat and because you told me that I was getting it comped. At this point, we were over it, and left. Such a disappointment. Ozumo seems like a restaurant that I would love, but their inept service and disorganization defers that emotion. 

As a foodie, I just hate it. I can't stand it when the food I order can't even show face on the table. And there really was no excuse.

Ozumo, YOU'RE FUCKING OUT!
author: Charles L.

description:
SHHHHHHHHHH

Be wearwee wearwee kwy-yet. I'm hunting call girls.

My guy friends told me this is the place to watch this type of thing happen. LOL It was great! We sat for happy hour to see if anyone got a happier hour! How fun is that? LOL

Drinks were tasty, ambiance awesome, decor gorgeous......

Sadly we didn't see any hookups, but we will play "guess the call girl" next time we go.
author: Chan T.

description: Our favorite sushi place in the city. Very fresh, creative, and delicious. Service is great. They go out of their way to make a special occasion a great experience. Awesome views of the bay bridge at night. Must request a table with a view. The saki tasting flights are a nice way to try different types if you are not sure what to get. All the sushi rolls are off the hook.
author: Erin U.

description:
Happy hour here is AWESOME! Usually there is an open bar area or an open table. Drinks and food are $4-$10 range. The service here is quick and friendly. I really enjoy myself here and I like to bring my friends here, so we can have a place that isn't blasting music and having to shout over each other It's also close to work which is a big plus!

For happy hour, I highly suggest the karaage and wings.
Oh they also have a TV by the bar in the front, so you can try to catch a game there too.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
As sushi lovers (from the east coast), we were overwhelmed with all of the choices in San Francisco and didn't even know where to begin with choosing the restaurant which would define our west coast sushi experience.  After a lot of "googling" and reading review sites (Yelp included), we settled on Ozumo.  

If you're not looking for it, you might not find it. A small sign hangs above the door on a low trafficked street. Upon entering, we were guided to the back of the restaurant, seated beside a wall of Sake.  Our waiter explained to us that they operate two different kitchens, one for sushi and the other for their cooked dishes.  Since we ordered some pieces and I added a cooked fish dish as well, they came out separately, which was not a big deal at all.  The sushi was probably the freshest, best tasting I've had anywhere.  The cooked sea bass, over tempura battered green beans was out of this world too.

We enjoyed the atmosphere, specialty drinks and most of all, amazing food.  I highly recommend for those who love raw or cooked dishes.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Melissa E.

description: One of the better sushi spots in SF but still not comparable to LA, Vegas, or New York. Food is a little salty. Atmosphere is fun.
author: Natasha Y.

description:
