The lunch menu's Sapporo Ramen is quite possibly the best bowl of ramen outside of Japan.  At $15, it's pricey and easily the most expensive ramen I've eaten, but it's oh so good!  And it does come with a side of salad and edamame.  The shoyu broth is delicious and well balanced, not too salty like at many other Japanese restaurants, and the crab is fresh.  What makes the dish stand out, however, is the melt-in-your-mouth chashu pork.  Here you get at least 4 or 5 slices of pork in the bowl, whereas other places will include only 2 slices at the most -- and they won't be nearly as good.

The Spider Roll is good, but not great; the ingredients are fresh and the portion is decent.  I don't care too much for the Iced Green Tea -- it tastes like a canned diet tea instead of something they brew themselves.

Service is attentive and the space itself is clean with modern Japanese decor.  Oh, they play Japanese instructional audio in the bathrooms, a nice touch :-)
author: Art M.

description:
Been here a couple times for business lunches, but not really anything that I would pay extravagantly for. The first time we were here, we had a huge group and got a really nice view of the water. The food was decent, but like I said, I maybe would not pay that much for it. 

For lunch, they also have these noodle specials, and it being way closer to work than any other ramen place, It's a happy medium. I would have their ramen over hapa ramen, and plus! you get to sit inside and eat out of a real bowl!
author: Angela H.

description:
Overall:  If you like variety and options with a trendy vibe this is the place for you. 

Food:  The omakase offers so many flavors and textures. So if you are gonna shell out the cash for that, you should just get the sake pairing too.

Service: Our cute and bubbly server Jenna gave us a night to remember that felt like we were being served in her home. 

Atmosphere: Expense accounts, couples, birthday parties. and creepers looking for Asian girls.

Decor:  Trendy.

Value:  This place ain't cheap but you will leave full without feeling bloated. If you order the sake pairing you will probably leave hammer time.

Return-ability: I plan to stop by at least 2 times a year.
author: Roger H.

description:
I went here with my husband last night and am still raging about it.  And I'm shocked at how many 4 star reviews this place has gotten.  We were told there were only seats at the sushi bar (which has some strange height issues that leaves your food at shoulder level)  and sat down only to be flanked by empty tables on all sides. Had to then endure an awkward pause before the guy who sat us would agree to check my coat.  Really?  I have to ask you to check my coat and then be treated like I'm asking for a personal favor? 

The food here is fine - it's not amazing for high-end flashy sushi, but it's fine. The pricing is ridiculous.  My husband had a cocktail (which tasted like a crappy appletini that had been raped by a pomegranate) and a beer, and I had two small glasses of cold unfiltered sake.  We had two starters (and just about a perfect amount of sushi, shared a dessert, and the bill was..... wait for it..... $216!!!!

The main thing about Ozumo that really made me crazy was the excessive number of douchebags hanging out as if they're hired body guards.  They're not wearing headsets, but boy, do they wish they were.  I know Ozumo is trying to be a swanky hip place, but that doesn't mean it has to feel like Vegas. 

As we were heading for the door to leave, I stopped to retrieve my coat from coat check.  There were, I kid not, at least 6 aforementioned douchebags hanging out by the door - WHAT THE FUCK ARE THEY THERE FOR!  Is this place a front for some douchebag in training school?! The guy who got my coat for me gave me a "here you go darling" as he helped me put my coat on.  Final fucking douchebaggery insult.

Never again.
author: ki r.

description:
Ozumo is a nice space with fresh and tasty food.  The garlic edamame, though nothing special, is really good.  The sashimi was very fresh and almost everything we ordered was delicious.  You must get the black cod!  

Ozumo is always satisfying-- that is probably why I've been here on numerous occasions and wouldn't mind going back.
author: K V.

description: The food was good and we loved the saki sampler but the portions were small.  I had the lobster roll and it had only 4 pieces. It was like $25 and had 4 pieces? Ridiculous. But the bison dish was larger and very tasty. We also had a hamachi app and it was very good.
author: Heather W.

description:
People are crazy when they say this is the best sushi place in downtown. 

It is the best Japanese bar in downtown. But really, there are lots of other places for sushi that is better (eg, Zushi Puzzle).  The fish is fresh, but none of the dishes will wow you (although they dress all of their entrees well).   

However, this is a very happening restaurant during bar hours, with a pretty decent crowd and good buzz. Good place to blow off some steam after work.
author: Mark M.

description:
My friends love this place, and come here often, so I am usually coming here because of this. I guess my friends also like the cute waitresses that work here, and the women this place draws. 

But as far as my review goes, I would say that everything is pretty good...the food, sake selection, vibe, service....but I just can't get over how overpriced it is. I think it's a little overrated, but it's definitely a pretty cool place to kick it after work and socialize.
author: Emy s.

description:
I'm with Toro E.  The drink pricing is messed up here:  I asked my waiter to recommend sake for me only to find out at the end of the meal that the half bottle was $200.  AND YOU DIDN'T THINK IT WAS NECESSARY TO TELL ME BEFORE HAND THAT IT  WAS $200 FOR A HALF BOTTLE LIKE I WAS ORDERING A DIET COKE OR SOMETHING.

Don't worry -- I paid you guys for it but I'm dropping my money elsewhere from now on.

Oh yea, I forgot about the time that my friend and I ordered albacore tuna but received hamachi instead.  We pointed this out to the waitress who denied it.  She reluctantly went back to the sushi chef to confirm; came back and said it was hamachi.  I order albacore all the time, albacore is my friend, and that was no albacore.  So we had her go back to the chef; same response.  It wasn;t until we demanded to have the chef look at us in the face and tell us it was albacore that she admitted it wasn't albacore.  Hey, if you're out of albacore, just say you're out -- like all other sushi restaurants do.  I'll just order something else, like I love uni.  BUT PLEASE DON'T TELL ME THAT PIECE OF HAMACHI IS ALBACORE.
author: Yum Y.

description: Fabulous restaurant. Great place to go with friends, a date, family, and business colleagues. The food is excellent! Service is great too. I really enjoyed their Sake flights and the green tea ice cream was delicious. Definitely a must to go back!
author: Miguel L.

description: We had a 1:00 reservation on a Monday.  We were seated immediately, served drinks and order taken in a very short amount of time.  We ordered Yakisoba,Gyu-Don, & a sushi roll.  The food came out after a short wait and of the three, the least interesting was the sushi roll.  The other dishes were executed flawlessly and very tasty.  My son also ordered a flight of 3 different sakis.  He decided he is not a saki drinker.  The decor is very nice.  The service was excellent.  The food very good.  Price is higher than what we pay in Sacramento but it is to be expected in San Francisco and in the financial district.  For the most part I do recommend if you can justify the price.
author: Michael R.

description:
I've been to Ozumo several times. Service has always been great, no issues there.
Ambiance is lively, and the place is always busy.
Sushi is overrated and over priced for the quality. My opinion is your paying for the scene. If I was a drunkard I would probably like to get loaded at this place and then give it higher review because I don't know any better since it has the let's get a buzz on feel. The only reason I go there is when I have a date and she picks the restaruant, I have to suck it up and pretend it is great....
Actually what annoys me is white people doing a wai and they don't even understand the meaning of it and think they do....so friggin annoying
what is more annoying is people that eat rolls, only rolls and rave how great the sushi is.  Annoying it is.
author: Kenn P.

description:
An old unfinished review from a few months ago....
************************
Ozumo comes close to 5 stars for me.  Everything tasted very good, and I had the opportunity to try several new things.

We sat at the bar for a drink before taking our table.  My wife and I ordered from their cocktail menu - she got the Giddy Geisha and I went with the Jinsin.   I'm not a whiskey drinker, but anything with candy cap mushroom flavored simple syrup is going to get ordered by me.

Our assortment for dinner included the seaweed salad with sea grapes, uni (very yummy, but thought they might be fresher)...  {end of unfinished review}.
author: Greg H.

description: Loved this place. They take reservations, but since we arrived a bit late we were seated at the bar. There are SO MANY sakes to choose from.  My friend and I ordered the age dashi tofu, edamame, yamabuki, dohyo, and tons of sashimi including uni, salmon, yellowtail, eel.....They were all great and the sake as well. The atmosphere is nice and romantic for late night dinners. Definitely can dress up and enjoy a date at this place.
author: Sooshi K.

description:
Took my girlfriend to Ozumo for Valentines Day and, I've gotta say.. it was pretty tasty.

Started off with the Hanabi (Hamachi and Avocado w Jalapeno Ponzu) which was amazing in itself. But next we had the Shacho Roll which had Maine lobster with mango and cilantro. By far the most expensive roll I've ever had at around $23, but it was jaw-droppingly delicious! The Kana Croquettes (basically crab cakes) were good, and the Gyu Tataki was so juicy that I just wanted to let the meat sit in my mouth and enjoy! The sashimi was fresh and we enjoyed everything we got.

The main drawback to Ozumo would have to be the price. But then again it is ranked $$$ on Yelp... It's great for special occasions and definitely worth a try, but be prepared to leave with a much lighter wallet. I've had comparable sushi, sashimi, and beef for a lot less. Usually you can justify spending more for an outstanding ambiance, but I really didn't think there was anything special about it. Maybe the tables by the window where you can see the Bay Bridge are worth it.
author: Brad Y.

description: Loved this place. Great trendy but comfortable atmosphere. Menu was familiar sushi with creative twists. Sushi quality was very good.our service was outstanding. Good value, great meal.
author: Kim A.

description:
The sushi was alright, for two of us we spent $190. Don't get me wrong for amazing sushi I would have been happy with this purchase, but not the case. The sushi was alright, and I'll leave it at that. 4 pieces of thin sliced sashmi... $26.. YIKES. Red flag number one should have been how fishy it smelled walking in. 

The icing on the cake.....

I asked for a glass of sake, it came to the table and my partner asked where in japan it was from. The waitress as sweet as hell as she was didn't even want to say it.

Of course it was from Fukushima. The 3 of us gave the "oh shit" look and the waitress began to get nervous. 

Serving up radiation with my mercury fish as is. 

Then the meat is from Idaho.... gross. 

I WILL NOT BE RETURNING HERE!
author: Maria L.

description:
Overrated, underwhelming, pretentious.  

Service was a bit poor, from the moment we walked in.  The hostess did not look thrilled to see us.  We were a large group, dressed casually, late on a week day night.  You could tell she was hoping we did not have reservations so she could turn us away.  It took a while to be seated, and they argued with us at length about adding one more person to our reservation, even though there were empty chairs through the restaurant and there was room at our corner table.  Once everyone was finally seated, it took quite a while to get a server's attention to order drinks and food.  Our server was not attentive and was fairly brisk.   When serving our group, she had told us that a few of the dishes would take a little longer to prepare, and we agreed that she could start bringing out appetizers and a la carte dishes.  However, almost an hour went by and everyone had finished their orders but the people who'd ordered duck still had not gotten their food.  They had to eat after everyone was finished.  I did not feel we were advised well about the delays for this dish or else we would have asked to have our other orders put in later, or would have ordered something else.

The food was not exceptional by any means.  It was good, but not great, and for every dish I tried, I could think of another San Francisco restaurant where I could get the same dish, only a version that is better executed and less expensive.  I do have to say the sake flight was pretty good and reasonably priced.  Too bad all of the food items were disappointing.

I don't see any reason to go back here again.  This place is great if you want to show off to out of town friends, but that's not really my thing.   To me this is an example of the worst type of dining - places where the service level is dependent on how fine our appearance/dress is.
author: Heidi M.

description:
Great food! Great service! Great atmosphere! Delicious cocktails! 
Love the Sapporo ramen and soba at lunch. Just recently tried the Hiya yakko and it was the best homemade tofu since my trip to Japan in October!
author: Ang A.

description: Recommended by a friend. I called last minute and was able to get a reservation at the sushi bar. Loved it! Great wine and superb sushi!
author: Dawn F.

description:
I love Ozumo! The ambiance, service, view of the bay, service, food, atmosphere...everything was awesome. Parking however, is a bit hard to find....although they do have valet. My friend and I came on a Sunday night and it was pretty busy inside. I love the little bar area upon entrance, with some water fountains and nice japanese decor, and as you walk in, you see the long row of japanese wine and sake. Love! The bathrooms even have a recording playing that teaches you basic japanese words/phrases! very amusing indeed!

Food-wise, we ordered a baked salmon roll which was delicious, their hamachi sashimi appetizer which was amazing, and their signature cod fish. It was cooked so tenderly, so buttery and soft, and seasoned to perfection. In the end, we got the fruit chocolate fondue to end our awesome dinner. Expect to be paying quite a bit here, but I think it's worth it considering it's the entire experience that counts :)
author: Louisa L.

description:
Stopped in here late last night because it was next to our hotel. 

My wife had a roll with eel and avocado, one of the best I've had.  I had fresh oysters, our server new where they were from and said they were good today, I really enjoyed them.

After dinner she brought us some champagne for our honeymoon which was very thoughtful.  

We had a great view of the bay bridge and had fun watching the sushi chefs do their thing.  Great service and a fun evening.
author: marc r.

description:
Met my buddy for dinner here the other night. Even though there are many restaurants in SF, its hard to find a fine sushi restaurant. I think we ordered the Ozumo roll, Gindara, Yellowtail and spicey tuna cones. They were all great. I'll definitely be back for the Ozumo roll and Gindara. 

Parking is limited. If you can't find street partking, you can valet in front for $40 or you can valet at the restaurant next door for $10.
author: Romeo R.

description:
this is my way over due review for ozumo... i seriously was not a fan of ozumo years back because their service sucked... but thank goodness i gave them another shot a year and a half ago... told you this review is over due... but since then, i think i came here like 10 times... i did indicate that i'm a fan now! 

i am a big chirashi fan... because sometimes it's hard to decide what you want because you want everything! that is why the chirashi is the best decision... always get their daily selection of fresh fish and i dont even have to decide on which fish i want! 

the chirashi is under their bento box section for lunch.  it comes with edamame and daily veggie as a starter (currently i believe it's spinach with this yummy peanut sauce).  The actual dish comes in two boxes. One box is the sushi rice with tobiko sprinkle on top with veggies on the side and the second box is the yummy yummy daily selection of fish! It is SO good... all the sashimi are super fresh and the pieces are good size!  And one thing that i must say is: i love is that they give you TWO pieces of each fish vs one at other sushi places around the area.  only down fall is that they chirashi doesn't include amaebi or uni... but you can always ask them to add on so that's cool!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Oh sushi how i love you!

I always get excited when i know sushi is involved...

Ozumo has good fresh fish and nice drink menu and is in a prime spot.  But i do feel it is a bit overpriced for what you get.  I know it's San Francisco and you are paying partially for a beautiful ambiance.  But i hate...i repeat.....HATE...when i leave a meal still hungry.

We all know these kind of places but i just feel like i should let you Yelpers know what's up.
author: Reggie A.

description:
Food was okay. Nothing exceptional and overpriced for something so-so. 

Service was great however our waiter came around a wee bit too much to ask how we were doing and how the food was than we would have liked. 

The front area of the restaurant looked very trendy, very LA. They definitely had the FiDi crowd in mind as their target since that's who you'll find having HH here in the evening. But the back area was lit up and seemed just like any other Japanese restaurant with the sushi chefs in the middle of the bar area. If the windows were a bit bigger, we would have had a nice view of the water/bay bridge. 

I didn't think our reservation that we made was necessary. A group of guys walked in w/out a reservation and asked if they can sit at a table which they spotted on their own and they got seated immediately. We waited about a minute or two before getting taken to the back portion of the restaurant to our tables. Well, at least I got my 100 opentable points.
author: Esther A.

description:
Ozumo's was fantastic, and especially since it was rented out for a private event.  Sushi, sake, more sushi, more sake.    The atomophere was fun, the food was great, and the sake was excellent.

I would go back next time I'm in S.F.
author: Paul C.

description:
Ozumo gets my vote for the all-round best Japanese restaurant in all of San Francisco.  I've been three times now, and each time, the food, cocktails, ambiance, and service are all on point.  It's a chic and beautiful restaurant with chic and beautiful people, but I never found it to be pretentious. 

The vegetarian dish I chose last time was their grilled vegetables, which sounds boring, but was so amazingly prepared and well-presented, I was blown away.  

Seating with a view is the best seat in the house, but even if can't do the window seating, the dining experience is still well worth it.
author: Angella S.

description:
So I came back a few weeks ago to meet my guy and his business buddies here for a couple of drinks. The hostess was SOO nice to me, as I had this huge huge bag of stuff and took it off my hands for me.

We had a great table and the waitress paid very good attention to us, which is refreshing considering the service I had last time was so poor. I'd say stick the bar and sushi bar and avoid sitting down to eat at a table, at least when it's busy.
author: Alita M.

description:
I really enjoyed this sushi place. Good vibe.

All the rolls are pretty good. No complaints. Good quality.

Opt for small plates to share.
The Hakkaido scallop sashimi was too fishy.

Do get the Chocolate San Chu thing - mochi dessert (with red bean cake).
author: Mia N.

description:
Wow, went here for my Dad's birthday with a mixed group of sushi and fish lovers and some not so into fish and everyone left with a wonderful time! Compared to other sushi places, Ozumo offers a great deal of variety with delicious desserts, incredibly fresh sushi/nigiri and sashimi. Check out the pictures I took of the hamachi sashimi!!

The server helped us decide on a bottle for the night where they have anything ranging from $30 a bottle all the way to a thousand dollars for sake! We settled on some soju? (not spelling it correctly but that's how it sounds) and it was fantastic. 

Here's a quick recap! We got seated where we had a beautiful view of the bridge and our server was so patient we had a party of 7 and we were all ordering randomly extra of certain entres. Everything I tried was fantastic, the little pot roast thingie epic. Sushi amazing. They even have lobster in the sushi! A wonderful mix of contemporary with classic dishes like the grilled rice skewers and fuji apple phylo dessert with ice cream that gave Mitchelles a run for it's money.

I can't wait to try it out for lunch, the bar looked hopping and it didn't have crazy loud music like other sushi bars. I HIGHLY recommend this place, even if you aren't super big on fish you will definitely find something yummy at Ozumo!
author: Debra R.

description:
Had 3 rolls for lunch: the Bucho, the Kamiwake and a standard California roll.  I thought the fish was very good and fresh, and the combinations were creative.  

It is fairly expensive, but would be worth it for a nice dinner or business lunch.  You can probably guess that by the fact that the menu outside doesn't list any prices

Atmosphere is trendy and I'm sure has a great Happy Hour crowd.  The bar seemed pretty well stocked and they for sure had a large sake selection.  

Overall, I thought it was really good, but probably not for everyday eating, at least for us mortals.
author: Jared W.

description:
My boyfriend took me to Ozumo for this year's Valentine's Day dinner. We arrived about a half hour early because he wanted to avoid traffic. We were greeted at the front door by the hostess and were told we could either be seated or kill some time and have some drinks at the bar. So we sat at the bar and I ordered one of their signature cocktails while my boyfriend ordered a beer. To my surprise, the cocktail wasn't much of a cocktail, but rather a straight shot of alcohol. I forgot what the name of the drink was, but its sweetness was completely overpowered with a strong taste of alcohol. I didn't want to the drink to go to waste so I forced myself to gulp it down. (I should've ordered the moscato, since it's my favorite wine, just to play it safe!)

I kid you not, by the time we were seated at the dining area, my eyes were half open because I was so buzzed. I didn't expect to get buzzed before dinner, but that's what happened... and it didn't help that I didn't eat a snack before coming to dinner.

The menu had a selection of what seemed  to be appetizing meals, from a variety of fresh sushi all the way down to the entrees. We ordered some sushi, unagi and a California roll. I ordered the kobe beef with vegetables and my boyfriend ordered the bacon-wrapped scallops. The sushi was delicious and so fresh; it was unlike any other sushi I've had in the past. However, when our entrees arrived I was a bit disappointed because the portion of my meal was so small! The kobe beef was cut up in small pieces, even the root vegetables were bigger than the pieces of meat! Despite the small size, it was delicious and tasty. My boyfriend's meal, on the other hand, was so good! The scallops were so big! We looked at each other with an unsatisfied look... we kinda wanted to order more food since the food we ordered didn't suffice.

For dessert, we ordered a sweet potato bread pudding that came with banana ice cream. The banana ice cream stood out more than the bread pudding for me.

This place is a higher-end Japanese restaurant. The atmosphere is warm and cozy, the food is delightful, but the portions are too small! I guess I didn't expect the portions to be so small because I'm so used to eating at Japanese restaurants that serve huge portions of food. If you choose to come here, I advise you to eat beforehand... otherwise, if you want to spend a lot of money for food to satisfy your hunger then go right ahead! I would come back because the food is delicious, but maybe just for the sushi.
author: Anne Y.

description: Sushi was very good. Also the atmosphere was superb.
author: Brian S.

description:
I've always enjoyed my visits to Ozumo. Expensive but here are a few scenarios where Ozumo's hits the spot: a) need to impress a client, b) meet up with a friend to sip on fancy cocktails, and c) host a celebratory large group dinner.

My last experience was a pretty interesting one. Party of 6 that appreciates a good meal, regardless of cost. Perusing the menu, a few were attracted to the $125 omakase, others were eyeing the $75 sushi only omakase. Our waiter was a little off his game this evening and it took way longer than usual to order. When he was finally ready, he informed us that if one person does the full blown omakase, everyone does. Nuff said, bring it on! 15 minutes later, he returns to tell us the chef rejected our order because it was too late in the evening to complete all the courses. Bummmmmmer! The sushi only omakase was still an option so I went with that. I'd say there were about 12 total pieces of fish. Not a huge amount but everything was unbelievably fresh and flavorful. 

Other notable dishes of the evening:

- Uni risotto (must have - even if you don't like uni!)
- Black cod
- Washu Ribeye (!!!)
- Agadashi tofu
- Edamame (steamed to perfection)
author: Susan L.

description:
Upscale Japanese Restaurant. My wife and I have eaten here a few times.  Atmosphere and decor is great.  Sushi and Sashimi are awesome.  It's too bad, they no longer offer the Lobster Risotto.

expect a hefty bill at the end of the night. All those sushi's add up quickly.

Food  4.5/5
Service    4.5/5
Atmosphere  4.5/5
Overall   4.5/5
author: Ronnie G.

description:
AWESOOOMMMMME! Me and the GF went out for dinner as a Christmas gift to me, which was very nice indeedy!  I don't know where to start w/ the compliments... big factor is that it's been a few weeks since we ate there so I gotta bring it back from memory.  

So we arrive promptly for our reservation and we are walked over to our table, in the corner, which was nice and cozy :)  Then we are greeted by the manager (which was a surprise), then he informed us that we had the option of creating a tasting menu according to our tastes (which again was a surprise).  We had about 6 or 7 different dishes, each different from the one before, and each just as exquisite.  I've eaten at many Japanese joints, and this place definitely set itself apart.  

Our server, who is awesome at her job, came to our table and talked w/ us about our tasting menu.  She gathered our dislikes, which was basically the GF's dislikes, since I'll eat practically anything as long its dead and fresh!  :)

First came the very good edamame.  It came out warm (surprise!) and in two different plates w/ two different flavors.  The first flavor was plain, as usual, and the other dish had the bean pods marinated in garlic and soy sauce, damn I enjoyed suckin' on the skins more than eatin' the beans themselves.

Then came the next dish, which I believe was the "Hanabi", basically Hamachi and avocado slices in a sour soy sauce, topped w/ cherry tomatoes, bean sprouts, and something else... it was EX-CE-LL-ENT!  The GF does not like raw fish, but this time, it was a goodtogo!  It had a sweet and tangy flavor, as well as still retaining its Hamachi flavor.  The sauce was just right and did not drown out the fresh taste of the sashimi.

Then our server brought out a small plate w/ roasted chili peppers to cleanse our pallet.  Some of our peppers were spicy, which was fine by us! 

The next plate was... damn, cant remember!  But it was HELLA good!  I remember a dish that we did have.  It was slices of "Washu" beef atop a slice of egg plant and cucumber, then it was topped with a sweet teriyaki steak sauce... mmmmmm.... excellleeennnttt.  We were lovin' this dish let me tell you!  (guess I just did...) 

The other plate was that of a baked fish... think it was butterfish or salmon, either way.  We were wow'ed again!  Prior, I believe we had two separate dishes of their signature rolls.  Not sure what kinds, but they were very good, w/ fresh grade A ingredients.

Then it was topped off w/ an awesome dessert!   Think it was like a hibiscus ice cream on shortbread w/ a sweet sauce and fruits... BOMB!   :)

That was good food.  Had a blast! Cant wait to go again.  Now I must comment on our waiter/server.  She was very attentive, charming, and knowledgeable in Japanese food and sake.  She got the GF just right in the planning of our tasting menu.  She also recommended just the right bottle of sake!  That's how you get a tip peoples!  

We had a great time, even though we were going to go to 1300 Filmore because Ozumo informed us that they were not planning on opening after renovations on the day of our reservation... now they tell us, the day before.  Anyways, everything worked out in the end indeedy!  Nuff' said.
author: Jo R.

description:
This place has been reviewed to death, so I'll keep it short and sweet.

If you can ever save enough stomach room to eat dessert here at Ozumo, absolutely DO. I know, I know- after the uni risotto, their fabulous spider rolls, a serving of their fresh hamachi, perhaps throw in a plate of their scrumptiously moist and tender sea bass- there simply is little room left for even another sip of tea.

But, their desserts are impressive, indulgent, and savory. I usually am so full after a meal at Ozumo that I opt not to even LOOK at the dessert menu.

I'm not sure what possessed me to have a gander last week- maybe the weakening effect the holidays have on my abilities to make good meal choices. Whatever.

The Fuji Apple Phyllo was to die for. I am not kidding. Possibly one of the best desserts I have had all year. I swear. Order it.
author: Elaine T.

description: What a wonderful restaurant! I loved the robata, sushi and sake as well. I will make sure to stop by every time I go to San Francisco
author: Ric C.

description:
You're pretty much paying for the view. It's gorgeous and you couldn't have a more perfect view while eating your sushi. 

I ordered the Edamame (of course), Hanabi, Ozumo, Spicy Scallop and Dragon roll.  

I would like to try Ozumo in Oakland since we live in Oakland and they were recently featured on the Malou Review. Next time...

Overall, not bad at all.
author: Cindy W.

description: I want to live here. Enough said. But to keep you yelp "reveiwees" happy I will go into detail. The service went above and beyond expectation. Our waiter was not overbearing but was attentive. Ozumo was simply beautifully, modern with an architectural touch. The lighting was vibrant and young.  All of the sushi we had ordered was so delicious- especially the spider roll. I had a great time at Ozumo and plan to return, if not live there, haha.
author: C M.

description:
atmosphere is nice. bathroom has weird shit playing though haha. 
but
lunch at Ozumo SF didn't disappoint. 

starter: edamame and cucumber salad. excellent and fresh. 

appetizer: gyoza. good/solid. nothing rather special.

Nagasaki Chanpon (Japanese wheat flour noodles): this hot soup tasted like... if butter was a soup. it was very rich in flavor but did not have overly salty properties. ie i never reached for my water cup once during this bowl. but soup was a slap in the face with awesomeness. the broth is made by both pork and chicken. in the soup was braised pork, black tiger shrimp, manila clams, and cabbage. and the soup stayed the right level of warm throughout the meal. OMGEEEE

Dessert 1: never saw a dessert menu. I just asked the server to bring out recommended items. anyways. housemade pumpkin cheesecake over a sweet crispy layer some sort of almond cookie. and next to it was housemade brown rice ice cream. tasted like a really refined tea ice cream. YUM!

Dessert 2: Macaroons! super light and flaky. inside was green tea and a lemony paste. sooo good. with grapefruit and pomegranates to accompany.

so worth it :) please give their lunch a shot!!!
author: Albert V V.

description: Food here is awesome, we sat at the bar and started  with the hanabi ( fresh yellowtail and avocado  with a jalapeno ponzu). Yummy!!!! Then the bartender melissa recommended a few  fresh belly sashamis with a super cool japanese craft beer (it had a smiling dolphin on it ). Her recommendations were spot on . I would give 5 stars but the prices were a little high for my taste. . But I will definitely be back (for a special occasion)
author: Jes D.

description:
Still my favorite Japanese place of all time. 

 The best service ever and the sweetest sushi chefs and servers!
author: anita h.

description: Beautiful decor, extensive sake list, excellent service and delicious food!  Love the sake flights and the unique rolls.
author: dawn A.

description: It's more in the pricey side, but the sushi is good. They have my favorite dessert-- Chocolate fondue for only $12. That's why i come back every single month!
author: Emily M.

description: Food was wonderful and the presentation and atmosphere were outstanding. The sake list was incredible... It has something for everyone. The price was expensive, but if you are looking for a great dinner then you won't be disappointed.
author: Kc C.

description: Not bad, but nothing spectacular. I like the decor and the friendly service! The three stars is for the food.
author: Amanda T.

description:
Amazing food and service!

After seeing many reviews recommending the black cod I had to see for myself. Even with all of the glowing reviews I was still blown away with the dish. The fish just melts in your mouth.

We tried a number of different nigiri and all of the fish was incredibly fresh.

Ozumo has a large selection of sake and imported Japanese craft beers. Greg was able to recommend great pairings with our meals.
author: Bobby N.

description:
Certainly not the cheapest option for sushi, but absolutely well priced and great value for the delicious quality. The spicy tuna roll (Sekiwake) was my favorite, and everyone else at the table loved the Bucho (tasted great, but tempura shrimp isn't my idea of the best sushi roll out there).

Also, service was excellent, atmosphere wonderful, and specialty cocktails topped off the evening.
author: Lesley R.

description:
3 stars if you're paying for yourself
5 stars if you're paying with an expense account

Great selection of fresh fish, good sake options and the sushi chefs know what they're doing. Goes off on Thursday and Friday with the work crowd - ghost town on weekends now
author: Magic M.

description:
Amazing place, full of energy, we loved the food, I would recommend the traditional  Sushi than the fusion cuisine which was ok, but the sushi was exceptional!! A great range of (very expensive) sake!!! 
Really enjoyed our evening there, would love to visit again!
author: Antigoni I.

description:
Ozumo is a great place for a special occasion.  Their food is pricey but it delivers quality and flavor, so as long as you don't go there too often (or you can fling large sums of cash at fish any time you please), it should definitely be on the short list of ab-fab destinations.

We were in a mad dash at the last minute as we thought our reservations were at 8:30 but we didn't leave the house until 8, and they sat us with no complaint at 8:20.

Building on previous visits, we had planned to definitely get some sushi; the lobster; possibly the duck; and, other than that, open to suggestion.  The lobster is served on a bed of uni (sea urchin) risotto, which is sufficiently great to stand alone as its own dish, and yet, as it's served with lobster, it vaults it well into the stratosphere.

This time around we had a few special items -- the o-toro nigiri sushi (WOW!  This actually beat out EVERY OTHER DISH this visit, including the lobster), and some blue fin tuna sashimi (paired with regular maguro sashimi -- we actually liked the regular more, though they were both excellent).  A pot-roast-tender beef dish served atop potato; small beef slices on top of spinach and eggplant with a bit of ginger and cucumber slices beneath; and (another favorite of this outing), salmon teriyaki on skewers.  Sadly I can't remember the Japanese names of the dishes, but these descriptions should more than suffice, and you can't go wrong with anything on the menu in my opinion.

Dessert was standout as well, they brought a celebratory birthday custard-type thing, and we also had fruit milk chocolate fondue, and dark chocolate pudding in a sesame/poppy-seed basket.

If only I hadn't been driving, I could have gotten smashed on sake to wrap things up.
author: Walter K.

description: I agreed with one the reviews about the sashimi being over priced and fishy. I had 2 cocktails and my husband had 2 beers 1 appetizer and a sashimi plate and our bill were over $160.00, we don't mind paying for great sushi but the sashimi was very fishy.  For that price it's better be super fresh!
author: Cesar O.

description:
Sukiyaki hot sake soup! I Sake to you will you sake to me?!?!?!?! 

OK, so that's not the proper opening to a five star joint, but I couldn't help myself!

Located on the Embarcadero, on Steuart Street Restaurant Row, Ozumo's doors open into the hip trendy dimly lit bar featuring DJ's some of the best down tempo and contemporary DJ's. Just a few steps above lead to the main Robata dining room with large glass windows giving you perfect views of the waterfront and the breathtaking bay bridge. 

Between the main Robata dining room and the lounge, are two brilliant private dining room that are perfect for your corporate dinner when you want to impress your guests. The Japanese Style Kotatsu room and the Sake Room, a private dining room encased in glass with sake bottles that surround it. Both offer the perfect blend of Japanese and American dining experience. 

Ozumo has a reverence for old world Japanese cuisine and it shows. You'll find things here at Ozumo that you won't find at any other Japanese restaurant, like Sashimi Farm Raised Tuna. It's so delicate and rare, unlike anything you've had before. Did I tell you, that you can only get it here? 

My old favorite here was the steak and lobster Japanese style tartar (no longer on the menu), but my new favorite is the Iron Hot Pot Sukiyaki with Washu Rib Eye Thinly sliced, tofu, shitake mushrooms, enoki mushrooms, cabbage and noodles. This is served in a hot sukiyaki broth over an small open flame and serves two. This a conversation piece for your large group or your intimate party of two. This was insanely yummy. 

The staff is knowledgeable on the menu so don't be shy to ask them what their favorites are on the menu. They are well trained on the menu, or you can ask for Alvin the GM. He has been with Ozumo for many years now and understand the meaning of "hospitality". 

Ozumo is sexy. The menu is amazing and the food is a culinary masterpiece. Enjoy many years at Ozumo. I've been there since they opened years ago. I'm a loyal fan.  Upscale Japanese Fusion at it's best!
author: Sandy C.

description: I usually meet interesting people to talk to here. The drinks and sushi are great too. It's a fun place to go to after work and you can generally find a seat at the bar, even when it's getting crowded.
author: a f.

description: Very conflicted here.  I really do not like giving restaurants under 3 stars unless they have truly asked for it.  A 2 star overall rating  in our area seems to be the kiss of death for restaurants.  So instead of 2, I am giving 3 just for how nice the place is, place is very cool.  Unfortunately, their food offering is very un-cool, marginal, not bad.  They are just missing their mark for their pricing.  For the price the food should be outstanding and sadly it is far from it..
author: BGinLove B.

description:
Ozumo feels like a place that belongs on Sunset in Hollywood....I'm suprised this place hasnt been recommended to me more often!

Going in on a Friday without a reservation, we had to sit at the bar.  The full menu can be ordered from the bar, so not a bad way to go.  

For drinks I ordered the Sparkling Geisha ($11) - Lychee flavored sake in a passion fruit puree, topped w/ Chandon sparkling wine.  quite tasty.  

Sushi was very fresh and all the small plates added a great twist to traditional Japanese.  I ordered:

Amaebi ($20 for 5) - Not on the menu, but i love raw sweet shrimp and these were large and very very sweet
Yamabuki ($12) - Fresh uni and shitake risotto, unlike anything i've had before.  The slimy texture of uni is what usually turns people away, but if you mix it into the creamy risotto, it blends quite well and the flavor is fantastic!  This is a "small plate" but is definitely enough for dinner.
Futago ($15 for 5 pieces) -- Grilled washu beef w/ garlic spanich over a cube of grilled eggplant.  Beef is super tender, spinach is fresh, and the miso sesame sauce that tops each piece makes every bit perfection.

I'm sure this place gets overly crowded with yuppies at times and isn't the scene for families or if you want a quiet first date, but come with your coworkers or a large group and I promise it to be fun.  I'll definitely be back!!
author: Kendra W.

description:
Great atmosphere, large place.  More than likely needs reservations but we walked in at 11:30 right when they were open and was able get seated.

Sushi and rolls about average.  Good service.  Overpriced. but I was on an expensive account so it didn't matter too much.  

Lots of business people, even sitting at the main bar and sushi bar eating.  Lots of business people having drinks at lunch.  And we're not talking about a simple beer or glass of wine.  Martinis, sake, highballs.

Listen in the bathrooms to the Japanese lesson you're given, in place of playing nice, soothing music.
author: Debbie E.

description:
Those working here probably know what I'm talking about when I say that it's hard to find a place near the Embarcadero to grab a drink and relax on a late Friday afternoon. As much as I love you guys (and find myself needing your services from time-to-time *ahem*), if I get stuck in the middle of another law school social, I'm officially giving up on this area and heading back to the Mission to throw down some post-work PBRs with the local hipsters. 

Thank you, Ozumo, for saving me from this fate.

What we have at this little gem is good food/drink, great service, and a diverse and laid-back crowd. The fare here is pretty standard Japanese, but it's executed extremely well and with some nice surprises thrown in for good measure. Edamame smothered in a spicy garlic sauce? Yes, please.

Drinks are excellent as well. My recommendation is to go with the Bulldozer. I'm not sure of the exact composition of this masterpiece, but it's so good that I keep thinking it should come with one of those dainty umbrellas and I should be having one of my female friends order for me out of fear of public shaming. 

Fret not, however, as with a name as unexpectedly manly as 'Bulldozer,' I found myself throwing down drinks as fast as my awesome servers Felix and Rebecca could bring them.

I think I may have found a new spot to get bulldozed. Now where are those lawyers again?
author: Leo K.

description:
Good sushi, but expensive!  This is one of those places you that you look at the bill and say "what the hell did we order?!"  It adds up fast.  

I eat here when I am not paying, but there are definitely better priced equally good sushi restaurants in SF.  But the ambiance here is better than many.  They have this special spicy tuna roll... maybe it was called dynamite or tsunami or firecracker?  Anyway that was yummy... but not on the menu so ask the server.
author: Ryan S.

description:
came here while on vacation with the hub with our two friends who live in the area. the ambience/decor was beautiful and view of the bay bridge was amazing. 

we ordered a bunch of dishes to share: vegetable/shrimp tempuras; soy garlic edamame; agadashi tofu; miso soups; black cod; filet mignon with bacon wrapped haricot verts; and two sushi rolls. my personal favorites were the edamame and filet mignon. now, i know... edamame? no, these arent just regular edamames! think of hot steaming/cripsy edamame with the flavor of soy garlic bon chon chicken. yes.. its possible!!! the filet was soo moist and flavorful and resting on delicious japanese mushrooms.. oozing with rich flavor. overall excellent meal with unexpected flavors and preparation. our server was soo sweet and attentive all night as well. i cant wait to go back one day!
author: lesley l.

description: I'm not sure why this place isn't better.  The sushi is largely pretty good (with the exception of a few things I've had there that are not that fresh) but the prices are over-the-top ridiculous.  I love the awesome sushi restaurants in the city and am happy to pay for it, e.g. Eno, etc.  But this place doesn't come close and is double the price of most sushi places.  If the quality was there that would be fine, but it isn't.  Also, there are pesky little nats flying around the sushi bar when I've sat there, NOT something you want to see at a sushi bar.  Three stars is too high but there is no option for 2.5.
author: Kay R.

description: I'm a sashimi aficionado and can't find sashimi any fresher or of higher quality than Ozumo. They are constantly coming up with new creative plates every week. The sake selection is outstanding as well. This place is Nihon Shoku at it's best.
author: Katherine M.

description:
I really can't complain about anything, except that it is a overpriced.   But what can you expect from downtown sf?

I have nothing bad to say about the food.  The sashimi is really fresh.  The hamachi, which is my favorite, melts in your moth.  So does the sake (salmon).

They have an incredible selection of Sake.  Given that I'm no connoisseur of sake, I can hardly tell the difference between different flavors.  Our waiter was very helpful in helping us make our selection.  

We got a ton of rolls and small plates.  Everything was excellent.  The only thing that was tasted a little funny was the toro with asparagus roll, but that's because I don't like asparagus very much.  The fish was all very fresh, and you could taste the difference between the quality of the fish here and your average sushi restaraunt.  

The dessert was good as well. I recommend the chocolate fondue, as they give you an assortment of fruits, and mochi balls to dip with.  Very tasty and an excellent ending to your meal.

With about 6 or 7 plates of food and 2 desserts, and a bottle of sake between 4 people, that added up to about $80 bucks per, which isn't too bad, but is on the pricey end.  

I'd definitely come back!
author: mike j.

description: Amazing service, consistently awesome food, and they never flinch when offering to make something vegetarian.  In fact, that go out of their way to make sure you're happy. Ozumo has become one of our favorite regular local digs.
author: Sherry G.

description: Great ambiance but food is really just alright for the price. Two scallops - though delicious - for $28 is crazy. California roll mediocre - served kind of warm, flavor understated.
author: Kurt D.

description: My friend & I came here for dinner one year on my birthday & it was amazing! I really think this is the place bc of all the pictures. I don't remember the name of the place but I can't forget how it looks. So I went on their wed site to make sure and it is the place. I'm about 99.9% this is it but I didn't see fondue on the menu. When we went we had their Japanese hot pot soup (veggies & meat), then we had their fruit fondue. Both was so good its out of this world! I want to go back but I'm not sure if they still have the fruit fondue. Its not on the menu now but maybe they did before or maybe it was specially made that day I'm really not sure. So does anyone know what I'm talking about? Lol help!!! ;(
author: Michele T.

description: The food was delicious. The house specialty Black Cod was tasty and cooked just right. Although the dishes may be too small for the big eater, the food was well presented and tasty. Kitchen is exhibition style, so you can watch the staff prepare your meal. Be prepared for Japanese language lessons in the bathroom.
author: Les W.

description: This is great sushi and Japanese in the financial district.  You'll find that all the hotels in the area, the concierges will recommend this place for Japanese food.  One of the reasons is that the hotel upstairs in same building is mostly occupied by Japanese visitors and this is evident in the dining room and bar.   You get good authentic Japanese here. The food is consistent and they have a nice variety of lunch choices.  You get what you pay for here and it doesn't disappoint.
author: Jen W.

description: Way overpriced.  Under staffed during lunch, it took forever to get service.  No water or hot towels for our table.  Sushi was just okay.  Do NOT order tempura and ramen.  Very loud...
author: TopCat W.

description:
As simple as it may sound I love a place that greats me with a smile when I walk up to the host, add to that a 5 step greeting from every member of the team as I walk to my table, and that level of hospitality inspires me to put this place on my list of favorites.  The hospitality is 5 stars at every level as I enjoyed my dinner from the sushi bar. The food quilt was a strong 4 as well as the well designed atmosphere and view of the bridge. I hope to see more people visit them allowing this to be the new standard for other restaurants to measure excellence to.
-Nick
author: Nick S.

description:
Went here for Valentine's Day, thanks honey!!! The ambiance was nice, very modern. We had to sit at the sushi bar, no table :-(. However, my b/f and I enjoyed dinner. Boy was this place crowded, we went on Friday night (early VDay). Make sure to purchase gift certificates at Costco, saves you $20. The certificates has a face value of $100.

Sashimi - it was really fresh, had aji, hamachi, some ebi special, other fishes.

Sekiwake roll - it's spicy tuna roll with salmon and hamachi topped with peanut sauce. The roll itself was okay, but went well with the sauce. It needs to be a little bit more spicier.

Tempura Yasi - it's assorted vegetables with tempura batter. omg it was so delicious, maybe because it came out really hot and fresh.  That's how it should be.

Hanabi - slices of hamachi topped with some kind of ponzu sauce, a must!!! The pieces were sliced very thin, but went well with the sauce.

Hiyashi Soba - this was my favorite!!! It's soba noodles with prawns, cucumber, etc. This dish was so refreshing, I can eat more.... Another must!!!
author: Nhung T.

description:
Went for 5:30 on a Friday night with spousal unit. Immediately seated, plenty of tables available. Bar was pretty crowded.

The Garlic Edamame was recommended by a friend and it was excellent. The waiter, of course, pushed Saki. I don't care for it and the waiter replied that in his experience people who say they don't like Saki have never had good Saki. I asked for a suggestion from their extensive menu and it turned out he was right - I just don't like bad Saki. 

The waiter was very good. Friendly and knowledgable on ingredients, preparation, and presentation.

We had the Tuna Tartar appetizer that came in a bowl and was supposed to be eaten with potato chips. It was very good but didn't scoop well. I had to use one chip to push it onto another chip. No biggie, but if this was a first date, it would not have scored points :-)

We had an assortment of sushi. It was good. I've had better and I've certainly had worse. No complaints, just not what I would describe as outstanding.

For dessert, I had the cheesecake. This was to die for. Highly recommended. Outstanding!!
author: Bob K.

description: Food was fantastic as always. Service was attentive as expected. The only downside was they were out of or did not serve a number of items we ordered.  Better communication to the wait staff on the status of entrées would solve their one large flaw.
author: jess d.

description:
I actually felt really bad for Ozumo last night when our party waltzed through the door demanding we be seated immediately. We were drunk, famished and celebrating a friend's new job. Did I mention it was packed?

My first thought was wow, look at all those fancy cars parked out front and then I realized that Ozumo itself was a powerhouse of professionals, executives and socialites. It would appear that this is the "it" place to go for sushi: great bar, hot people, swanky atmosphere and great views(depending on where you sit). I just couldn't enjoy myself, though. I was slouching so badly from hunger that my boobs might as well have been dragging against the floor.

When we sat down, which was actually relatively quickly, we literally just ordered the first 5 things we saw on the menu. One by one the meals rolled out and one by one they were devoured within seconds. I'm not even really sure I can report out on the food considering I didn't stop to enjoy it at all. I do remember the shrimp tempura being amazing. Along with sea bass wrapped in bacon. God, YUM.

I want to come back here when I'm not a crazy person. I think I might really enjoy myself.
author: Julia N.

description:
Fantastic food and service for drinks and snacks on a beautiful October evening.

Weather permitted us to sit at a little table on the sidewalk, which let us experience the energy of the bar area (the walls were slid open) without the noise, and the people watching was great.

Best of all was the super-solicitous attention of the two waitresses. This is unusual because we were outside of their normal sight range so they had to make an effort to check on us, and also because we were two older women together, not radiating particular coolness or the promise of big show off tipping. But both waitresses made a friendly and textbook perfect effort to keep our glasses and plates filled, provided active advice on drinks and dishes, etc.

Finally, the drinks and food were superb. The citrus martini and the cucumber martini were just exotic enough to be interesting without being cloying. The grilled octopus salad was lightly dressed so as to be tangy without any oiliness or sliminess. The edamame come in 3 choices of preparation! (cold, hot salted, sweet) and were perfect.

The tab was $100 for drinks and appetizers for two, but it was truly a "night out" experience worth paying for.
author: laura r.

description:
This review is for Noontime Noodles. I had their Sapporo ramen, which was fine. 2.5 or maybe 3 stars for flavor and broth. The pork was great and the real crab was a nice touch but their broth was really lacking. Ramen is all about the broth for me. 

The serving is on the small side, especially for $12. If your appetite is bigger than mine was today (did you work out today? did you skip breakfast? are you a man?) then it will not be enough food for you. The edamame was overcooked.

They lose a star for service. My check was wrong - charging me $15 for a bowl of ramen. If I was a less forward person I probably would not have said anything, but as it was I had to find my server and ask her about it. She apologized, obviously, but charging $15 for a bowl of ramen is both highway robbery AND ridiculous when every single table has a sign advertising the $10.95 lunch specials.
author: Merci V.

description:
I went to Ozumo for lunch last week with a colleague.  I had a bento box of mixed sushi.  

I was a bit surprised as the the fish did not taste as fresh as I remembered when I came here for dinner.  It was very mediocre.  Maybe they save the freshest fish and the nicer pieces for their dinner patrons?  Our lunch bill came to about $20 per person before tip (we each just had a bento box).  It was pricey for lunch and I walked out slightly hungry.

I'm not sure if I will come back again for lunch, but I might be willing to give their dinner another try.
author: Paul K.

description: Made reservations for my family and I. Had to wait about 15 minutes next to the bar(first thing we see entering) I felt a bit uncomfortable waiting with the children(teens) while standing there(my only complaint). Once we finally got seated toward the dining area located closer to the back where the sushi bar is, we felt much more comfortable. The food was great, the presentation was amazing and the servers were incredibly awesome and helpful. I would definitely return again. The overall atmosphere was great. Thank you Ozumo staff for making it an enjoyable dining experience. Blessings!
author: Marie H.

description:
Been here many times and I must say that I do come back more so for the atmosphere...fun place!  I'm not saying that the food isn't good or great, but it is overpriced for the atmosphere / location.  Yeh...so why don't i give them this review a 4 star for their atmosphere, right?  

Their food?  It's good...some great.  Their fish is usually fresh...I only eat sashimi so when their toro, hamachi belly, ankimo, or salmon belly is fresh-fresh...it's great!  Though I can get that at a lot of differ places around the city as well.  I've tried their fusion plates which they are known for...their seared kobe beef is great!  Everything else I had tried...I don't remember...so yeh...

I will return to this place as it is a cool, fun place to go to.  I will continue to drink here and continue to order their overpriced food where I can get at other sushi places around the city...just because.
author: Patrick C.

description:
An upscale contemporary Japanese restaurant where the amazing decor is matched by its wonderful staff and food.

A few co-workers decided to grab happy hour after work. Ozumo's was the closest place.  No real expectations.

The Staff: 
The staff was super helpful, friendly, and courteous.  I believe the two who helped us were Rebecca and Felix.  They were knowledgeable in the food, drinks, and provided very helpful suggestions when we were puzzled.  

The Drinks: 
Wide-ranging menu and can accommodate you if you're looking for beer, liquor, or any kind of cocktail. 

The Food:
Hanabi (Hamachi and Avocado w Jalapeno Ponzu) - extremely tasty
Edamame w/ roasted garlic - this was a surprise.  Edamame is usually prepped by steaming them and served with a dash of salt.  However, these were glazed w/ roasted garlic. The pairing worked quite well.
Various sushi rolls - I didn't order the rolls, but I ate them. DELICIOUS

The Decor: 
The front bar is dimly lit and has a nice subtle ambiance to it, while the back is a brightly lit bustling restaurant complete with a sushi bar.  Works really well regardless if you're with friends or entertaining guest.  We sat at the bar-lounge area, but the restaurant is worth a second visit for dinner.

Overall:
The premium you pay for the service and quality of the staff/food/experience is worth it.
author: Tuan M.

description:
I am having a passionate affair with the miso black cod. Om nom nom nom nom. I love you. 

Everything else that I've tried here is completely amazing too. I was here months ago and don't remember the specific dishes but oh my freaking god, amazing. And I never even considered myself a big fan of Japanese food, especially not sushi... but I loved EVERYTHING at Ozumo. 

One thing to keep in mind - YES, the portions are small compared to most Americans' idea of a hearty meal - but you need to take the time to savor each wonderful mouthful. Don't rush the pleasure. Sip your sake, eat slowly and thoughtfully, have some good conversation along the way, and I promise you'll leave satisfied.
author: Corrie H.

description: Good sushi + good service = good times at Ozumo.  The decor and theme can feel a bit over the top, but it's done well.  The sushi was excellent and the sake was good, too.
author: Tom F.

description: On a recent visit to San Francisco we wanted to find a nicer sushi spot.  The hotel suggested Ozumo, I yelped it (of course) and we decided to check it out.  It was a Thursday and there was only one reservation left, so I would suggest calling ahead!  The bar area was pretty cool...dark, modern, great service, great selection.  We sat at the sushi bar in the restaurant, which had a totally different feel from the bar...very fast paced and fun!  Not cheap sushi at all, but worth every penny.  We aren't hardcore so we did an assortment of rolls and edamame, which all came out very fast.  And it was amazing...interesting creations and all different.  4 star is because our server was very snooty and barely paid attention to us once we placed our food order (never got a second beer).
author: Rebecca P.

description:
This place has a great atmosphere with an awesome view. Hard to make last minute reservations on a Fri or Sat night so make sure you book in advance. 

In terms of food.. yellowtail is great but forget ordering toro here. I've ordered toro three times in hopes that it will get better but it is always mediocre quality. I have yet to find toro in SF that beats the quality you find in LA. 
Gindara from the Robata grill is really good. 
Also.. if you like tempura.. their tempura dish is very unique.
author: Seda B.

description:
This is my dad's favorite restaurant. I can tell why as it is so damn good.

The place is a bit pricey and portions are small but every bit is worth it. Every thing is fresh and tasty. I don't think there's one thing I tried that I didn't like.

I really recommend their spicy scallop roll. Mmm I'm drooling just thinking about it
author: Victoria Y.

description: I always go to ozumo. They have the best customer service and the waitstaff always greet you, almost every single one of them. It's probably one of the biggest sushi restaurants in sf. They have a nice bar/lounge area and a huge dining area in the back. I would usually sit and order in the bar if I have work later on or don't have that much time to dine. The food is delish and their fish is always fresh. I have always been a happy camper at ozumo. For drinks I usually stick with the whole goose and soda but I tried their geisha drink and sake flight. Which wasn't bad at all. I definitely recommend this place to people that enjoy sushi or a new experience.
author: Lisa Z.

description: I really cannot comment on the food because 45 minutes after ordering I still had not been served my first piece of Sushi. I have been to Sushi Bars all over the world in the last fifty years and I have never been ignored for so long. The Sushi may be so good most people are willing to wait forever. I guess I will never know since I spoke to the manager and explained my frustration before I left. Negative Five Stars in my opinion. Dining should be a pleasant experience. This most definitely was not!!!!!!!!!!
author: John P.

description:
I don't think I've ever been to a Japanese restaurant that's THIS overpriced. Now, if you're going to be an overpriced sushi restaurant, then your fish better be DAMN FRESH. So fresh that it's living in Bel-Air with Uncle Phil. Ozumo's sushi had the taste and freshness of your typical, run-of-the-mill, discount sushi restaurant. You cannot charge freakin $9 for six small pieces of bay scallop sushi when the bay scallops aren't fresh and you try to cover it up with loads of spicy mayo! You can't charge $8 for three pieces of sweet corn tempura when the tempura isn't crispy (more dry and chewy) and there's NO flavor!

This place had a pretty large sake menu and the service was pretty good. It also has a pretty awesome interior -- walls just lined with hundreds of sake bottles. The back part of the restaurant has a pretty terrific view of the Bay Bridge, as well.

Unfortunately, all that goodness just can't make up for how mediocre the food is -- and even worse, how unbelievably high the prices are. Seriously Ozumo, either improve the food quality or lower your prices. Seriously.
author: Roy C.

description:
So I don't like Japanese food. I'm vegetarian, and don't find vegetarian sushi to be a filling meal. To me, it's like being told that I'm having spring rolls for my dinner ... and paying through my nose for it. 

However ... I really enjoyed Ozumo's. This place is surprisingly huge ... you'll keep walking and walking to get to the back ... with a fantastic view of the Bay Bridge. Definitely a great, happening spot, and a cute date spot too. The sake was great -- a whole bookful of choices, and the waitress chose a really good one for us. The vegetarian sushi was good (there's only one vegetarian option) and a couple of veggie side dishes, but it was filling enough. I'm not a big fan of Asian styled desserts either, but the dessert was enjoyable. For a type of cuisine that I'm not naturally fond of, this place was pretty darn good. I'd go back.
author: Antara B.

description:
I've been to Ozumo twice, the first time we waited about an hour and the food and service was excellent (no reservations + casually dressed).

Second time (dressed in formal gear + reservations + specific request for a quiet spot away from the noise [I am hearing impaired].  Waited nearly 1.5 hours despite arriving 15 minutes early. Got seated in the noisiest spot in the back of the restaurant. My girlfriend asked for a fork about 3-4 times and it was never brought. Two of the orders were wrong (we did not cancel out of respect for the establishment nor were we offered the option).

Don't get me wrong, the food was great, I eat sushi about twice a week  and my bill usually ranges from $100-$200, but I expected better from Ozumo-especially considering the fact we had reservations and we were properly dressed for this restaurant and the service was still below par (from three different people - that's the kicker).
author: Jey P.

description: Omakase, sake pairing, service, atmosphere, sake mama awesome! 11/2011
author: Penny L.

description:
I've had both good and bad experiences as Ozumo and that it why i gave it 3 stars

Good: When I sit in the dining room, my experience is usually great- the staff is friendly and accommodating. They are always willing to substitute rolls and are open to custom rolls. However it can get a little pricey, really fast ( ~ $30 -40/person)

Bad:  Last time I sat at the bar/walk-in section. The staff (waitress) is not as friendly and much less accommodating - unwilling to customize rolls, because they are too 'lazy' to walk over to the chef and ask about customizing rolls. 

The decor is nice, and i am usually pleased with the quality.
author: Harvinder K.

description:
Went here last night for dinner and drinks with a date.  It was my third time visiting, his first.  As usual, wasn't disappointed with the food, drinks and service.

One major complaint: not a lot of options for vegetarians.  Yes, it's a sushi bar with lots of fish and such, but there really are no main course meals for vegetarians at all.  I made do with edamame, seaweed salad, tempura and the one flavour of vegetable sushi they have.  It would be nice to have a main course dish instead of sides and appetizers though!

I'm taking away one star for the service.  It's not terrible, but I found it a bit slow and strange.  Our dishes came out very staggered, my companion getting his before me, while I continued to munch on the appetizers that we had.  His sushi came out, mine took another 10 minutes to appear.  I ordered a second cocktail, it took at least 15 minutes to arrive (I did get a waiter coming over to tell me there'd been an unexpected accident with it and they were remaking it... I kept picturing my drink in a bad car wreck).  

The price wasn't too horrible: $120 for the two of us, which included three drinks and a *lot* of food that we didn't even finish eating.  We spent more the week before at a different restaurant and didn't get even half the food we got here.

The ambiance and decor really is amazing too.  I still love the walls of saki bottles!
author: Cassandra J.

description: This place is super pricey. People seem to stick with the cheap stuff, even then your bill will be impressive!  And it wasn't just us, I looked around and many other groups did the same thing..  tons of orders of spicy tuna rolls n rock n rolls..  The quality of the fish is good but not impressive. You can get the same quality and even better at many other places.  I do recommend this place for groups n tourists with cash to throw.   Be prepare for a $upri$e.  All I can say after a 600 dollar bill with 6 friends, I came home and made myself a tuna sandwich to fill me up.    If u can expense this place, I do suggest u take advantage of it:).
author: Demanding T.

description:
What a great high end sushi experience!  We particularly loved the signature roll- the Ozumo.  I mean, it was really really good.

Everyone was really welcoming, from the front door staff to the manager to the server and back servers.  The decor was romantic and beautiful.  Mike (our server) was able to recommend excellent food options as well as a bottle of sake.  Instead of steering us toward one of the more expensive bottles, he helped us choose one that would be great for a first time.  Still, the sake was $98.00.  He made me feel comfortable ordering things I knew nothing about.  It was a really great experience.  

All that being said, dinner for 2 was $213 and we weren't that hungry. 
I'm sure we'll go back, but we'll probably skip the sake or maybe try a flight ($20) with a less expensive bottle of wine.
author: Leah L.

description: By far one of the best sushi experiences I have had on either side of the Pacific Ocean. Very very expensive but soooooo worth it. The sashimi was fabulously fresh and this spinach peanut thing was plate licking good. Not to mention the giant bowl of chocolate fondue I wanted to dive into and spend a few hours in! A great place to take your sushi connoisseurs! They won't be dissapointed.
author: Drea L.

description:
My short and sweet review:
Went to Ozumo on a Saturday night, at 7:30. The sushi was presented well, tasted fresh and didn't do much to distinguish itself from other high-end sushi fare (I'd recommend the Bucho roll). 

Service was not the best, as our waiter busied himself with many other things besides, well, waiting. 

Location (near the Ferry building) means you pay $10 for valet, so add that into your cost if you're driving. 

THE SCOOP: Two people, three rolls with dessert and one drink = $130. The sushi here is good, but certainly not budget-friendly and probably best for lunch.
author: Tom A.

description: Had a great experience at Ozumo last night!  Mel took excellent care of us.  House sake and tuna appetizer were a perfect start.  Sushi and tempura were good also.  Finally the chocolate fondu totally yummy, I love it with the mochi!  Will definitely be back.
author: Emily G.

description: I think this is one of the best sushi reastaurants in SF. Yummy and fresh fish and a fun environment with great service. Prices are a little steep, but still always think its worth it.
author: Jackie G.

description: The ambience is not bad.  Decor is nice but the food is mediocre and expensive.  The sake is also expensive here.
author: Byron L.

description: I was there again in the new year eve. The tofu tasted different from the last time I had it. It was still good, but not as good as the the first time, made me "wow" for it.
author: Herman K.

description:
I placed an order through their website (Seamless). I went to pick it up, but the order was not ready within 30 minutes of my pick up time. The staff hadn't started making the food yet and claimed to have lost my order. And then they double charged me for this order. I called for a refund and they said that I would need to wait a few days for them to double check the paperwork.

Not very happy with the service and would not recommend.
author: Matt C.

description: Ozumo is by far my favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. Besides delicious sushi and gorgeous decor it has one of the BEST bartenders in the world. Ladies and Gentelmen, let me introduce you to Marcos. His charming personality and superb mixology skills are the main reason why my friends and I have become addicted to Ozumo. If you are not sure which cocktail to order, worry no more! Marcos is there to mix something extraordinary special for you and you will be coming back for more :)
author: Boriana G.

description: For me this was one of the best meals we had on our visit to San Francisco. Service was excellent, the food was fresh and amazing, and the interior was trendy and comfortable with a great view of the Bay Bridge (even from our seats at the sushi bar). My boyfriend is not big on sushi, but they had good bento box options for him. We both enjoyed the miso soup (a lot) and he even liked my shrimp tempura and crab roll.
author: Kristan H.

description:
Executive Summary:  As a happy hour location Ozumo was a major disappointment.  Limited selection & predictable offerings. You can do much better, for way less near the embarcadero (palomino, Chaya, cosmo, or even Mexico DF). 

It offends me that so many people like this place.  

The HH offering was $5 rolls (you can only choose from 3- California, dynamite roll, vegetarian[$5 for an ounce of cucumbers cut up in a roll of seaweed and rice-- really?!]) is actually MORE expensive than the really good stuff at Wayo.  Also we ordered some tempura vegetables and shrimp.  I do mean singular on the shrimp, as you get one(1).  Service was HORRIBLE, but presentation was good.

I had to walk past the kitchen on my way to the restroom.  On my way the cook staff all yell something at you like hello( in Japanese?).  I have no idea what they were saying, and the whole thing seems a bit contrived as they were hombres who don't appear to have heritage that extends from the Land of the Rising Sun.   Maybe if I spent more time in the restroom (where they play learn to speak Japanese tapes) I would know what they were talking about.  Will try to never go back.
author: Brian F.

description: Kamoizumi Komékomé Sake & Fatty Tuna  - WOW! Need to go back way over due!
author: Paul M.

description:
Food is too expensive for this quality.  I guess you should think you are paying this much for the location...  The location and table with the view of Bay Bridge is very nice.  But it's really over charged.
Before I had this experience at Ozumo, I had told everyone that wait persons in San Francisco is very knowledgeable and friendly, but I won't be able to say that anymore.
author: Sachiko M.

description: The sushi was great, but my favorite was the spicy martini drink.  I would also recommend ordering the Futago and the Hotate, simply delicious!
author: Mary G.

description:
Place is nice. Happy hour is from 5pm till close. Supper cool. Had the cigar rolls which is some type of seafood egg roll which was great. Had two orders of that.

Busy and nice crowd! Definitely will come back.
author: LinLin L.

description: This place serves delicious cuisines with an upscale yet relaxing atmosphere. The restaurant looks small from the outside but it's actually quite sizable. There's a bar, dinning tables along the way, and dinning rooms. In terms of dishes, I highly recommend the uni with quail egg nigiri, hanabi with avocado, and the pork chop. I'm never really a fan of red meat, but the pork chop deserves a compliment. The staffs are all very welcoming and friendly. Great place for a birthday gathering or a date!
author: Nawei C.

description:
Ok.. I have been meaning to write a review about this place with a busy schedule. This is my first time using yelp. I like supporting local restaurants/ business's so the experience must be REALLY bad for me to bother.

I've been to this place twice. First time was few months back, a co worker suggested the place. It was a good experience the first time. The ambience was nice and we were there for HH. Food is good(3-4 stars), portions are small for the price which is expected at a fine dining restaurant and this place is far from fine dining. 

So about 3 weeks ago I re visited Ozumo and brought a few of my friends with me (whom one is one of the biggest food critics in LA) with the hopes of impressing her/them with a great choice of a classy restaurant w/ great food, ambience and phenomenal service.. I wanted for once to take her to a great restaurant for she is a tough one to please as you can imagine.

So long story short ..first thing the waiter greets us at the table(I won't mention his name to save him from embarrassment) with hickies on his neck. Restaurant etiquette 101- hickies are unprofessional, classless and completely inappropriate in any profession especially in a restaurant settting. I was appalled that a restaurant like Ozumo(especially for the prices they charge) would allow their employees to serve food and be at a dinner table with hickies! Tacky and disgusting! I was embarrassed that I misjudged this place and brought my guests to this place. Aside from the hickies, he wasn't that great at being attentive and was chatting it up with his fellow co workers. He was knowledgeable about the food that's the ONLY thing I was impressed by but not impressed enough to pay $400+. Luckily for you, I didnt have a local food critic with me. 

To management: please read the basic etiquette manual and live up to your name and your prices! TGIF and Chilis wouldn't allow this!

Overall food gets 3-4 stars, subtract 3 for crappy service and you get 1 or less stars unfortunately. I will never spend another dollar here.
author: Shannon S.

description:
Good sushi, but not as good as Akiko's. 

Prices are FAR too high for what you get in terms of the sushi and fish options. Feels like they are playing a joke on you. 

Great huge space with a fun ambiance. Some good lunch bento options and I liked the agedashi tofu quite a bit.

In sum --- good place to have lunch if you are here for a business meeting, else skip.
author: Ravi A.

description:
Went here after work on one of the rare warmish SF days, and was able to snag one of the high tables in the lounge looking out onto Steuart St.  They had the windows open, so it was a great spot. I was in the mood for a warm drink, so I ordered a pot of tea our server recommended, which turned out to be great!

My friend arrived and ordered a saketini and we started poring over the menu. Pretty much everything sounded good, so we had to make some tough decisions. Much discussion resulted in an order of "Dohyo" - which was a tartare of big eye tuna with avocado creame and spicy tofu. It was served in a cunning little molded shape, which we promptly demolished with the endive leaves and gyoza chips provided for dipping. 

Then the "Gindara" came, which was luscious black cod marinated in saikyo miso.  Finished off with a plum wine spritzer cocktail, which was light and perfect.
