Very tasty, my only complaint would be that at $32, entree pricing is on par with places like Nobu, while the food, while good for a SF neighborhood spot, is definitely not.  Overall a good night though, with great service.
author: Jaimie M.

description:
Just moved in town, really enjoy the city so far.
so after checked Ozumo, decide to write my first review.
overroll good place, nice people and good food, only one complain is that table next us was really loud, can not chat with my friend... but will return
author: David W.

description: Best sushi ever.  I go there all the time for happy hour, lunch or dinner,  but had the pleasure of the private room this time.  The service was a+ amazing.   The sashimi  choice and the the fish was unbelievable.   There were so many textures, types of fish and choices to satisfy any craving.  recommend for a casual dinner or client meeting.
author: Billy B.

description:
A *perfect* sushi experience. Flawless. 

If you have money to burn, this is the best fireplace in the city.
author: Tim W.

description: This place deserves a * for its ambience which boasts sophisticated elegance with friendly service. They have plenty of choice in Sake so if you are a huge Sake lover you might rate this place higher. I just think the place is outrageously expensive but I'm also not a huge Sushi or Sashimi fan and certainly not at those price points. The best Sushi I've had was prepared at home courtesy of a Japanese family.
author: Monish S.

description:
I've been to this fancy sushi restaurant a bunch of times and the food is always fresh and the view is spectacular.  Good looking people and friendly service are always found here.

The bar is usually packed and is a great place to see and be seen.  Bartenders are always attractive women and very pleasant.

What's good?

Ozumo Roll
Toro (market price was $20 per two pieces the day we went)
Hamachi
Kobe beef

Costco has $100 gift cards for $80 which knocks 20% off your bill.  Ozumo also participates in the Healthy San Francisco program so we had to pay an extra 4% to cover the employees' healthcare!  I am not a fan of paying this.

Always a great experience with great people watching and great food.  Pricey, but worth it for special occasions.
author: Curtis C.

description:
I hold true to everything in my previous review, except one thing: 

Some of the food items are kinda' bland. Though the tempura items look delicious, they kinda have no taste. And on another recent trip, I had the sushi bento lunch and it lacked in flavor also. 

Still this remains one of my favorite places for happy hour and for people watching, but I may not be ordering anymore food for a bit.
author: Denise B.

description:
i came here with low expectations considering the mixed reviews on yelp.  we were able to get seated right away even with no reservations for a party of two.  i loved the ambiance and even sitting at the sushi bar was quite cozy with comfy chairs and a nice view of the bay.

food: 

tuna tataki salad: small portion but good flavors with the pickled ginger.

tuna tartare: a great appetizer to start with served with gyoza chips

uni risotto: a very unique twist on a risotto and i absolutely loved the uni on top which started to melt

agedashi tofu: i always love ordering this dish, although $11 was hard to justify for 4 pieces of tofu, i would have to say they were quite delicious and different with their panko crust

salmon hamachi roll with salmon inside: our server warned us against getting another roll since it was sent back 3 times from other tables so we opted for this roll which was quite delicious.

salmon and albacore nigiri: the fish was fresh i liked how the salmon was served with a lemon

Yes, parking is hard to find around the area and it cost $10 for valet, but it's definitely worth a try if you're in the area and looking for good japanese cuisine.
author: Carli F.

description:
If you want to see and be seen while you eat, this is the place to do it.  

The food is fine.  It's not the freshest sushi, but it's not bad for a price (12-15 a roll) that's reasonable for the area.  The robata grill is hit or miss, but when it's not overcooked, it's tasty.

The service is close to the edge of what I will accept without walking out of a place or leaving a couple of pennies (my mother actually did that once at a restaurant) as a tip.  The last time I was there I almost wrote our waitress a note reminding her she was in a service industry.  

Next time I'm in the neighborhood seeking Asian, I'll probably go to Chaya.  They're always much more pleasant.  

I waffled between a two and a three on Ozumo, but after a few days reflection, I'm giving it a two.  Ozumo, please train your staff to be nicer to your patrons.
author: Tullia F.

description:
This was my 2nd time eating at Ozumo's. First time was lunch, enjoyed it very much so I suggested it to my friends as a dinner place. 

We first started off with happy hour at the bar - little too loud, but it's a nice place to hang out after work, nicely decorated. 

The wine list - @ least wine by the glass, is a little disappointing. I know it's a Japanese place, so I should have sake, but I really wanted a decent glass of wine. $10 for BV Cab that costs about the same for 2 bottles at Costco?? Could make some better selections and charge the same money. 

We had 5;30 reservations for dinner, and we were promptly seated. Everyone is supernice there, no complaints about that. 

No espresso, but really good teas. 

The only other thing that bothers me is the main dining room, the chairs seem kinda dirty and oldish looking. Am I missing something, is that the look they are going for?
author: Denise V.

description:
Meh... is the exact word that comes to mind when I think about my dining experience at Ozumo. At first glance this place my seem like a hot spot to grab sushi, but there are a few things to note before you venture down town to be let down.

Normally, I like to have a bottle of sake with dinner, but at Ozumo there is no such thing as a bottle of sake under $90.  This is quite absurd to me considering I've ventured to many-a-sushi spots and paid substantially less for a bottle of sake for two. I will say that the gomae was fantastic for a starter! I was happy with the sushi presentation, but once I actually picked up my chopsticks to eat a roll--my taste buds had a different reaction.  I wasn't blown away by any of the rolls we had. My great company and I love blue fin tuna and we have had it a few places around town; however, I was not happy with the quality at Ozumo at all! 

Lastly, the interior space of Ozumo is sort of negatively random.  The front entrance is super trendy, sleek and dark--then as you walk through the rest of the restaurant to the main dining area you feel as though you are in an entirely different establishment.  To me, it was reminiscent of cafeteria?!  The table and chairs were completely wrong for the space and were comber sum.  On a nicer note, their plates and glasses were pretty. That's all I got.  Ozumo is waaay overpriced and overrated.
author: Nichole P.

description:
The Food:
Very fresh and served with a flourish.  Don't expect monster portions but expect everything you get to be extraordinarily well done.  

The Ambiance:
The bar has a very cool feel and is a great place for meeting up after work.  It's dark wood and candlelight without feeling stuffy or old.  The sushi bar in the back is a great way to get seated quickly if you don't have a reservation.

The Bottom Line:
Great downtown spot for sushi and it probably won't kill your wallet.
author: Dan H.

description: We must have walked in right before everybody got there christmas bonus checks. Nobody was paying attention to the customers. We asked for help 5 times and never got good service. The sushi presentation was ok but for the price we paid, I would have expected a better quality fish and a better quality dish. I must say that since there are so many choices for fresh fish sushi bars in the financial district, this place has got to shape up. Won't be coming back anytime soon.
author: Rod L.

description:
This review is all thanks to Jessica for creating a concierge sake-sushi tasting party.  Thank you Jessica!!  

Ozumo is a swanky, trendy, wonderfully delicious japanese restaurant.  They have the largest sushi bar in the bay area and a cool sophisticated dining room w/ a trendy lounge bar area.  They always have great dj's last visit Kwai Le Cheif was spinning. :) I was impressed to see they book such talent... 
The food is killer: some of my favorites japenese dishes include: Hanabi, sliced yellowtail sashimi and avocado w/ warm jalepeno ginger sauce. The Futago: grilled Washu beef, sauteed ginger spinach & jalepeno eggplant w/ miso sesame sauce...not to mention their sushi is incredible!!
I will be back soon, sheik, sophisticated, beautiful restauarant with top notch service and to die for fish!~

OH and they have an awesome Lichi/champagne cocktail...I think it was called the Geisha Girl and I am in LOVE with it!  yum.
author: Michele K.

description:
2.5 stars bumped to 3 (for good service!)

You don't just pay for the fresh ingredients, you pay for the ambiance too -- which is so overpriced!

That being said, we knew what we were getting ourselves into as we walked to Ozumo. A close 5 minute walk for us in a thriving SoMa neighborhood, there was valet available but hardly any other parking.

We didn't have reservations which sucked dookie because I have an OpenTable account but we just didn't want to be ghetto and make reservations 5 minutes before leaving - oh what the hell, we'll do that next time if we need to :)

Hostesses were very sweet - as she took us to our table in the back, I complimented her pretty blue suede boots and she told me where to find them and this and that. Super friendly!

We initially wanted to sit at the bar in the front (so dark and trendy oooh) but we instead, had a table in the back near the sushi bar, where it's quieter. Our server was pretty nice too and read off the specials for that night.

THEY HAVE KOBE STEAK TARTARE AS ONE OF THEIR SPECIALS. She didn't even need to say anything else, I was sold!!

Steak Tartare with Gyoza Chips and Quail Egg: Holy moly, what. a. rip. The portion was uber small and it had a small DAB of dijon mustard to the side - I had to ask for more dijon. I take it back, it wasn't that good. It was literally just a small pile of ground beef with no seasoning and a quail egg on top. Worst steak tartare ever!

Ozeki Roll: Really tasty, I liked it! Then again, I love cream cheese :)

Spicy Tuna Roll: It had a peanut sauce on the side and it was a very interesting combo. Good roll too!

Seafood Hot Pot: Dinky ass pot with a sweeter broth than what I usually like. Good array of seafood that came with a bowl of rice (no noodles). Not worth it - avoid.

Sparkling Geisha: Delicious!!
+ 2 hot sake
= about $150 after taxes/tip for 2 people.

Of course, portions here were super small so if you plan on having a full blown meal here, be prepared to spend $$$! I liked Ozumo, it seemed like an awesome place to just chill and have a few drinks and nibble on some appetizers, but definitely not a place to have a good, hearty dinner. 

I'd come back strictly for a few drinks and maybe an appetizer or 2:)
author: T L.

description: Been here a couple of times with co-workers (10 of us) and with last minute shuffling the hostess found us a seat at the window that overlooked the spectacular bay bridge view.  I definitely scored with this one.  I ordered appetizers for the table and then everyone ordered their own entrees.  For starters, I went with several orders of the Hanabi (hamachi and avocado) along with spicy tuna tatare.  Easily 1/3 of the table got the signature dish Gindara which is their excellent MISO  black cod.  Service was outstanding for such a large
author: John O.

description: The atmosphere is nice and so are the people... but the doormen looks like pimps and the waitresses well... you know where I'm going with this... I'd definitely come back if I was with 2 or 3 friends but this is DEFINITELY not very accommodating for any group over 10 people... there just isn't any seatings for big groups... you'd most likely have to split into two groups at different ends of the bar... on the plus side... the apps came rather fast...
author: Nathan D.

description: I love coming here I like the tempura everything seams fresh also the sushi is good and ask for hot sake ;) it makes the meal more wonderful xD I really don't like the miso soup but the rest of the family did :p
author: Doris F.

description:
THE FRESHEST UNI NIGIRI in SF bay!!!
Tried most of their sushi and they have the best toro and uni!!!! The toro and Uni just melt in my mouth and it does feel like heaven!!!!
Tried their sea bass dish and wagu & kobe beef, they are all tasty and great!!!
Lovely wagu beef (medium) served with potato salads.. that is my favourite dish!!! The tempura prawn is one of the best too, served with butter fried prawn plus the fryed decoration!!! MUST TRY!!

My favourite jap restaurant in the bay area!! You get what you paid for guys!!!:D
author: Ana F.

description: Sashimi was great!  Sake was awesome! Service was top noche! Couldn't ask for more!!!!
author: Aimee R.

description:
The company I worked for in 2006 held the company holiday party here. Well, it turned out to be an awesome choice.

The restaurant is has a fabulous location. It's a good area and cabs are plentiful if you happen to have a little too much sake. 

The interior of the restaurants is gorgeous. In my drunken haze, I remember a lot of browns and the bathroom was very clean.

As for the food, the sushi was stellar. It was so good that it sparked up more interest in sushi for me. Now I am a huge fan. The chefs here made me a believer.

I need to come back. 

Soon.
author: Archie G.

description: Why bother to write a comment if you don't bother to respond to my email? Which, I might add, was sent solely because you requested that I fill you in on the issue I had at your establishment.
author: Jacqueline A.

description: Went there for lunch back in August, great place and I am sure it is even better for dinner. I ordered a few rolls that were all excellent, the fish was fresh and in abundance. The restaurant is very hip, the Sake bottles in display made me want to order some but I did not want to get drunk in the middle of the day! When I am back in SF and I am craving some sushi...I know where to go! It is a little pricey especially when you get a bottle of San Pellegrino and they charge you $7....for water!
author: Marco A.

description: I love this place! It is my favorite boogee sushi place in the city.
author: Kevin K.

description: My husband and I had a great experience here.  Our server was very knowledgable of all the sake's on the menu and attentive but not to in your face.  Our food was amazing. Overall I can't say enough.  It was great!
author: Angela C.

description: There are so many options for sushi in San Fran and this turned lot to be a great choice for a group dinner. Cool atmosphere with a great view of the Bay Bridge. We loved the small-plates menu and the opportunity to share and sample a bunch if different things. The tuna tartare, the filet, and the prawn tempura were particularly good. Extensive sale selection and an ample wine list. This isn't the place to go if you are looking for traditional sushi but its strength is an avant garde menu in a trendy setting.
author: Nayiri B.

description:
Used to come here after happy hour near by. 
This time, after a really long week, decides to go Shanghai 1930 for dinner and drinks, my favorite Jazz spot in the city. BUT, they are closed on Sunday! Ugh! 
Although here was the second choice of that day, but it doesn't change my review starts for it. Very welcoming service, nice seating at the table at the back behind the bar area. As well as the bar, but less noisy. Ordered bunch roll and sashimi, and litchi martini. (Of course not only finished one glass...) BTW, they mad very well done Litchi Martini. Yummy!
The whole meal made the Sunday's rain and shitty mood all go away. Nice! I had a big smile at the moment walking through their wooden heavy front door.
author: Flora F.

description: Great place for an after-work happy hour drink and light food. Trendy decor, high quality sashimi that's elegantly plated, and an extensive wine list.  This is more of a trendy, upscale restaurant than your local sushi bar.  Price can be a little steep (but that may be to the three bottles of wine plus the sake we had for our table of four) but was not disappointed with my experience here.
author: Kent W.

description: Took the now ladyfriend here for our second dinner date on a Friday night and was pleasantly impressed with the bar entrance / hostess greeting / service walking to the dining area / saki tasting / robota grill. Sushi was unbelievably well crafted and fresh. Must try the Ozumo's roll upon arriving if its your 1st time. The bottle of marshmallow / peach saki we decided on was different but not too sweet and had smooth pleasant taste of which I haven't tasted before. Will definitely be back to check out the robata grill next time around.
author: Easy E.

description: The food was good but even the web side says they are open till 11pm when we hot there on Saturday night the hostess told us they are not going to serve dinner!!! We asked for the manager and after going back an forth he told us they will serve us dinner if we order right away !!!! The bar tender was rushing us to the order before we had time to Oder a drink. Not a good experience at such beautiful city!! They were not attentive. I will not go back.
author: Ramesh L.

description: Good food and decor, but service was a bit flaky and they were out of two of the items we ordered. I expected a bit more for the price.
author: John B.

description: It's hit or miss. First place I liked sushi after so many failed attempts.
author: Hatifa E.

description: The Place is totally OVERPRICED!  There are so many other sushi spots to go to where you are paying not even half on what this place will charge, and the food is just as good or even better.  SAVE YOUR MONEY!!!!!!!!!!! DO NOT COME HERE AND WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: David F.

description: Fantastic!  Can't remember what we ate (asked the server to just bring an appropriate number of his favorite dishes for the table) but it was all good.  Kind of spendy though.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday February 20, 2009 @ 7:30pm
Company:  Sara & Justin & Michael
Crowd:  FiDi Professionals in Groups- Men in Hugo Boss Suits Sans Tie & Ladies in Chloe & Trendy Couples 20-40 Somethings- Guys in Striped Shirts & Girls in Hudson Jeans w/ Jimmy Choos
Vibe:  Energetic
Music:  Techno & House
Decor:  Sleek & Contemporary.  Enter into A Hoppin' Bar Scene w/ Bench Seating.  Bright Orange  Lounge Seating in Tightly-Packed Sofas & Cushioned Benches w/ Tables for Deux & Quatre Where We Opted to Dine on Small Plates.  Few Steps Ascend to The Zen &  Airy Dining Room.  Impressive Sushi Bar & Light Wooden Tables for Quatre.  
Service:  Friendly & Efficient
Imbibe:  Sparkling & Geisha Martinis & Saketinis
Devour:  We Shared Small Plates-1.   Tuna Tartare w/ Chips.  2. Hamachi w/ Jalapeno Ponzu.  3.  Beef in Miso.  4.  Oysters on Half-Shell.  5.  Tuna Sashimi w/ Quail Egg.  6.  Uni w/ Brown Rice Risotto.  7.  Octopus Salad.  8.  Chocolate Fondue w/ Mochi Ice Cream & Fruit
Total:  $183.96
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
We ordered  Gyozas, and Hanabi- Hamachi and avocado with ponzu.

I had the Mifune Bento- Tuna Yellowtail Salmon and Shrimp Nigiri with a California roll and spicy tuna roll

And for dessert: Fondue with fruit,Green tea ice cream roll. 

Everything was delicious! The bento is a lot bigger than I thought it would be. We had a wonderful view of the bay bridge which was a really revitalizing break from the florescentness of my cubicle all day. I love how they manage to work in fruity freshness into everything. Even my lemonade tasted "fresh." even though it didnt taste squeezed--did they spike it? no complaints here!

Ambience is pretty nice with good service to match. The hosts in the front kind of seem cold at first but its prolly cuz they are wearing stuffy business suits, they are actually very polite and professional, however im not sure if i like awk. business greetings--I get enough of that in office culture!

This place can also cater to a lot of crowds, big and small, business or casual. They have a ton of seating that give off different moods. A really nice place, can get pretty pricey though.

Oh and the desserts are hugge (esp. the fondue) so I would definitely share unless your selfish or fat.
author: Amy S.

description:
I know, I know fish is expensive and the location is half the price, but I just can't get over how pricey this place is. I just can't. 

Funny story though, I tell the waitress I'll have the mackerel (which is the special of the day) and I'll have it as unagi. She goes to say something and coughs a little. She says, "I'm not sick, I just get very excited about mackerel." Hilarious.
author: Corey V.

description: I am not sure if everything is worth it here. The sushi is fresh but nothing special. I would only come here for the lounge environment. Drink some sake and beer and just hang out, you can for sure find a better sushi place than this in town.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I lost two limbs while dining here. 

We sat in the bright dining room (in contrast to the dark and lively lounge/bar area) with a view of the Embarcadero and the Bay Bridge, which made the perfect backdrop for my friend's birthday dinner. We may have over done it with the food, but everything was really good, and the bottle of sake gave us a reason to break between dishes. 

DON'T come here if you're not willing to fork up an arm and a leg.
DO get the Shacho roll (lobster &tuna= O), grilled filet, and Hamachi in ponzu sauce. Just do it!
author: Deanna T.

description: I wouldn't come here expecting a cheep meal at all. In fact I'd come expecting to drop at least $120 for a meal for two. That said my first fresh memory was taking, who would be my current girlfriend here and the experience was so great that we stayed a little bit past closing that night. The pork jowl is amazing and the Ozumo roll was great in it's own right. They have great chefs and the quality of food would definitely explain the prices. We had sixty dollar hot sake which was recommended by the staff and was as good as the staff advertised. I definitely would want to go there again when my wallet allows for it which should be soon. Their front bar isn't that bad either. The bartender poured his drinks strong and definitely didn't water down the drinks he served.
author: Danny G.

description:
A nice sushi restaurant with good quality sushi. There is a lot of seating so the restaurant is not small but you still might have to wait if you do not have reservations. The decor and ambiance were nice and what you would expect for a restaurant in the financial district.

On the expensive side for sushi outside of happy hour. There isn't a dish that really called to me to have to come back here as opposed to other sushi places I have been to.
author: Beth K.

description: Some of the best sushi I've ever had.  Lots of great sake options (get a flight), very friendly service, and awesome decor.  Have a delicious meal, then take a walk on the Embarcadero--what a great location.
author: Alex O.

description:
Not much to add to the other 800 reviews of this place, but I do have to say that the staff was friendly and willing to ask about cooking styles to determine if something was vegetarian. The waitress was honest about the fact that they use the same fryer for the veggie tempura as they do for the shrimp tempura. The curry was excellent and 100% vegetarian. Stay away from the noodles though since they use a seafood broth. 

Sushi lovers at the table were delighted by the fish of the day sampler and the hubby was very full and smiling after his bento box.
author: Pamela R.

description:
For the price I paid for dinner, I would have expected all dishes to be great quality. 

The sashimi and rolls were great tasting, but the experience was dampened when I ate a dish with tuna, a quail egg, and crushed yam that was really just over-priced sashimi with a tasteless, white paste that had the consistency of spit.

You're really paying for the location, which is filled with restaurants with inflated prices due to its proximity to the Embarcadero and touristy Pier 1.

Eric
author: Eric W.

description:
Swanky Japanese dining up in here.  You're going to pay a pretty penny to dine here but you get great ambiance, DJ, yummy drinks and decent food.  

Gindara - This was definitely one of my favorites.  The black cod was super flakey and moist.  Tastes like BUTTER.
Hotate - I love scallops and this dish did not disappoint.  Scallops were fat, plump and super delicious.
Edamame - is awesome if you like garlic.  If your on a date stay far far away.
Suzuki Kusshi - Mmmmm anything wrapped in bacon is A+++ for my palette.

Sashimi and Sushi - Meh, it was good but very pricey.  I could have gone to my local sushi joint and got the same thing for half the price.

My advice: Stick to the small plates and dishes from the Robata Grill.
author: Michelle N.

description:
*dun dun dun ddduuunnnn*

100th REVIEW! 
(*crowd roars and cheers*)

So for my 100th review I decided to not be treated out in celebration but to treat out a coworker for their special day. I have never been here except for a random happy hour here and there. The happy hour here is really fun - DJ, drinks, food - what else do you need?!? 

Anyways we had really early lunch reservations because when we arrived the restaurant was pretty much empty. We were seated promptly in the very back of the restaurant with a great view of the water. We ordered:

*Diet Coke
*Hot Tea
*Gyoza
*Hanabi
*Rock n' Roll
*Tonkatsu Bento
*Gindara Bento (special of the day)

It was tons of food for two people but we managed to eat it ALL! I really enjoyed the Ginadara and would definitely come back - it was buttery tasting and cooked perfectly. The tonkatsu was just meh and I didn't like how I took a bite and the meat would come apart from the fried goodness. The tonkatsu came with a mustard type sauce instead of the normal plum sauce so that was an interesting flavor. Overall the meal was delicious. That lunch was about $80+ . Pretty expensive for just lunch for two people but I think for a splurge it was great.

When we finished lunch (about 1.5 hours later) the restaurant was really busy and even had people dining in the private sake rooms. Those rooms look so amazing! I want to dine in there next!
author: Julie F.

description:
Um...it's fine...not great. Expensive, but good...but yummy sushi isn't exactly impossible to find in SF.
The drinks are total novelties and pretty good - mango syrup honeydew rosemary thyme martinis (well, maybe not exactly) . I can imagine its a good place to go to try to pick up on rich banker types...but I'll admit that I didn't exactly give it my best shot.
author: Kristen Y.

description:
We got some specials of the day: katsuo from Hawaii (skipjack tuna), shime-aji, and saba (last 2 flown in from Japan)

The aji was really fresh and had a clean taste and melty texture. So good, as was the saba. I got the 5 pieces of katsuo sashimi to share and it was okay-good, but not spectacular. A little seared on the outside, drizzled with ponzu sauce. There was even a hidden sixth piece under it all. I knew I'd never order katsuo at Ozumo again when I realized it cost $30. Not worth it, even served in the beautiful abalone shell.

Curry Rice had good flavor and tender veggies, but I'd rather go to Muracci's.
Pork Gyoza - $6 for 5 and they weren't crispy on the bottom. : (  The pork tasty a bit smoky which was a nice surprise, and it comes with chili oil and soy sauce.

As always, an expensive menu that can be hit or miss. We were able to get a table for 2 on Wednesday at noon walking in, but were tucked away behind the sushi bar. Our waitress was really friendly and asked whether we wanted everything at the same time and if we were sharing--touches that make dining so much easier.

Still weird getting greeted in Japanese by all (including non-Asian) staff. Kinda like walking into Safeway where anyone working says hello, lest you're the secret shopper ready to snitch.
author: Amy N.

description:
I love Ozumo.

I come at least a couple times a month for lunch and happy hour.

For an appetizer, the garlic/soy sauce edamame is delicious.  It is a bit garlicky, but not overwhelmed with garlic. I always brush my teeth after eating this, but it's so worth it!

For lunch, my favorite dish is the Kaisen-Don.  It is a divine mix of sea bass, prawns, and scallops in a yummy soy sauce mixture over cabbage, bean sprouts and rice.  The seafood is incredibly fresh and perfectly cooked and seasoned.  This dish never disappoints.

For happy hour, the makimono sushi platter is a really good deal -- 18 rolls (California, spicy tuna, veggie, or unagi) for $13.  The kara-age (Japanese style fried chicken) is also very good.  (I also love the dish of chilled spinach with peanut sauce.)

On to the beverages... for an unleaded option, the daily fruit spritzer is always good; for a leaded option, the Giddy Geisha is a pleasantly (but not overwhelmingly) sweet lychee martini.
author: Lynn F.

description: It makes me sad to have to write a bad review about this place.  We usually come here for dinner and the service and food are great, even when they are busy.  We came here for lunch today and the service was absolutely awful.  The waitress took 10 minutes to even acknowledge our presence.  We ordered edamame prior to ordering lunch, 10 minutes later our edamame went to the table next to us, that table arrived after we did btw.  Our waitress was no where to be found for a good 15 minutes. When out waitress finally came to take out lunch order she asked if we had any questions, I asked "where is our edamame?", she had a confused look on her face and walked away without taking our order.  She returned 5 minutes later and said there was a "mix up" in the kitchen.  She finally took our order, it took 30 minutes to arrive, we asked for the check as soon as we got our food since we didn't know when we would see our waitress  again.  Food was ok.  Our waitress would pass our table multiple times and not even look our way, we tried to get her attention but it was like she was in another world.  Sorry to say we left her the tip she deserved, $2 on a $108 dollar lunch tab.   It should not take over an hour from the time you sit down to the time you get you food.  Get your act together ozumo, your service used to be good.
author: Daisy L.

description: Seriously...no pickup orders after 6pm but hey order room service and it will be 45 minutes to an hour - FOR ONE PERSON! What the heck?
author: J. G.

description:
Holy crud is this plae amazing. I was a little intimidated at first because, yes, it's pricey and fancy schmancy. I didn't want to pay an arm and a leg for a california roll. Fortunately I was pleasantly surprised and, dare I say it, this place went well beyond my expectations. 

We enjoyed a really great bottle of unfiltered chilled sake to start. The razor clam appetizer was ok, not great to be honest but it did have a little kick which I liked. The first roll out was one with lobster, tuna, mango and cilantro topped with caviar. WOW. Just AMAZING! The flavors were terrific together and something unexpectedly light yet intense. No rice on this roll, but some sort of flat bread or crepe like thing. We also enjoyed the filet mignon - I was worried about this because...well, there were no utensils except chop sticks. Fear not, the filet is the most tender piece you'll ever eat. It's served with some grilled green beans wrapped in bacon and a drizzle of pesto sauce which I'd like to take home in a 5 gallon bucket. 

Dessert was the chocolate fondue. At this point I was full enough but one taste of that chocolate would have made me consider getting another bucket to take that home too. We paired it with a port and it was just fantastic. 

Overall one of the best meals I've ever had in my life.
author: Ariel G.

description: Ozumo never let's me down. We came here on a rainy Tuesday nite and I was impressed by how busy they were...for a weekday! If I'm with a small group, I always prefer to sit in the lounge area. Not sure what it is, but those booths make for an intimate setting. We started with toro...just melts in your mouth then moved on to pork belly and filet mignonette for the finale. Overall, great service and even better food. I feel like the chefs there know how to pair every ingredient perfectly.
author: Milli A.

description:
-very trendy and upscale settings
-a little over-priced fusion sushi
-very good service
author: Candy T.

description: I love Ozumo! They have sofa seats, which makes it so comfortable and will just wanna stay longer and order more dishes! The view in their main dining room is very pretty. Too bad I was not sitting there and just saw it when I was walking to the bathroom. Their sushi might not be too special, but their sashimi is fresh and sweet. I think their cooked dishes are better. The duck breast is good. I heard they will change their menu from time to time, so I will definitely go again after a few months!
author: Foodie A.

description:
I love this place and am never disappointed. I may be poorer each time I leave but always satisfied. The sushi is great - the garlic soy edamame is craeveable! The sakes are good - just don't let thm sell you on the high priced ones (they can really add up quickly). Everything is tasty.

The bar vibe is cool and the restaurant is nice as you can actually have conversations. I never feel like we are so close to others that we are forced into their dining experience. 

Whenever I get asked for a recommendation - this place is always the first one ot of my mouth.
author: Elisa V.

description: I went to Ozumo a couple weeks ago, and WOW, the food is AMAZING! A little pricy, but great ambiance and it's right on the water. My favorite was the blackened cod. The best way to order at Ozumo is to just sample..so, a few appetizers, a couple main dishes, some sushi and of course dessert if you have room. I had the chocolate fondue. It was quite a production! The service was great as well. I'm giving it 4 stars because it was a bit pricy. Otherwise, I would recommend going to Ozumo to anyone and everyone if you haven't been! I will be back soon. Make sure to make reservations! It gets busy.
author: Heather E.

description:
I put Ozumo in the same category as Blowfish to Die For, Mas Sake and Sushi Groove. Overpriced and overrated. 

Just the other day, somebody suggested to grab a dinner at this great sushi place nearby. I kept saying in my head, "please don't let him say Ozumo, please, please," and sure enough, it was. When I don't know the person that well, I just can't tell him in his face that  the place he thinks highly sucks so bad that I'd rather be hit by a bus than robbed of my hard earned money. So, I had to make an excuse, and then passive aggressively bash the restaurant on Yelp.
author: Yuko K.

description:
If you're looking for popular and trendy, this is the place. However, if you're looking for good and fresh sushi, keep moving.  

I came here with a friend, who is a definite sushi fanatic, and we were both very disappointed.  We both enjoy good FRESH sashimi and this is not the place for it.
author: Deborah H.

description:
I have been here several times for business lunches.  The surround-sound "Irashaimase" as you walk in the door and are led to your table is somewhat irritating...but I won't quibble with trivialities.

The food is a bit pricey for the quality, and while it is good, I never leave here truly satisfied.  The garlic edamame is probably the best thing on the menu.

The service here is mostly arrogant, and often incompetent.  I frequently have to ask whether or not a particular item I ordered is coming, because the server did not bother to remember that I ordered it.  I have been mischarged, and then treated rudely when I called  attention to it.  The absolute worst is when I received a credit card belonging to someone else and my credit card was returned to another customer.

Overall summary: not worth the hassle.
author: Em S.

description: Delicious, stylish, impeccable. It's a terrific choice for a date or for just hanging out around the bar enjoying their sake flights.
author: colleen w.

description: 0zumo...what a great find. Ozumo has the best sushi and is such a beautiful restaurant.
author: Charlene T.

description: When i am in San Francisco, i am going to visit Ozumo. the Sake selection is formidable except the service is not the best and it is very expensive in my opinion. The sushi is very fresh and is lavishly prepared and served. i enjoy ozumo a lot and i would highly recommend it if you get an opportunity to try it out!
author: Elias K.

description:
Ozumo occupies a pretty specific niche in my life.  There is GREAT, much cheaper, sushi in this city -- Sushi Zone, for instance.  But sometimes I want good sushi in a nice, upscale setting -- e.g., for an anniversary, or taking a parent out.  On those occasions I come to Ozumo, and am always happy.  I could eat my body weight in the salmon belly and uni sushi, and the chocolate cake & green tea ice-cream dessert is AMAZING.

Moreover, my firm had a work event here recently which I helped organise, and it was a great success.  The staff were extremely nice and helpful, and the guests were very happy with the food and atmosphere.  I recommend it for those purposes as well.
author: Sarah B.

description: Great decor and energy! Super friendly and helpful staff. Food was yummy! We ordered the albacore and yellowtail sashimi - both were super fresh! We also ordered the sea bass with forbidden rice and it was delicious! Even their veggies were yummy! We had the eggplant and the sweet potato. Will definitely go back.
author: Jenny H.

description: Personally the best sushi I've had in sf! Incredible cocktails too! I've been here numerous times never to be disappointed...great service, friendly bartenders, and consistency make me happy to return!,
author: Chamisa H.

description:
My last visit there left a really bad taste in my mouth. mind you this is a place we go to often enough.  Second time in 2 weeks there.  Two of us placed a last minute dinner reservation but then a friend was nearby. We asked the waiter if it was ok. He said yes but his manager might not be. So we tell the friend 'swing by!'.  After he arrives, we get interrupted 2 additional times to be "kindly reminded" that the 3rd person was a courtesy and not generally allowed.  

I totally understand if a restaurant is bustling but there were seats nearby available and Japanese places do not pride themselves on being spacious.  Ozumo is not branded as a place where it's supposed to be romantic.  Why would the waiter and the "manager" be so rude to customers?  Especially when we ordered a sufficient amount of food?! Do they understand anything about service and the hospitality the real Japanese display?! Japan and other authentic Japanese places have servers that actually understand what they're saying rather than mumbling japanese to appear like a real Japanese place.  It's over-priced and we went for convenience but seriously forget this place if you're using your money.  It was pretentious and rude.  In the end they didn't even offer the usual dessert menu nor a cup of water for our friend.  Seriously?! Do they even know he's a Yelper Elite with over 1000 reviews?! Even if he wasn't, never ever treat customers like that. If you accept guest and paying customers, treat us like guests.  Not askin for the red carpet but just a little respect.  Eating is a thing people who like people enjoy doing! don't go into any business where you don't understand such basics.

Eat at Zushi Puzzle or kiss or at the Embarcadero or Ferry Building instead.  When customers pay a premium, space and time spent there should not an issue. ever.
author: Emm C.

description:
very pretentious experience, not hardly worth it for the prices they charge. tried to set up dinner for a large group and like many of these new eateries they want to tell you want you can and cant do and what to order.  Went to Delancey St farther down on Embarcadero and they were very accomodating. 
Went back to Ozumo as a foursome to check it out and while the decor is very inviting the atmosphere still felt pretentious and didn't feel Japanese.  I have to bet that the owners aren't Japanese. Food was OK, portions small but for the price, there are many better options on the area and for Japanese cuisine.
author: R S.

description:
Came here to grab a few drinks  with coworkers prior to a work dinner on the same night. I loved the place! We had a few rolls for appetizers and the sushi was fresh and delicious. The Raspberry Kamikaze was not such a bad choice either ;) 

What I liked most was the laid back feel of the place. It was classy yet chill. I could have stayed there for hours. Great place to go for business, a pre-date, or to catch up with friends in the city after work. 

I'm looking forward to try their dinner and will definitely bring my friends in the city here for drinks next time!
author: Kath H.

description: Best sushi ever. Especially the albacore when in season.
author: Joon L.

description: I have eaten here twice.  Both times excellent and attentive service.  It's the sushi that brings me back.
author: trixy b.

description: We are regulars as they have amazing sushi! I'm all about the whole experience.... So I must sit at the front part of restaurant near the bar for the vibe as the back of the restaurant has what I call 'cafeteria' lighting!
author: Renata D.

description:
I went here with my French friends :)

A trendy-ass, expensive lookin' place. Nice ambiance, and we sat by the bar (right next to the door, which was kind of bad b/c of the wind factor). We ordered a lot of things, and I guess the idea is to eat the small plate, but share it with everyone. 

We got to octopus, which was super tasty and ranked number one. The crab cakes were super awesome as well. Not oily, and crunch on the outside and moist and juicy within. Then some beef-eggplant thing was really really good. I hate eggplant, but it tasted really good then. Then there was some hamachi-something or other....forgettable. Then the bacon lardon which was good, but felt too greasy. But the bacon was melt-in-your-mouth. And the let-down was the roll which was mediocre for the price. And then fondue for dessert which was super awesome!

I'd say skip the rolls and go to the small dishes. This was definitely and EXPENSIVE ASS place, however, I didn't pay so I wasn't complaining ;)

And -1 star b/c although our waitress was super sweet and super knowledgeable about the menu, my god, it took her FOREVER to get around to us, and it too years for the food to get out.
author: Dustin H.

description:
I usually give poor ratings to places like Ozumo, that's a little pretentious, too much fancy stuff going on, trying too hard to be cool.

Yet Ozumo is really just, cool! AWESOME drinks, sake flights, cocktails, nothing is bad here. The food is yeah, the fancy americanized stuff that I usually don't care for, but they actually put some thoughts in it and make the dishes that tiny bit more exciting. 

The bartenders are all pretty cool, great recommendations and super chill!
author: Yuchi C.

description: The atmosphere is fantastic, great for a date or low key celebration. The food is delicious. Some of the staff was not very friendly. My waiter was great, very nice & mellow.
author: Kristy W.

description:
i haven't been back since the first review i wrote, but it was just as good as i remembered. 

Hanabi-Slices of hamachi and avocado drizzled with a warm ginger and jalapeño ponzu sauce (fresh with ton of flavor)

Dohyo-Spicy tuna tartare with avocado cream, cucumber and shiso,
tobiko, ponzu and wasabi oil, served with gyoza chips (excellent)

Futago-Tataki Washu beef, sautéed garlic spinach and eggplant served with miso sesame sauce (just melts in ur mouth. I love this dish)

Tontoro-Barbequed Kurobuta pork with crispy brussel sprouts and yuzu vinaigrette (when it first came out i was kinda not willing to try it, but i'm glad i did. it's soooo yummy)

Gindara-Black cod marinated in saikyo miso and sake kasu and grilled over bincho charcoal (by far one of the best places that does the cod perfectly)

Gyu Kakuni-Slow braised prime short ribs & daikon with a Tohoku region red aka miso sauce (just melts in ur mouth)

Tempura Yasai-Assorted vegetables with a delicate tempura batter (nothing special, but just wanted some veges and the batter was light and crispy)

Dark Chocolate Fondue ~ warm Belgium chocolate fondue with fresh fruits (this dessert is huge) they give u cake, bananas, strawberries, pine apples, apples etc...something that isn't too heavy but enough to satisfy you.

yes it's seems pricey but it's worth every bite.
author: Karen H.

description: Outstanding sushi and the best garlic edamames! Awesome place to have drinks and dinner. Classy crowd! I recommend making a reservation on weekends, it gets pretty busy there!
author: ELLY M.

description: Great Japanese restaurant and fairly good sushi bar. Make sure to try some of the other items besides sushi. We've had the black cod and the filet and both are absolutely phenomenal. Sushi is fairly standard for San Francisco but good overall, probably worth 4 stars. This place definitely loses some points because you pay an arm and a leg for your meal, pretty standard for the Embarcadero. You'll get a great view of the bay bridge if you sit in the back of the restaurant, and the front of the restaurant is a bar and great atmosphere. Ozumo gets some points back for the atmosphere but it is busier/louder than other sushi places in the city. If you want great sushi and a quieter meal that is maybe more reasonable I'd try Okoze, or maybe Zushi Puzzle (great sushi but kind of a dive).
author: Kate N.

description: I don't usually write  reviews but I was so disappointed in this sushi place I just had to warn others.  The table was sticky.  The waiter was nice.  The sushi was just ok and the service was slow.  We ordered a platter with sashimi and it was mostly greens and radish.  The pieces were about one inch long and 1/2 inch wide.  Would not go back.
author: Ruth N.

description:
I find myself here every  month or so because I can't seem to find a good sushi place around the SoMa/Embarcadaro area besides Whole Foods.

I can never leave Ozumo without ordering at least 3 "Giddy Geishas"! ;)
author: Tiff T.

description:
The food is high quality; drink selection outstanding.  The service is pretty good, though a bit inconsistent.  The girls working the front are darling and one showed up in the bathroom with salt and seltzer when she saw I had spilled something on my blouse!
Daytime reservation lady was pretty caustic, so use opentable.com for under 6 people.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Love the ambiance of this place. Great for fun evening out in the town!!!
Sushi Chef is very friendly, prepares your food in seconds!
author: Lovetea C.

description:
Another overpriced restaurant on the  Embarcadero.  Yawn.

Once you walk in, there's a bar, lounge area with loud dj music which is the place to see and be seen from Wed-Friday night.  Lots of financial district folks getting off work and doing the whole happy hour thing.  But you walk in the back which is most likely where you will be seated since the front is packed and it's a first come first serve type deal.  The back restaurant looks like any other restaurant and you kick yourself for not going to another lower priced sushi restaurant who will probably serve you the same thing without the glitzy front room.
author: Nezza F.

description: The atmosphere was comfortable at the bar, when we sat we were greeted by our bartenders who were very pleasant and extremely attentive. Our drinks were perfect, which seems hard to find these days and kept us ordering more. The icing  on the cake was the owner sent over a sushi complimentary dish to us just because! Which was awesome and we will be returning again soon to try out the restaurant side!
author: Manny R.

description:
I really wish I could give Ozumo a higher rating.  If it were just the food I was rating, it would get a solid 4 stars, if not 4.5, for some of the best fish in the city.  That said, the highly inconsistent service, high prices, and attitude that is sometimes apparent detracts from what would otherwise be a contender for one of the best sushi spots in SF.  I've noted a couple of hints that might help make the experience the best it can be.  

1) Get your drinks at the bar.  After ordering a bottle of sake, we had an ice bucket almost immediately as a tantalizing reminder of what was to come, but waited almost 20 minutes for the accompanying bottle to materialize.  That said, the bartenders are consistently fast and courteous, and much more helpful in the drinks department.

2) Sit at the sushi bar, if you can.  Again, highlighting the inconsistency of the wait staff, the sushi chefs, by comparison, are personable, knowledgeable, and provide excellent service.  They always have good advice on which fish is the freshest, and I've had good luck entrusting at least a portion of my order to their creativity, by asking them to make their favorite.  

So...outstanding fish but so-so service and sky-high prices demote what should be a higher-scoring restaurant down to a 3+star experience...but I'll remain optimistic that they can improve.
author: Michael S.

description:
Full disclosure:  I worked here for six soul crushing weeks before I said "Sayonara, suckers".  

Cons: Horrid place to work: stunningly incompetent management and creepy owners.  It was the type of gig that truly drives home all that is wrong with western society in general.  Marx...Springsteen...love you...call me.  

The hellacious work environment can definitely impact the service, unfortunately.

Pros: Got a gift certificate to Mrs. Fields and a Vicodin as gratuities from two separate patrons on the same night - they also left cash - the cookie money and drugs were just extras*.  Sweet.

So, notes from the inside: The food, both the sushi and the robata, is outrageously good  - always fresh and thoughtfully prepared BUT be prepared to drop stacks of dough.   I also learned a great deal about sake and I recommend the "sake flights" to anyone looking to broaden their horizons.  I was impressed with most of the staff's knowledge about the food and sake, they can be a great resource for recommendations and pairings.  

* you know it's bad when random patrons recognize the crapulence of the work environment. 

Yeesh, that job suuuuucked (sing song voice).
author: Mokirobinson M.

description:
I came here with a friend and 2 puppies. Surprisingly the manager was nice and let us bring in our pets to sit at the table, provided that they stayed in their travel bag and not make a fuss. For the duration of our dining time, they slept adorably. 

The reason why my buddy and I came here the other night was because my friend was talking about how great the dark sakes tasted. 

Word of advice: don't mix dark sake with sashimi or sushi. it'll be a war zone in your tummy. Recommended to drink this kind of alchol with some kind of cheese or something mixed with miso. It brings out the best in flavor.

We ordered a variety of finger food since we mainly came here for the alcohol. 

Atmosphere here was good, clean and welcoming. Definitely a place to come back to when I visit this neck of the woods again. The waiters and waitresses at least speak some Japanese and the place is Japanese owned, a plus in my book. 

One star less since our wait time and food was a bit pricey. until next time i guess.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
This is NOT your neighborhood sushi place that serves reliable California rolls and Teriyaki chicken.  It is something altogether different.  If you understand that, then I think you can better understand and place in context some of these other reviews.  

--Ozumo is expensive.  Is that the same thing as overpriced? No, it is not.  It is a very beautiful restaurant in a waterfront view location on a block that includes several other very high end restaurants.  If your point  of reference for Ozumo is your neighborhood sushi place, then you are approaching Ozumo all wrong.
--Which reminds me.  Ozumu has some sushi on the menu.  That's where the similarity to your neighborhood sushi place ends.  No, it's not "authentic," whatever that means.  They offer an interesting and creative menu which is Japanese influenced, no doubt, but is also influenced by other cuisines around the world.  

Other differences from your neighborhood sushi place: 

-Excellent attentive opinionated service
-Amazing and unique wIne list which has plenty of good reds, but specializes in the excellent whites which will best complement their food.  I recently had a wonderful and hard to find Cloudy Bay Sauvignon Blanc and a very nice Sancerre.  
-Gracious and professional  host desk which tries very hard to accommodate all requests and always wears a smile (a true rarity in SF).  
-Beautiful dark sexy bar, with cute, flirty female bartenders (who, by the way, don't insist that you "settle up" before moving to your table like some restaurants do in a very obnoxious way - - -cough cough, bacar, cough cough).

I have eaten dinner here at least 3 or 4 times and lunch maybe 20 times and never have I had a less than stellar experience (and no, I am not personally acquainted with anyone who works there.)  Ozumo is my favorite restaurant in the city, without qualification.
author: Jay Z.

description: Expensive and worth every penny. Fresh fish, creative rolls and bentos. Been here 6 times for lunch this year and it's freakin awesome. GO THERE.
author: Michael C.

description:
We were looking for a good Japanese Restaurant and the concierge at our hotel recommended this place.

First impression: Very nice interior, the hostess appeared a bit snobby, huge saki bar.

This place was so dark inside that I tried to read the menu by the light of the small votive candle on the table. It is times like this that I remind myself that I need to start carrying a small flashlight in my purse. 

From the start, I was very confused with their menu, this was before I even had a sip of the overpriced saki the waiter recommended. We were told that the theme was family style or small plate dishes. We asked the waiter for recommendations and placed our orders. When the first dish came out it contained 3 pieces, which just didn't quite cut the mustard when there were 5 of us. You would expect the waiter at such a trendy, expensive restaurant to be able to do the math. 

Next came the sushi rolls, the majority of their rolls have tempura in them. I am not a fan of tempura, so I found the selection very limited. We ordered the Ozuma roll which had grilled unagi in it. It was okay, ended up ordering a second one because one roll only allowed one piece per person. We also ordered a plate of asparagus which was tasty and some other small plate items which were not memorable enough for me to even list here. 

Finally, we decided to order the Yosenabe, which is a seafood hot pot, but our waiter suggested that we may like the Shacho Shabu-shabu better. We didn't. It consisted of a few thin slices of rib eye and vegetables and the broth didn't have much flavor. Also, note that the Shabu-shabu was $10 more than the Yosenabe, so we now realized why the waiter suggested it. 

So, after paying the $300 plus bill, we left, feeling moderately ripped off, very poor and still very hungry. Lesson learned - don't trust the recommendations of an inexperienced waiter who obviously didn't know anything about authentic Japanese food at a trendy, very expensive Japanese restaurant.
author: Nancy B.

description:
I was fortunate enough to catch one last dinner wtih my friend before his flight out.  Longtime good friends, we've always made it a point to catch as many good meals as possible during the brief intervals we are in the same town at the same time.  It's a good way to catch up on gossip, as well as just plain old catch up on each others' lives.  

Since he was stuck in Fidi/Soma area for the duration of his business trip, we kept it simple by going to Ozumo.  I haven't been here for years...last time was for lunch when I was living in NY and came to SF on a business trip myself.  We swung by at 5:00 on my first ever President's Day off (I really mean that first time ever seriously...I've never once had a job that took it as a holiday before).  They were still preparing the place, so we swung around on the chairs of the pier and enjoyed the gorgeous view of a rare sunny February day.

I love the furniture at Ozumo, particularly the stools and chairs.  The dark wood is beautiful and those curving seats are so much more comfortable for my back than a flat stool.  And the whole decor is chic without being annoyingly hip (it's a very fine line between sophisticated chic and cliche chic...with the majority of popular restaurants veering dangerously towards cliche chic).

As for the food...I ordered two smaller dishes: the beef tartare and shrimp tempura.  I love beef tartare but would never order anywhere but a pricey establishment as I'd be scared of any cheap beef tartare.  And it was wonderful.  A disk of red raw beef with a raw quail egg, some wasabi floating on an endive leaf and a curlicue of another sauce (not sure what was in the sauce).  Mix it all together, and it's a perfect dish for a carnivore.  The shrimp tempura was perfectly nice (I feel that most shrimp tempura I've had in my life has been quite wonderful unless the oil is off...after all, it's fried shrimp.  There's not much that can be bad about that).

Service was cordial, if a tad overformal (and not in the Asian sense but sort of "we are professionals in the high-end restaurant business" sense.)

But best of all was my friend absolutely enjoying his sushi (his wife is pregnant, so he's been keeping away from sushi for her benefit.  That's love for you...I doubt I'd give up sushi for anybody.)  Great company, great conversation.  Always makes me a little sad that so many of us are flung in different cities.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Too 

Fucking 

Expensive.

**after much prodding on the part of others I will explain below why this place is too fucking expensive**

A) I have eaten in sushi restaurants all over the world, including New York and Los Angeles and I have never paid this much money for my food.  

B) I got all of the standards I get at sushi restaurants, tuna sashimi, yellowtail, dragon roll and kobe beef shabu shabu, and it was totally and completely average.  I did not drop my jaw in disbelief at the quality of the food.  Which is what I expect when an entree is $42.00. 

C) What's up with the crazy Vegas atmosphere.  I wanted a nice, boozing dinner with friends not a club vibe which included tons of inebriated suits who would drunkenly stare at my boobs every time I went to the bathroom. 

D) Too fucking expensive.
author: Claire C.

description:
*Bar Review Only*

Let me just say that on decor alone, I would give this place 5 stars. And the music was really good. They were playing deep house last night. Sweet. 

Great selection of drinks and lots of bar seating or lounge type seating. This place will definitely be on my list of chill drink spots. 

But my favorite part was the Japanese lessons while using the restroom... When I first walked in and my eyes were adjusting to the light, I heard:

"Konnichiwa. Ayako desu."

I looked up thinking there was a lady working in the bathroom. Then I realized it was a recording. hah... Kinda embarassing, yeah... 

But bathroom lessons are awesome! Especially at a place like this where you can sit at the bar and the chances are pretty high that you can meet someone. My bathroom Japanese lessons would go a little something like this: 

"Kokoni yoku kuru?" (Do you come here often?)

"Biiru o nomo?" (Do you drink beer?)

To bartender: "Motto tsuyoi nomimono o kudasai." (Stronger drinks please)

"Ima kara doo suru?" (What shall we do now?)

"Hoteru ni ikoo." (Let's go to a hotel.)

"Namete ageru." 

"Kuchi no naka itte ii?"

"Saikou datta."

Sorry, but I can't translate the last three phrases. You'll just have to use your imagination, or get a Japanese friend to translate them for you. But all of these are very useful. So memorize them and try them out next time your with a Japanese person. 

:)
author: Jen D.

description:
Wow this place is really good! Been here for both lunch and dinner. Had the sushi which was very fresh. Since it was lunch, and I had to go back to work, I opted for the ice tea (instead of sake) which was very nice. It was their tropical flavor. 
Make reservations if going for dinner because it's hard to get it! Lunch was not as bad to try and get a rez.
Will definitely be back!
author: Lauren W.

description:
Ways Ozumo is similar to my first date in high-school:

They were both hands-on:  The boy a decade ago tried to grope me and got denied.  Ozumo had two people that swarmed us from the moment we entered and immediately began showing us the available places we could sit.   

I didn't know what I was getting into:  Fortunately, Ozumo wasn't a boy with acne and wandering hands.  This place has a great atmosphere. Professional and classy, but not too uptight.

They were both dim:  Bad thing for the dumb teenager in the late '90s, good thing for Ozumo. I look way better in low-lighting.

Reservations are suggested:  Even the boy in high school knew that my time is precious and you need to schedule in advance.  I went here on a Tuesday evening sans reservations and the earliest they could fit us in was 8:45. (Good to know people go out on Tuesday.  Apparently they aren't all like me, rushing home after work to sit in sweats, eat ice cream, and watch The Biggest Loser)  Since it was booked, we opted to be seated by the door, which encouraged people- watching.  Normally, I try to refrain from gawking, but the crowd at Ozumo was almost begging to be watched.  Far be it from me to make beautiful people feel ungawkworthy.  I'm such a giver.

I enjoyed the food:  Now, eating at Ozumo is a little fancier than sharing the sampler at Denny's, but I'm pretty sure everyone but my younger brother will agree with that.  Our dinner: The kobe beef entre was delicious paired with cabernet.  The cod was flakey (just like my date in high school) and incredible.  We also shared a tempura shrimp roll and a California roll.

I didn't pay for either of them:  In high-school, my mom picked up the tab (God bless that woman for feeding my batter-addiction) and last night, my friend picked it up (God bless that man for spending on a meal, what I spend on three months of groceries).

One difference between Ozumo and my high-school date:  I'll see Ozumo again.
author: Janney B.

description:
I've been down on Ozumo for a couple of years now, but after last night, it's back in my good graces.

My frustration was that for such a beautiful restaurant with great food, why was the service so atrocious?  I mean, seriously, it's a crime to spend a fat wad of cash, only to be subjected to long waits and general apathy.  

The key may be to go with a larger party and get one of the private rooms.  There were 10 of us last night in the sake-tasting room, which is a delightful spot to enjoy a meal with good friends.  It's a shoes-off affair in this room, so make sure your socks are in good order and try to pee before you sit down.  

We started with the edamame - 1 each of the salted and garlic.  I always prefer the salted.  For my appetizer, I got the sashimi martini which was pieces of yellowtail, tuna & salmon with a spicy sauce and seaweed at the bottom.  The fish was extremely fresh and tender, and the sauce added a nice bit of unexpected flavor, but was not overpowering.  I also ordered uni with a quail egg which is my usual guilty pleasure these days...and the pieces were huge and delicious.

I think one of my other frustrations with Ozumo is that I always felt that the sushi menu was limited, so I decided to try a regular entree for a change - and I am so glad I did.  I ordered the Gindaro, which is marinated black cod.  It was delicious.  The sauce was a wonderful mixture of salty, tangy and sweet - hard to describe but really great flavor, and the fish was incredibly tender.  I love the skin as a contrast to the soft texture of the fish - it gives you something to chew on.  At first the portion looked tiny (and for $24, I was surprised), but it turned out to be an ample amount and worth the price.

I also tasted one of the hot pots, which is definitely on my must-have list  of dishes for next time.  It was the Iron Pot Sukiyaki, and the broth was so flavorful, with tender pieces of beef, vegetables, and a large bowl of miso sauce on the side for added flavor.

They have an extensive sake menu, with a lot being offered by the glass, which I like.  I had one glass of filtered sake, and one glass of unfiltered - I have forgotten which ones they were but the staff is good at making recommendations according to your taste.

Most importantly, the service was very good and the server seemed to genuinely care about our experience.  Plus it seems like we had our own staff of busboys to clear the plates.  Everything came at the same time, and in a reasonable amount of time.  BIG improvement from the past few times I've been there.

The bar on Friday night is a clusterfuck, so unless you like to have your drink knocked out of your hand on a regular basis, I'd avoid it.  It is a great deal on a weekday night for drinks and half-price sushi at Happy Hour.

We ended up paying around $130 per couple including tip, which is expensive, but for a special night out, not unreasonable in my opinion.  And now that the service is back on track, I no longer feel like I am being hosed.
author: Liz S.

description:
The five stars is particularly for their lunch menu....the dinner, while delicious, is a bit to rich for my blood.
The sushi here is absolutely amazing. Pretty sure it's the freshest sushi i have ever eaten.  The bento boxes at the lunch hour are a great deal and the portion size is filling.
author: Kelle K.

description:
Only reason this place doesn't get 5 stars is because it's 1) over priced, and 2) the desserts are disappointing. 

So let's start with the beautiful decor, this restaurant is sleek and dark and the perfect place to impress a date.  This place is also huge, has tons of different seating areas from the main dining rooms, to the big bar set ups and the small private sake tasting room.  

Service was attentive, and the Giddy Geishas (cocktail) sounded AMAZING. i'm DEFINITELY getting it next time..Smirnoff vodka, lychee juice & passion fruit puree. OMG..only reason i didn't get it was 'cause i had to budget myself and @ $11/cocktail...not exactly cheap and affordable. 

I started off with an order of warm, garlic soy sauce edamame, and it was yummmm...i mean, you can't really mess up edamame, but @ $6/bowl, again, way too pricey. I mean, come on! garlic soy sauce soy beans. yea. 

I decided on the Ozumo roll, grilled unagi & cucumber roll topped with snow crab, tuna, avocado & spicy sauce.  This was phenomenol.  The roll was also huge, so very much worth the $18 tag. Damn this roll was good. 

my girlfriends got tempura which was flaky, crispy, had mushrooms, a good variety of veggies, and even tempura noodles!  The Dragon, tempura shrimp roll wrapped in grilled unagi & avocado with sweet soy sauce. Also delicious.  

The very long & extensive list of Sake & Ginjo is impressive for any sake connoisseur. 

The desserts were...eh =( so sad. the warm chocolate& azuki bean mochi was a disappointment.  just very bland.  We also got the green tea ice cream crepe roll...and it was so tasteless. There was barely any green tea ice cream, i mean, the dish barely even registed COLD, there was just way too much crepe and it was blah blah blah. NOT good at all. 

i would definitely be back for the rolls and sushi here, but if i should get dessert i think i'll stick with the chocolate fondue. You can't really mess that up now can you?!
author: Lulu C.

description:
I went for happy hour although I didn't get there in time for the specials.  I enjoyed my shochu and grapefruit juice cocktail but then switched to Absolut Pear and soda because that's who I am.  The drinks were fine and the place is pretty but it took forever to get the check at the end.  Something about 2 different servers so 2 different bills which required several servers and hosts to be reminded a few times before we finally got things sorted out.  

I am glad I didn't wear a dress or a skirt because climbing onto the outside bench of one of the communal tables could've been a little more riske than I was in the mood for that evening.
author: Seong P.

description:
It's everyones favorite show...TOOL TIME!!!!  This is where my night changed from genuinely pleasant and reminiscent of Japan to super-gaijin-power-fest!!!!  I rate this place + or - a star based on the crowd alone.  And yeah, wasn't feeling it last night.

Usually meet my FiDi friends here, royal exchange, or americano...of all the three this place has the best service in my opinion...Matt and Jesse are cool cats that make a greyhound crazy delicious--to the point where i asked Jesse- is this freshly squeezed? Matt jumped in and said he saw a freshly squeezed label on da juice carton--hahaha!!

Oh...try the deiwa sansan nihonshu--very smooth and crisp!!!

I was at the corner of the bar chopping it up with friends and starting crying out of the hilarity in watching some early 90s sumo vids loopin again and again.  Man they are what mote-mote is all about...but damn, i really think they should outlaw all the rice throwing in the beginning of the ceremonies-- shit, rice is my life!!!  Guess that is why iam not fit for the mental toughness of that sport..i would be psyched out quick style.

The bathrooms are quite an experience with Japanese in-flight instructional audio teaching the essentials of the language--
how do you ask for a menu? menyu onegaishimasu...how do you ask 
for an appetizer? apetaizaa onegaishimasu...so fucking funny!!!

Yeah, maybe will be a four next week...
author: omar b.

description:
Oh man, this place is great. The servers are a dream... speaking of "Dreams" I can't WAIT until Dreamgirls comes out in a couple weeks!! Jennifer Hudson, oooh yes!!! Sing it Girl! Beyonce ain't got nothin on you.

oops ok sorry - so anyway back to fishy stuff.

The servers tended to our every desire when I was here for Ben's company party over the weekend. This is a great place to throw a party people. The space is open and quite huge. The decor is ultra modern and it transitions nicely. You first walk through the entrance into a dark bar/lounge then up a few steps through the dimly lit kitchen area, past a suprisingly sturdy sake tasting room made of Sake bottles and finally ending up in a large bright open room with a big ol' sushi bar in the middle. It's quite a journey.

Sorry that I keep mentioning the servers.. but they really were outstanding, if you didn't have a drink in your hand, you would be politey approached by a server asking if you'd like one - one of them did a great Borat impression... she was hilarious... totally personable, but still professional at the same time.

Wooo! We had a great time here. Corporate Event Planners, definitely put this on your list of places to throw your company holiday party... or anything party. It really is wonderful.
author: Richard T.

description: Very swank, larger-than-it-seems sushi place. Watch beautiful people come and go as you sample some better-than-average sushi. We stuck to the relatively small selection of sushi rolls and weren't disappointed. Spicy scallop rolls could have been a bit spicier. Their saki list is unbelievable with a separate, giant menu. If you're a saki fan, go to Ozumo and rejoice. I'll be back.
author: Michael R.

description:
This has become one of my favorite happy hour spots. The crowd is spotless and clean, not unlike the space the bar itself. Very urban professional. From 5-7pm, some of their sushi rolls are $4.50 each, which is a relative bargain for the high quality of fish they serve at the connected restaurant.

Steuart Street has become quite the after work scene. With Boulevard, Shanghai 1930 and Americano in the vicinity, it's definitely one of the more libationally affluent happy hours I've experienced in the city.
author: Nish N.

description:
If I were  lesbian..... this would be the best place for the freshest fish!!!
Highly recommend the flights of sake.
Wow, the black cod with miso sauce melted in my mouth like butta'. 
Then we shared the duck...fabulously delicious, tender, sweet and succulent.  
We ended  the dinner with the fondue and an apple crisp.  
A wonderful dinner, wonderful service from Sagen, I'm taking all my clients here.  Beautiful decor and gorgeous views of the bridge...and, oh, (ouch) of the guy paying for this.
author: Gemma P.

description:
One of the Steuart Street restaurants. Bar seating was a bit unusual as it's one long bench and you do have to climb over if you are not siting at the edge.

Food wise it's overall good. Uni was fresh but on the smaller side. Anago and Unagi were both on par. Hamachi was pretty good. Spider and dragon rolls were good. Did order the scallop with tobiko roll but I don't think they know what they were doing. They did just the scallop roll and had a big scope of tobiko on top, instead of chopped scallops mixed with mayo and tobiko. A bit unusual and was not the taste that I wanted. Presentation was good, however.

Service was good, simple and friendly and the bar servers warmed up after a while. Also pretty reasonably priced for the food and ambiance.
author: T L.

description:
This place is one of my favorites! I've had almost everything on the menu. It has a great bar and they are open for happy hour. If you are a female and there with just your girlfriends, be prepared to give the " stop staring, I'm here to eat foo!" look. 

But be warned, this is not a place for you if you want to get full for a good price! you can spend 300 dollars here and still not be full. 

The Cod is excellent, it just melts in your mouth!. 

The Shabu Shabu is good but sometines they make the broth too salty.

The Kobe is very pricey and you only get 8-10 thin pieces ( for over 100 dollars)  but there's nothing like fat infested beef. They serve it to you with real wasabi and some sort of root salad that you won't ever eat.

The spareribs just MELT IN YOUR MOUTH. 

The loster roll is different, they put jalepenos in it which gives it a kick but its very good ( it better be at that price!)

For the sides, the japanese sweet potatoes are really good. You have to make sure they have the Purples ones! yup, purple! they have the best flavor but they don't have it everyday.

When you  do go and plan on valet parking, make sure you roll up in your nicest car! I've gone a few times in a nice car and they charged us 10 dollars and park it in the front everytime. last time, I came with my friend in a not so fancy car and they told him it would cost him 15 dollars if he wanted them to park it close!! so wrong! but nonetheless,,, the food was excellent
author: Anna T.

description:
Scene, Yo!  Friday happy hour here is an f'n scene!  I saw me some Marina, some cougars, some Ruby Skye pre-partyers and heard me some paltry remixes of tunes I adore (Miguel Migs' "So Far" to name just one :/).  

But the food is pretty good even if overpriced for what you get.  Get the hamachi small plate w/ jalapeno ponzu -- buttery slices of fresh hamachi complemented with the lovely tang of fresh ginger, jalapeno ponzu, baby radishes and avocado.  Make sure you wrap a bit of everything in each slice of hamachi.  Nigiri and shrimp tempura are also tasty.

Would not recommend the ceviche nihon, however -- whitefish, scallops in yuzu lime juice -- absolutely no tartness and unnoticeable flavor.

Drinks are superb as well.  The raspberry sake cocktail was one of the best made drinks ever, perfectly balanced and incredibly smooth.  The Geisha vodka cocktail (lychee, vodka, passionfruit) was very sweet, as warned our server.  Still pretty good.  

I used to really dislike this place.  Things change.  Perhaps I changed? Naahhh.
author: Natasha S.

description: So far, I've been here twice. I'm only writing a review for the second time because the first time was one big sake blur. The second time I came, I ordered the soft shell crab. It was crunchy and flavorful and unlike any soft shell crab I've had before. My sister ordered a beef dish. I forget the name. They served it on a hot slab of some sort, still sizzling. The meat was tender and juicy. The daikon underneath was full of flavor from the meat. It was really pricey though. However, I still recommend it.
author: Dallas P.

description:
Great food, not worth the price by any means.

I get that because of its location it can draw the crowds willing to pay, but you can get equal and better quality fish elsewhere for a fraction of the price.  I've been here several times now but more recently on the company tab, which is probably the one way I'll keep coming back here.  The carpaccios/sashimi salads are all great, especially the hamachi with jalapeno.  Well balanced with citrus and heat, and the fish is good quality.  The specialty rolls are tasty as well, but quite small especially when given the price.  Some of them, for example the Ozumo roll, have a bit too much going on for my taste, but that's just personal preference.

The sake list is quite long which is nice, but again some of the bottles are twice what you'd pay in Russian Hill/Japantown.  The service has always been good, especially during the weekday lunch hour when people are in somewhat of a hurry to return to work.

I'll return, but again, only if someone else is picking it up.  Otherwise, I'll stick to Ace, Okoze, and the like for my raw fish needs.
author: Jake D.

description:
The sushi is fantastic. I mean truly fantastic. The place is gigantic. The bathroom teaches you Japanese.

They get a star knocked off for marking up their sake so much.
author: Jordan M.

description:
This place has really fresh sea food and the vibe was just right.  It is expensive but you get what you pay for.  A good place for date night.

My favorites:
-Shacho roll (main lobster, mango, jalapeno, cilantro, wrapped in tuna, with spicy sesame sauce)
-Ozumo roll (unagi and cucumber roll topped with snow crab, tuna, avocado, and spicy sauce)
-Warm edamame with garlic soy sauce
-Dohyo (Tuna tartare)
-Kaki Kaki Kaki (N Japan Kusshi Oysters with great sauce)
-Gyu Kakuni (Short ribs)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
