There are many criteria to judge how a sushi should taste- be presented and served...So I found myself relying on these measures to find quality sushi bars...
I took a friend of mine from out of town on a thursday- there's dj music that greeted us in the lobby/bar area- it seems that most places nowadays are trying to accomodate the drinking crowd to provide extra income.  We were seated at our table- the decor was minimal with walls of sushi bottles adorning the hallway.  
Our sushi were well prepared- fresh and neat...rolls tightly wrapped-fresh crab meat. (these are the 2 stars)
Our Service was not well executed-- there was a long interval waiting for the next sushi order.  When we brought this up to the maitre'd- he was unphased...I havent returned here since!
The music was a bit distracting.
author: Arissa C.

description:
This place is so overpriced, especially for the quality. I went with a rather large group - maybe 15 people and it was super expensive and we all left hungry and sober. First I might add, that our waiter was super annoying. He seemed very pushy to sell items and get us to order expensive bottles of sake. I asked for a sake recommendation and he pointed to a bottle well over $100 dollars. Hell no! We did end up getting a bottle I have had before, which costs $20 at the sake shop, but they were charging $60. That's quite a mark-up there.... 

The food was plain average and it was super exp. I thought my beef sukiyaki would be something substantial and special, but it was small and around $20 bucks for nothing more than a bowl of broth with scant noodles and 4 peices of beef. RIP OFF!!! 

Also, someone rude in my group (not a friend of mine) ordered Toro that was $50 dollars and expected us to split the bill evenly. Oh this person was either incredibly rude or  very stupid (most likely BOTH) to think he/she could get away with that. Regardless, I didn't get a bite of that exp Toro, though it looked amazing, but at $50 - I'll have to wait another lifetime when I am reborn as Paris Hilton.

Not coming back here again.
author: Karen C.

description:
Simply a great dining experience (lunch, happy hour, or dinner).

I like the Sapporo Ramen, Spider Roll, and Hoyo Genji.

A bit pricey but you get what you pay for...
author: Francis M.

description: Checked Ozumo for lunch yesterday. Not sure why people would be disappointed with Ozumo - great atmosphere and excellent rolls, sashimi, and nigiri. Wish I could remember what I had, but it seemed like a dozen different items that considered to be anywhere from good to excellent.
author: Jeff F.

description: Really good sushi!  The sekiwake roll is my absolute fave here.  The service at the bar is a little slow though.  It took 20 minutes to get my check.  Sit in the back dining room if there's a seat available.
author: Kristal D.

description:
We got the private Kotatsu room at Ozumo last night. You have to take off your shoes and slip onto cushions around a big marble table in a private Japanese themed room.  Everything we ate last night was amazing. 

I started with the Giddy Geisha Martini - vodka, lychee juice and passion fruit puree - $11.00.

We got the Dohyo (tuna, avocado and chips) and the Iron Pot Sukiyaki as appetizers and then started ordering sushi like crazy. 

Some of the highlights were: Beni toro, tako, maguro, hamachi - sashimi 

and Ozumo, Yokozuna, Ozuki, Bucho, Spicy Scallop - rolls

I think our bill ended up around $950 for 7 people. It was a work dinner so our vendor paid and even at these prices they said they want to make this their new client dinner spot. It was yummy!
author: Jackie G.

description:
Very very good but definitely pricey. One friend and I just returned from spending $180 on lunch. Yikes!

The service was friendly and knowledgeable and the atmosphere is gorgeous. Just be careful with the sake recommendations - some of those bottles are pretty chere!

We sat at the sushi bar and the chef serving us did a great job at finding less common fish that fit my finicky restricted pallette. He was also so sweet and cute and obviously loves working at Ozumo.

We will definitely be back, but only when one of us is having a REALLY bad day and its been a REALLY long time. Otherwise, I'm gonna go broke fast.
author: Lise L.

description:
I just got back from this place. I had to wear my sunglasses on the way home because tears were streaming down my face after surviving the hellish gamut of onceovers. I'm going to start going to Lafayette on weekends to visit my friend's chickens.

Next morning update:
The fried amaebi heads are surgically altered to make them more appealing, but in doing so they remove all the delicious parts. And I can get a better ratio of fish to rice elsewhere. But the edamame was excellent - I would go back for that.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Wonderful sushi.  Albeit I still love Boathouse in Rohnert Park because it shares all the same qualities, minus the view of The Bay.

But if you want gourmet sushi in San Francisco, go to this restaurant.  

I recommend this place to those of us out to impress someone.  It's got ambiance, elegance, serious style and an absolutely fabulous menu.

The sushi chefs at the sushi bar are lightening fast - we ordered, glanced around the room and when we looked back, the order was in front of us.  Seriously, it was that fast.  Now THAT'S instant gratification!

The Kobe style beef dish is to die for.  With only one cocktail on the tab, four of us ate at the sushi bar for $250 (after a $40 tip), so it's a bite out of your wallet.  Be prepared!

I give three stars because the prices are too high, the bar dining service sucks, the hosts/hostesses are arrogant jackals and the best sushi on Earth is in Rohnert Park (North Bay): Boathouse Sushi.
author: Michael O.

description:
Tofu. 

I know, I KNOW! You think I'm crazy. Go to a high-end Japanese restaurant and order tofu?? 

Trust me. Order the tofu. It's the block of the most exquisite silky, yummy, delightful tofu I have ever eaten, battered and lightly fried and placed in some amazing sauce. Get it. Trust me. 

We listened to our waiter, who suggested the cod (divine!), scallops (that were on this marvelous risotto) , and also got the habachi, the Ozumo, the garlic edamame and pumpkin soup.

*deep contented sigh*

This was an amazing meal. Probably one of the most expensive I've ever had, but downright amazing. 

And the tofu. Get the tofu.
author: Monica G.

description:
From 4-7 pm, mon-thurs, Ozumo is my FiDi cocktails locale of choice. And I'm not only saying that because it's three doors down from my office (i am saying that, but i'm saying other stuff, too). For those 12 aforementioned hours there's always a seat, even for larger (8+) groups, the sake's always warm, and the sushi's always delicious.

Hits: the luxe sake lunge, zen lemon drop,  and classic spider roll.
Misses: Friday evenings, sake bombing before dinner, and hard-to-find-when-intoxicated bathrooms.
author: Mandy Z.

description:
Dear Ozumo,

I came by Friday after work to pick up a 200 dollar gift card for a company party. You had me standing there waiting for nearly 15 minutes.  You weren't that busy. I had to ask twice to remind someone to bring the gift card. That's just poor service. Once the card was brought to me I took it from your employee and walked out. I didn't have to sign anything or go over any paper work, it was a transaction that should not have taken more than 5 minutes.

Since this is the only experience I have with you, I gave you one star. Perhaps someday I will return and give you the chance to earn more stars.

-Alex
author: Alex R.

description:
I've had two experiences here. One out in the dining area and one in the private "Saki Room".  I'm sure it comes as no surprise that I recommend the later...(and no, its not for the simple face that I'm surrounded 360 degrees by alcohol)
If you can get it, book it! The room is wonderfully private and romantic. Other tables in the dining area are much too close together, restricting you and your party from discussing "sensitive" topics, such as, what exactly you don't remember from the night before. ;)
 I recommend  the scallops to any female patron. The reason I phrase it that way  is the dish is mouthwatering, but only comes with four pieces!  Any man...we'll, at least those I dine with would absolutely need one or two appetizers before hand. 
One last thing, I would recommend ordering one of their  Saki flights as well. It was really fun being able to sample a few in one sitting....

....I'm sure that had nothing to do with any subliminal message I was contracting from the sheen off all of those bottles. ;)
author: lacey b.

description:
First, the decor is gorgeous. Blond wood, clean lines, dramatic silhouettes. A mixture of organic and urban. I'm the type of girl who's heart goes all aflutter for good design. And Ozumo did it for me indeed. 

The sake lounge in the front is a bit of a hormone-soaked pick-up scene, full of downtown suits and hopeful cleavage. Usually places are like this are more concerned with pheromones than food, so I was initially pretty turned off. But my food friend insisted that the sushi here was fantastic, so his word prevailed. 

We thought our waitress was helpful when we ordered - cheerfully recommending dishes and steering us away from others. We ended up getting a couple forgettable appetizers, the sashimi setto dinner and two rolls.  We relayed to the sushi chefs that we were willing to get a little adventurous with the sashimi. 

The result? 

Our sashimi set was everything sashimi should be. You know like when you pop a piece of sashimi in your mouth,  close your eyes to intensify the sensory experience, and simultaneously sigh in deep pleasure? Yeah. Like that. (I KNOW I'm not the only one who does this!)

As for the rolls. What the HELL were we thinking?  I usually don't order rolls, but the waitress was insistent that they were the best dish of the night. And they were HORRIBLE. The fillings were some variation of imitation crab salad, BOTH of them. And the rice was simultaneously dried out and mushy. How this is possible, I don't know. Suffice it to say, the rolls were left unfinished. 

Thank god for the sake flight to wash down the roll debacle. If you're interested in exploring sake, I'd highly recommend the flight, which gives you a tasting of different sake types. An explanatory card helps you along, so you, too, can taste for the "wonderful viscous, creamy texture with hints of lemon peel and sandalwood".  One flight is perfect for two. 

An incidental note: Hypothetically speaking, if you happen to be driving your friend's car home, (perfectly sobered up, thank you)  and a cop pulls you over for, say, a broken tail light. The cop just might be able to still smell the sake on your breath when he leans in to talk to you. Hypothetically speaking. 

So yes, back to the food. Food friend and I left a bit puzzled. The sashimi and the sake were perfection The rolls seemed like they were pulled from the dumpster of a midwestern all-you-can-eat sushi joint. Probably the most uneven food experience I've ever had. 

In my ramblings through this city, I'm sure I'll end up at Ozumo again. Perhaps next time if I come with hopeful cleavage, my experience will be more favorable.
author: Umami Y.

description: Came again for bf's dinner.  It is crowd for Wednesday. The service and food are great just I felt the tables are so close to each other.  I can totally heard the conversation at the tables next to us.
author: Lily Z.

description: We absolutely love Ozumo, lychee martini is awesome, food is great...
author: Glenn S.

description:
Last night a few friends, my girlfriend and I went to Ozumo.  I've been before, but it was a couple of years ago and I had good memories of the place.  Last night reminded me why I liked it so much, and had me asking why it's been so long since I've been back.

The food was awesome- first, the sushi.  My girlfriend & one of our friends had the sushi and they absolutely loved it.  I'm not exactly a sushi connoisseur, but I will say this: the sushi chef's there should be called sushi artists.  The way they laid it out made it look amazing.

We had a variety of appetizers, and my favorite was the hamachi with jalapenos.  I wish I could remember the name of it - unfortunately I'm horrible at this.  My entree was great as well - some sort of filet mignon with bacon & mushrooms in a sauce that was just incredible.

Beyond the great food the service was amazing.  Our server, again my memory is horrible (I blame the drinks!) was a girl named Danci, and she was really amazing.  All smiles, and extremely helpful.  My buddies convinced me to try some saki (I'm usually a cocktails sort of guy) and Danci helped us find a bottle of unfiltered saki that was as good as I could have imagined.  I might be a convert!  Thank god for friendly, knowledgeable staff, right?

Anyway, the end of the meal was as good as the beginning, though honestly I didn't eat much of the desert as I was already in food coma.

Sure, the place is a bit pricey, but you should go in expecting that - and the food and service are totally worth it.  I'll definitely be going much more often, and who knows, maybe next time I'll try another saki :)
author: Michael B.

description:
Ozumo, Ozumo...
When in doubt, I head over to Ozumo.
For a good time - zoom zoom to Ozumo.

The first time I ever went to Ozumo was with some good friends.  We ordered martinis and beers - - sat in comfortable "booths" with nicely-cushioned benches, and had a ball.  I love the atmosphere here in the front room - bar area.  Since then, I've frequented Ozumo a lot, but never reviewed it because this place is, first and foremost, a restaurant.  But, when wanting sushi, I always seem to end up somewhere else rather than coming here!  I was finally able to order from their late-night menu a couple of months back - - and in all fairness, it was past midnight and perhaps not exemplary of their normal cuisine - - but the sushi was FAR from good.  The sushi at Chaya next door is actually better, and theirs is nothin' to write home about either.  So, this review is for the bar portion only - - I reserve my opinion on Ozumo food.

Other times, we've gone here after dinner to finish off the night here w/ good drinks.  

Once, I walked in here to meet a man who, at that time, was "bigger than life" to me.  Funny that this was only one of many, many nights at Ozumo before and since that night, but I recall that one moment... perhaps because he turned out to be such a dud, or perhaps because it's rare, but so enjoyable, to feel dreamy about someone, even if it's all based on bullshit or my imagination.  One can't help what one's brain insists on recalling.

And then, on other nights like last night, it's just a chill place for two girls to hang out and drink.  Of course, by the time we got to Ozumo, Jacey was pretty well into a state of giddiness, mixed in with umpteen runs to the restroom - too funny.  Guys found it adorable nonetheless - and it was good material for conversation.  :-)  Silly girl.... "Unni... you got me all ^&$%& up.... hee hee hee hee.  Who's this guy?  Oh hellooooooo hee hee hee!"  So cute!! Or some guy will approach her and start talking, and she says, "Oh yeah, you're the one who was sitting here earlier... oh dear... no you're not.  Unni, he's not, right?  HEE HEE HEE".  Oh, dear, indeed!  Time to zoom zoom out of Ozumo, girlie.... hahaha!!

Anyhow - - Ozumo's sake selection is impressive - and I think I've now had as much of the unfiltered Nigori sake here as I've had my dirty Martinis.  
They have valet up in front, always a good thing.
Seating is very important in a lounge atmosphere, and Ozumo's seating is comfortable and inviting.  Lighting is just dark enough to make you look good - haha, but light enough that there's nothing you miss either.  Music is loud enough to get you in the mood, but never too loud that you can't hold a long conversation.  Atmosphere here is just good.

All that said - - I don't know what their business schedule is - - sometimes, last call feels really late, and other nights - - last call seems to come entirely too quickly!
author: Grace K.

description:
Went here for some snacks/drinks at the bar the past two times I was in San Francisco for work. Drinks were great, and the head bartender (Joshua) was a great guy. I didn't have any Sake, but they have a huge selection. I've only sat at the bar, right next to the floor to ceiling glass windows in front, so never had any problems with a lack of light (since I've only been there on the earlier side).

Funny story about one of my visits: bartender was chatting with me and then almost laughed, and had me turn around -- some guy had just pulled into one of the diagonal street parking spots, only he went a little too far so the front of his car went up on the curb. What made it amusing was the fact that he was driving a Ferrari. whoops.
author: Zach B.

description:
My first impression, based on the frenzied activity (read raging hormones) at the bar, was that we'd walked into a Pan-Asian Harry Denton's. DOH! The business casual and not so casual hipoisie were lettin' loose. Chatting frantically between shots of this, sips of that and edibles. Great atmosphere for a post rugby celebration. Then we were kindly ushered to the back portion of Ozumo, where the restaurant actually is. The crowd is a mix of sophisticates, business travelers and a diverse group whose blood is at 32 degrees F..... well cool, not cold. "Shaken not stirred...grrrr."

The service is fantastic. The sushi even better. The bar makes a mean Mohito or  Caipirinha. The dinner menu is on the pricey side but well worth it. The sake is out of this world: especially Wakatake's Daiginjo "Onikoroshi" -scared my demons away for sure. 

4 duckets for bathroom Japanese lessons, minus 1 for the frat party out front.
author: Johnny C.

description:
Can you say pretentious?  This place is a serious throw back to the 80's.  I half expected to see girls in turqoise high heels and neon blazers doing coke in the bathroom.  Seriously.  The sashimi is excellent - very fresh and lucious -  but the entire menu is overpriced, the atmosphere is some sort of outdated "industrial chic," with lots of wood and glass, and the wait staff acts like you're dining in Boulevard or The French Laundry.  Please. Get over yourselves. 

 If you're into rubbing shoulders with  20-something-Marina-types looking for frou-frou cocktails and expensive sushi, then this is your place.  If not, I'd suggest going elsewhere.
author: Cara K.

description: 2 stars for great location.  Lunch was good but left feelng hungry.  They serve sooooo little.  Menu should list everything as an appetizer as portions are super small that would even leave a 3 year with a growling stomach.  :(
author: Seasbass A.

description:
Minus one star for screwing up Shabu Shabu.

I'm a whore for Shabu Shabu and I've been searching all over the U.S. for a proper version of this seemingly simple dish.  After Ozumo, I'm still looking.  Now why did they have to go and fuck this up?  Shabu Shabu is NOT supposed to be served with a miso broth, and where the hell is the sesame dipping sauce for the beef?!  Ponzu sauce is for the the veggies, not the meat.

Minus two stars for calling what they served me "Kobe" beef.  Whateva.  

Folks, it's not "Kobe" unless the cow was slaughtered IN Kobe Japan.  What I was served was on the low end of USDA prime and it was $42 for about 1/3 lb.

Oh yeah, good ambiance, hot chicks and all that stuff too...I'll be back, but not for the food.

P.S. Alexander's in Cupertino has real grade 12 Kobe for $200 a lb every once in a while.
author: Will H.

description:
Went here for drinks early on a Friday and it was paaacked. Somehow we waltzed up to a sweet table just as people were leaving. Nice! Ordered pinot grigio ($10/glass) and it was SO delicious I had three more glasses. $40 on wine! I'm a capitalist pig. 

Then, in our collective drunken stupor, we ordered some plates of food, which I don't really remember, except I know they were small. The bill came to $300 for four people I think. Stupid pinot grigio. Made me spend all my money on weird quasi-sushi.
author: Ella c.

description:
I pondered giving this place 4 stars but considering tonight will be the third time I've had it this week, I s'pose I should give it 5 stars.

The sushi here is outstanding, top notch, first rate, etc. Definitely some of the best sushi in SF. Fresh as can be and creative. 

Pros
- BEST EDAMAME I'VE EVER EATEN. Its pan fried with roasted garlic and soy sauce. Incredible!
- Sushi some of the freshest and best in SF
- The guy at the front reminds me of Bear Grylls. Totally handsome.
- Nice, tentative yet non-pushy staff
- I often look like crap (casual, hair cleanliness questionable) when I go in there yet they still treat me nicely
- Very large menus - large kitchen menu, large sushi menu, large alcoholic beverage menu

Cons
- They screw you on the specials! Of course they don't tell you the price and I picked a special roll. That roll added $18 to my otherwise $28 bill.
- The front smells like spoiled eggs (??)
- Expensive
- The crowd is uppity, I prefer down home trash types.

My girlfriend is visiting from LA and I'm taking her here tonight.
author: Chrissy Q.

description:
Ate here last night and the food and service were very good.

On the other hand it's definitely an OPM place (other people's money). I was there at the guest of a company and so enjoyed the evening but if I'd been picking up the tab I'd have been very pissed off - I like a kiss and a cuddle when I get fucked, not a bill.

This is a very, very expensive place. The $200 bottle of sake tasted worse than the $50 one and the waiter was constantly on the upsell. That said the food was good, although I'm not sure how Japanese lamb chops are. 

All in all OK, but not worth the money.
author: Iain T.

description:
Concerned you're not spending enough on a glass of wine? Disgusted that the price of sushi has plummeted so precipitously over the last few years that it has become the dinner of choice for commoners? 

Well, you are in luck. Ozumo is just the place for you. You can go there, feel instantly hipper the moment you walk into their sexy, trendy space (particularly if you're not at all hip to begin with), bask in their v flattering lighting, and eat generally excellent sushi for entirely too much money, accompanied by generous pours of lovely, overpriced wine. For example, I enjoyed a hefty pour of Cloudy Bay Sauvignon Blanc (yeah, I know, that was so 5 yrs ago, but it's so good), for only $17/ glass. Delighted at the bargain, I ordered a second round. 

And the sashimi "martini" was definitely priced in the double-digits, but man was it delicious. Buttery, creamy, huge pieces of raw everything, even tuna belly. And hell, I wasn't paying.  (Even the dessert was yummy, although there was some dubious attempt to incorporate wasabi into a chocolate concoction. No, no, no.)

Bring on the expense accounts, sugar daddies, and travelers riding high on the decline of the dollar.  Friends with money: This is your go-to-dining spot.
author: Kathleen G.

description: Super sushi, top quality and freshness. Recommend the beef tartare with quail egg from the robata menu. It was out of this world! Rolls are small (it would have taken 5 or 6 to fill me up!) but good. Amazing (but pricey) sake menu. We asked our server for a recommendation on sake, since there were so many, and she did not lead us astray. I don't remember which one we ordered, but it was sooooo good. Gorgeous interior.
author: Anastasia B.

description: This place is absolutely amazing! Seriously the service was amazing we felt like kings! The food was so delicious and fresh!! Gabriel was our waiter and did a fantastic job! Knew so much about the sushi we ate, and explained each entrée. Roger was the chef that prepared all our meal and even came over a few times to ask how we were if we liked the food etc. All in all thus place was amazing definitely my favorite.
author: Julia L.

description:
Ozumo, Ozumo, Ozumo. I would give you 5 stars but I have had some random fishy bites.

Excellent Hanabi and Black Cod.

Would definitely suggest putting the air on a bit more - everytime I've been its hot and humid inside.

Overall great place, great sushi, great location, bad parking! : )
author: Lauren F.

description:
I've been here three times most recently for a company paid event for several people so I was able to sample quite a few items at once.  In general, great quality of food and good service but the price is a bit over the top for a regular lunch.  It's easily $40pp for lunch.  I think it's pretty much the same price for sushi/sashimi at dinner.  

For those prices, I had assumed that the service would be better than it was.  I was meeting a party here once and thought I was the first one to arrive.  I checked in and told them I was with the party in the party room and would wait at the bar area.  When I got tired of waiting and called another member of the party, it turned out that they had been waiting in the room the entire time which the hostess had neglected to tell me as I waited for 15 minutes.  

Back to the food, the sashimi was really fresh and great!  The tuna tataki was amazing as well.  Even the edamame was much better than I could ever make at home.  Everyone seemed to enjoy their food quite a bit.  The one thing I wanted to try that I didn't get a chance to was the ramen.  Overall a pretty good experience but I realized afterwards that it was not so special that I was looking forward to the next time I go back so... I would say three stars taking into account price and four stars on a corporate budget!
author: Susan L.

description:
Kobe beef shabu shabu. Every time I come here I get this. And I always want more and I want to come back the next day. I can't describe how good it is. I'll just give up now. get there and get it.
Oh! but don't only get that. the grilled veggies are good. and yea, the sushi is good. really good. i really shouldn't write this when i'm hungry. 
great sake collection, too. and pretty to boot.
author: Margie L.

description:
I'm counting the days until I can go back to this place.  SO GOOD.

My GFs and I went there on the first night of a girls spa weekend.  It totally set the tone for the trip:  modern, sleek decor with potent nigori and to die for dishes.  I'm sure my friends are sick of me saying this but their garlic edamame should be banned for being so knee slapping tastey.  Load up on it, I don't care if you're on a date - it's a guaranteed orgasm.

Everything from their simple hamachi sushi to their must-have hanabi, futabo and tanabata were to die for.  So fresh, so flavorful.  I'd love to try every single item on the menu, esecially thir omakase.  Strong drinks and sake.  We had excellent service from the bar and waiters.  The restaurant itself is huge for a sushi joint.

The place definitely isn't a secret as evidenced by how packed it was for a 6:30p reservation and by the fact that Ozumo has come in random conversation by friends of mine all over the country.  If you're in the part of SF, it would be a disservice to yourself to not give it a try.
author: Joy P.

description:
Went with my in-laws who were visiting from Atlanta with the nephew (he's two).  We made reservations (it was a group of 10 + kid) and the hostesses were so friendly I thought I was in the twilight zone.  We were put in the sake room (the walls were glass with sake bottles and it did not cost us extra nor was there a minimum).

This place is GREAT for kids.  It is just loud enough that a noisy two year old goes unnoticed but still quiet enough for the adults to talk to each other.

Food was great.  We did order the special but we asked the price first and even though the roll was $20 we ordered another two!  It was that good.  Two people did not want to eat sushi so they ordered gyu-kakuni and wahu gyu.  They loved it!  The wahu gyu was like $50 but he thought it was that good.  It is great to find a Japanese restaurant serving more then teriyaki and tempura as an alternative to sushi and sashimi.  The Dohyo was so good we had to order more so the entire table could have a taste.  The food is expensive but it is worth it.

The service was excellent.  They refilled our drinks promptly, the server was quick, friendly but not intrusive, and he checked on us to make sure there was nothing else we needed.  They even took special orders for the kid.  My nephew wanted to eat avocado with his edamame so they brought him an avocado from the sushi bar sliced up to look like a flower or something.  He was delighted.  They charged us for it but we weren't expecting anything for free.  Our server was totally accommodating and friendly.

It was the best dinner experience with a large group and the kid.  It was so good that we went back later in week instead of going to another restaurant as planned.
author: Angela A.

description:
Really nice atmosphere - trendy, bright, clean.  It's a great place to take clients - moderate noise level...just enough to cover-up any awkward silences, but not too loud so that you can't hear what the person right across from you is saying.

Everything we ordered was fantastic.  Super fresh sushi, with cuts that are hard to find at other places.  I also liked how we didn't have to choose anything - we just asked our server to put together an assortment of fish, and they were able to accommodate (kind of like omakase, but just one course of sushi).

All of the cooked dishes were good as well - the beef dishes were very tender and well flavored.  Also, don't overlook the vegetables!  The robata style mushrooms and the purple yams were some of my favorite dishes.

Overall, very good service and great food - I'll definitely be back.
author: Anna H.

description: Emailed Heather shortly after she commented on my review however I have never heard back.
author: Jennifer And Uri W.

description:
One Word: EXPENSIVE

Don't get me wrong, Ozumo has good food.  The fish is fresh and the quality is good, but you're gonna pay for it.  

I like sushi.  I eat an OK amount of it and I've tried a decent amount of sushi restaurants.  The quality of fish found at Ozumo can be found at much less expensive sushi restaurants.  What you're paying for here is atmosphere, service and "innovation."  

Atmosphere - Ozumo is a trendy place.  Bring a date here if you want to splurge a little.  The bar is always full.  The interior dining area is not.

Service - Our server was very attentive - to the point of overly so.  He was very good about filling up our water glasses, but he would also reshuffle our plates and practically reorganize our table while we were still eating.  Attentive - yes...borderline annoying...yes

Food - the quality was good.  I wouldn't say it was the best sushi I've ever had, nor was it the most creative, but it was above average.  The saki was good.  But for $150 bottle, it had better be DAMN good..hehe

Would I go back to Ozumo?  Probably not.
author: Johnny C.

description: The food is really good here and the ambience is cool, BUT very expensive and very small portions. Our bill here every time is around $300, and hungry an hour later. :(
author: S G.

description: I had lunch here a few days ago.  Anyway the food was good but it's very pricey!  They charged us $6 for tea --- talk about overpriced.  I had  bento box (salmon teriyaki and tempura)  and ordered the scallop roll.  The bento was OK but the scallop roll was delish.  Cute place but very overpriced.  My friend and I spent $85 for lunch....for bento boxes and dessert.  In my opinion that's way too much $ for lunch.  We didn't even have alcohol.
author: Christine P.

description:
Very consistent sushi, great sake selection, mmmmm!

Ambiance=$$$$$$, unless you dine in the Kotatsu room or sake tasting room (there is a minimum you have to spend even if the rooms are available) , no mmmmm!
author: Aaron I.

description:
So expensive and not worth the money!

Connie M. and I came here a few months ago, and despite knowing one of the managers and getting a hook up, I still did not think our $80 tab was satisfying nor filling enough, or worth a second visit.

I honestly cannot remember a single dish we had here.  I guess that proves how unmemorable this place is to me.  We even ordered some of the manager's recommendations, but I guess it wasn't that good given that I can't remember.  I'm even looking at their menu online and am drawing a blank!

The 2 stars go to the impeccable service (it better be impeccable for the $$$$$ you'll be paying when you go there) and a decent happy hour.  Not the greatest in terms of prices and food selection, but it's a nice place to hang out after work.
author: Diane L.

description:
Ozumo is a good - albeit expensive - lunch spot since it's close enough to work and presumably has quality fish. It's also big enough that you can drop in and sit quickly or make reservations just before you leave the office, so no need to wait or plan ahead. 

Good sushi & other japanese food, great views of the Bay, but a bit pricey.
author: Mary C.

description:
Previously working in the financial district, I used to hit up all the restaurants along the Emarcadero for happy hours, business lunches, or just nice dinners.  Of the multitude of places, one of my favorites was Ozumo.  With a dim trendy decor, plenty of tables (including areas with tatami mats), and the ability to sit at a sushi bar, order robata grilled items, or have a drink at the sake lounge area (they also serve wine, beer, and spirits as well), this place has it all.

The sushi here is the freshest I have ever had.  Like butter in my mouth, the pieces of toro and hamachi melted the moment they left my chopsticks.  For rolls, I really enjoyed the savory Ozumo roll (unagi + cucumber topped with snow crab, avocado, tuna, and spicy sauce).  The spicy sauce was more tasty than spicy and the biggest contributor to the "you can't eat just one" mentality that developed during my dining experience here.

Although Ozumo is quite pricey, I will definitely be back.  Probably more times as a happy hour spot, rather than a dinner place.
author: Herman N.

description:
I've had lunch here on several occasions and have always been impressed... fresh sushi, attentive wait staff, modern decor (although it does take some time between courses... 

I finally went here for dinner Friday nite and was shocked to see how different it was from the daytime: they have a busy HH (the line at The Americano now is a JOKE), DJ and outside dining... prices are slightly higher than lunch and yes overall the prices are on the higher side. 

It's a large modern space and they even have a private dining area for a party of 8 enclosed with glass shelves holding huge bottles of sake, but it's still a part of the main dining room so you don't feel like you're away from everything.

I enjoyed my time there and will definitely return!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
I went to Ozumo for dinner with my fiance recently and I enjoyed myself a lot.  The service was great and the sushi chef that we were seated next to was so nice.  We decided to try a few of the small plates and an entree. The marinated black cod was very good, and we also had the ceviche and the fried calamari (I don't know why my fiance keeps ordering fried calamari everywhere, it was good, but you can get cheaper calamari).  The ceviche was just okay for me, but my fiance liked it.

I loved the view from the sushi bar.  You can see the water and the Bay Bridge.  We also saw Mos Def dining there (just had to throw that in! By the way, he's really nice.) 

I would take a star away for the price, but it's SF on the water, so it's kind of expected.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I chose Ozumo as THE restaurant to treat our parents after our wedding ceremony and for the in-laws to meet and mingle.  So my expectations were very high (probably more so on myself than on the restaurant.)  We booked the beautiful Kotatsu room months in advance and were eager to find out how the families feel about this restaurant.

Kotatsu room seats 12 people comfortably.  The space is pretty and fun and secluded.  However, the walls are not completely enclosed so the loud techno music from the bar will overpower the whole room.  You sit on the ground level but your feet dip into the trough below the table so you appear siting Japanese style, but really you are sitting on a bench comfortably.  The two kids with us were ecstatic about the room.  They have enough space to run around or lay down and the music only fuels their already every-growing energy.  The only inconvenience, besides not able to converse quietly, is that it's hard for the wait staff to squeeze in behind you to serve you.  I feel bad for their backs, but they were attentive and didn't seem to mind crawling back and forth.

Personally, I didn't care for the food so much.  About half of us had the Omakase menu, which I had been salivating for a while.  But it was only alright.  Plating, flavor, and choice of ingredients were not as refined or as interesting as other more authentic Japanese restaurants I have been to.  But after all, this is a trendy hip environment catered to Happy Hour folks with a fat business expense account.  Not exactly the type of place that encourages you to close your eyes and slowly savor the details of the dishes in serenity. 

For us who had the Omakase menu, We had miso soup with chunks of crab meat, a hamachi appetizer, lamb cubes on a skewer, grilled salmon, a plate of sushi and sashimi, giant scallop on a bed of risotto, beef, and a pretty plate of fruit/mochi with chocolate fondue.  It's an enormous amount of food but none really that memorable.  

Some who opted for a la carte menu had the kobe beef, which was so good that they exclaimed they'll be dreaming about it for years to come.  Sounds like it was worth the $105 price tag.  

With some miscellaneous stuff like rice, one cocktail, a pot of tea, and endless bottles of Voss water, the tab was an astonishing $1500 including tax and tips.  So if you ever worry about not able to meet the $1000 requirement for the room, I don't think it'll be a problem.  

Overall, the experience was very enjoyable.  We were able to get seated way before our reservation time and never felt rushed to leave.  Ozumo is able to please many different palates and personalities and ages, including people who don't even like Japanese food.  I highly recommend it for a special occasion for a group of people with diverse taste.
author: Candice B.

description:
I dined here because my company's work related event.  Would I come back on my own pocket? ... Possibly not.

It's a trendy, hip place to dine at!  And you'll love your servers.  They are highly trained and attentive to your needs.
author: Kioko O.

description:
Again, REALLY good my office paid for this (thank you office!)

Went on my birthday for lunch and have to say it was good - ambiance etc, but not crazy good - worth that much money.  
Service was typical sushi - everyone got their food at different times.  The service was good, but again, nothing out of the ordinary for a sushi place.  At one point one of the servers was turning away with empty beer bottles, having to be asked for refills.

I will say the mushroom salad - to die for & sizable!
Sashimi was very good - agree with previous reviewer(s) expecting more diversion from the standard ameri-shi rolls.
Also, VERY thoughtful - they brought a complimentary dessert.

I would go again maybe for happy hour, but not drop those kind of dollars on a full meal.
author: laura g.

description:
Had dinner here last night for a farewell dinner.. FOR ME!! 

Food is pretty pricey, but it's not bad at the same time. We had our waiter order our food so we had no idea what was coming. The best part of the meal was the Lamb Chops which was very yummy!

This is really a place you'd go for dates and client dinners. This is where you go if you're trying to make an impression. Otherwise, if you want good food just for you and your friends go elsewhere save yourself some money.
author: Paul G.

description:
Good sushi---Not the most fresh I have had. Amazing Sake. Great Atmosphere and great service but expensive.

This is a great date spot for those awkward first dates when you fear you may run out of things to say.  Also great Happy Hour spot.
author: Krystle M.

description:
For all the haters who said there are no good looking men and women in San Francisco, I ask you to have dinner at Ozumo! Enjoy a great looking crowd, a DJ who spins on weekends, and some of the best sushi San Francisco has to offer. The presentation is wonderful and service is great. This place is ideal for large groups or intimate dates. 

It's a bit pricier than the token sushi joint in the Marina, but let's face it: you're also paying for the ambiance along with the raw fish. I don't mind paying more if it means I don't have to dine amidst Barbie and Ken clones.

Ozumo serves a great seaweed salad with 3 different types of seaweed! Their sashimi is delectable! The sake we had (forgot the name) was the smoothest I've tasted. Again, a pricey sushi restaurant but definitely worth a trip for special occasions.
author: Lara D.

description: Pricey? Maybe, but the sushi is good and the atmosphere feels chic and warm. Lots of different things to try and some really beautiful specialty rolls. Worth a shot and super close for a lunch or after-work drink in FiDi.
author: A H.

description:
One of my three most favorite Japanese restaurant in SF! 

Love the food but wish it was slightly more affordable to go on a daily basis.
author: Lisa S.

description:
I could not have been more underwhelmed with this place.  I was staying at the Harbor Court Hotel next door and this was the closest option for sushi so we decided to check it out one night.  It looked cool enough from the outside, but once we went inside things went downhill.  

Although it was a Monday night and nearly empty, the host wouldn't seat us in the dining room because there were only two of us and supposedly the dining room tables were for parties of 6.  So we ended up sitting at a lounge table in the bar.  In front of the DJ booth.  Not exactly the relaxing dinner I had in mind.  

The service and sushi were all very unmemorable but I do recall the bill being quite high.  Save your money and eat somewhere better.
author: Kelly R.

description:
My boyfriend brought me to Ozumo for my 21st birthday dinner. As soon as I walked through the door, all I could think about is how there were SO many white people and so few asians (if that's any measure of how good a Japanese restaurant might be). Boyfriend said that it would be a popular restaurant for the wives from that show Real Housewives of Orange County. 

The food was good, but not $100/pp good by any means. It was my first time being served sushi and Japanese food by a 6-foot-something leggy blonde girl. 

A bowl of rice does not accompany entrees.
author: Amy D.

description:
Happy Hour = fantabulous. 

Dirty Martinis = hanger dirty. All of the bartenders know how to make a good one, and it's tough to do with a discerning palette. 

Happy Hour specials = eh, but you are in the fancy shmancy part of town, so what can you expect?

For business dinner = 5 stars... perfect place to take a coworker and wow them with the sun setting behind the hills of the Bay Bridge. it's just an amazing view and I am in awe everytime I see it.

Sushi Bar = great place to sit and eat. The chefs know what's fresh and they aren't afraid to tell you when something else is better. Recommendations have always been stellar.

Sake = YUMM-o (squared). Great selection. Even better is that the bartenders and servers really know the menu inside and out. If you tell them the general type of sake you enjoy, they will recommend something fantastic, guaranteed.

Servers = very attentive and knew when to leave you be.

All in all, great place for dinner. 4 stars for value. 5 stars for ambiance. 5 stars for service. 4 stars for the yuppies that like to hang out there and crowd the bar. 

Thanks Ozumo! I shall be back!
author: Annie T.

description:
Fancy schmancy sushi - check.
Servers dressed in black - check.
Good looking patrons - check. 
Long wait - check.
Extensive bar menu - check. 
Tredy decor - check.

Yes. Ozumo is another trendy and modern hotspot for Japanese cuisine. Not sure how the place is at night since I came for lunch, but its dark interior at the bar area seems like a sexy place to see and be seen. Noise level is ridiculously high. Half of the time I was going, "huh? what did you say?". Server was trying to act cute but no, sorry, you're not that cute. Food was good - fresh sashimi, innovative menu, but my kobe beef burger was rough! My cow must have put up a fight...
author: Nancie T.

description: Best sushi, hands down! The tuna tartare app is amazing. In fact, it was hard to share. The lobster roll was delicious and paired nicely with Duckhorn Sauvignon Blanc. If I lived here, I would definitely be broke because it is expensive, but totally worth it. Oh, and make sure you have a great concierge or make reservations well in advance because in order for us to get a table, we had to promise to be out of there by 7pm (and they reminded us of that). To sum it up, it's a fantastic place that you must try.
author: Regan M.

description:
I had the nerve to show up here last night in jeans, v-neck t-shirt, and faded chuck taylor sneakers...my uniform pretty much. felt VERY out of place.

great food, decently priced for what it's worth...the environent wasn't really me...not too big on the upscale sushi scene just yet, but hey...I'd wear a dress shirt for this place.
author: Trav M.

description:
Went here for appetizers and drinks after work with my company CEO and other fellow employees...AMAZING!!! 

We sat in the front, by the bar area (susper spacious), which was really nice and not crowded.  Its seperated from the main dining room so you dont feel like everyone'es on top of eachother - also gives you a chance to enjoy the decor - very sleek.  

So fried calamari is usually really good at most nice restaurants - as is most fried food - but the calamari here was quite expetional.  It seriously melted like butter in your mouth!  YUMMM 

They have an amazing Sake list and very creative cocktails - that are pretty weak in the alcohol department.  I would say it would take two to give me even a tiny buzz and im a light weight.  

Anyways all the food we had was awesome and the drinks great (if a little weak, but i guess thats good so no one embaressed themselves infront of the boss) - maybe its our own little nobu in the heart of San Fran
author: Daniella K.

description:
Sushi was mediocre. Portions small. 
Way too noisy inside.
Seating not very comfortable.
Decor nice, but not sure if I'm a fan.

Good to experience once, thanks....
author: D T.

description: Boyfriend took me here for my birthday since i LOVE sushi. Had a reservation, but somehow still had to sit at the bar and wait for a table (hrm..maybe that's just their strategy) The food was good and service ok, took forever for our server to come to our table though.
author: Anh P.

description:
The service here is outstanding. I came with every waiter's nightmare - a group of ten people who were loud, somewhat drunk, late for their reservation, in and out at all different times, and ordering pretty much one of everything. Despite all of that they took great care of us. We had a great table in the back with a beautiful view of the bay bridge. It was the perfect choice for a large group.

The sushi is really fresh, but strangely, what stood out in my mind was the dessert - this chocolate fondue that was seriously amazing. A strange thing to order at a sushi place, I admit, but it was delicious.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
Make reservations before you go or you have to turn on your vulture senses to try your luck for a table in the lounge.  The food and service were excellent.  I loved every dish.  Garlic soy edamame, futago (grilled wushu beef), hanabi (yellowtail/avocado) and all the sushi rolls were delicious.  The sah-kay menu was impressive and tasty.  

However, the only problem is that this place is definitely not for the financially disadvantaged.   This place is so expensive you might be expected to put out after dinner.
author: Christina C.

description:
Average, overpriced sushi: 
Not-so-fresh tasting ingredients; I've had better at half the price.

Horrible, unfriendly, service: 
We watched our drinks sit and melt at the bar for at least ten minutes before our server decided to mosey over to the bar and even begin thinking about bringing them to our table.  Obviously we were an inconvenience.

Oh, PS...it wasn't busy...it was a Tuesday night.

Three stars because I can't give 2 /12 and I am feeling too generous to give two.
author: Beth G.

description:
Excuse me! Those were the words I echoed most of the night while dining at Ozumo. 

We arrived early for a friends bday party. The plan was to get drinks before everyone arrived and then get seated. We had made reservations and it was starting to get busy. 

When you walk in to the sushi restaurant, the area is lit dimly with a small area for the bar. We mingled in the area but it began to fill up by 8pm. Our waitress was very slow and hardly took the time to come check on us or get our orders. Once we did get the drinks..they were overpriced and crazy weak. 

Once the party had arrived, we began to get seated. The waiter came up and seemed to be out of it..literally. He couldnt focus and we kept giving him our orders and he couldnt understand us. Not because the place was loud, he kept checking out women walking by. I understand he has carnal needs but focus on us when we will be tipping you. 

We all placed our orders. We each ordered 2-3 apps each. He began bringing out food in odd amounts. Several people only got one of the apps that had been ordered. We waited 30 minutes..literally..before he came back.  We told the server and there was no apology. He didnt say why our order never came but he just didnt charge us like it was acceptable. It was a friends bday and she didnt even get the apps that were ordered for her. 

We went to pay and the waiter just dropped the check. Not asking if we wanted to pay seperately or if we wanted more drinks...nothing. 

I was very disappointed. We had been planning all week on having a great time and it was a horrible mess. You might want to go by Ozumo for the atmosphere but not the food, drinks, or prices.
author: Adam B.

description:
If you're willing to drop some major coin and you really love and appreciate sushi and fine cocktails, Ozumo is the place to go. The food is to die for, so incredibly fresh and delicious. You will find yourself in a chop stick battle over the last piece of salmon sashimi or handcrafted roll.

The views of the bay and bridge are stunning...very romantic. It's really expensive but worth the splurge. Make reservations unless you're heading in during the late afternoon.

The only bummer about Ozumo is that Jesse, the cute bar manager, no longer works there...sigh...As a former mixologist myself, I must recommend his Lychee martini ;-).
author: Lynsey C.

description:
Just had dinner for two @ Ozumo. We had walked past it and it had seemed like it would make for a cool dinner. Perplexingly they had to check if they had any seats because we didn't have a reservation, but it looked like they had plenty when we were seated. 

The biggest thing about Ozumo is that you are definitely paying only mostly for the interior "feel" of the place. It is definitely overpriced. We had ordered some spinach, Gyu Filet and the Shabu Shabu Hot Pot. Being Asian; the Shabu Shabu Hot pot was probably the worst dish. Who's ever heard of Shabu Shabu served in a tiny bowl of overly salty broth over some weak coal? The worst thing about the Shabu Shabu was that the water wasn't boiling. We asked the waiter if that was part how it was supposed to work since our beef had been sitting in the broth uncooked in non-boiling water and he wasn't quite sure, but agreed that the water did seem a little too luke warm to cook food in it and brought it back into kitchen to heat up the broth up a little bit more.  The Gyu Filet was actually pretty decent, but overpriced.
We had Ginger Ice-Cream with Red Bean and Mochi for dessert, which was okay.

Our Waitress was slow. She may have been overworked, but it looked like the she had her eyes on people in suits ordering ridiculous amounts of sake (which the place appears to be famous for). 

Probably would not return. We spent 100 dollars + on a meal for two for relatively mediocre food. It seems like a good place to perhaps hang and chat, but if you're thinking about getting your bang for your buck in terms of food, you're high mistaken if you come here.
author: Seymour L.

description:
One for the money, two for the bitches
Three to get ready, and four to hit the switches.

something about this place keeps me from giving it 5 star, you will know when what I'm talking about when you get there (maybe you wont, fuck it). have a good time anyways.

Food is great consistently.
author: An u.

description:
My favorite place for $$ dinner in SF.

Great food, atmophere and service...just they make you pay for it. 

Related- to sushi restaurants  (out of 5 possible stars)
Venue- 5
Service- 5
Food factor- 5
Overall exp- 4 Stars  
Drawbacks-It is aweosme and probably my favorite restaurant in SF but  it really is a lil too expensive. Minus 1 star for $$.
author: C R.

description:
After tonight I have decide to take a break from the male species.  It is not the fault of Ozumo.

2 awesome girlfriends took me here for cocktails and suprised me with a bottle of  champange and great food for my bday.  It was one of those times when you have had it with everything in your life and realize there are still a few people that make all of the bs worthwhile.

This place has always had a fun crowd and can help get your mind off things.  After being dumped via a "phone call" from a 5 year relationship last week I was looking for lighthearted fun.  The incident of a 30 year old male asking me if I was done with my beef carparcio and sashami so he could eat my food was really the last straw.  Although I was quite full I took the most enormous bites of food I could shove in my mouth and stated I might even order more.

Clueless, he and loser pals looked suprised when we abruptly got up to leave.  They were suprised to find we were not planning on table top dancing and shots for the rest of the evening.

I have had it !  I normally love Ozumo- fantastic food!!  Future Yelp reviews will likely be on Netflix videos- taking a break.   Any good comedy recommendations besides my dating life???
author: rachel c.

description:
(BAR) 4 star
 
They focus wide selection of sake which includes premium import sake. I am happy to have sake bar in walking distance from my place even I live out of Japan. Two glasses of Denshu always make my day Friday night.
  
(Restaurant) 2.5 star

I've been there a couple of times to dine but have never been impressed with their food. Overall, it's pricey for quality. It's rediculous to pay $5 for plain miso soup and $34 for Gyudon. I don't know what's special in $34 Gydon as I never thought I wanna try the one, but I prefer to sit down at Yoshino-ya and have $5 Gyudon. Even in Financial DIstrict in San Francisco, their pricing is very aggresive.  
 
Eating at Sushi counter would be nice if you are served by a good chef. Once I ate at Sushi bar and they miscounted our sushi pieces, and they ended up to make our bill very cheap. Well, it means that their operation is not great... I've been careful to audit the bills when I eat here. =)
author: Yoko S.

description:
This is my favorite SF restaurant.  I frequent Ozumo's and I have yet to have a bad experience or a less than perfect dish.  Everything is soooo good.  I've tried things I've never tried before and loved every single thing, which is soooooo unlike me.  Did I fail to mention that they actually carry my favorite nigori sake?? That's rare.  You must have the summer snow and anything you order, you'll love.  The bar is nice too as it brings in a mixed swanky SF crowd.  

I HEART OZUMO!! THANK YOU! =-) hehehe

I'm hoping the Oakland location can live up to the SF location.
author: Alicia K.

description:
If you like to spend a lot of money this is the place for you! No item under $10, just the way sushi should be! Get ready to wait an hour to sit down and then another 20 minutes to place your order! 

To be fair, the financial district isn't really my scene, and this pretentious place is just the reason why.  I will say that they have quality fish, but they better, considering the price.
author: Anthony S.

description:
It's swanky, which is what I like about it, but not quite happy enough for me and my crew.  The food is a bit overpriced and the happy hour drinks (mostly vodka-based) were strong, but not particularly tasty to me.  

On the upside, the servers are pretty friendly and I do like it when the music isn't too loud to carry on a conversation.  There's a decent chance that if I came back in a few years I could really dig this place.
author: Krystle S.

description: Eh. Not happening again. A whopping $150 bill for some so-so sushi experience. I have had much better sushi experiences at other places, at a much more reasonable price. Using fancy words in the menu or putting fancy sauce strokes on a plate does not mean you hike up the price. And if you are looking for a fine dining Japanese cuisine, then I expect the quality and taste to be top notch (Chaya, it's neighbour, is a good example). But if I were to close my eyes and eat the sushi, I would think I'm having some Bento packaged sushi in your local grocery store. May be we ordered the wrong things? May be sushi is not Ozumos forte, as opposed to the fish steaks? I do not know. But then don't jack up the price to 23 bucks for a sushi roll with 4 pieces, cammman people! Not a satisfied client for the dough I paid. The only reason I give it 2 stars is because of their sake flight and their edemame.
author: Reema M.

description: Really impressive place, ended up eating here twice in one week.  Food and sake are as good as it gets!
author: Arin R.

description:
I've been here for lunch and dinner once each time... and I wasn't paying.

The food was great! The sushi is fresh and they have a wide selection of fish and rolls. But they also have many innovative sushi dishes and rolls. The Kobe beef was the best I've ever had. I could see why it's in the "Top 100 SF Restaurants." 

The service was good and the people are sweet. 

Definitely a good atmosphere place with beautiful decor. Very poshy if you're into that type of stuff.
author: Aromy X.

description: The fish was very fresh and delicious and I was able to try some things I had never eaten like black snapper, but the service was horrible. I sat at the sushi bar on a Sunday night and was basically ignored by the waitstaff for the entire meal. I had to beg any server that happened to walk by for water, a beer, chopsticks and napkin. After sitting there for 15 minutes, the sushi chef asked me what I'd like.  I told him a drink!. Ridiculous.
author: GA M.

description:
Flippin' amazing. I've been here over a dozen times - which averages out to my firstborn's college fund someday or a nicely equipped BMW 3 series. Its not cheap by any means, but if its quality, atmosphere, and sake you are in search of - this is the SF mecca. 

Fresh sashimi and nigiri - a wonderful selection of the basics that they exquisitely present. Options for those that don't do the raw bit are the hot pots and they offer a kick ass steak. Its a great combination to have the cold fish and the hot slab of meat. The filet was cooked tp perfection and came accompanied with a moist shitake mushroom sauce. 

Wine and sake list is more than adequate with a few exceptional choices of California wines. I recommend the Duckhorn Sauvignon Blanc if they have it. 

Professional service to top it off makes this a highly rated destination to wine and dine those that have a discerning palate. 

**If you are thinking about hosting an event - they have great private rooms** I notice that crap since its part of my job.
author: Stacy T.

description:
The dim lighting, stiff drinks, and plummy feel of this place makes it a prime happy hour spot if you're single and wanna mingle.  Totally a financial district twenty-something crowd hang out.  Girls, pay attention, I met my last rich older boyfriend here.  Besides the somewhat decent atmosphere, the sushi is to die for.  Very decorated sushi with a hybrid fusion flare.  I usually turn my nose up at inauthenticity, but I am fond of the dishes here.

However, it's a very striped-shirt scene and most of the people aren't that great looking.  Also be prepared to shell out $70 for a couple of drinks and one appetizer.
author: Renee K.

description:
Everyone I know thinks Ozumo's is overpriced for what you get, but I have been to Ozumo's about 8-9 times and the food has been consistently good.  True, you get pretty small portions, so if you are hungry I wouldn't go to Ozumo's unless you want to spend alot of money.  BUT...their food is GOOD!

Their Hanabi dish--yellowtail sashimi sliced thinly, drizzled with jalapeno sauce--is sooo good! Everytime I go there I order it and everyone loves it. The Futago- pieces of Washu beef delicately piled ontop of eggplant and spinach--is deelicious. I especially like the presentation of the dishes--like little individual napoleans piled delicately (they give you four).  Their washu beef "hot-pot" is also great--soft pieces of tender beef in a warm and slightly sweet miso-broth. Yum!

Service has always been nice, attentive, and quick. Nothing super special though.  Also, it is pretty loud inside the restaurant.

If you don't like fu-fu food then you won't like ozumo, and it is not a traditional japanese place. But if you like great fresh fish, innovative dishes, and lots of flavor--then Ozumo's is probably the best place in the Soma/Waterfront area to get Japanese-ish food.
author: amy k.

description:
Tonight was our first time at Ozumo and it was amazing!  Service is some of the best that I've experienced in San Francisco.  Our server Aimee was knowledgeable, attentive and had a great attitude.  I don't mind paying more for excellent service like this!

The uni risotto was DELICIOUS!  We'll be back just for this dish.  The japanese saba and suzuki (sea bass) sushi was melt-in-your-mouth.  The grilled unagi on the robata was not as great - I liked the crunch, but it was a bit dry.
author: Tone C.

description: I have to admit...I love Ozumo.  Lychee martinis, shabu shabu, and their Hamachi app is one of my faves.  The prices could be better but I do love having dinner here.
author: nicole s.

description: Good for environment and drinks... usual happy hour place and maybe stay for some sushi.
author: Scott C.

description:
This is right around the corner from my office, so naturally, it's the place I go with business folk.  It's good for that, since it seems everyone else who dines there is doing the same thing I am.  This wouldn't be a place I would think of when I'm romanticizing the perfect place for a lovey dovey dinner.  I like that they play language tapes in the restrooms - however, I'm not sure I'd remember what I learned in that 3 minutes. 

A great lunch spot if you're in the financial district for a power lunch!  Decent sushi and bento boxes, fast and friendly service and did I mention loads of sake?
author: Freckles D.

description: Ozumo gets my vote for the all-round best Japanese restaurant in all of San Francisco.  I've been 6 times now, and each time, the food, cocktails, ambiance, and service are all on point.  It's a chic and beautiful restaurant .....Thankssssss
author: Sanfrancisco O.

description:
Skip unless:
you're loaded and enjoy overpaying
- or -
someone else is paying and you dont mind them overpaying for the quality of food

We came to dinner here because I had a gift card, and I am always happy to try a different sushi place.

In the end, I was glad we were not paying for it. 

The hightlighs: 
*we had fun neighbors at the sushi bar who were kind enough to tell us what was good to order. 
*The service was very good and our server was knowledgeable. 

The other stuff:
*The food - good not great
1) Sashimi - we ordered the day's special ( kampachi i think) tiny pieces and not in the top 3 ive had in the city
2) Special Roll - very good but should be at that price
3) Meat grill ( cant remember which one). Good not great. The best part of this dish was the fun little condiments they serve with it. We heard that these types of dishes were the speciality of the house. ???
*The space itself is kinda cool and the bar looked sort of fun. Glad I was able to see it, not hurrying back by any means.
author: Christine B.

description: I was treated to dinner by a relative who swore by this place. The sushi is good. Not great, not OMG this is amazingly good, just good. Okay, the salmon belly was pretty great, but other than that, I've had better fish at smaller places with less attitude and "atmosphere." We had a sea bass dish, and an appetizer of beef served on spinach and cucumber which were both good. Again, not OMG this is SOOOO good, just good. The miso soup was way too salty, and I'm a salt freak. The service is very attentive, but so what if the food isn't stellar? You're paying way too much for the food here, I suppose because of the 90's Dot Com era atmosphere, but that is just annoying to me as a long-time San Francisco resident who remembers the fun days before the invasion. Not likely to go back, I'll be heading to Ariake for amazing sushi and a relaxed and cheerful atmosphere.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Ok...I am a hung over, but this is the place that did it to me, so I feel obligated to share my experience. 

This is a popular place for happy hour, conveniently located downtown. 

When you walk in there is a large bar area with plenty of seats around a square bar and smaller tables that ring the bar. There is a big wall of windows that opens to the street, so you get some natural light...and a little bit of the people watching factor. 

The dimly lit main dining room has a great view of the Bay. I would say it has date potential, but the restuarant is pretty lively and loud, so it's not exactly the coziest atmosphere. 

The crowd is mostly made up of hip dressed professionals. Probably from the many offices that are in the neighborhood. 

The food is basically contemporary Japanese. That means there is sushi...as well as some other interesting dishes. 

My favorite is the futago...which is basically a mini pile of beef and garlic spinach sitting on a piece of eggplant. All of it is covered in a Miso sauce. 

The sushi is also descent...and they have other dishes like mini hot pots. 

Did I mention the Sake? Yes...there is a decent selection...as my hurting head will attest to. 

Come for the happy hour, have some good Japanese food, then stay for the happy hour.
author: Stephen L.

description: What a wonderful dining experience!  Pricey sushi served with panache in a brightly illuminated dining room full of blond wood.  This restaurant served the best tasting raw tuna appetizer as well as a lovely soft shell crab roll.  Go hungry and forget that you will eventually have to pay the bill. Be aware:  There was a real delay in getting seated though we had reservations.
author: Lynn S.

description: I went here on my birthday sushi crawl. The Lobster roll we had was awesome. I cant wait to go back and try more food. I don't recall the second roll we had but I know I'll be back soon for more. Their green tea was really good and as an added bonus Willie Brown was hanging out there also. So i know their other food is going to be good.
author: Kameelah R.

description:
Overhyped, overrated, overpriced, overit. 

Possibly a bit dramatic, but I was expecting really good things. The staff were all quite cool and the ambiance was sweet, but the sushi wasn't anything to write home about. Yesterday when we went, they were featuring the new updated menu (first day), so not sure what to make of that, but I wasn't overly impressed. 

We ate pretty much everything they had to offer (seriously - no joke) on the sushi menu and they don't rank in my top ten by any means. Tried the YamaKake (maguro, mountain yam and quail egg) outside the sushi menu and I usually love this dish, but the raw quail egg killed it - just made it slimy like someone spit in it when mixed with the yam.

My guess is they are now targeting the upscale and trendy Japanese food more than the sushi going forward. Focus on hotpots, organic meats and what not. May go back to try the non-sushi fare, but only if someone else is paying.
author: Mike C.

description: Love this place! A friend and I went after work and it was great sushi. The spicy tuna just melts in your mouth. The atmosphere is cool, the view is awesome, but this place can be pricey. Thankfully we split the bill so that helped. If you plan on taking a date here, be ready to drop at least a hundred. If it wasn't so expensive I would have given it 5 stars. On the other hand its SF so it's expected. Def gotta try this place at least once if you love sushi.
author: T H.

description: Sushi was somewhat average. Way to expensive, I would have been upset if I wasn't on the expense account. Restaurant environment is cool though. Would rather try another sushi restaurant next time I am in SFO instead of paying $15 a roll
author: Matt B.

description:
A great experience - We dined as Ozumo on 4/30/2010 and the experience was pleasant. The hostess was very helpful when we called to make reservations and also upon arrival. The restaurant is very "hip" and clean and their sake selection amazing. 

My wife and I took my mother for an "upscale" sushi experience and we are pleased to report that Ozumo managed to convert her into a sushi believer. The Toro did it, she was still talking about it the following day. 

We highly recommend Ozumo and when in S.F. we will make it a point to relive the pleasant experience.
author: Lyon K.

description: Ozuma is a beautiful space   and  in San Francisco  the main room is golden and opens to a  spectacular  and romantic  sparkle of the bay bridge,,,  Both  The Ozumas  have  great fresh beautiful food and wonderful service ! And one can study Japanese in the restrooms with recorded phrases...
author: Claribel j.

description:
Read a good review about this place a while backand had been meaning to check it out.  Finally did...

My friend and I arrived a bit late for dinner.
Went to the back where the restaurant portion is and sat at the sushi bar.

I liked the ambiance of the front/bar area...looks like a nice spot for Happy Hour sometime.

We were hungry and experienced sushi lovers.

I wanted some miso soup and decided on the pumpkin miso soup because it sounded rather unique.  It was a sort of thick pumpkin miso porridge sprinkled with pistachios.  I enjoyed it but was very different for a miso soup.

Next...sushi/sashimi -
We ordered the Ama Ebi nigiri - It was very fresh.  However, we never go the deep fried ebi heads like you normally get.  We thought that our sushi chef may have forgotten and reminded him but he said that they don't do that here.  Humm...a bit odd.  Never heard that before...
In general, we felt the nirigi orders were fresh but a bit on the thin side.

Then, for sashimi, we order the 5-piece Toro.  It was fresh but disappointing.  The sashimi slices were almost paper thin; not chunky like we were used to.  Again....hummm....a bit odd.  Didn't feel like we got our money's worth with this order.

We wanted to have the spanish mackeral nigiri.  And the sushi chef suggested a different kind of mackeral which was very fresh and to our liking (forget the name of this fish).  We liked it enough to place another encore order of it.

The service was okay until we felt rushed at the end by our waitress who seemed to be ending her shift.  We didn't like that.  We hadn't been sitting for long.

Also, the sushi chef was very kind and entertaining.  However, our sushi order arrived a bit slower than what we are normally used to.  Not that we want to feel rushed to order more and more, but we were hungry and the pace was a bit slow.

So, at the end of the meal, we both felt that we were satisfied but not enough to come back for more sushi here.  I personally would like to try Happy Hour here sometime.  

In general, I think this is a place for someone with an expense account or if they are being treated.  Just too pricey for what you get!
author: Rebecca K.

description:
Last time I went here, I was with my boss (the fun type who says stuff like "That's how we roll") and a co-worker (looks like your average young father of three but he's a former UFC fighter).  I'll skip right ahead to 10am the next day when we all got into the office:

ME:  Dude, I have a massive bruise on my elbow and it hurts like hell to move my arm.  

UFC:  (Hysterical Laughter)  You don't remember playing tackle football with (BOSS) in the middle of Howard Street (with no football in sight) and taking out a whole rack of newspaper dispensers with the body of drunk (BOSS)?

ME:  (Hysterical Laughter) Sort of....

UFC:  Or when you asked the (obviously gay-date) couple next to us "Why aren't you pansies drinking?"

ME:  (Hysterical Laughter) I think so....

UFC:  Or when the restaurant manager came over because we were dropping to many F-Bombs and you scared him away with the statement "Don't even F____ with me!" because you were in the middle of a great story.

ME:  (Hysterical Laughter) No.

UFC:  I should be in the hospital right now...do you realize the three of us drank 6 bottles of extremely expensive sake?

ME:  Wow...I need to stop drinking for a while.

BOSS:  No you don't - I haven't had that much fun in a long time...That's how we roll!

Anyway, Ozumo is what you make of it.  It can be a great date spot as long as you're not sitting next to me, my boss and my ex-UFC co-worker fueled by $X,XXX.XX of raw fish & alcohol.  It can be fun for a (tame) happy hour.  And if you know your sushi, a delightful dining experience for a special occasion.  I have been going here about once/month but since I'm confident the Yakuza are looking for me, I'm taking a little break.
author: Ari G.

description:
Last night was the first time in over a year I visited Ozumo, and it has gotten exponentially better. Ozumo never did much for me previously, but after last night, can't wait to go back.

Loved the well-dressed, well-heeled crowd, loved the sleek decor, was satisfied by the decent (but not exceptional) cuisine, and really loved the Akatsuki - Ozumo's version of a pomegranate margarita. Pure yumminess.
author: Deb I.

description:
Ozumo's has a solid bar and lounge area.  I had a friend who use to DJ here and that was also nice.  Good tunes and great for after work and early evening drinks.  Haven't been in a while I think I will pay another visit soon.  

The seating can get tight when it gets packed but the vibe and atmosphere is good.
author: Moe J.

description: I had great memories here. My first time trying raw sushi and one of the best!
author: Aniko N.

description:
I'm surprised I have not yet written a review for this place.. Well here it is.  Some of the sushi rolls options are quite unique but the california rolls are not so good.  Spider rolls are good, but scallop is not.  There are lovely views in the back  but the sake "room" table gives you a bit of privacy.  My first time here, I enjoyed the sushi/rolls/appetizer plates.  Yet the more I went here, the more average the food seemed to be.  I do enjoy the sashimi though, guess you can't really go wrong with that.  

The bathrooms are kind of cool, if you consider Japanese language training as you use the facilities as cool.  First time I used this bathroom I got totally freaked out that someone was talking!  Then I realized that the voices were trying to teach me how to say useful Japanese phrases.  Pretty nice but random voices in a bathroom can make you jump (or at least I did).

It's definitely overpriced so I would never go here on my own and pay for it out of my own pocket.  I have heard some better reviews about some of their dinner options but unfortunately I have not been able to try it.  Oh well maybe next time.
author: Yosie G.

description:
Ladies and gents once again we have another place here that's solely focused on marketing and decor vs the food. They seem to have pulled it off successfully.

As you walk in, it's dark and posh. The waiters are NYC Madison Ave style. The portions are tiny and trendy looking but very tasty and expensive.

Good place to woo somebody. Make an impression on a client, girlfriend, guests...

Definitely not recommended as a go to type restaurant. 

Bottom line, there'll always be a clientele for these types of places and that's been pretty evident this last saturday because the place was almost full.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
Excellent food.  Strong, fun drinks.  Beautiful restaurant.  Beautiful (and attentive) waiters.  Mmmmm....

Oh, it is a bit pricey.  But it's worth it.  Well, I haven't been here in over a year, but if I had a job, I'd go more often.

***  Update ***

Went here for lunch the other day, and the staff wasn't as hot as I remembered (maybe it's just their evening staff?).  But we sat at the sushi bar and our sushi chef was super cool.  And one of the other sushi chefs was pretty hot.  

The food was great, as usual.  We had their sashimi-san platter, rainbow roll (I know it's so wrong, but I love it), garlicy edamame, butternut squash miso soup (with pistachios), and some salad with tofu.  All of it was fantastic.
author: S J.

description:
Went here on a date, and unlike many other yelpers here, found the service to fine. The lady was very friendly and helpful and gave her recommendations on what to order. I have never had the sushi or sashimi here (except the scallops), but I feel like for a place like this, it is probably better to try the omakase or the small plates since they're fun and creative if you want to get away from the usual japanese fare. The place is beautiful, with a clubby feel to it, but we had a small table for two in the back so the loud crowd in the front at the bar wasn't an issue.

Ordered a series of small plates and scallop sashimi. Ordered the Hanabi (hamachi with avocado and ginger/jalapeno sauce) which was really good. No complaints with the tuna tataki salad. Don't really remember what else was ordered besides the scallop sashimi (tasted kinda fish, not fresh and sweet) and the sampler of sake (which is fun to try, reading the cards as you taste the sake even though usually I couldn't taste anything that the cards said I should be tasting). I think the sake did me in.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
I really like coming to Ozumo.  It's a consistently loud, dark and fun setting, and a sceney place to grab a bite to eat without dealing with anything too obnoxious.
