In terms of the food, I love their sashimi and hot dishes.  I always order the same thing: the charcoal grilled filet mignon w shitake mushrooms, the hanabi small plate, and the sashimi martini (one of my favorites - yellowtail, tuna and salmon on seaweed).

Good atmosphere, okay service, great food and drinks!  Only downside (or upside, if you are so inclined) is you'll likely get hit on by some skeevy guy having a drink at the bar while trying to make eyes at you.  Avoid at all costs, especially as the drinks kick in!
author: Emily C.

description:
The Gindara - black cod marinated in saikyo miso and sake kasu - is a MUST!  Tender, juicy, and melts in your mouth.    

The entire dining experience is exceptionally excellent and so much fun that you almost forget about how expensive it is! 

Great date place and guaranteed a** by the end of the night or your money back!
author: Victoria F.

description:
Six of us went here for a business dinner.  We let the waitress order for us, and had a ton of great stuff, including a couple of kobe beef dishes, squid, toro, maguro, hamachi sashimi; some amazing maki that I don't even know what was in it: maguro and some black fish row; some lamb chops which were terrific; pan seared gigantic scallops on zucchini.  Accompanied by a nice (chilled) sake. 

Service was great, the ambiance was good: very clean/modern wood decor.

I'm sure the bill was crazy expensive, but the company picked up the tab, lucky us.
author: Bill O.

description:
Great place, very fun atmosphere, trendy decor. Loved the Bucho role! Looking forward to going back and trying several other items.

The only reason I give it a 3 stars is because I have yet to find a sushi restaurant in San Francisco that lives up to both Mirai in Chicago or Katsu-Ya in Studio City, CA
author: Jackie J.

description: Overall Ozumo would be a great restaurant if it was half to 2/3rds the price. What we normally get for $50 at other places (even in SoMa), cost us 100$ at Ozumo. Yes we should have read through the reviews before going. Save your money and go somewhere else for good sushi.
author: Erik H.

description:
Great sake list, great atmosphere, Nabe (hotpot) is the best food here. 
Willing to go back but I felt it's bit over priced..
author: Cindy N.

description:
I can't say enough about this place! They have a really attractive bar setup, and the restaurant is huge.  There's a great view of the bay, seeing as how the place is right on the embarcadero.  

The food was delicious. We had a large party, and ordered several different rolls and just passed them all around, so unfortunetaly I can't say exactly what we ordered, but there wasn't a dish that I didnt enjoy.  Even their edemame was great.

Later on in the meal, I took a quick trip to the restroom, and I may have had too much sake, but I could swear that there was a looped recording teaching me japanese phrases.  Not only did they serve up an great dinner, but they helped me get a little learn on as well. 

The service was excellent, and very attentive.  And we understood why as soon as we got the bill...which was pretty damn steep.  But even with me emptying my wallet and scraping out a few extra bucks from the emergency shoe stash, I'll definitely be back.
author: Charlie P.

description:
My friend brought me here for our first dinner together, and I fell in love...with the restaurant and maybe with her, too.  The atmosphere is upscale, cool, Japanese with low lights and soft house/trance type music setting the mood.  And yes, in the bathrooms there are Japanese language instructional tapes playing...pretty fun. 

The menu is fabulous and extensive with sushi, robata, exotic seafood plates, even some pedestrian chicken and beef selections (though I don't know why you would order that with the great seafood on the menu).  I don't drink much sake, so when I opened the drink menu and saw the dozens of sake selections I pleaded ignorant to our young, pretty blonde server.  She suggested several and then offered to bring three samples for us to try, free of charge.  How about that!

So we tasted and selected, while sipping a tasy miso soup and munching on edamame.  We ordered small plates of hamachi and tuna, both expertly prepared and delicious.  Wonderful food. 

We had a beautiful view of the bay bridge as twilight settled over the bay, and the food, the drink, and the atmosphere was simply entrancing.  I think I'm falling in love...but got to go back to LA tomorrow!
author: Steve G.

description: Delicious! Came here for a team dinner but someone ordered for me so I can't tell you exactly what I got but the service was great!
author: Daniela R.

description:
HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE SERVICE (if you eat/drink in the front open seating/bar area... not sure if you have reservations, it may be a different story).

i've been to ozumo twice.  the first time, we ordered some dishes that never came out, yet were charged on our bill.  i'll excuse them because it's very very busy on a friday night and i can see how something like that can happen.  besides, we brought it to the attention of the manager and he took off those items from the bill.  

aside from that, the wait staff is pretty slow.  like i mentioned above, either the food never comes out, or it comes out after a long time.  but whatever, what can you expect on a friday night?

the second time, my friend and i encountered a rude waitress.  we ordered the wrong thing and when it came out, we said we didn't want it.  and this was after we had already paid for it, because for some reason i guess this time around they decide to give us the bill before we even get our dishes.  anyways, i'd think that we can do whatever we want with the food that we've already paid for, right?  we can eat it, or not eat it.  maybe i'm a bitch but i just expect good service from a waitress at a trendy high end restaurant, no matter what the customer says or does.  the waitress gave us an attitude because we didn't want our dish and that was enough to piss me off.

otherwise... the food and drink is decent enough, i suppose. 

i think it's better to just go for drinks or something and not expect too much from the service...  i hate that place but may still go back because the last time we were there we met some cute guys.  :-)  i just hope that i won't run into that rude waitress.  :-/
author: Christy I.

description:
My problem here isn't the Sushi -- the sushi is great.  It's the prices.  Getting the bill here is like getting the bill at Costco: you feel like you chose wisely, everything you got was good, yet the bill is somehow 3 times what you thought it would be.

Other than that, I guess I would describe it as Mas Sake's east coast (of SF) brother.  Trendy scene, DJ/loungy music, crowded bar up front, and big restaurant in back that not everyone is aware even exists.  Oh, except the staff isn't as hot as the staff at Mas Sake.
author: Maneesh B.

description:
So I was eagerly awaiting the opportunity to come to this swanky restaurant on someone's expense account, and did last night.  We told the waiter to 'wow' us, and I wasn't too wowed.  This is no Matsuhisa (Beverly Hills), and the sushi, although good wasn't fantastic.

The much ballyhooed yellow tail came drenched in some soy mix that made it way too salty.  The tuna sashimi was cold and very firm--not unlike the way you get it at some cheaper Korean/Japanese restaurants.  The desserts, well, although good did nothing to really compliment the type of foods we had been eating, ie, it was too rich vs. palatte cleansing.

There were some good things, however...the white tuna sashimi was the right temperature and melted in your mouth.  Why the other tuna didn't do this remains a mystery.  We ordered a nigori, unfiltered sake to wash everything down--the bottle the waiter brought us was fantastic.  The sweetness of the nigori sake was the right compliment to saltiness of soy.

So, for the expense of the meal vs. what you get...it was overall disappointing.  Again, would of preferred to spend the same dough at Matsuhisa, whose food is sublime.  I think that LA and NYC has the best Japanese restaurants--more innovative and daring.  Still hopeful that there would be one here, though.
author: Nancy H.

description:
I decided to give Ozumo a try because I hung on to a shimmer of hope that it would surprise me with great food despite over priced japanese food (knownig that jap. food is already overpriced to begin with).  However, it ended up being what i feared, really expenisve japanese food, at small small proportions that failed to impress.  Service was also dissapointing, we got our food at very different times so half th etime we had our food and were waiting for our friends food to come.  I really would not reocmmend this place but if you really want to waste a lot of money on mediocre food, this is the place to be. 

Only thing i love about this place is the ambiance and bar.  It is really nice indeed.
author: Charles C.

description:
Let's call it what it is, an over-price upscale restaurant created to attract suit and tie crowds who look like extras from a restaurant scene in Sex and the City. But there is no denying, the food is delicious. Despite the small portions and confused servers, the miso-flavored fried calamari was so tender, it could and would melt in your mouth. 

With all restaurants, let's start with the critique of the food. We ordered the shacho which is the most expensive roll on the list, for 23 dollars, we got 6-8  pieces of lobster and tuna rolled up in a little petite package. As tasty as the spicy scallop roll. Both great and fresh, but quickly off the plates because it was that small. 
I felt cheated most when we ordered grilled asparagus, for 9 bucks we got two skewers of asparagus that equals two sticks. Like I previously mentioned, good but very, very small portions. 

Next, to review the service. Perhaps it was during dinner but twice they messed up on our order. The first one was to our benefit because we got a miso crap soup that was meant for the people sitting at the bar two seats down. The second time, they gave our food to the wrong person, actually to the guy who the soup was meant for. Yikes. 

Location. Our luck ran out because we had to pay 12 dollars to valet. After five minutes of circling the Embarcadero, it made more sense.
author: Thia T.

description: This place is really good, really expensive, but FANOM sushi.  Great for work events or something really special or something you can expense. The fish is so fresh, and the sake selection in incredible. If you like sushi, ball it up and go here.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: There's a thing called Kurobuta that they serve here.  It happens that the brussel sprouts are in season and combined with the pork, they have the perfect dish.  The meat is tender and juicy, the brussel sprouts are grilled or fried or something but whatever they did, the sprouts are crunchy and slightly bitter and paired with the fatty richness of the pork, every bite is unctuous and textured and amazing.  This is a memorable dish.  Stay away from the udon.  The miso cod was cooked perfectly, flaky and tender and oily.  Soo good.  Overall, this is a great place for dinner.  I am looking forward to my next visit.
author: n y.

description:
"Right. So I think I'd give this place 3 1/2 stars. I'll be honest, I don't get the concept of paying an arm and a leg for rice and raw fish. Before you judge me, yes I love sushi, yes I appreciate that there is a skill to cutting the fish but at the end of the day it takes skill to prepare any type of cuisine and most involve a lot more than steamed rice, raw fish, and some seaweed. Man, I'm all riled up, zen shreya zen.

Alright, back to Ozumo. The food is good, the decor is nice, and the service is fantastic. But I couldn't believe my date dropped almost $200 for raw fish (ok fine there was a fair amount of sake involved). Guess if you want to impress someone with the size of your wallet, take them here. Otherwise, there are better places to go in the city."
author: Shreya C.

description: While everyone at our table loved, loved, loved the food-I took off two stars.  We were seated quickly in the quieter back room and had a fantastic waitress, Natasha.  I have a non-life threatening gluten intolerance and she was super informed and helpful with the menu.  The problem was that the majority of our drinks and food was delivered by another lady, (not fantastic Natasha) who switched stuff up for every course.  First, our drink order was delivered all out of whack, but we easily switched them around.  No problem.  Then, we were all given an amuse bouche and I asked if it was gluten free.  She said half of it was so I ate the other half and it was delightful.  She came back a few minutes later to say it actually wasn't.  Since it was only the size of my fingernail, I wasn't too troubled by it.  However, my fantastic squid dish which should have been made with tamari instead of soy sauce, must have gotten mixed up with my husbands because I ended up with horrible joint pain by the end of the meal.  Unfortunate.  It wouldn't stop me from going back, but I am going to be EXTREMELY vigilant next time around.  I hope the waiters who serve the food get the extra training to rise to the same level as the waitstaff who actually take the order.
author: Shannon A.

description: Yum. This place is delicious. Hard to get a table, as there is usually a wait, but if you sit in the bar area for drinks and apps, it's pretty worth it. Definitely pricey, so make sure you're ready to pay. All the apps were delicious, and the drinks were creative and interesting.
author: D C.

description: It was my first time to Ozumo's and I loved it! I'm definitely going back.
author: Jennifer K.

description: I like their lunch.  I brought my mom and a friend there, and we had a good time.  The portions were pretty small though -- we had 2 appetizers, 2 lunch boxes, two rolls, and a dessert, and we were only medium full.  Total damage was around $130.  Good restaurant setting, and good service.  If I'm craving for Japanese lunch, will definitely come back here.
author: Elena L.

description: Ozumo is as close as you can get to yummy sushi and dining room ambience.  Otherwise you have to fly to Japan or Hong Kong at the very least for fine sushi dining.  I say this place is close enough to what I saw and learning from watching a Hong Kong television broadcast show, "the Rippling Blossom" where they describes the best sushi of the best.  They have the exotic choices you actually learn from the show.
author: Esme W.

description: Bland experience. I had my normal Macallan 12 as I waited for my date at the bar. Once she arrived, I had to pull one of the two bartenders in this small bar over after 5-7 minutes of staring them down. And they weren't even busy. A nice wine was suggested for her and we were off to our table. The Tuna Tartare was recommended by all and so we started with that. It was BLAND. Unfortunately this was the best thing we had all night. Next the Cuttle Fish was a special and it came out tough and ok as far as the flavor. So, like a bad better, I was chasing at this point and I ordered the signature roll. The Ozumo roll. I've had better Sushi at a 1/roll joint in LA, just saying. So, overall the experience was BLAND and my bill for two people was $35 at the bar, for two drinks, and $155 for the meal and a couple of drinks. Not worth it. I wasn't even that impressive and atmosphere for a date either. Pretty un-extraordinary.
author: Brian A.

description:
Those stars are for the food and the people. Another biased review, but the food actually is really good and they have a pretty extensive sake list. It doesn't hurt to know the managers and staff because the restaurant gets pretty crazy hectic on Fridays (and probably every other day of the week). I don't know if they still don't have an air conditioner, but a $7 million restaurant should have one...because no one likes a stuffy lounge/restaurant. 

Good for financial district lunch.
Try the kaiso seaweed salad for a different salad.
Their fish is very fresh and pretty much melts in your mouth.

Go ahead...try it.

(But they're pretty pricey too...$6 for green tea!?)
author: Maureen B.

description: First impressions of restaurant-Blaring disco music,Michael jackson's "Thriller". Too loud and too percussive for an elegant dinner. Sushi itself: nigiri was great, tempura greasy,and little flavor to the batter,ugh. Maki, so,so, not a big fan of mayo on great fish. Decor- elegant,clean lines, indirect lighting well done. Stick to the plain fish and the quality is lovely.
author: Betsy A.

description:
One of my favorite dining spots in SF - I ALWAYS am down to go - 

I love the green tea mochi ice cream, the shabu- shabu (sounds like some ancient sex ritual), and the lobster and steak tartare!!

The bar is very sleek but I prefer to dine in the company of the many chef's who always seem to always please me by making the marilyn mon'roll.
author: Yelper A.

description:
Fun place, chic decor.  Happy hour is fun and the incredible sake selection doesn't hurt.  Easy place to make friends...  :)

Went for lunch today.  Food was all good with strong bento box selections as well as solid, fresh, but not necessarily incredible sushi.  The server was nice but I should note that our entrees arrived before our appetizers, and dishes did not come at the same time.  The server noticed this but just shrugged and said thats what happens when you have so many different kitchens.  As if that isn't their fault.   

Will def come back for sushi and sake and sake happy hours...  (not a typo)
author: Brad C.

description:
Damn!  When did we get so friggin' old?  Now don't get me wrong, the missus and I aren't geriatrics yet.  Hell, we're both still children of the 70's!  But we sure do feel every bit of our age when we step into Ozumo.

The onslaught begins the second you walk in the door.  Eyes widen and a feeling of nervousness comes over you... "did I walk into the right place?"  You're expecting a Japanese restaurant but walk right into a trendy bar filled with hipsters and beautiful people.  For some reason, everyone seems to be wearing black...

Keep walkin' and things open up into a vast space.  It's, it's, sooo modern.  Goddamn! we're old!  Again, the restaurant is filled with impossibly beautiful people, all so hip and trendy that you want to strangle each and every one of them.

Food is good.  But pricey.  This ain't Nobu.  It's nouveau Japanese and I suppose they charge so much to support all of the decor and keep those damn hipsters coming.  As my grandpa once said, "I hate goddamned whipper-snappers!"

Do I sound bitter?  If I do, I apologize.  It's just that I don't remember a time when I was ever cool enough to fit into a place like Ozumo, even when I was single, fancy-free, and trolling for hotties in my twenties.

Sorry, it's getting late.  I'm going to take my Centrum Silver, rub some tiger balm on my back and go to bed.

Thanks for reading.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description: Took some work clients here and the atmosphere was awesome. We got a nice table by the window overlooking the bay bridge. Everything was downhill after that. Service was outrageously slow. Each plate came out in 10 minute intervals and people were waiting around for other orders to arrive but after a while we just gave up and started eating it as we received our individual orders. I wasn't impressed with any of their food taste wise and it was way overpriced. The portions were tiny. They comped us a dessert for the horrible service but you can't change a first impression with a client. You pretty much just pay for the ambiance here, everything else suuuuucks like a vaccuum!
author: Daniel N.

description:
I love Ozumo as long as someone else is paying! This is a fun place when you have extra cash and want to try some inventive rolls, see and be seen and hang out near the water.

As long as someone else is paying I'm always down for some Ozumo sushi, if not you'll find me in the Sunset.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I've only been here once and my first experience was very pleasant. I came here with my previous coworkers and we were in the private room which was really nice. The service we received was friendly and the food was good. I think we tried almost everything. It was my first time drinking sake and the sake I had was gooood. Dessert was delicious by the way.
Yes it is a little pricey but hey, I'd go back there after payday.
author: Anna P.

description:
Solid sushi, and I do enjoy their small plates.  It can get loud and can definitely be a bit of a scene, but after either of the Sushi Grooves it's still your best bet for good fish and a good vibe.  They also have a great dessert with mochi and green tea ice cream.

It's only the high price that pulls me down from 4 to 3 stars.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Been wanting to come here since it was featured on Travel Networks "Top 10 Bathrooms" in the world.  But when I came that is not the first place I visited.  I waited until the end of our little Happy Hour experience.  

The Staff was very friendly.  As soon as we walked in, we asked about the Happy Hour.  It was about 5:50p and it ended at 6pm so she said it ends soon but just as long as you get your orders in by 6pm, you are good to go.  

So we found a seat and when we asked one of the bussers, he said he thought it ended but the waitress swooped right in and handed us a Happy Hour Menu.  Not the best Happy Hour Prices but the lounge is comfortable and this would be considered a higher class spot so no complaints.  She actually even came by around 6:15p and told us Happy Hour was wrapping up and asked us if we wanted anything else.  Now, I thought that was really cool.  

So they had 3 sushi rolls to choose from in terms of food at $5 a pop.  We had the Spicy Tuna and the California Roll.  Not too bad.  And then they had 2 types of Sake, also for $5 a pop.  And then a list of beers for $4 a pop.  

All in all, we spent $35 out the door for Happy Hour for 2.  Again, not the normal "Happy Hour" but a comfortable spot to have good conversation.  

But one thing I did notice as we were wrapping up our Happy Hour and on our way to that Famous bathroom of theirs, they had an open kitchen and whatever they were cooking smelled really, really good.  Smelled like some beef but just smelling it, I could tell that it would be tastin' good so I definitely have to be back for dinner at some point.  

Oh, and by the way, the restroom was not all that...  I knew from the show that it taught you Japanese but I thought it was at least nicer looking.  Just a standard bathroom.  Nothing special at all.  I should charge Travel Network with False Advertising..  LOL....

HAPPY HOUR DEETS: (Until 6p)
$5 Sushi Rolls
$5 Sake
$4 Beers
author: Mark W.

description:
I loved everything about Ozumo: the location, the decor, the ambiance, the service, and the food ... oh the food. The restaurant was about 1.5 miles away from the hotel where I was staying, so a colleague and I walked it over to the restaurant. It was a beautiful night for a walk. We met up with the rest of our party of seven for our reservation and were promptly seated at the back of the restaurant even though it was really busy for a Wednesday night anywhere. The restaurant is located right off The Embarcardero, so from where we were seated, we could see the bay.

The exterior of the restaurant is so trendy that I thought I'd be under-dressed (wearing jeans and a t-shirt) because it felt like I was walking into a club. The bar/lounge makes up the first half of the restaurant and the dining/sushi bar is in the back half of the restaurant. Both ends were full when we arrived.

Some people in our party usually don't do sushi or raw foods, but all the dishes were so beautifully presented that they were willing to try almost everything. Our server was very knowledgeable about the food and gave us several great recommendations. We started off with drinks,  a round of miso soups with tofu and wakame, and two different kinds of edamame soy beans (cold lightly salted and the other with a garlic-soy sauce).

Then we moved into various small plates, trying a piece of everything: Hanabi (slices of hamachi and avocado drizzled with a warm ginger and jalapeno ponzu sauce), Futago (grilled Washu beef, sauteed garlic spinach and Japanese eggplant served with miso sesame sauce), Gyu Filet (grilled angus filet mignon sliced and served with shiitake mushrooms and arima sansho sauce), Ozumo roll (grilled unagi and cucumber roll topped with snow crab, tuna, avocado and spice sauce), Sekiwake roll (spicy tuna roll with cucumber and tempura flakes, wrapped in salmon and hamachi),  and the Spider roll (tempura soft shell crab, tobiko, kaiware and cucumber) among other items. Everything was wonderful.

For dessert, we shared the dark chocolate pot de creme in a sesame Florentine cup, a light and fluffy cream puff dessert and also a chocolate fondue with Japanese-style pastries with a fresh and edible hibiscus flower. All were delicious.

I also understand that if you go to the restroom, you get to learn Japanese phrases played over the speakers. In the women's restroom, my colleagues were trying to learn how to say "Have you seen my husband?" In the men's restroom, "My wife is looking for me." Both of which we thought was pretty hilarious but makes dining at Ozumo a little more memorable.
author: Kayee I.

description: I was treated to dinner here... every dish that came our way was fantastic!  I felt like a princess.
author: Best M.

description: Ozumo is the perfect place for a high-powered sushi lunch; and that is pretty much the crowd that is here during lunch time. We ordered a few rolls for our table and they were all pretty delicious. You can tell that the fish they use are fresh. Of particular note from our meal was the dessert. We ordered the dark chocolate fondue. Absolutely delicious! You get an assortment of fruit, mochi ice cream, and cakes to dip into the hot dark chocolate. Three rolls, drinks, and dessert came out to around $150--another typical lunch in FiDi. At least you get the great view from Ozumo!
author: Angela L.

description:
The little cluster of restaurants here is clearly meant to serve tourists, especially those wielding expense accounts and insecurities.  So our expectations were low.

Waiting in the bar with all the loud, plastic posers brought no surprises, then.

But the restaurant itself is expansive yet comfortable, and the service was top notch.  The sushi was all above par, and I'd gladly give it five stars if it stood apart from the lounge.

So, reservations and good company are highly recommended.
author: Hans G.

description: Wow I adore this place. I go there for really good sushi, people watching and having a great time. For a romantic dinner or with friends. The best : the beef and creative sushi. Excellent service. Sit at the bar and you'll have some extras. Can't wait to go back ! P.S. It's expensive. Ok. I'm willing to pay cause it's an overall experience.
author: Karolina P.

description:
A review in four parts.

1.  We ordered plain edamame.  They brought the soy-ginger version, which was great, but not what we ordered.
2.  They brought a complimentary dish of plain edamame on their own, realizing the mistake.
3.  The sashimi was stellar.
4.  The rolls were hugely disappointing.  Sloppy & skimpy.
author: Ann M.

description:
Good thing I didn't have to pay out of my own pocket for this meal

You would be paying for the "ambiance," like the so-called oriental decor and sharp-edged saucers.  It might work to entertain some (maybe if you go there plastered), but did not make up for obvious flaws:

- bland, lukewarm and diluted tea
- sloppily assembled rolls. My coworkers ordered those new-fangled rolls with bits and pieces of fish on top and sweet sauces unctuously splattered over it.  Not my favorite

The ama-ebi was okay, but I did not get to try any others.
Entrees looked pretty average... cannot comment on those.
author: Satoru Y.

description:
To say service at this resturant is up and down would be an understatment because when it's down - it's pathetically down.

A group of friends went last Saturday night. Two of them checked their coats. When they returned to fetch them at the end of their meal. Poof! Both of them were "missing". 

If a resturant is going to claim they offer an up-market, fine-dining, hispter-ville experience - it damb well be able to check a couple of coats and return them at the end of the night without incident, much less deliver some tasty food along the way. 

In the very least, they should set the record straight - reinburse their customers - offer a free shot of sake - something! Rather, my friends were kicked to the curb on one of the colder nights of the year, without a coat and with an ambiguious "we'll get back to you".

Nice, Ozumo. Way to go.
author: Eric ..

description:
Great view. Great ambiance. OUCHIES to my wallet. 

 

Lesson  to be learned here: This is a fusion restaurant. Thus, one should order only fusion dishes. Nothing completely Western, nothing completely eastern. We had fondue for dessert here which is great but completely not Japanesey at all and really not worth it! DO NOT ORDER  20 dollar ramen or anything besides fusion SUSHI here. The sushi here is great tho, they even had mango-flavored ones!

Also this is a great celebration treat place with tablecloath and nice drinks and a great view of the sushi chefs. oo so hot :D
author: Helen H.

description:
Had this place recommended to me by a number of folks but I ended up being disappointed. Nice atmosphere - the food was good, not great. As some people here have said, not really worth the money and we were especially disappointed in the service. 

Not that the waitress wasn't nice, but she dumped an entire sake flight on our friend's arm and even though the manager came over to see if we were "alright", they didn't even offer to compensate by say, taking the dumped flight off the bill. When you're blowing $600 on one dinner, you'd think they could do THAT much. 

To make it worse, they automatically tacked on the 18% tip w/out even taking the waitresses's clumsiness into consideration. We won't be going back.
author: N J.

description:
I must say, when I first heard we were going to this place, I was expecting a Japanese P.F. Changs (in terms of food quality i.e. crap).  I'm glad to say that my expectations were exceeded.  Nice atmosphere.  I had the Kobe style ribeye the first time I went, and it was really good.  Price wasn't too bad at around $50.  So the second time I went, I noticed it wasn't on the menu anymore.  =(  I asked the waiter where it went, and he said, we have real kobe beef now, and pointed to the real kobe beef with "mp" next to it.  I now know that "mp" means Market Price, and from now on, it will be synonymous with "expensive".   Needless to say I had the short ribs, and it was pretty good too.

*update*  came here and had shabu shabu.  Yum!
author: Casey F.

description:
Expensive, solid food, good scene.  Good happy hour place, good and reasonably priced sushi specials at the bar, cool vibe.  Dinner in the main room is Japanese w/ both sushi and cooked food.  I prob give it 4-4.5 stars for bar or happy hour, 3-3.5 stars for sit-down dinner.

Went last night for a splurge dinner here, For some reason they weren't offering the $125 omakase (chef's selection set menu) , so we just had our waiter pick out his favorite stuff.  The waiter was excellent and put together a great mix of selections for us.  Service overall was very solid from both our knowledgeable waiter and all the other support staff.

Got started with some Masumi Nanago Daiginjo sake for $135.  Dry, but a little richer, fruitier, and fuller bodied than most dry sakes.  I thought this was good but not great.  Also had some hot tea and some edamame to munch on.

Started dinner with a platter of sashimi.  The toro was awesome as expected.  I generally don't love shrimp much, but the sweet prawn was really great.  The Beni Toro (salmon belly) was new to me and pretty good, very interesting taste/texture.  Hawaiian kanpachi was very good.  A couple of other things were somewhat ordinary, but nothing was bad.  Overall the sashimi was very good, but not great.

Next did a platter of nigiri.  Again the toro was awesome, everything else was OK.  The hirame (halibut) was not very good.  Also, had some sort of beef nigiri that sorta sucked.  Had a Bucho roll - tempura shrimp and other stuff, that was very good.  I'd say nigiri course was just OK.

Then on to some Japanese dishes.  We also got another bottle of sake here, an $80 bottle of wakatake daiginjo onikoroshi (devil killer!) that is much dryer and crisper than the first.  I preferred this sake to the more expensive first bottle.

The hanabi is the best thing here.  Delicious thin slices of hamachi with slices of avocado plus a sweet jalapeno sauce.  We got another plate of this it was so good.  For anyone who has been to Nobu, this is similar in nature to the yellowtail jalapeno dish there.  At $16/plate, this is a bargain.

Next had futago.  This is beef with eggplant and spinach.  I thought it was sorta tasteless and pretty much sucked. Uh, I do not recommend, obv.

Next we had gindara - miso black cod.  I'm generally a huge fan of miso cod, and this was definitely good, but I would say it was just about average for this dish.  I've definitely had better, more flavorful, miso cod dishes elsewhere.  Still, it was fine.

At this point the waiter asked if we wanted more food.  Since we were splurging, we said yeah for sure, what are you thinking?  He said how about either some scallops or some kobe beef, then finish out with some light miso soup.  We said, what the hell, send some scallops and some kobe beef, then some soup, great!

Hotate - scallops on a mushroom risotto.  Delicious, very rich dish.  Definitely recommend.  The scallops were pretty good, thought not great (I thought they were just a little tougher than they should be, maybe just a touch overcooked).  But the risotto was rich and perfect.  Overall very good dish.

The kobe beef was six TINY slices of beef with some fresh wasabi, special salt, and fine soy.  By tiny, I mean TINY.  Like smaller than a piece of sashimi.  Anyway, it was pretty delicious beef, definitely very tasty.  But later we noticed that those six tiny pieces cost $105, HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHA RIDICULOUS.  I'm glad I wasn't paying for this dinner!  I'd definitely recommend getting 7 plates of hanabi instead of kobe gyu.

Finished off dinner with some miso soup, which was very good.

For dessert had chocolate fondue with some fruits and mochi ice cream, which is, well, pretty good but pretty much exactly what you expect from some melted chocolate and stuff to dip in it.  Also had a sesame panna cotta, which I liked but my friends thought was sorta weird.  I'm a big panna cotta fan and thought it was pretty good, though I bet a lot of people would find the sesame taste a little too intense.  Also, the sauce was grey, which is sorta weird.

We were pretty stuffed, definitely could have done with one less course, maybe two.

Total for dinner for 3 was $655, so after tip was $780.  At $260 per, this was definitely very expensive for what we had.  However, if I were to do this dinner again (and I was paying), I'd skip the $105 kobe plate and have an $80 bottle instead of $135 for the first one, which would have made dinner about $480, or about $190 per after tip, which is much more in line with other high-end restaurants in SF.  Definitely a very good high-end Japanese meal in a cool restaurant, but I can't really see spending this much for dinner when there are so many great sushi and fine-dining places in SF, most of which cost less than here.

Some sashimi, rolls, and hanabi would probably be a pretty good and reasonably priced dinner here.
author: Deva H.

description:
3.5 stars.
Sushi Chef - Fantastic.  Super accommodating to my stupid new diet's needs, as well as my vegetarian friend's needs. 
Food - Great.  Just ordered typical stuff, but the one let down was the seaweed salad- lacking in all things typical seaweed salady. 
Server- Sub par.  Brought us the wrong kind of water (no biggie), took forever to bring our sake, THEN at 1:50 PM (NOT AM) said:
"It's last call for the kitchen.  What do you want." Not a question.  
We sat down at 1:20 and had barely ordered and started eating our first order of rolls.  My friend hastily ordered the same thing again, I didn't order anything.  I totally get the break between lunch and dinner service, but 1:50 on a Friday afternoon? Seriously?  At least be nice about it!!!
author: Kate S.

description:
Pricey but so Good!  I swear they have an aquarium in the back somewhere, b/c the quality of the fish is top at Ozumo's. Everything on their menu is delicious. The O-toro is so good and buttery, it just melts. Make sure you eat that last b/c everything else won't compare. Don't leave without trying their fruits and mochi chocolate fondue.  I also had my first seared Wagyu Beef nigiri. It was interesting. I think I like the cooked one better, but not too bad. The hanabi  is a must try (hamachi and avocado in warm ponzu sauce) MmmMm 

This place seems to be the spot to go on Thursday and Friday nights.
author: Kim D.

description:
Sushi is great, and drinks are fantastic.  Perfect place for work events when you are not footing the bill.  

Good sushi but left with an empty wallet and stomach. 
(4 stars for sushi quality - 2 for my still hungry stomach; average = 3 stars)
author: Megan M.

description: Took a visiting colleague here for dinner.  She had never had toro before, and it was one of the specials that our waiter pointed out.  I don't think my colleague will forget that any time soon!
author: Matthew G.

description:
Went here with a bigger group who wasn't afraid to spend.  We had a great time - cocktails were amazing!  :)  Try any of their house cocktails and I guarantee that you'll be happy :)

Atmosphere was very chic, and definitely bustling, but you weren't exactly pushed out the door...  Food was amazing.  We had a little of everything that night - sushi platters, lamb, cod, fondue dessert, sake...  Wow we were gluttons.

I would definitely recommend coming here, but be OK with spending money when you go.
author: Stephanie P.

description: I had been to Ozumo a very long time ago but I recently returned taking a client there for lunch.  I like the overall atmosphere here and I had a really good meal.  The sushi can be as basic as you want or pretty elaborate as well.  The service was very good as well.  The only downfall I would say is that it is a little too pricey.  Since work was paying it wasn't a big deal but there are many other cheaper sushi places that I could check out that are just as good.
author: Blake B.

description:
Sushi has undeniably become the darling of the trendy dining circuit in the last decade or so and inevitably, many establishments have put forth a concerted effort to haute-ify the minimalist art of raw fish preparation.  There are two distinct approaches to this trend: the movement from West to East (think Ron Siegel and the Dining Room) and East to West (Ozumo and Cha-Ya) come to mind).

The fundamental difference between the two vectors is that the West-East integration is much more complete and harmonious (at least when successful).  Siegel, David Kinch, et al have taken European techniques, integrated Japanese sensibilities and ingredients, and are now creating food that is more than the sum of its parts.  Their cuisine worships at the altar of the ingredient, relying on simplicity and clarity.  For this reason, they are at the forefront of Bay Area gastronomy.

The East-to-West approach has yet to find a way to synthesize the purity of Japanese cuisine and the technique of the French, possibly because of an unwillingness to compromise.  Sushi is best when the unadorned ingredient speaks for itself; when attempts are made to complicate nigiri and sashimi, most of the time, the result is muddled and flavors don't meld.  

Ozumo, which proclaims itself to be a purveyor of "contemporary Japanese cuisine" shines brightest when the "contemporary" is taken out of the equation.  The restaurant consistently sources some of the best fish in the city but its inventiveness is stymied by an inability to venture past the established sushi norms.  It, like many others, takes the "more is more" approach to dishes, weaving together myriad primary flavors or stuffing rolls with several types of fish.

However, those that order sashimi or nigiri are in for a real treat.  The supremely fresh, unctuous, glistening morsels are as tasty as anything served by traditional sushi joints.  And there's the rub.  Ozumo is the ne plus ultra purveyor of perfect and perfectly consistent fish, but it just can't deliver on its promise of "contemporary" Japanese cuisine.
author: Yan G.

description:
Food & sushi...very good.  I've been here both during the day and evening, and always liked everything I ate

Ambiance/vibe...not my cup of tea.  But this place is very popular for those who are into crowded restaurants where the 'buzz' is more around drinking, HH, hanging out in the lounge
author: Nana S.

description:
I came here for dinner with my fiance and two of his business partners from work.  The atmosphere and decor were trendy-upscale.  The service was REALLY slow that night.  We ordered five rolls and the crispy tofu.  Our waitress forgot to put in the order for one of our rolls.  At one point, our table was empty for 20 minutes as we waited for the next roll to come out.  Each order had about 5 or 6 bite sized pieces (not big at all).  The hamachi roll had some small and thin slices of fish on top...emphasis on small and thin.  All the rolls, themselves, were good, but the portions were just way too small.

We also had 3 orders of sake and 3 chocolate mochi ice creams for dessert.  They served a small scoop of green tea ice cream (tastes like vanilla to me, not enough green tea flavor) with chocolate drizzle, red bean topping, and 3 nickel size mochi balls (no filling) surrounding the ice cream.  It tasted okay, but not impressive.  They gave us Chinese spoons to eat dessert with.  I'm not sure if that's suppose to contribute to trendiness, but  they were not the right shape for scooping up melted ice cream from a plate.  Trendy is better if someone keeps practicality in mind too.  Plus those spoons are like 10 cents at the Chinese kitchen stores.

We had suggested ordering more food for our guests before dessert , but they said they were full.  We think they were being polite, because on the way home, I asked my fiance if he was full and he said no.  I wasn't full either (and I'm not talking about busting pants full, just comfortably full).  Our total bill came out to $180.  I guess if you need to feel cool, eat here so you can be seen, but if you want to feel like you are getting your money's worth (like if feeling somewhat full is important to you after a $45pp dinner) then skip this place.
author: Nancy T.

description:
Went here last night with smoe friends.  I read about this place before yelp so I came expecting a restaurant with decent to good food but generally overpriced because you're paying for the atmosphere.  I think the overall reviews of the place are pretty accurate.  I ordered the braised short ribs and a spider roll and the short ribs were very tender, which was good, but I thought the sauce was a bit salty.  The spider roll was good, but I've had good spider rolls at many places, so it's nothing out of the ordinary.  

They did have a gigantic sake menu so if you're there for that, you wont be disappointed.  

On a side note, one of my friends noticed that on their menu, they have two areas with the same words written in Chinese which basically meant meat dishes but one had all vegetarian dishes.  Also, while you're in the restroom, they have something playing that teaches you Japanese words.  

Overall it's more of a 3 1/2 star place.  I think it's cool to come with a group of friends if you're looking to eat out at a nice Japanese place in the city.  I wouldn't make the drive out here just for this restaurant though.
author: Wilson C.

description:
Loved the atmosphere and excellent sushi. A little spendy, but I'm willing to pay for it since there wasn't a single dish that I was "meh" about. The servers were attentive but did not hover, and they had excellent recommendations. 

I would definitely recommend it to friends and has been on my places-to-go-back-to list when visiting San Francisco.

Since we dined on a Sunday, we saw a lot of families (with kids about 8+)...definitely appeared to be a favorite of the professionals with kids crowd.
author: Shelly N.

description:
Update: Forget sushi - just hit the bar for some sake on a friday night. It's hopping and the music is fab.

I admit I used to be a fan of this place. But recently it's lost some of its allure. I stopped in this week with an out of town guest, who was staying at nearby Hotel Vitale. The service at the bar itself was great, but when we moved to a bar table I wondered if we'd ever get service at all.  Once we did, the seaweed salad disappointed us both, as we expected it to be, well, green, pure and simple.  Theirs apparently has several varieties..(read:  a little too exotic for seaweed salad purists.)  We did enjoy the sushi...(though their version of the Philly roll surprised us with COOKED salmon).  My main issue is the size of the rolls... I just don't see the point in making them so big it's uncomfortable to eat them in civilized company.
author: a p.

description:
Ozumo is a very nice, upscale sushi restaurant and bar. It seems to draw a lot of its patrons from the financial district and the neighboring hotels.
Great people watching here.
We came to meet friends for drinks, and sat for quite a while. We were not rushed out, our server was friendly and attentive, and it was a good time.
The restaurant is in the back and it is quite beautiful.
I would probably come here again if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I'm hooked.  I kept hearing amazine things about the sushi here from friends and finally got the chance to go.

Everything that comes out of the sushi bar is amazing.  I'm partial to specialty rolls (Bucho, Ozeki, Dragon, Spider) but can never pass up sashmi like Hamachi or Akimani (monkfish foie).

Not such a fan of the pork pot stickers (too minty and sweet for me) and I will never touch seaweed salad again (texture is toooooo weird!!).

I will be back over and over and over again :)
author: Kristin S.

description: I usually come here for work lunches so have been lucky to try an array of dishes here.  Must haves are the Hanabi and Miso Cod.  All the sushi rolls and sashimi are very fresh.  My favorite roll is definitely the Maku-Uchi.  It's definitely pricey but you definitely pay for the freshness and ambience.
author: Helen T.

description:
I want to like Ozumo's, really I do...  The quality of the fish is always quite good, the female staff is cute and sometimes even friendly, the bar serves stiff drinks.

But something about this place really bugs me.  I can't put my finger on it.  Is it the out-of-town crowd?  The hair I had in my lunch the other day?  (they didn't even comp my meal - i was pissed!)  Or maybe its the private party in the sake bottle room that is always too loud and obnoxious...

I dunno, something is just a bit off.  Certainly it can be said that their waitstaff in the dining room area leaves alot to be desired.  And since this place is uber spendy, I'd rather just go elsewhere

Tip:  the lunch menu is recently expanded to include a bunch of noodles and other "casual" Japanese food
author: Dave K.

description:
I agree with most reviewers that the food is priced higher than average. However, the food is also a cut above. All the dishes have a fusion touch. 

If at all possible, try the sushi bar, service there is excellent. You can ask for any Japanese sushi and they're make it for you, even if it is not on the menu. You can also ask for suggestions from the sushi chefs, if you are not well versed in Japanese sushi.

Aside from great sushi, their contemporary decor is very soothing and comfortable, especially the view of the SF Bay Bridge from most of the tables and the sushi bar.

If you are tired from sushi, try their shabu shabu dish, it is a pleasant surprise that the soup is excellent as well as the nice cuts of beef. 

Spanish Mackerel sushi is also a freshing change from regular sushi. Their ama-ebi, toro, hamachi belly, and uni are excellent!
author: Art L.

description:
Good spot for cocktails and appetizers in the bar area but that's about it.

My girlfriend and I just ate dinner there tonight and were highly disappointed with both the food and the service.  The tuna tare tar was forgettable and the tempura was bland.  Sumo roll was bad; small amount of fish and too much rice.  The best part about the meal was the spicy tuna roll.

And our waiter...our waiter.  This guy spent more time chatting with his co-workers that looking after his customers.  He always appeared when you did not need him and then disappeared for long period of time.   It was like amateur hour.  It was so bad that I had to flag down a bus boy for some spoons and then a hostess to get me some bowls.   Maybe I shouldn't blame him but blame the lack of management oversight in the dining room.  Either way...beware of bad wait staff.
author: Rene M.

description:
As others have said, this is an expensive but solid choice. Fish is very fresh, vibe is pretty cool and they have some interesting options for non-sushi eaters. In particular try the Dragon roll (great combo of rice and shrimp, etc.)

Service is solid, but this is a busy restaurant so don't expect to be in and out in 30 minutes. Sushi requires patience so go with the flow and you won't be disappointed.
author: Andy B.

description:
We were looking for something really special...

...We did not find it here.

The atmosphere was weird... I mean, we're in our twenties, but we're done with our clubbing days and this place was definitely for the club crowd.  It's super noisy, too.  And other reviewers are right about there being a "smell" when you walk in - but it's a typical sushi-joint smell - nothing that made me think the place was dirty or anything.

Turns out the restaurant's emphasis is more on the "atmosphere" than the food.  The food is your typical "we're going to be trendy and serve rolls with avocado and a bunch of sauce."  In other words, it's Americanized-sushi.  The tuna tar-tare had SO many different ingredients that you couldn't actually taste the tuna.  ...in fact, that was our problem with everything we ordered - so many ingredients and flavors were covering up the main ingredient.  We wanted to try new and innovative things we had never tasted before - we should have looked somewhere else.

Oh, and it took over half an hour for someone to bring us drinks.

We later found a more authentic meal, and fabulous, at Takara in Japantown.
author: D. L.

description: Fun place for happy hour. Bar is separated from the tables by a wall which is nice. Fancy decor. Food is expensive, but worth it when you're drunk and hungry. Bartenders make fun specialty drinks and they keep them coming which I can never complain about.
author: Jeannine L.

description: Service was great  food Not all that great. Food was small pricey not that tasteful. Menu is very small when it comes to rolls. Miso soup is bland no flavor
author: Jesse P.

description:
Went there on my birthday... unfortunately I was disappointed. Especially on that day...:(
First they placed us on a much too cold table directly under an air conditioning vent. When we complained they told us they have always issues with that table - well... why did they placed us there when they know it is my birthday???

If you go there I can only recommend the Sushi! We had only one roll (that was ok) because we went for the Chicken and Filet Mignon. The filet was ok but the chicken was horrible! Black, even cold and way too expensive! 
In other words if you want Sushi..then Ozumo is a good choice. For everything else go to Benihana...
author: Hendrik G.

description:
This place is awesome.  Usually super busy, and kind of crowded with after work financial district people,  but the sushi is great and the drinks are strong.  
The service is AMAZING.  Angela waited on us at the bar all night and even though it seemed like she was serving 40 other people at once we got everything fast - and never finished a drink without being asked if we needed anything else.  Pretty expensive, but a fun vibe and a great bartender.
author: Allison C.

description: Extremely well-executed high end Japanese restaurant.  The Sake list is very impressive.  Was lucky to dine in the private room.  Service was impeccable.  Enjoyed every morsel of Sashimi, rolls, and steak that were delivered family style onto our table.  This is the contemporary Japanese experience.
author: Ishak K.

description:
This place has changed...my...sushi eating experience! Brought that experience to the max! Everything is so fresh and tasty! This is the only place I can say that I can enjoy shashimi and not feel like gagging after a few piece. The price is a bit expensive. Let's just say this was the most expensive meal I have ever had in my whole entire life! Lets see what I had..

Hanabi (YOU MUST TRY!!!! LIKE A MUST!!!)
Toro Tuna Belly (Deelish! Melts in your mouth like butta)
Hamachi
Ozumo Roll
Spicy Scallop Roll
Yokozuna Roll
Tuna Tataki Salad (YUM YUM YUM)
Dohoyo (Refreshing)
Choco Chan (Way to finish off the dinner)
Yomedono (Sake...umm quite expensive...i could of survived dinner without it)

Overall, I love love this place and I would totally come back! Oh and everyone was friendly! VERY! Took good good care of me! :D
author: Alda H.

description:
I think your experience here will depend on your expectations going in.  I have to keep reminding myself that this is an upscale sushi restaurant with prices to match. I also sat alone at the bar. If I went with a group and sat at a table my experience may be different.  I really choose it because I am staying at the hotel next door and wanted something close by. 

I ordered the Tataki salad and miso glazed Black Cod with the house sake and a large Sapporo.  I thought the sake was pretty good.  I wish i knew more about sake.  I dont remember seeing one on the menu, but a sake sampler might be a good way to try a few.  My salad came around 15 min later.  It was good, but not stelar.  

The bar area was starting to fill up and the bartenders were focused on making drinks.  I saw a waiter drop off a few items at the bar and wondered if one was mine.  They sat there for a good 7 min before the bartender saw them. And of course, one of them was my Cod.  The bartender handed it to me and quickly ran off without asking if I needed anything else and it took another few minutes to flag her down again to get some silverware.  By now, my Cod was cold. I should have said something but I was pretty hungry and didn't want to wait any longer.  It was nicely plated, but didn't come with anything else.  For $28, I thought it would be served with a starch and/or vegetable.  With that said, I thought it tasted great and was cooked nicely.  But I was still starving and knew it would cost at least another $30-40 if I ordered more. So I decided to cut my loses and leave.  All total, my bill was $82 including tip.  Pretty expensive for cold cod and still being hungry.  I guess I should know better though. I always have a hard time getting enough to eat at sushi restaurants for a good price, let alone one in a prime spot.  looking back, I should have gone the sushi and roll route. 

I probably won't come back.
author: Mike E.

description:
Went here for a friend's birthday.  There were 9 of us and they automatically reserved one of their private rooms for us without telling us.  Luckily they were nice enough to call the day of our reservation and tell us that there is a $1000 minimum charge for the room.  There was no way we wanted to spend that much but they said they would waive it since they didn't tell us that before and it was the day of the reservation.  So that was nice.

We get there and the place looks nice and swanky.  We went to the private room which was small and enclosed in glass and we had to take our shoes off.  There was a random portable A/C unit in one corner which was kind of odd.  They should integrate that into one of the walls but they can't really since it's all glass walls.

The food was great.  The food was also very expensive.  Presentation was great.  However presentation doesn't make food taste better.  I prefer cheaper food over atmosphere/swankiness.  However I won't deduct stars for that because we knew what we were getting ourselves into and it's not like going here would be a common occurrence.  We spent around $600 for 9 people when all was said and done.  This included 2 bottles of sake.

Anyway it is great if you want to spend a lot of money.  If you want the private room they probably will keep the $1000 minimum intact.  Also there is a $20 per person cancellation fee for the room and they take your credit card number when reserving.  But if you are looking for high-class swanky Japanese then I do recommend this place.
author: Zubin D.

description:
Had lunch here last week with my co-worker, who happens to be Kate S.....scroll down below for her review. 

The food was great. Well, except for the seaweed salad. The presentation was beautiful and colorful. But I wasn't pleased with the taste. I barely had a few bites then I had to push the plate away. Our sushi chef was awesome and very accommodating. I had the shrimp tempura which was excellent! Mmmmmmm. Oh and I think our server was actually a robot disguised as a human. She was a bit unfriendly and a bit rude. Now, this whole thing about the kitchen closing at 2pm, which btw, we did not know until our server barked at us, yes barked, "kitchen closing. what do you want?" Something like that...anyways, if someone walks in to a restaurant at about 1:30ish, not knowing the kitchen closes at 2pm, shouldn't the host or hostess say something to the guest first?? Hmmm....
author: Lola D.

description: I frequent this place. It has it all. The food is fresh and fantastic every time. The bar area is a great place to chill while waiting to be seated. The staff is friendly and I have not had any poor service experiences. One of the best upscale sushi restaurants I have ever been to!
author: Marie C.

description:
Meh.  We've had enough parties here.  I don't want to go back =(

The first few experiences were good.  Food was good.  Drinks were good. Service was ok.

Then it moved to...food was ok, drinks were still good, service sucked.

I can go on to say that the food is now blah, drinks are drinks and service.sucks.ass.
author: K H.

description:
Had a holiday dinner here with the company a few months back and have also taken some dates here.  The food is excellent, the atmosphere is awesome plus they play house music which is a quick way to win me over at any restaurant (all other things aside).

The sake selection is huge but some can be a bit overpriced.  The service has been great; both in the private dining area as well as the main restaurant area.

The bar is usually pretty busy and it can be hard to get a drink but this place really shouldn't be reviewed as a bar.

I'll definitely go here again.
author: James G.

description: This restaurant has a grand, swanky entrance that opens to a very hip bar scene. What I do come back for time and again is the food. It is rather pricey but well worth splurging on. The fusion take on their Japanese fare is imaginative and well-executed. But the place to be is the sushi bar. Ozumo has some of the freshest sushi and sashimi you will find in San Francisco. And if you ask for Sushi Chef Kazu, he will advise you on what to order and take excellent care of you
author: Carol Y.

description:
Fiance took me here spontaneously after work on Friday night. I had just been promoted and he wanted to celebrate, but didn't have time to make a reservation. He called ahead to check if they were busy and he was told yes, but that the wait wouldn't be more than 45 minutes...we were prepared to order a bottle of wine at the bar for us to wait,  but we just walked in and were seated once we told them we were celebrating. Pretty nice, since they seemed busy!
The Vibe is upscale and makes you feel all swanky-like.
Our waitress was very educated on her sake and we were shocked when her coworker approached us and told us she was new and "still learning" They really put them through the paces here!
We enjoyed many new and different sakes... so much that i got drunk and forget them all.
I do remember the garlic soy edamame was a lovely start, and the Tanabata was to die for. The sukiyaki was just like my host-mother made for me in Japan.I would definitely suggest this next time i have parents or clients in town.

The fiance also said to mention this is a great place for groups They have this little Kotatsu room that's totally enclosed in glass.
author: Nikki M.

description: This was dreadful. I love fine dining and this just simply was an insult to my evening. No matter what you put on your menu, a professional, well mannered wait staff is the cornerstone of your restaurant.
author: Stacey C.

description:
WORST PLACE EVER!!!! 
This is probably the worst restaurant in SF! We go to SF every weekend and try a new restaurant but we did not see such a shitty place like this one! Don't let the fancy place fool you! 
We were about 16 people that went there. At first, the waitress was so busy I asked for dessert menu 3 times and she forgot! When she bring it She didn't say sorry about that!
After we ate our food, we asked for check and the point is we asked for separate check! And the waitress said we cannot bring separate checks for you! WHAT THE HELL? It means that one person should pay and others have to pay him later, but some of us won't be able to see each other later! We talked to her a lot but she said she cant! And we were 16! After lots of complaining and urging they admit to make separate bill for 2 groups! It means that 2 of us had to pay for all of us! Do you know how much money was that?!!! 
After that they said ok we only make 2 separate bill !but write down which bill has what food!!! we had to write down that who ate what to pay to those 2 person ! are you serious? It took 1 hour to write down and every time we calculated the price, it was wrong! BECAUSE the number of people was too many and that's normal to be wrong and this WAS NOT OUR DUTY!!!!!!!
I don't want to make it boring for you but just imagine 16 people who are waiting and calculating and talking about what they ate! Some people was not even able to remember what they ate because of difficult names of foods! They asked for menu and ....
 I went and talked to the manager, he said there is no way to separate check for 5 groups!!! 
They ruined our night ! after we check the price at home we saw that the made it in wrong way and we paid 84 dollars for nothing!
We hated this place and we will never come back here! They cannot do such simple thing! But they were so lazy to do that! 
They didn't even say SORRY and the waitresses were so rude!!!!!!!!!
author: Behnoosh N.

description:
Hmmm...Had an odd dinner at the communal tables to the right of the bar. The girl next to us was letting men feel her bared tatas - "okay, but you can only touch the tops". The guy to the right of me kept trying to rub up on me. Dragon roll good, but green tea creme brulee was as caca as the tatas. 

UPDATE: Still great food and bar as a whole. The front is the more interesting area to eat, but you have to deal with the noise.
author: Tanya P.

description:
Will taste better if your office is paying. 

Sushi can be very good, but it smacks of a place that's jumped the shark.
author: Megan W.

description:
They have lychee martinis.  
I wander around looking for litchee martinis in SF.

Places with lychee martinis get an automatic 4 stars.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Man did our night get sidetracked by this place. Originally planned to meet one of my bandmembers here for a short band meeting. Walked in and immediately realized that MAYBE this isn't the best place for quietly discussing business matters and taking down detailed notes, because it was so dark at the bar that I couldn't even see the words I was writing down. Okay seriously I sound like a bitter old man, so let me get on with it...

Ozumo is swanky, friends. Already covered the fact that it's a dark, moody atmosphere inside, with the kinda decor that made you think you were in a New York City nightclub, and a freakin' DJ to boot. Wait, this is a sushi joint, no? Whatever, I'll roll with it. I can't comment on the food as we proceeded to aggressively sample the sake menu, and food just, well, didn't end up happening, that's all. But the sake was fantastic, the waiters/bartenders definitely know their stuff, and the seating at the bar was this cool kind of raised bench that was super comfortable.

Okay now the bad news, but it's a case of knowing what you're getting into: Ozumo is seriously expensive. The "only on the company credit card" kinda expensive. My buddy and I had a couple of Asahi tallboys each, and maybe 3 or 4 sake shots each, and the tab was over $150. So beware. But I'll tell you what, for an upscale, cool sushi joint with knowledgable staff, you could do worse than Ozumo. Just not sure when I'll get the chance to go back...
author: Drew S.

description:
Did I miss the memo titled "Ozumo - #1 Sushi Restaurant for a Date in 2008?" 

I was taken to this restaurant THREE times in one week last month. It seems silly to complain about being fed sushi at what a friend called, one of the most expensive sushi restaurants in the city...

The sushi is good, the sake is good, but if the next guy who takes me here wonders why I am laughing to myself, it's because I don't even need to see the menu anymore.

P.S. Eating in the bar area--more sexy than eating in the main dining room area...

NOM NOM NOM
author: Cindy P.

description:
This was our friday happy hour spot for a while until it got crowded and the bartenders got snooty. 
Ozumo is expensive, but the food is worth it. The appetizers are the best things on the whole menu, oh and the cocktails too, which are both very pricey.
Their rolls are fresh, but not didn't rock my world, but the sashimi is so fresh it melts in your mouth. 
My advice is to come here and try something new and inventive on the menu. Hey, if you're paying so much for raw fish, you might as well go all out. 
Reserve a table that faces the large windows they have that look out to the Embarcadero, and watch the sun go down over a champagne-cocktail. bliss.
author: Scarlet S.

description: Great bar.  Not a great sushi bar.  Nothing special to see if you're looking for good fish, but still a decent place to go if you're in the area.  I probably prefer the hot food to the sushi here.
author: Mike F.

description: Nice japanese restaurant we went to for a business dinner.  Sushi never fills me up, but everything I tried was very good.  It was a bit dead that far out by the wharf on a Thursday night, but the restaurant was packed.  I hear the view in the back tables is amazing.
author: Joi P.

description:
5/24/2007 Update:

UGH! I went there with my sister last night for my birthday dinner. There were two enjoyable aspects of the dinner. First: the view it's right on the embarcadero and it lovely. Second: the company, my sister rocks! Everything else...sucked! Our waiter was useless, the sushi was ok (nothing to write home about), and the robata grill item I ordered was rare-I asked for medium-it's a pretty big difference, and the cut of beef was sub-par. 

Oh, and it was very $$$$, the tab pre-tip was over $140 and we only ordered 2 nigiri items, a small sashimi plate, an appetizer, and a robata meal plus two glasses of $8 wine and two saki's. 

I can't in good conscience return.
author: Leesa P.

description:
Oh how I have now entered the "beautiful people" eatery.  In my sun dress and flip flops while other diners sported in everything black and fitted.  We sat at a table in front of a TV playing Godzilla.  Because Godzilla is a Japanese classic...  and so is sushi...!  How I have connected the dots.  

So, no Hirami.  No Aji.  No Mirugai.  But they did have tuna tartare in a cocktail glass, dressed with avocado.  Kona Kanpachi was a decent surprise.  Then the rest of the dinner kind of faded into the techno music in the background...  One star for going so far to be cool that I actually "got it"...  One more for my sake buzz.  Would've added another star for the fact that I didn't have to pay for it (thank GOD) but that had nothing to do with the restaurant, so I decided to drop it.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
You can't really go wrong here. 

We've been dining here for years, I think since it first opened, and we've always walked away very satisfied. Although the last time we were here they rushed us along our meal even though we had a reservation, and the waiter kept bugging us what seemed like every five minutes. We haven't been back since but I'm sure we will soon because in my opinion it's one of the best sushi resturants in town. I know there are several really great places in the city but you can't really beat the location right on the Embarcadero looking out over the water at the bridge. The bar is a total scene so if you're single you might want to come in and have a looky look. Otherwise it's really dark with loud music and lots of people but hey, if you're into that who am I to judge.

It's pretty pricey so bring your credit card or make sure your date is holding so you can enjoy the fine cusine and get dessert.

PS. The miso cod is out of this world! It will melt in your mouth.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
This was a treat, I went here with a friend and Katy Perry was sitting at the table behind us. 

My friend and I sat at the bar. Great for people watching and toe tapping. Have a DJ against the back wall. Really sets a fun, clubby ambiance without being too intense. 

Bartender was a totally chatty cathy... something I usually appreciate. EXCEPT for when he acts like a Subject Matter Expert on subjects he's not too versed in. Obviously the bartender bothered me a little bit. 

The manager was very nice. I noticed how he was observing the guests making sure that everyone was satisfied. I can appreciate that a lot. 

Atmosphere is great. Wine selection: fun

Food: meh

I don't think people for there for the food. The rolls were on the small side and the rice was really dry. Don't go here for stand-still sushi. Go here to people watch, get dolled up, and hang out.
author: Alli J.

description: This place was simply amazing, great service, amazing food, and good memories! You could tell right away there was so much attention to detail in every plate. So far the best Sushi place I have been to yet... If anyone ever asks me for a good Sushi place to go to, regardless of where I am, I will always recommend this place!
author: David D.

description:
Great plates!

MUST GET:!

futago: thick grilled eggplant, pressed spinach, filet of beef with light sesame sauce. 

hanabi: carpaccio of hamachi with bold flavors including wasabi. 

gindara: black cod, burned perfectly on top, perfect mix of tangy sake with sweet and savoryness of miso.

sushi isn't amazing, but good. plates are definitely the stars here!
author: Hannah W.

description:
Great salt water eel, bad fresh water eel.
Very pretty joint, although lots of obnoxious out-of-towners- remember to bring a gun.
author: F B.

description:
We arrived at Ozumo at 8:30, and as one would expect on a Friday, it was quite crowded. Fortunately there was room at the sushi bar in the main dining room, and for the next 2  hours we were treated to wonderful fish and delightful sake. My thanks to Jessica for letting us sample so many sakes and Hiroto for his artistry.

We began the meal with a bottle of an amazing nama sake, the Tedorigawa "Arabashiri." Tedorigawa is one of Japan's oldest brewers and they make sake using the most traditional techniques. The result is beautiful: light, sweet, smooth, clean, silky, floral and effervescent are all descriptors that come to mind. It is a blockbuster and reason enough to visit Ozumo while they still have stock. Later in the evening we also drank the Genshu nama from Dewazakura and an old stanby, the Denshu. But, the Tedorigawa stole the show.

To match our wonderful sake we began with a sashimi sampler that included Maguro, Hirame, Hamachi, Sake and then Kona Kanpachi, Toro and salmon belly. Both the Kona Kanpachi and salmon belly are unusual, and the Toro was perfectly marbled.

From there we ordered nigiri. Each was wonderful but highlights include their Umi Masu (an ocean trout unlike anything I have tried before), the Amaebi (so sweet and delicious) and the Anago (beautifully concentrated flavor). The Shima Aji was also wonderful last night, and both salmon and Hamachi approached best-ever status. As good as the Maguro, the Shiro Maguro, the Hotate and Albacore were, they were esclipsed by the other offerings. We also ordered a half dozen Kumamoto Oysters and Hiroto made us a salad of crab, salmon and salmon roe in appreciation for the sake we were sharing.

Dinner was not inexpensive, but a day later I'm still marveling at how good it was. I like Ozumo, but previous meals were never that good. I can only conclude that sitting at the sushi bar made a big difference, and I can't wait to return to test my theory.
author: Paul J.

description:
**Disclaimer- this was my second sushi dining experience, so I am by no means a sushi expert..

If you read my Blowfish review, you saw that this was my first experience....and I just couldn't get enough so I went back for more on Sunday night.  Really good.  There was a party of 5 and we each ordered different things....which were all tasty but on the pricy side.  This place SCREAMS "come here if you have an expense account" because of the location and decor...so I am sure there are better more economical sushi joints in the city.

Funny, I tried the Tokyo Glow, mostly for the name and I wanted to start my week off with a glowing face...but walked away with some kind of hives instead.  Although, it was more likely an allergic reaction to one of the dishes.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Fancy shmancy japanese restaurant.  Pretty good food, as for the rolls, i have not been too impressed with them.  If you have gone to a good japanese restaurant the rolls probably compare with them, but the small plates are pretty good.  Must try their blackened cod- excellent!  Their cocktails are pretty good too.

Good atmosphere, friendly staff, but I could just be biased to it because my friends work there! haha.  anyway, good to try, and right down the street from Shanghai 1930 and Americano... great places to go after dinner! :)
author: Kimberly F.

description:
To call this place just a sushi place would be unfair. Its a very well balanced japanese cuisine experience. I dropped in on Friday night for dinner and walked into hear a DJ dropping some decent electro prog on a Serato setup, which impressed me even though the tracks were all like 6+ months old. I thought we were at a nicer edgier version of Blowfish, until we were escorted back to the main dining area. 

This area was more brightly lit. I felt like I went from some neo noir lounge in a Tokyo cyberpunk chapter to a "bistro no Kyoto".  Our server was really nice and extremely knowledgable about every dish, as well as the sake flight I partook in.

The calimari is cooked to a perfection beyond what I thought was possible with squid. It was amazing. The miso soup was very standard, but I mean how creative can you get with miso soup anyways? 

We got the spicy tuna and spicy scallop rolls for our sushi course. These were both amazing, although the sauce was pretty standard.

Our main courses were where our impression of this restaurant went from good to great. I got the gyu-don which were steak cubes seared medium rare and served with this insane japanese mustard and caramelized onions.

Let me digress a minute on this japanese mustard business. Obviously it was infused with a healthy dose of wasabi radish, but this stuff was out of this world. Einstein must have thought up the atomic bomb after having this dish. It was amazing.

The sake salmon dish was probably the best cooked fish I've ever had. I'm not really into seafood, sans sushi, but this made me want to eat it more often. It really was top notch.

It was my girlfriend's birthday so they brought out this cool black tea cream gelatto desert infused with berries that I really enjoyed. Overall this was the best japanese restaurant I've been to in SF and am kicking myself for not going there sooner.

Believe it or not its really not that expensive. $130 got us some good wine/sake and enough food to fill us both up and then some. I'm definitely going back as soon as I can.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
A trendy, minimalistic place with a magnificent view of the Bay Bridge, Ozumo offers a diverse menu of traditional and innovative Japanese cuisine.   My recommendations include:  
 
- Garlic soy edamame
- Chef's sashimi platter consisting of maguro toro, seared salmon toro, hamachi, ame ebi, sea bass and halibut (all A+ in quality, cut and freshness)
- Maguro tetaki (seared tuna, perfectly sliced with a bit of a kick from the ponzu and ginger) 
- Kobe beef with miso-cabernet sauce and mushrooms
- Black cod marinated in miso and sake 
- Chilled Sparkling Jumani Sake (fruity, crisp, sweet but well balanced)
- White peaches poached, finely diced, mixed with shaved ice and drizzled with white creme anglaise infused with black tea 

I'm not really a big fan of their ceviche (as compared to Limon's) and some of their rolls.

Net:  pricey, amazing sashimi, great Kobe beef, impressive sake selection, worth checking out, 3.8 stars (rounding up to 4)
author: TK W.

description:
If I reviewed them a week ago they would have gotten 5 stars.  I've been coming here for 6 years and have always loved their sushi.  This week I went and sat at the sushi bar.  In the middle of my meal a small cockroach ran off the plate.  Uuuuuggggh.  Was so grossed out I couldn't eat anymore.  

That being said, every other time I've been there I thought the sushi was great (but a bit overpriced).
author: Patrick C.

description:
That's it, I'm officially striking Ozumo!! No more meals there. I've never been so underwhelmed with expensive sushi before. Ever.
The place is quite pretentious, they have a terrible execution to food service, and the one or two people that have always waited on me have been quite incapable of attention to their busy sections. The drinks are lackluster, but of course, way too overpriced.

The only reason I gave this place two stars instead of one, they have great matches. Yes, matches. They burn to the nub without fear of blowing out, which is more than I can say about the food here.

Blah.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
