I met a friend here for happy hour, as she claims it is her favorite sushi place in the city. It's a pretty nice place, dark, candlelit, opens to the outside. However, these are the kinds of places that worry me--useully these kinds of restaurants rely more on their "cool" decor and overprice food, rather than focusing on creating great flavors.

Essentially happy hour on the Thursday that I went, was a complete Sausagefest. I walked in and I felt the record player scratch as every dude in the place swiveled his head 180 degrees to stare at the fresh meat that entered the door. As I proceeded to scan the room for my friend, their hungry eyes followed me all the way to my seat. 

Once settled in, I was greeted by the douchiest of douche bag bartenders. I ordered my drink from him, but he didnt acknowledge that I placed my order. We tried to order food from him, he ignored us. When we tried to get our last-call drinks before happy hour ended, he ripped the menu away from us. Um, k. Luckily there was another (friendlier lady) to help us out.

I'm giving this place 3 stars because the food is pretty good, especially the appetizers, and because I had a good time catching up with my friend. It's pricey, however, and the crowd is very Marina-esque, so I doubt I'd go out of my way to come here again. I'd probably go for happy hour again though...but only if someone esle suggested it.
author: Sabine S.

description:
For me, Ozumo is past its prime.  The food is way overpriced for really small portions and the service is mediocre.  They have a nice drinks menu, however.

I also find the servers are a bit haughty.  One time, my colleague visiting from Japan was asking about some of their menu items. Not picking up on his thick Japanese accent, they proceeded to describe "traditional" Japanese dishes incorrectly  and mis-translate Japanese words in the description (as my colleague pointed out).  Sometimes, the hosts have sat my party in the undesirable middle room even though tables in the back room (with bayfront windows) remain empty through the meal.  Also, on occasion my party's entrees came several minutes apart which was a bit uncomfortable.

I did have a great drink which feature crushed up jalapeno in a martini.  It gave a really nice flavor to the martini.

In terms of food, I've sampled several items.  I think the uni risotto is really scrumptious.  The black cod is also sublime.  However, the sushi didn't blow me away nor did the squash soup I had (which wasn't as sweet as I would have liked it to be)

The decor is nice if you can swing a table in the back room.  However, I don't really like the Studio 54 vibe going on in the front bar, especially at night.
author: Jeff A.

description:
Contemporary,  trendy, expensive, and delicious. 

When I first entered, I felt transported to a dark izakaya in an alley of Osaka. The dark wood, walls of sake bottles, and dj music set the mood. As we waited to be seated, we had a drink at the bar. Low and behold, the hostess never came to get us (which apparently happens OFTEN), so we had to approach the hostess stand...finally she was ready to seat us.

We walked back to the brighter, back of the restaurant. Tons of tables were ready and available. We were seated next to 1 of the 2 private rooms, where you sit on your knees sans shoes. 

We ordered up a storm.

For dinner: garlic edamame (YUM!), dohyo, shacho (lobster sushi), and various nigiri. Everything was great. They could have spaced the food out a bit better, but it was all very enjoyable. The table shared some sake and Saporros, so we all had a fun time. 

For dessert: green tea crepe--I will pass next time.
author: Misha F.

description: Ate here a couple of years ago for our 5th year wedding anniversary. Very impressed with the food, decor, atmosphere and service. Sat at the sushi bar were all the action was and remembered devouring the Age Dashi Tofu and the perfect cuts of sashimi.  Most people are on the dressy side but you can definitely get away with a nice pair of nice jeans and cute top ... it's a place to see and be seen with upbeat music in the background.
author: Sassy G.

description: Great place for sushi, vibrant and very big with multiple areas in addition to the bar at the front. Superbly fresh sushi and nigiri, delicious asian fusion with kale or eggplant salads with soy dressing. We've been here before and loved it. But during our last unplanned stop, we were a bit disappointed by the hostess (that must have been new and not charming or friendly) at the desk at the entrance. We didn't have a reservation on a Monday evening and we asked to sit at the sushi bar in the back. We asked only after she "decided" to notice we were standing in front of her desk. Lousy interaction from the start. She told us it'd be 1/2 hour because she just had two people be seated  at the sushi bar and now it's fully occupied. Although we said we didn't mind sitting at the sushi bar she told us to "go sit at the bar instaed because the sushi bar is full and she just sat a lot of people there". That was a lie. We declined. We were curious and walked to the back and we were surprised to find the sushi bar two-thirds empty... Anyway I recommend this place but wish management gets rid of this unprofessional and unqualified hostess.
author: Keith D.

description:
It's a very nice restaurant for sushi and sashimi. The sushi bar has amazing chefs that would chat with you and make recommendations for your dinner. 

However, like most sushi restaurants in the city, it does not open on Saturday noon for luncheons.
author: Vickie T.

description: As others have reviewed - the rolls were mediocre - the cod was delicious but I know I can replicate that at home - the hanabi tasty but nothing special - the tontoro was the best dish, melts in your mouth but the portion was too small as an entree - my favorite was the sake samplers our friendly waiter recommended - i was able to learn which sake I liked the most and the price for the sake was very reasonable!
author: J C.

description:
My friends and I came here for happy hour, I arrived a bit after my friends, and they had already ordered.  The second I sat down the waitress asked if I was ready to order, I said I needed a few minutes - and she never came back.  About 15-20 minutes later we had to flag down another waiter to place my order.  It took over 30minutes for each of our orders to be prepared - mine was merely one california roll and beef skewers.  

Needless to say, the service is atrocious!  It seriously took 30minutes to prepare 6 pieces of meat and 7 rolls!  As if that in itself wasn't ridiculous enough, the bill came and charged us $6 for each pot of green tea.  The entire pot barely equaled 2 TINY cups... Generally, green tea is free at Japanese restaurants - not here!  Instead they overcharge you so that they can buy cool pots.  At $6 a pot, they should give me the pot.

The food was decent, but when you're basically ignored by your waitress, it's kind of hard to leave the place with a pleasant aftertaste (no pun intended).  Not to mention the outrageous cost of hot water and a bag of green tea.  Would I come here again?  Definitely not.  There are much better happy hour spots in the city.
author: Lara T.

description: Great fresh sushi, with a great upscale atmosphere.  The rolls are not big, but the quality is great.  A bit on the pricer side, but well worth it.
author: Deanna H.

description: Great happy hour w/ $4 cocktails. Love their version of a sake mai tai. Inventive menu. Great ambiance. Trendy crowd. Something was missing, though. Like it was engineered for me to want to be there for 45 minutes and not a second longer. Don't know exactly how.
author: Andrew K.

description: Spacious, modern design, I'd come here just for the cocktails, because they create a fantastic space to chill with your pals.  Sushi is fresh, but nothing to write home about.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Expensive, sassy and food that is presented in one bad @ss way!  This is where I ate Toro, the belly of an unfortunate tuna for $100- 10 small slices of joy (on the company dime).  The sushi overall was great, well presented for the Hamachi, Maguro and dragon roll.  I also like the appetizers; I would highly recommend the Sakura beef and Ebi shrimp.  For sake, stick to Otokoyama, yes the $6 glass, not the $200 bottle.  Enjoy the ambience and the well informed waiters that truly understand the intricacies of traditional Japanese food, customs and dining experience!
author: Manny F.

description: Mixed thoughts on Ozumo.  On the one hand, sushi here can be very good, and they some very creative dishes.  Good ame-ebi, mackeral, and hamachi (try the hanabi!).  Items off the robata menu can also be very good, and one of my faves is the grilled eggplant topped with fillet, spinach, and miso.  Good sake selection, but very pricey.  I found the same bottle at other places for over $20 less, but I guess you are paying for the location.
author: Peter L.

description: Great place for happy hour.  Rolls are kinda small, but good to share with a group of people.  Nice setup of the bar in the front and the restaurant in the back.
author: Josh L.

description: Best sushi in SF.  Gyu beef skewer is killer and $6.  Dohyo ($16) is a spicy tartare with avocado and chips... great to share.  Toro is amazing but you'll need to take out a second mortgage.  Liberal pours on the cocktails, rounding out a delightfully foggy evening that I plan to repeat.
author: Kevin G.

description: Quite possibly the best sushi I have ever had. The toro melted in my mouth like butta, and the ikura tasted of the ocean. Service also deserves 5 stars- the bf and I were craving oyster shooters, and although it wasn't on the menu, the chef whips up the most delicious shooter I've had to date. The quail egg, ponzu, and scallions balanced one another perfectly, the tobiko popped pleasantly upon contact, all I could say is wow, texture. Gourmet sushi doesn't get much better than this.
author: Irene C.

description:
Meh.

The rolls were not very inventive, nor were they as tasty as I hoped. On top of that, they were outrageously priced. What you'd normally pay $12-14 (TOPS!) for a fancy roll, you pay $18 at Ozumo. We only got 2 rolls, and they weren't very big. And charging $6 for edemame? Ludicrous. (Though, in their defense, it was the best I've had before! Still should be free...)

What saved the night was the spare ribs entree. The meat practically melts in your mouth. What meat can you cut with a gentle push of a chopstick? It was tender and very tasty.

I think you're paying for the ambiance at Ozumo, which is great, but probably not worth the price.

For the price, you can get maybe twice the amount of sushi with even better quality elsewhere. I suggest Zushi Puzzle in the Marina if you want very fresh fish, extensive menu, and good value.
author: Erica M.

description: Dined here for New Year's Eve dinner.  We had a great and attentive server who recommended some tasty rolls. I have had better sushi in other places, but overall I still liked this place.  Variety of drink selections and some were good.
author: Reeni P.

description:
Perhaps the best sushi I've ever had outside Japan, and certainly the most expensive. A fantastic way to really impress a date.

The bar facing Steuart St. will open its giant glass doors on warm afternoons -- perfect happy hours await you.
author: Billy A.

description:
I'm a big time sushi fan.  Went here for lunch with business clients.  Nice view from our table...found myself wandering away from the conversation to stare outside.  

The atmosphere was pretty cool inside.  Chic.  Very New York.  I liked it a lot.  

The food was pretty good, but I have had better.  It was an average sushi joint to me, with a pretty sweet atmosphere.  The service was a bit slow though.  Overall, I'd recommend if you want decent sushi with prices that won't break the bank.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I am addicted to the Garlic Edamame.  It's just soooo GOOD.  The seafood is always fresh and it's a fun establishment to take a date. 

Minus 1 star for the price because it's a tad bit pricy, but overall the place is worth trying out.
author: Richard C.

description:
Short version: great food, great service, knowledgeable staff for recommendations, pricey.

I asked my coworkers for a good sushi restaurant near work, and this was the recommendation.  I went with 2 co workers, and we started with edamame with garlic sauce, which was a very tasty appetizer.  When I was ming my sushi order, the staff was very helpful and knowledgeable.  Based on what I ordered from the menu, he made several good recommendations for market fish they had that day that wasn't on the menu.  The Spanish mackerel he recommended was especially delicious.  Nigiri sushi varied in price from about $7 to $12 for most items.
author: Brett C.

description:
I would come here every other day if I could afford it.  This is the best sushi I had in San Francisco. Whether you're with friends or on business this place is amazing, and the service is great. 
Unfortunately, all dishes and drinks are overpriced by a mile like 15 dollars for two tiny pieces of sushi, You could probably buy half a salmon for that price.
They have a good selection of sake and their entrees are all very good and nicely laid out. I especially like the yellowtail collar (burikama). 
As long as you do not come with a hungry date, it's a great restaurant!
author: Chris H.

description:
the sushi is good here and this place is very sceney.

However, there are a ton of great sushi places in SF.  This place is in the upper middle, but is outrageously priced.  It is a good option for business travellers or out of town guests but not as a regular sushi place
author: Spencer G.

description:
I'm writing this review several weeks after dining here, and no one dish really stands out for me...it was all good.  I the service was great and nearly everything we tried was delicious.  Oh, I do remember that the market price for toro was $10 per piece that night...ouch!  Overall, it was a nice experience and I'd go back.  Try the sake flights!

One funny thing - while we were sitting near the bar waiting for our table, a group of loud, obnoxiously dressed people (drinking 40s of Corona, no less!) started addressing a waitress rather rudely.  She was polite back to them, and THEN they called over a manager to complain about HER!  I felt so bad for her!  Our table was ready at that point, so I don't know how it all played out...hopefully they got the hint that this was not their sort of place, and went to McDonald's or something.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Ozumo is def one of the more upscale sushi restaurants in the city so be prepared to spend a little more than usual.  First indication is the sake list which had a bottle listed at $1100 for the first choice.  Uhmmmm..ok.  Who the hell knows about sake other than you want it one of those mini jugs and want it hot right now?!  We resorted to a sake flight which was good but was a total jip in my opinion $16 for 3 shot glasses worth.  Onto the food..really good I'll have to say.  Presentation was nice, ingredients tasted fresh, and service was attentive...I had the yellowtail collar which would have scared more people when you saw it's presentation, but it looked even scarier when I was done with it.  I actually visualized taking the kitchen hostage until I could get more, but remained reserved nonetheless.  The hamachi appetizer and tuna tartare were amazing as well and gone in a second.  Lastly, I'm a pannacotta freakazoid and have to say that was one of the best!  Tasted like a citrus bomb...shaved meyer lemon skin and grapefruit added a nice touch.  We also shared a chocolate flourless cake with green tea ice cream which was equally amazing.  Go here if you're up for the sushi dining experience, but just know there are also plenty of really good sushi places to try in SF if you don't want to spend so much.  Domo Arigato!
author: Darren B.

description:
I love this place. Wonderful innovative Japanese food. The Uni Risotto is to die for, creamy, unctuous and immensely satisfying.  Their Hamachi with Ponzu dressing (their signature small plate) is also extremely delicious, the Hamachi is almost meat like in texture, and nicely complemented with a slightly citrus soy sauce... delicious.

Great Sake menu too with a good selection of small format DaiJinJiu. 

Definitely worth a visit or three.
author: Shay S.

description:
We went to a couple special meals here and it was very good. but too loud. the friend japanese specialties were the best.

i would recommend this to anyone wanting japanese fusion.
author: Jim D.

description: Ozumo is hit or miss. First time I went, my friends and I had a 45 min wait on our food. The next time I went, however, my food came right away. Either way, the food is amazing and I definitely recommend it to everyone!
author: Sara S.

description:
Lacking in service...the waiter brought something we didn't order and completely forgot about something we did. 

You gotta love the saki samplers though. i agree on the overpriced sushi comment.
author: Kristina A.

description:
Ozumo's is all about dining with ambiance, and the prices reflect more of that than the value of the meal. It's sleek and modern. Business professionals crowd the place for happy hour. Gorgeous people are everywhere. Again, you're paying for the atmosphere and eye candy.

The sushi menu is not as innovative as Chaya or Zushi Puzzle, but the food is decent. There is a sake tasting area, which I have yet to try. Many partners at my firm rarely visit Ozumo's, and so it's not a business luncheon favorite.
author: Cathy H.

description:
I don't mind Ozumo, but the sashimi is consistently underwhelming.

Pretty good place to stop by for a drink and some rolls.
author: Liza P.

description:
What a FEAST I had here.  

The ambiance was pretty awesome. Very modern and contemporary with sake bottles lined as wall dividers. Dark, sleek and great.  The only issue I had were the tacky red netting surrounded by the rope lights that were hung out the windows overlooking the beautiful embarcadero.  Very dorm room-esque.

Service was attentive and pretty efficient. He couldn't really recommend any good sake which I thought was off since Ozumo prides itself as a Sake bar... that was pretty annoying.  However, once the drinks did start flowing, we just ordered flight after flight and trying all of the specialties.

Our party ate like kings and queens. We had an 11 course meal.  

Seaweed Salad was very seaweedy. I wasnt sure if I was biting into salt or sand at one point. I bit too bland for me.

Eel Salad was delicious. eel was deliciously prepared and delicate on top of micro greens. Recommended.

Tuna Tartare was very average borderline tasteless. Presentation was outstanding.

Sushi rolls were average. The flavors were all semi bland however the presentation again were excellent.  Extremely fresh which was nice.

The tempura was pro bally one of the highlights of the evening. Perfectly fried to crispness and that batter was not heavy or thick. It was a hit.

The fish braised with green tea rice was a bit lacking flavor.  very bland.

The Kobe style beef was not as tender as I imagined it to be, however again presentation was excellent.

Fillet Mignon was delicious as well, but by that time everyone was just so stuffed!!

Overall, this place is pretty expensive. Our bill for 11 people came out to be $1700 so it's not cheap to say the least. I don't recommending here if you are extremely hungry, however I would recommending tasting sake here and munching on goodies. Just make sure your waiter knows what the hell he is talking about.
author: Joel Y.

description:
Ok, so I'm from LA and may be biased, but the ambiance ROCKS! I love the Dj, the lighting, the vibe is great.
 
The food is quite good, but not as good as Katsu-ya in LA and much much pricier.  Our service was really 'strange'..don't remember the name of the waitress, but she pretty much bullied us into ordering certain things. My friends and I got a laugh out of it, but not the coolest of circumstances.

If you like to people watch, this may be your place. Seems to cater to the pretty out of towners.

Really should have given it 3 stars, but I would go back.
author: Aaliya Y.

description:
I'm sure the food here is fine however, we never got to eat it. If you can get through the hostess desk unscathed, "GOOD LUCK TO YOU." 

I made reservations 4 weeks ago for my Birthday this last Saturday 10/19/2013. My husband and I showed up 20 minutes early for an 8:15 reservation. At check-in my husband mentioned that if a table came up sooner we'd be happy to take it. The hostess looked at us like "You've got to be kidding" but said if that were the case she'd let us know. We were enjoying ourselves at the bar and realized some time had past and looked at our watch, it was 20 minutes past our reservation and no one had approached us for an update. My husband approached the hostess desk and inquired about our expired reservation and all the hostess said was "Well, we're busy tonight."  There was no apology or "I'm sorry, next table up is definitely yours." So, when my husband returned, I said "Forget it , let's just go to the SUSHI bar."  We sat down at the sushi bar upstairs, my husband  went to the bathroom and some woman in white ( I think the Manager?) said "Excuse me these seats are RESERVED." Behind her stood, the hostess who'd snubbed us earlier.  So essentially, we left this place that I had chosen to celebrate my birthday at with a reservation made 4 weeks prior with no back up. We went around the corner and were offered a 9:30 seat at CHAYA where we received superb service and excellent food MINUS THE ATTITUDE.

I work in customer service.  I have never been treated so poorly-EVER! We will never patron this place nor recommend it to any of our many friends. The hostess staff was rude, unprofessional and down-right snobby. Unforgivable,  in my opinion.
author: Danielle V.

description: On a Friday night I had the Blue Crab and seaweed salad, the grilled vegetables (egg plant with bonito flakes and peppers), and Gyu primed filet mignon. Although I didn't love the beef the dining experience was top notch. This restaurant tries to be the best Japanese restaurant in the City and often succeeds. I found the waitress to be a bit pushy in trying to have us order more dishes. It is not an inexpensive place to eat. It is an impressive place to eat for a well deserved night out in SF.
author: Mikes M.

description: Super tasty sprizer drinks, nice ambiance and good service. I would identify the food offering as California Cuisine....sushi (with a modern twist), burgers, salads, etc. Good place for business lunch or just out with friends.
author: jamie j.

description:
I first read about Ozumo in Wallpaper magazine. They'd
received positive press for its high style interior,
thanks to top Tokyo design group Super Potato Co. The
6000 square foot former home of Harry Denton's has now
become a landmark destination for the design conscious
jet setter. Atmosphere aside, the food here is top
notch Japanese. Innovative, yet traditional sushi
offerings left me pleasantly content. Ozumo typically
offers a fixed menu, omakase-style, which I highly
recommend. Reservations have been fairly easy to come
by, but when you call, be sure to ask for a table
close to Embarcadero street, where the Bay Bridge
views are to die for.
author: Philip M.

description:
Ozumo is a great place for happy hour on the weekdays! I came here with my friends yesterday after work and it was happening! We got there around 6pm and it was packed! Drinks are really good here. I had the Geisha Moon and it was made with pineapple infused vodka with lychee puree. YUM! Appetizers are pretty good too. We got a bunch of sushi and Japanese sweet potato fries. Delicious. Definitely yet here early on Thursday, seems like people start drinking here around 430!

I had dinner here a few years ago and it's only ok. Food is not bad, but really overpriced for Sushi and entrees.

Update: Since my bf was working late last night, I decided to meet up with him for dinner. Ozumo is close by, so we came here. Since it was on the company's dime, I didn't mine the prices. Hahhahaha.... We started with the sukiyaki. The broth was warm and savory filled with slices of beef and veggies. It was delicious. We also had the rainbow roll and spicy tuna roll. Both were very good. Loved the extra drizzle of siracha sauce on top. For dessert, we had the caramelized apples served in a phyllo cup with rice pudding flavor ice cream. It was yummy!
author: Denise L.

description:
In an attempt to flee the Saturday night mayhem of the Mission after my birthday dinner at Andalu, my girlfriend and I took off for the Embarcadero.  Not sure where we wanted to go, we just wanted somewhere we could park without having to give more money to a valet.

On our way to Americano at about 12:15 we stumbled into Ozumo.  Intrigued by the sexy lighting and older gentlemen in ties, we walked in.  Turns out they were having last call.  A little early for our tastes, but we stayed anyway.  

Matt at the bar took care of us though, and even entertained us while he counted out his cash register.  We were there until about 1:00am, and which point there are a few other bars in the vicinity to check out.  

The decor in Ozumo is hot.  It's an Asian/French ambiance, with low lighting and amazing furniture.  I love when you walk in somewhere commercial and you immediately want a piece they've decorated with.  The bar stools are amazing, and they have these long, high wooden benches at the bar that are comfy, but also look so cool.

Great place to have a relaxing late night drink after the escape from Valencia.  I can't wait to go back and eat!
author: Rachel G.

description:
I definitely loved the atmosphere at this place.. doesn't have banging music that blows your eardrums like Blowfish.  Still very yuppie.  We got to sit by the sake bar at the front o the restaurant.  THey ahve these really cool seats there.  They have a big selection of sake and even a girl promoting a brand of sake going around.  Very expensive place... you're basically shelling out about $100 per person with food and sake there i'd assume.. 
food was yummy and they decorate it alll cute
restaurant ambiance and decor is five stars

would definitely come back with some work ppl
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Yeah, I'm glad this was a company lunch and I didn't have to pay.

Although the sushi was great and everything tasted fresh, it was overpriced.  Sometimes that's just how quality sushi is, at least I could tell I wasn't going to contract dysentery from a bacteria riddled piece of hamachi nigiri.  Right?

The decor was nice, we had a party of 8 and they sat us in this private room all enclosed by lucite shelves decorated with empty sake bottles.  Cool atmosphere, especially the bathrooms that gave mini Japanese lessons while you were using the receptacle.  You can't really beat learning and peeing simultaneously.

We tried two types of sake, a nigori that was called something like Winter Snow or Winter Night, either way, it was unfiltered and great.  Then we had the Dewazakura Oka or how ever you spell it, that I first became entranced by at Yoshi's, which was equally delectable and fresh tasting.

We ordered two types of edamame to help ease our tummies while patiently waiting for platters of recently deceased fish.  I don't like shit on my edamame, I like it cold, plain, slick, and green - just like I like my men.  There edamame was fresh and I feel like you can tell a lot about the quality of Japanese food just by edamame, so I interpreted this positively.

My coworkers ordered the edamame bathed in sauce and heated and garlicked, which I didn't try because I didn't want to subsequently kill someone with my breath, but they all loved it and ate it up quickly.

The service overall was friendly, helpful and speedy.  Our group of 8 was in and our of there in an hour and 15 - not what I expected from the look and feel of the place.  Our waiter was good at dishing out suggestions and taking orders, as all waiters should be.

We followed the edamame with two orders of their gyoza, which were absolutely great.  Cooked to gyoza-standards perfection.  Yeah, that doesn't exist, yet . . .

Then we tried one of every roll and the kona kampachi, hamachi and maguro nigiri - all were fresh and delectable.

I literally have no complaints about Ozumo at lunchtime, it was a great company lunch, pricey but quality.

My only qualm would be that it was just sushi.  Nothing stood out to me or made me crave it enough to want to go back and pay for it myself and I have no problem spending ridiculous amounts on good food or drink.

So, its good, but it's nothing memorable.  The decor almost leaves more to talk about.  Still, I have to reiterate, it didn't let me down I just have standards and they are set by level of memorability apparently ;)
author: Lauren G.

description:
So, I don't eat raw fish, but this place has plenty of other delicious things.

To start, you have to try their garlic edamame.  Best edamame ever.  Also try their Kani Salad (crab cake) - I get this every time I come.  So good.

As for the cooked rolls, in order of TDF-ness:  Ozeki (baked salmon), Yokozuna and Ozumo rolls.  They also do good tempura rolls and  spider rolls.  Their california rolls are pretty average (and I am comparing that to the Taraval Okazu-ya rolls).

Of course, the people I came with got sashimi and all that raw stuff.  Their opinion:  fresh and very good.
author: Violet C.

description: I only came to this grand Japanese restaurant because my team celebrated our success. Although I can afford parts of the menu, everything was out of my price range. Although that was the case, the sushi, nigiri, and sashimi were absolutely delicious. The service was also very good too! I will definitely come back in the future.
author: John V.

description:
The food here was just okay. Nothing special.  Was $270 somehow for 3 people.  

Our hotel encouraged us also to make reservations but the place was completely empty.

Likely will not return.
author: Anna L.

description: Good Japanese! It's expensive, so make sure it's a business lunch or a special occasion. You will see a lot of suits and ties here.  I did like the quality of the sushi here and the service was good.  It can get very crowded and sceney but all the better for people watching! If you can get a seat at one of the long raised tables in front, even better.  They make some might fine mixed drinks here as well. Lastly, I highly recommend the sashimi here!
author: Ka C.

description:
The best meal I've had in years!  I'm warning you now that this review is a bit biased because I went with one of the owners and I can't guarantee that the service and fish quality would have been as incredible if I wasn't.

That's why I'm going again...yes...that's the only reason, really.

First, the sake selection was impressive and well-chosen.  I had eight types of sake utilizing the sake flight options.  The lounge area is intimate and architecturally soothing.

Next, the hot plates...we started with the hanabi, slices of hamachi and avocado with a ginger/jalapeno ponzu sauce, which turned out to be one of my favorite dishes.  The hamachi melted in my mouth and the sauce accented the flavor of the hamachi rather than mask it.  The futago less impressive, but the tenderloin was juicy and flavorful.  The sakura, beef carpaccio, was much better in the non-seafood category.

The sashimi was very high quality, fresh fish.  The toro was, frankly, beautiful.  I almost couldn't eat it...almost.  What really got me was the mackerel.  It wasn't saba.  The waiter advised me that it was a younger mackerel.  I forgot what it was called, but if they have it, get it.

It's almost a shame to get rolls or nigiri there.  Any additions take away from the fish.  One thing I have to commend is that they use snow crab rather than that god-awful imitation crab in anything with crab.

I rarely order cooked fish at a sushi restaurant, but someone else I was with did and I'm grateful for it.  The hotate, sake herb soaked scallops with a raspberry vinaigrette, was plump and bursting with flavor.  The cod tore apart easily and soaked up that miso-sake sauce goodness.

The desserts, I could have done without.  Not that they were bad, but this place would never be known for their desserts.

The prices are a bit steep if you are big eater.  Some of the dishes were small even for me and I get full off garnish usually.

Overall, to have this meal over again to the caliber I had it, I'd pass up great sex.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Let's just all be clear here.  Ozumo's is a place where pretty boys and girls go to meet (just like the sign says on top of a dumpy bar in Chinatown).  This is not a place to get top sushi.

Ozumo's is well located in the financial district nearby the legendary Boulevard's.  Somehow besides Boulevard's that block over the years has been the home of "high-end" chain restaurant.  Both Chaya and Ozumo's have sister restaurant in SoCal.  That in itself is not a knock.

Ozumo's is a fun, loud place with nice decor.  The kitchen is relatively fast given the number of patrons.  Be prepared to shell out some cash though.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I've been here a few times over the past several years and have never been a big fan.  But the last two times, I would say that they have something going on.  A good afterwork bar scene for the downtown crowd, friendly (one really hot) bartenders and good drinks make it a great place to post up. 

Dinner is high end, tasty japanese dishes with friendly and knowledgable staff that know their sushi and sake.   My waitress went as far as to break down the regions of sakeville like napa valley and i walked out drinking better sake and knowing it (and paying for it)!. domo origato!!
author: Kevin J.

description:
Went hear with my boyfriend and his parents to celebrate him turning the big 22. I loved the decor and the staff was very knowledgeable and attentive. 

All the dishes brought out were bursting with such exquisite flavors and uniqueness. At first I was frowning on the size of the portions which seemed rather small and delicate. But by the time we had finished our last dish, the rice began to expand throughout my stomach and I felt content. 

Not content however to find out after arriving back home with my boyfriend where he told me the shirt I choose to wear wasn't "parent appropriate". WTF? Apparently I had too much cleavage showing. I thought to myself "hey, it was you're birthday not there's".
author: Ericka A.

description:
i have NO idea why ozumo chooses to ALWAYS be dark.  But whatever, they have sushi and sake so i'm thrilled.

The sushi is great, but i am usually there for happy hour festivities... meaning drinks, not food.  They do have great sashimi and an amazing selection of sake to boot.

Crowded, hot, and loud... but what hopping happy hour isn't??
author: Alison R.

description:
Not so good for groups: mediocre quality on the set menu, odd service.

Work had organized a big group lunch (around two dozen people), so we ordered from a set menu with three choices of bento boxes.  I had the sushi which was ...  mediocre.  Not as bad as Safeway, but not as good as at SFO.  Pretty appalling, given the price.

I can only imagine, based on the other reviews, that their bento box sushi is somehow lower-grade than the rest of their sushi.  But given how disappointed I was with lunch, I'm not willing to spend more money to find out.

On the service side, things were a bit mixed.  On the plus side, they took our orders promptly, were friendly, etc.  The odd things were..
- They ran out of green tea.  One of my colleagues said she'd been there for dinner and the same thing had happened.  They're a Japanese restaurant, this isn't supposed to happen....
- They served desert two-people-to-a-bowl.  Um, I like my coworkers and all, but I don't usually share ice cream with them.  Fortunately, they did bring us extra empty bowls when we asked, so a germ-fest was averted.
author: Patricia F.

description:
Two words:  Happy Hour

Come for the happy hour sushi and a cocktail.  Their happy hour sushi list is small, but affordable and really good.  The decor is awesome, but the staff is a little slow and snotty.  That's were the cocktails come into place.  Some how a little vodka can make all of that go away.  

Last time I was here with some friends after work, we bumped into Steve Young while getting our table in the bar area.  I tried not to be "starry eyed," but I couldn't help but to keep looking over my shoulder to see if he would pass by again.  :-)

Go for some happy hour sushi and cocktails.  You won't be disappointed and your wallet will be happy too.
author: lea m.

description:
I threw our company holiday party in the Ozumo Sake Lounge.  OMG, with over 100 sakes, you know it was a success!

The food is amazing!  The sake is never ending!  The staff is hip and attentive.  The DJ's spin some groovin' tunes, just right for the atmosphere of the place.  

I've been several times for lunch and dinner and drinks and appetizers.  The staff has gotten to know me by name and that's always a good feeling.
author: Eric E.

description:
Ichiban for sure!

Dee-licious food, awesome happy hour, and when DJ Label was ruling the turntables, life was like a Zen garden whose gentle rocks, well, rocked. 

Though New Years Eve reservations were more populous than Shibuya crosswalk at rush hour, I managed to score the private Sake Tasting Room. Sugoi! The prix fixe menu was stunning (kobe beef, scallops, amazing sushi), the sake to-die-honorably-for, and the ambiance truly superb.

A glitch in the matrix? Once I dined there and our waiter didn't know anything about anything and couldn't answer a single question, but I'm going to send that experience to the floating world of bad dreams and banish it from my mind. 

Why? Because Ozumo is happiness best served cold with soy sauce.

Sure, the food is more expensive than popcorn at a baseball game in Tokyo, yet this inauspicious fact is mitigated by a very reasonable happy hour which you MUST attend! You won't even have to sumo wrestle with your wallet!

Oh, life is incomplete without Ozumo!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Great food, and super fresh.  They have a lot of great dishes that are a great mix with traditional Japanese fare, as well as some great stand-by's.  

Sapporo and Chimay on tap was a big plus, and the staff was very quick and helpful.  Not too sure I understood the seating situation; even on a normal weekday I would still make a reservation, or try to find a spot up front---they have the same menu, just not the view of the bay.  Guess you could sit at the sushi bar too, but that isn't great if you have more than 2 in the party.
author: Andrew A.

description:
YUMO!  Fantastic sushi - always, always, ALWAYS order the special sashimi, whatever it is, it has never done me wrong.  

The set-up/dcor of Ozumo's is awesome... love the trendy, young and fresh vibe.  Love that you can look at the window to the bay while you're chowing down.  Love that they serve some of the best Sake available.  Love the service at lunch and also the bar service for after lunch cocktails.  Love using the restroom and learning how to say "would you like to have a drink with me" or "how do you get to the airport" in Japanese.  

Do not love two things... the prices (though I rarely pay), but it IS worth it!  Also, do not the service on a busy night.  Great place for lunch and happy hour - dinner is debatable... you must have patience, which I do not.  But that is why I love them for lunch!  

Kanpai!
author: Kris I.

description:
The sushi was ok, not fantastic but still good. I really liked the strawberry martini drink they have; was def. the highlight of my meal. I have a feeling the more I drank, the better the food tasted :-)
The ambiance is nice though, especially for San Francisco. It's nice to see people get a little more dressed up even if you are just going to a bar. I did have the distinct feeling that most of the people around me worked in finance though. I wonder why....
author: shadi m.

description:
Interesting foods. but is this Japanese? I am not sure. 

Sushi rice was not as soft as I like and the sushi was very expensive. Fish itself was fresh but sushi is more about rice, isn't it?

Hanabi: Hamachi sashimi, sliced avocado, and ponzu sauce with A LOT of garlic, was good but I don't prefer garlic with Japanese food. I think it kills the flavor of fish. 

You should go there for atomosphere but not for sushi. Midioca food and hip atomosphere. Great intro to Japanese food. 

1 star for creative appetizers 
1 star for atomosphere and a good company
1 star for the view
author: Mika G.

description:
I have always enjoyed the food and atmosphere at Ozumo.  By far the best sushi quality in the area.  No other place offers a great social atmosphere and a traditional Japanese restaurant feel in the same place.
This being said, it is the service that drove me to write this review.  I was there for dinner this week.  While taking off my jacket, a button tore off my lapel.  While checking my coat, I mentioned my frustration with the idea of  walking around the rest of the evening with a silly looking jacket.  When I went to pickup my jacket 90 minutes later, the button was back on.  Apparently, Carla took my jacket, found a sewing kit and put the button back on.

This is service that I have never experienced before and made my evening.

Well done...and thanks.
author: Dewey R.

description: Beautiful presentation, fresh fresh fresh, not just the ordinary Japanese food, excellent wine selection, beautiful people and lovely waitresses- simply a joy going there, either for the food or for hanging out at the bar. There is not more to say, love it!
author: Angela R.

description: I was at a coporate dinner sponsored by Lithium technologies a group of about 20 people on Friday June17th. The food and service was EXCELLENT! The wait staff was patient and accomodating. The manager took time out to check with the organizer of the event to make sure everything was going as planned. We had a 6 course dinner and the timing of bringing everthing out was perfect. A mistake was made in one of the items that had been selected and it was quickly corrected. I would not hesitate to go back!
author: Marsha M.

description:
This is a good after work spot as it is convenient to the Financial District, Fridays are definitely a little crazier. The sushi is very good, but overall the restaurant is pretty pricey considering other places you could go in the city for sushi. Definitely get a reservation for a group larger than 2 or 3, or be prepared to hang out at the bar for a long wait (which isn't a terrible option, the bar is big and is a good scene for people watching) 

the "small plates" are very tasty, especially the hamachi one and the one with the beef and eggplant. Sushi is very fresh. However, overall everything is very overpriced. 

bottom line - great place if you can go on the expense account.
author: Jessica W.

description:
First visit had drinks at the bar; second time around sat in the back at the sushi bar and had the BEST time. Food was amazing, service great--thanks, Hilary:)

Exceptional sake menu. Exceptional sushi. Very cool atmosphere.  First rate...as close as tokyo as it gets.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Wendy F.

description:
My boss and I were talking about where to eat one day and she always wanted to come to this place because it is Japanese and she loves Japanese food.  It's in a nice quiet part of SoMa, next to Perry's and a hotel.  

When you first walk in, you are met by hundreds of bottles of sake. I understand that this place is well known for having a vast array of sakes. 

As far as the food, we ordered a nice appetizer of snapper, which was just okay.  It was served warm which I am not sure if it was supposed to be, but probably was.  We both ordered the Ramen which was really good.  The noodles had great texture and the broth was tasty.

my one complaint is that i didn't feel so great after the meal, somethin didnt sit right.  Not sure what it was, but Ozumo is a great place to go on a date or just a casual lunch or dinner, I'll be back soon.
author: Dustin K.

description:
overrated. 

I judge a good sushi place by the rice. There has to be the exact amount of rice for a nirigi - not too much. Also, the rice has to have the right amount of vinegar aso that it gives it that little kick. I don't think the place mastered that. Shameful how they can't even master the most basic step. 

Happy hour is good though. Good prices. Cool beer. Great selection of sake. And great ambiance
author: Keara C.

description:
Ozumo is certainly an experience. I recently went with three friends coming in from New York on business, and fortunately on their tab (it came to about $450... ok including two bottles of sake and some kobe beef)! For a Japanese restaurant, I think that overall their food is overpriced, and I'd definitely go elsewhere for my every day sushi needs, but some of the outstanding (non sushi) dishes, notably the black cod, I would definitely come back for. 

We were seated quickly, in a section of mostly people on dates, although the place was loud enough to be a little rowdy, and giggly as we caught up with each other. The waitress could not have been nicer, and made some excellent suggestions for our meal.

Drinks: One bottle of sake during dinner, a bottle of unfiltered sake near the end of dinner. (The unfiltered sake has a more pungent taste that can overshadow food. I was actually very thankful for the waitress telling us this in advance.) I wish I had written down the names, because both were superb.

Food: 

The O.k.: 

::Kaiso Seaweed Salad. For some reason the flavors of this were off, and the assortment of seaweed I didn't find very appealing.

::Hanabi. Slices of Avocado and Hamachi in Ponzu sauce, sadly this dish just seemed a little bit bland- I wanted a little bit more acid and taste to it.

::Bacon Wrapped scallops on mushrooms... I can't find this on the menu... but it wasn't very memorable anyway.

The Really Good:

::Oysters. Great. Just great. And I moved from New England where we get the best of them, and certainly have had some good ones.

::Warm edamame with garlic soy sauce. Yummy!

::The Toro (Tuna belly) sushi. A nice piece of fish.

::Kobe beef. Yes, we shelled out out the $105 for ten very thin slivers of wagyu beef. It was good, melt in your mouth, burst of flavor, but I won't do it again. The presentation was pretty, with some carrot kinpira (that I make better at home).

The Stand Outs:

::Gindara- Black cod marniated in Miso, was so incredibly delicious. The cod melted like butterfish, and was evocative of some of my favorite long marinated items on the menu at Nobu and Blue Ginger. I would most definitely order this again.

::Pan seared scallops on mushroom risotto- perfectly cooked scallops, and such a lovely risotto. I was worried that it might be too salty based on reviews, but we seemed to arrive on a perfect night. 

::the amberjack sushi (special) Just beautiful pieces of fish.

It was a lot of food, we didn't have dessert, and we were all pleasantly full. While I'd hesitate going back because of the price, that black cod ($28) might call me back sometime soon. But for sushi, I think I'll try to find a new place that is a little more affordable. All in all, enjoyable.
author: Samantha T.

description:
Don't get me wrong, it was one of the greater sushi experiences of my life, but the price is a big downside. Other than that, The fish was extremely fresh and the environment was lively. They also have a great Sake list with unlimited options.
Highly recommended if you're not footing the bill.
author: Philip T.

description:
Very overpriced but the worst part is the ATTITUDE of the hostesses. They are unfriendly and unwilling to help.When i tried to call in and buy a gift certificate they told me I had to FAX in a form that i had to download from the web!!!!

Said i just wanted t buy over the phone and pick it up and they said they couldn't do that. Just very unwilling to help a customer.

Oh and it's usually 110 degreees in the back so get ready to sweat.
author: David P.

description:
Just got back from lunch.  Ordered an assortment of special rolls.  Scallop roll was spicier than the spicy tuna roll.  Too many rolls filled with the ground crab salad.  Yech.

Very frsh, good service, overpriced, campy.  There are better and more authentic sushi places in the city, just fewer tourists reviewing them.
author: Lauren J.

description: It is a popular Japanese rest, their food is above average but a bit pricey.
author: Antonio L.

description:
As a place for sushi, I want to love Ozumo but I just can't. This place is only two blocks from where I live so I have been many times. But I just never love the place. 

On the PLUS side:
- The sushi is very good; sometimes amazingly good. And the selection is always good.
- Good appetizer and dinner items. Mostly delicious.
- It has a fun, trendy atmosphere and often has a fun vibe. Nice views depending on where you sit. 
- Good wine and sake list.
- I go to sushi by myself fairly often and this is a good place to chat with other patrons. People are really friendly at the sushi bar.

On the NEGATIVE side:
- The prices are really insanely high. I am NOT a price sensitive consumer at all; especially with sushi. But my bill here has been more than I have paid for the finest, most exclusive sushi in Tokyo (including the bad exchange rate). And it can be twice as much as I pay for the best Omakasi in SF. The sake and wine is especially pricey. 
- Many (most) of the sushi chefs are not Japanese. Although they do a fine job preparing the sushi, it isn't the same thing as getting sushi from someone that apprenticed for years in Japan.
- The sushi staff is pretty stand-offish. I like to have a conversation with the sushi chef. That has never happened for me here.
- The rest of the staff can be just a bit full of themselves. They sometimes give the sense that their restaurant is "all it" and that you are lucky to be there. And overall, the place can be a bit more of a scene than I am looking for when I just want good food.
- I don't like how the seats at the sushi bar are so low. I am 6 ft tall but the sushi bar feels too high. It makes sitting at the bar a bit uncomfortable.
- The soy sauce is low sodium. You have to ask for regular soy sauce. Since low sodium soy sauce is really just watered down soy sauce, it doesn't work with sushi.

Overall, this is a very good place but a very bad value. And, again, this is coming from someone that almost never pays attention to price.
author: Kevin K.

description: Excellent, authentic food.  Very fresh.  Expertly prepared. Wonderful staff.  Great sake selection. Good bar that is nicely separated from the dining room. I've been dining there for years and have never had a bad bite.
author: Henry H.

description: Our second time here and just as outstanding. Everything from the sushi to the vegetable tempura (light and fluffy) to the incredible black cod was superb. Rice pudding was the cherry on the sundae! Will go back again. A very special place!
author: Suzanne L.

description: Good food, good atmosphere, very pleasant staff. Bit pricey though.
author: Mihai M.

description: Over priced Sushi, this place is a fake. Service was friendly, Fresh sushi, yes, but my overall experience in the city didn't win too many stars with me.
author: P B.

description:
This is a great place if you can get a seat at the sushi bar--- Otherwise I guess you can enjoy the ambiance, which don't get me wrong, is beautifully stylish. I've observed though, that service is much better at the bar, otherwise you may find yourself trying to flag someone down as it gets pretty busy. 

The bar is tres chic as well. It's sorta loungy and on weekends they sometimes have Japanese DJ's spinning, which makes it a more upbeat place to hang out. The bartenders are really friendly and definitely make this place all the more positive for me.

They're certainly more on the pricey side-- but you're paying for the atmosphere. If you're in the mood to 'see & be seen' in a comfortable and sylish spot with decent food, this is the place for you.
author: Ikeb I.

description:
Great overall menu. Great fusion appetizers, good sushi, great sake, and good atmosphere. Some of their fish dishes are awesome.

Solid wait staff and service.
author: Bernard M.

description:
Sushi is top notch, but i could be biased because i had to wait almost an hour for our before we got to the table (even though we had reservations). Portions are small, but rolls are excellent. Try the spicy scallop or the rainbow roll. The seaweed salad was not very good. 

With our waitstaff, they were friendly, but often got us the wrong dish and mixed us up with other tables. We had to ask several times for our requests. I have been here before, and im giving them the benefit of the doubt tha tthey were just having an off night. 

I would come back here again, but will have snacked on something first.
author: Sonia C.

description:
AMAZING Restaurant.. Amazing food..the sushi is some of the freshest in the city.. the robata and kitchen serve some really great stuff.. but the price.. it's a little over my budget.. 

must haves..
Gindara.. awesome black cod marinated in sake miso rosated/charred on the robata grill..
hanabi.. their "signature" dish.. thin hamachi served medium rare with a warm jalepeno ponzu
YAMABUKI you have to have this.. this is my personal favorite.. for 10 bucks you get a creamy rich uni risotto... 


if you can afford to eat here .. then please do.. 

Working here is a whole different story.. if i were just a customer eating here i would've given it 4/5 stars but after working in Ozumo.. dealing with the shitty management and owners this place ends up with a 2/3 star
author: Timothy W.

description:
Incredibly expensive sushi.  Good, yes, but still expensive.

The number one reason to go to Ozumo? Most might say the food, but I say its the Japanese language lessons in the bathrooms.
author: Eric P.

description:
188 reviews?????????  Damn!!!!!

The sushi is absolutely great here.  They have this really neat low couches and low tables so having lunch or dinner there feels like you're in Tokyo!

On a side note, it's too bad they closed their Newport Beach location.  Everything on their menu is great and authentic.  One of the best sushi places in the U.S.
author: Maome S.

description:
Hello Sake flight...  The bartenders in this place know more about rice wine than many of the self proclaimed "wine connoisseurs" that I've encountered (from a person experience standpoint).  The bar is aesthetically appealing with its very wooden structure and stools and while you chat it up with a knowledgeable bar staff and build up an appetite, there will be some fantastic sushi awaiting your city-centric and hard to impress pallet.

Ozumo is in a really great spot (it is pretty quiet, easy to find, close to Market St., the Ferry Building, the Bay Bridge, etc.) so you have no excuse NOT to find time to pay this little spot a visit.

Also, if you walk out onto the sidewalk and turn right you will find a pair of glass doors that form a sharp angle on the sidewalk (I forget the name of the place) that is home to a really great basement piano bar.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
It's one of the go-to bars for after work. The place can get pretty busy on a Friday, so if your co-workers are thinking about going then make sure you send someone to go first and secure a section of a bench for you guys. 

The drinks are ok---nothing spectacular.

The appetizers are pretty good. I recommend the Carpaccio, but for those who are weak in the tummy, I will warn you, it does look like raw meat... but still, it taste good.

Apparently ALL of my male co-workers think the bartender there is cute. So, fellas... 

Advisory:
It smells like a toilet there. It's like everytime someone flushes the toilet at the YMCA, you get a wind of sewer smell. This can ruin any good conversation you're having with the hottie next to you.

Basically, nothing jumps out at me, so it gets 2 stars.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
We ate dinner in the bar, which is really loud, clubby  and dark,  not my favorite way to eat dinner.  The sushi is good, but nothing amazing and for the price you pay, I think it should be close to the best.  The service was not that great, but from what I heard, it might have been an off night.  

I would give it 3 1/2 stars and might try eating in the dining room next time.
author: vanessa c.

description:
This restaurant gets 1-star automatically for charging $4 for a small bowl of miso soup.  If you want a couple mushrooms in the miso soup, they charge you another $2!  That's just absurd and just plain wrong.

For the people who think that Ozumo has the best sushi, they are paying too much for sushi that's not spectacular.  I've had better quality sushi at other japanese restaurants in San Francisco and in other places in my lifetime.

This place is just over-priced and for the food that you get, it's nothing special.  For the amount of food that we ordered, it would probably be a $60 bill at a decent japanese restaurant.  However, it turned out to be $100+ at Ozumo.

Granted, it is nice inside and a pretty big restaurant, so they've earned that 1-star for that.  I'd go with a group of friends to have a drink at the bar, but I would not recommend eating there due to the fact that there's better places out there.
author: Michael F.

description:
Atmosphere: 5; Service:3; Food: 4
I thought the atmosphere was stunning with extreme modernist design.  They have this "room" surrounded by sake bottles! Super cool!
I had lunch there with a group of co-workers and I thought the lunch menu price was completely affordable in such an enjoyable ambiance!

I wasn't too impressed with the service, it came with a bit of attitude. I can actually do without it.
author: N. C.

description:
I think this place is overrated. Granted, it is nice, chic and tasty -- you can get the same satisfaction at another sushi place for way less. I must say the waiters really know their stuff though. Our waiter recited everything that was on the menu from top to bottom and more. Each dish is specially handcrafted with delicate detailing -- so nice; you dont want to eat it!

I've been wanting to go to this place for the longest time and when I finally did; i was really disappointed because I was expecting orgasmically tasty sushi!!!
author: Bonnie Y.

description:
Very expensive but delicious.  Great ambiance and good service.

Although the spider roll was good, the chocolate fondu and mochi ice cream were especially delicious.

Great place and even better if someone treats you.
author: Ankur P.

description:
Went here for a bday dinner.
I'm very picky on sushi as I grown up in Japan so i went with a rather low expectation.

The rolls are very much Americanized, but well combined. The nigiris were good, and the side dishes were creative with rather authentic taste. Ozumo is rather pricey, but I think it's nice for an occasion.
author: Lance C.

description:
*READ IF YOU ARE GOING TO DINE HERE, AND NOT GO HERE FOR HAPPY HOUR*

Ozumo is an appealing restaurant with its interior design and japanese like atmosphere. It has a lot of faults though with all this.

Food: My god, the food sucked. First off, the portions they give u are incredibly small ( not enough for 1 person) on most dishes, and cost WAAAAAAY too much for such a petite amount. Second, the food takes way too long to prepare. Lastly, for the cost of the dishes, u expect heavenly tastes. NOT HERE, the food takes like plastic sometimes and isn't worth the cost.

Service: the service isn't great for such a high quality restaurant. The waiters rarely come by to check on their tables, and u have to actually wait to get refills on drinks.  Also, everytime i've went, the waiters have either messed up an order or forgot to put it in, which shows how inexperienced they are or how bad the pay is if experienced waiters keep leaving Ozumo....

In the end, i do not recommend Ozumo. Food is overpriced and service sucks. If you do go, stick with sushi, you can't go wrong w/ their sushi at least. But as critics of SF have said about going to Ozumo, "Your money will be O-Zum-ing out of your wallet"
author: Dylan T.

description:
Based on NOT sushi

Minus one for not being kid friendly. As soon as our waiter showed up, I asked for rice and some chicken ASAP. After the water, the tea, I asked again. they finally brought it much much later. uncool when you have an angry hungry 23 month old

BUT the rest of the meal was great
we had
sukiyaki - though only 4 pieces of meat? kobe beef though. and they had the raw egg in there, without asking or without enough liquid to cook it, if I had wanted it cooked...
a bunch of the robata grill
sweet potato (who could not love carbs?)
baby corn - great for the little one
salmon - my friend called it perfectly cooked!
unagi - different from any other presentation that you are used to... good
chicken "tender" - basically your basic chicken skewer - no biggie

dessert!
loved the dark chocolate fondue!! had all sorts of stuff!  strawberries, bananas, cantaloupe, mango, cake, mochi ice cream (didn't work well but was delicious on its own)
BUT they did not work out regulation of heat or how much chocolate, b/c by the end the chocolate was burning/burnt...

as for tea, the person asked "tea for the table?" and only brought 1 pot, so we did not get charged $6/person.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Another late night business dinner.  This time, I'm at Ozumo with 7 other people.  The big boss is well known here apparently.

We arrived around 7:45pm and I realized it reminded me of a place...  oh yeah, Blowfish.  Lots of city people around the bar drinking, trying to look cool and chic.  And the music was pretty loud.

We were shown to the private room in the back.  The boss ordered sushi, main dishes, drinks, dessert.  I don't eat raw fish so I had some of the other shared dishes: ebi tempura roll, edmame with salt and garlic oil, the black cod marinated in miso, and the seared sea scallops.  Everything was good but very salty.  Everyone was drinking, heavily, including 900 year old sake.

Bill came and I took a peek - including tips, the total was $2500.  WOW.  OUCH.  Glad that I didn't have to pay.  We didn't have that much food because I wasn't even close to being full; it was probably the alcohol that dented the bill.

The place was ultra modern and had a cool atmosphere.  However, the quality and quantity of the food doesn't match the price you pay.  I suppose you come here to be seen, but for me, I'd rather hide at a corner chowing down better tasting food somewhere else.
author: Yuan W.

description:
Good place for FiDI happy hour or a power business lunch.  Not so good when you're not willing to drop serious dough on a lunch/dinner that will leave you hungry at the end of it.

Beautiful ambience and venue though.
author: Riza A.

description:
Went there once and that's it.  No more!! Too pricey for mediocre food.  Decor is superb, but I base my rating based on the food not the decor.

For real authentic sushi...try Osome or Ryoko's.  You won't be disappointed.  Not the same atmosphere like Ozumo, more of a true traditional Japanese restaurant.  Especially Ryoko's...it's something like you would find in a Japanese movie.

Ozumo seems like it is catering to more of the "whitey" (I am by far not a racist) crowd.  My person opinion(and it is just that my "personal" opinion) is that any restaurant that caters to a specific crowd is only cheating their patrons because they steer away from the authenticity of the food they are serving.
author: Thomas P.

description:
Best of the best sushi places in the Bay Area!!! This is a beautiful place located right near the water with a spectacular view of the Bay Bridge. My husband and I ate here on the 4th of July. I couldn't have asked for a better experience! 

First off, food. Mouth watering delicious menu. (We didn't get to taste everything, however if I had room in my stomach I would've!) The beef tartare was unique with a compliment of a wasabi spice and the grilled octopus with hint of pesto sauce was delicious. Perfect flavors combined with a delicious one of a kind sake. For those of you who are big on sake, this is the place to go! Their array of sake, beer and wine list seems like it goes on forever. However, staff is very knowledgeable on pairings for certain meals and made the meal even better. (Thanks Mr. Greg Nasser for the recommendations!!) For our entree, the black cod fish melted in my mouth. Beautifully displayed and delicious with a side of Brussels sprouts and mushrooms! Each bite was savory! This is a MUST try! Last but not least dessert (my sweet tooth certainly had room for this!). We shared a chocolate soufflé with green tea ice cream. This sweet treat was the perfect ending to our perfect meal! It had just the right amount of sweet bite to it and an amazing green tea ice cream to combine the flavors. I'll definitely be going back for more! 

Second, the staff (everyone!) was so welcoming, helpful, and kind. I've never experienced anything like this. From the host, waitress, chefs, and manager. Everyone made the experience unforgettable! Thank you Jena and Greg for your kindness and hospitality! 

If you're big on sushi, sake, delicious food and a good time, definitely don't miss out on this hidden gem!!! We'll be back for sure!!!
author: Emma N.

description: Had drinks/appetizers on a recent Sunday, late afternoon. Then onto dinner in the main room with a gorgeous window view of the bay.  At the suggestion of our server, we enjoyed an Akebono  roll, black cod, rice and for dessert, apple phyllo w/ ice cream.  ALL delicious ! To top it off, we enjoyed wonderful conversation about other restaurants to try  in the city with our server, Saul. He made several suggestions and wrote them down for us! We will be back... Anxious to try the Ozumo in Santa Monica.
author: Debbie B.

description: Went here for lunch with some friends and have to admit that they have not lost their touch. Had a spicy tuna roll that was to excellent and friends had flat steak don buri that looked like it belongs in a magazine. He said that it was perfect.
author: joseph c.

description: We went to Ozuma last night for girls' night out and had an amazing experience. We received incredibly attentive service at every interaction. We left our dinner up to our sushi chef's, Todd and Charlie, and they didn't disappoint, every plate that was sent out was better than the last. The sushi was so fresh, and the black cod melted in your mouth.  Our tableside check-ins from manager, Brian and chef Alex to make sure we were taken care of were much appreciated. All in all, a fabulous dinner.
author: Amy B.

description:
I went there for lunch after seeing the sign outside for "noon noodles" which are basically a few of their dishes for 10.95. I had the Nagasaki Chanpon noodle bowl and it was so so. The miso broth was very flavorful but everything else in it was bland. The crab tasted of imitation, mussels were very small and the 2 large shrimps were without flavor.

The service I received was horrible. I waited over 10min at the bar before anyone approached me to take my order. Then after I did order the food and a water, the water never arrived. There also must have been an issue with my food since it took at least another 20min just to get it.

Overall I don't think I'll be going back since there are so many other lunch options in the city.
author: Travis J.

description:
Food: 
Toro
Tuna Nigiri
Spicy Tuna Tartare
Octupus Salad
Ribeye steak with mushrooms

Service was great. She was knowledgeable about the different sakes and food suggestions. 

Food...was awesome for the most part. The only negative experience was the octupus salad. I was expecting for a cold salad, the octupus came right off the grill/saute...on top of that...it was burnt so we had the charcoal taste through that salad. I never had Toro before until that evening...OMG...melt in your mouth!!!!! I love Tuna sashimi, and this is just even a better part of Tuna!!! The tuna nigiri was fresh and tasty. The spicy tuna tartare is hands down now my favorite in the city...I only have XYZ and Osha Thai to compare to that. But this tuna tartare is mixed with spicy mayo on top of avocado and in a bowl of this sauce...It comes with wonton chips... yummmm.... Now onto the ribeye...cooked to order...it tastes like any other ribeye and seasoning did not stand out too much. I like mushrooms so glad that came on the dish. Didn't really care for the artichokes on the dish but oh well... Our tab was quite pricey after a cheaper bottle of sake and probably about 6 mixed drinks, our tab was about $400 for 4 people. Ouch...
author: Helen V.

description: The Roasted Yellowtail Collar (Hamachi Kama) served with Daikon-Ponzu Sauce was outstanding!  Thought I would not be able to eat such a large piece but when I was through, only the bones were left - ate the delicious crispy skin too!
author: Mary R.

description: Great service. Excellent food. Knowledgeable staff... ask for charlie .. She's really very helpful and extremely nice :) will defffff come back very soon.
author: Setrak F.

description: My buddy and I were looking for some good sushi the other weekend so we thought to give this place a shot. Absolutely a must if you like good service and plain awesome food. Our waitress was extremely versed on the menu and made some excellent recommendations for us. We started with the beef cheeks, which happened to be a special, and they melted in my mouth. You cant go wrong with anything here. Garlic and soy edemame is superb, toro is off the charts fresh and another melt in your mouth bite, and one of the the best california rolls around if you are looking for the standard sushi order. If you have some coin to spend, this is rediculously good spot.
author: Hunter S.

description:
Sooo my best guy friend and I had our 23rd birthday dinner here. We had reservations for around 20 people. We ended up arriving late for our reservation so we ended up hanging out at the bar for a bit (maybe like 15 minutes at most). So we took a couple of birthday shots before dinner. 

The ambiance was beautiful. Dimly lit. Very Japanese feeling. The bar had wooden benches instead of the typical bar stool. Very modern, yet natural feeling with plants at the same time. The bartender was amazing! My best friend and I got to talking with her about what her favorite shot was to take. She told us she was from Europe, and to try her fave. She poured us both 2 shots and it tasted like WOOD. OMG I almost threw up, but it made for a good laugh - and she did warn us.

My friends ordered me the "tokyo glow" which was a fusion of citrus and sugar and it was delicious. Perfect strength - had a little bite to it, but not too strong. Out of habit I wanted a sashimi plate (i LOVE sashimi), but couldn't find it on the menu. My ex-boyfriend and I asked the waitress if they had such a thing and we were pleasantly surprised to find out that they did. She asked us if we wanted "quality or quantity?" - and I opted for quality. I expected to get a few pieces of sushi: some salmon, tuna, halibut, yellow tail BUT when it came out it was 3-4 pieces of that plus roe and sea urchin (which I did NOT try ew). The sashimi was PHENOMENAL. It was the freshest I've ever tasted (no exaggeration) - I mean melt in your mouth fresh. My ex-boyfriend and I shared that plus vegetable tempura which was an art form in and of itself (we were also surprised by the quantity that came out). The presentation of the food here is gorgeous. We ordered sake for the table, but by that time I was pretty sloshed so I can't really tell you whether it was good or not. My friend ordered the "hanabi" which was amazing - it had avocado with a ponzu sauce. Again, the presentation was prime.

When the bill came out we realized why the sashimi platter was not on the menu - it was $200. Hahaha. I guess that's why it wasn't on the menu! Whatever though, it was SO worth it. This is arguably one of the best sushi places in San Francisco.
author: carol a.

description:
I like this place only because.

I like this place because;
I can enjoy beautiful view of the Bay Bridge.
Sushi can be a very authentic.
If I sat on the counter table I can talk to Japanese sushi chef by Japanese.

I love Hamachi Kama (Yellow tail cheek; most soft part of this fish.) and all other exotic sushi neta hard get else where.


Sometime I don't like this place because;
The sushi chef try to nice to me gave me piece of roll call "Syacho" was too spicy!!!! It was ruin everything I taste goodies.

Also I don't like the little chubby bleached blond Hostess not try to let me sat at the main sushi bar. She try to convince the hall way corner sushi bar seat is better, because can view the out side more.
However way of she said is little bit rude. She make me feel stupid in the way. 

But still OK. It was miner cat fight.

Overall this place is food is good. 
But since I am master of the cheaper food seeker price is bit too high.

That why I gave the 3 stars.
author: Faith I.

description:
Ate here for dinner once and the food was completely overpriced.  Was the sashmi fresh?  Yup.  Was it Tsukiji quality that would demand such prices?  Nooooope.   Service was okay: our waitress was pretty but like... uh.. kinda, helluva, OMG!, young and not very knowledgeable.  

So what do I come here for?    Yeah, you guessed it.  Drinks.  Gotta say the bar area is pretty nice.  Come here to have some drinks and hang out.  However, if you "break the seal", expect to have dumb Japanese lessons while visiting the can!!
author: Tim L.

description: we celebrated my bf birthday there with my cousin, venue was awesome and the sushi were delicious, but it was too pricey. another thing it took to damn long for our food to come. we got there @730 at night and we didn't finish dinner till 10pm. we ordered a total of 7 sushi, each sushi took like 20 mins to come, they served it one by ine whiched i though was ridiculous cause we had to wait for the other one to come and by then we were 10x hungrier.
author: Loi L.

description: Food was fantastic! 5-star quality!  Service was a bit slow. We had to remind the waiter a couple times for part of our order, drinks were very slow coming and the waiter was not very helpful in the ordering process. He acted like he was too busy to actually wait on us. Overall, though, great experience. Definitely will be back!
author: Brian C.

description: Place is awesome!! Now that I am officially a sushi snob, I give this restaurant a five star.  Fresh food and great service.  Our server Felix was hilarious! He made our dinner much more enjoyable.
author: cher l.

description:
I enjoyed a very special night here, and Ozumo's staff made it impeccable.  The sushi was out of this world,  fantastic oysters and other appetizers.    The service was perfect and the ambience in the big dining room was airy yet private.    It's expensive - but you pay for what you get.  

Love the different rooms - I haven't been here for happy hour, but am planning to check it out sometime soon.

19/09/2006 update -- I went for dinner last week and was pretty disappointed.   The service was dismal - the maitre d' acted like he was doing us a favor for giving us a table at our reservation time.  No water and the waiter tended to ignore us.  Off my fav list for sure.
author: green t.

description:
This restaurant is stunningly gorgeous as is the bar. it has a true big city feel about it. The food off the regular menu is quite good.  I have had extraordinary sushi here and i have had mediocre sushi as well.  i think, perhaps, that the food only really suffers when they are very very busy. i'm always willing to try it again.
Update 5/8/06: Went last night and it was quite good.  Best were: Saba, Aji, Salmon Belly, Anago, and Hamachi.
author: sarah C.

description:
This place is ok ... if you are in Las Vegas and are in search of a theme restaurant.  But we are in San Francisco, folks.  The place where restaurants don't have to build in themes and extravagant staging.  Our restaurants -- the good ones -- have an inherent charm, an unstaged and unaffected greatness.  I felt like I was in LA or Las Vegas or Phoenix, but not in San Francisco.

Pros: Decent (but not transcendant) sushi, lively atmosphere, very busy bar scene.

Cons: Watered down drinks, cold fried calamari, staff that seemed to all be quoting from the same script.
author: J M.

description:
This is the answer to starters on their menu:
Hanabi, Gindara, and Kukuni.  Ask for the specials and go from there.  Dont know anything about the saki but mmmmm its was good
author: Porfirio R.

description:
Good place for Japanese food

Food is good and fresh 

The atmosphere  is very nice 
warm and comfortable 

I been going often 
especially when you near Embarcadero
author: AZAM A.

description:
Big night out with the CEO...and a trip to Ozumo, all expenses paid, made me a sushi believer. 

For a company dinner- this is the place to go. 

Service was entertaining and excellent.

Sushi was out of this world- beautiful fatty tuna, octopus, yellowfin tuna, and the rolls (spicy tuna, etc.) were fantastic. 

And their sake was the most flavorful taste adventure ever.

For dessert- green tea ice cream in a chocolate sauce. Odd combination- but what a combination! Delicious.
author: Heidi E.

description:
In this busy busy world we live in, Mr & I and his good friends from good old Texas finally had a chance to get together.

At first Mr & I tried to make reservation at Frisson, booked - called Bacar also booked then finally Ozumo's we got in for 8:30 PM dinner reservation on  a Saturday night.

As we waited for our table, our group ordered Bangasa, Tokyo glow, Ume (Plum) Shu & Green Tea Lemon Drop (w/c I like). Prepaid when we are at the bar.

Dinner: 
Since one of W's friend is vegetarian, she had Man-chan's Squash Soup & Mori-Roku w/c according to her is great.

while the 3 of us ordered: 
5 pieces Sashimi - Maguro, Hamachi, Salmon ( fresh Sushi, yummy)
Dynamite & Rainbow Roll
Dohyo & I forgot the name of the main dish.

And for sake, a bottle of Sake - Masumi "Arabashiri" for 4 people is perfect $72.00

total bill $250+ (don't mind paying since we got great service)
author: jubi l.

description:
I've been here twice....once on my b-day....the toro was amazing....
The second time was New Years eve one year.....unforgettable....i asked to keep the menu for my collection.....hehe...they gave it to me....
author: d o.

description:
It's unfortunate that this place is so overpriced for the small portions.  If my company picks up the tab (like previous comments mention) then all will be good!  Which leads me to the next point: the crowd is the typical after-work, happy hour, financial-district crowd...which I'll leave it up to you to determine as a positive or negative point.
