Overall, if money is no object and you want to impress your party with not just good sushi but also a large selection of sake, Ozumo will get the job done.
author: Valerie F.

description:
401st Review

Ozumo rocks even on weekends.  This is a typical hangout for happy hour during the week.  However, I came here 2x this month on a weekend vs. happy hour after work and both times I had a great time!  The place was so packed that we couldn't find a seat.  Amazing!  

Also, parking is FREE since lots of free parking after 6.  Don't valet and save the money for another flight of Sake.
author: Gin H.

description:
A place so good, I had to order twice.

"People, stop eating my food!!!" With my friends there, this place was just a battle field. 

The place is cool and I felt comfortable... but in the end, I really wouldn't go here because the food was kick-ass; instead I'll go back because of the atmosphere.
author: Cristoper C.

description:
If you want high-end Japanese food with a killer view, come here.  Ask for the specials: one time I was lucky and got hotate (raw scallops) flown in from Japan and those suckers were SOOOO good.  Deliciously sweet, fresh...to die for.  All the sushi and sashimi are of the utmost quality, but you can find the same at a more reasonably priced restaurant.   But the restaurant is beautiful.

I recently had the Yakisoba (pan-fried noodles with a sweet soy sauce) and I wouldn't order that again, not for the price.  It basically tasted like something I could have at a regular Chinese restaurant.  A friend ordered the Kurobuta (braised pork short rib), and that meat was so tender and delicious.  He was disappointed with the size of his entree and left hungry, but I told him that he should have filled up on the view instead.
author: Courtney B.

description:
So I finally went to Ozumos, of course I made sure it wasn't on my dime! Thanks to the company I worked for we got to feast.
Hmm..what can I say the 1st sushi roll that came out was not so tasty. The rice was hard, that was the Spicy Tuna Roll. Next! Rainbow roll, and the "Special" roll, those were yummy. Honestly though, I could have had the same quality at a lot cheaper place. I was impressed with the edamame of all things, it was garlic infused edamame. Had a kiwi strawberry spritzer, umm bland. Main course I had the Beef and mushroom Don, umm tasty mushrooms but bland beef. Ok off to desert, the best part! Had a green tea crepe, very light and tasty. The flourless chocolate cake, holy crap! That was the best thing, it had red bean in the cake, not super rich but rich enough. Overall OK experience. We got to sit in the "private sake room" that was cool.
author: Karen T.

description:
Update 5/12/08 (subtracted one star due to crap service):

Added Ozumo to my ever growing list of Japanese restaurants in the City I won't patronize.

Went on a Friday this time around 8:30PM, with no reservations. The nice hostess said that we could either wait around 30 minutes or try to snag one of the tables in the lounge, as they are available on a first come, first served basis.

Of course, all the peeps in the crowded lounge area have the same idea, so whenever a spot opens up, it's like a feeding frenzy of people gunning for the same seat.

Well, we were chillin' and didn't mind the wait. We sipped our expensive beers (2 x Kirin drafts + 1 x Chimay draft = $21, LMAO WTF???) and waited about 15 minutes before we were seated in the dining area proper, a very pleasant surprise.

A bonus for me- we got to sit in front of the open kitchen to see the culinary magic of Japanese fusion cuisine brought to you courtesy of pipe hittin' Latino line cooks.

When our noob server came, that's when things started to go downhill. He didn't understand or know the menu. He required me to point to the menu items to take our order, and to say the menu items loudly and slowly.

Now I usually don't mind doing this in a Chinese, Korean, Thai, or (fill in the blank) ethnic restauruant where you have to rely on body language and gestures to communicate with FOB service staff. 

But in a restaurant that charges an average mid $20's+ for plates? To add insult to injury, our server wa hakujin no America-jin deshita! Fuck that noise.

Since I read Japanese, I pointed to the robata-grill menu in Japanese by the kitchen, with menu items written on wooden slats as is customary in Japan. Only problem was that this simple, reasonably-priced (read: cheaper) menu was more for display than actually being something you can order. The noob waiter tried to explain away the menu as being the chef's "experimental" menu. WTF?

We gave up at that point. We quickly scarfed down the appetizers we'd ordered and promptly bailed.

We wound up finishing the evening with a stellar meal with good service at Nopa.
__________________________

Original review:

It's an okay place to go if you're going on an expense account dinner, as prices tend to be high. But then again, they're not serving you crap like you get in other alleged Japanese restaurants in the City.

Good Japanese food (especially sushi) requires fresh, pristine ingredients and folks, sorry, but Ozumo doesn't cut costs and serve maguro from Costco. If you want cheap Japanese food and value quantity over quality, go somewhere else like Ebisu or Kabuto.

Relative to restaurants in Japan, Ozumo would probably be considered mediocre. Sadly, in San Francisco, Ozumo would be one of the better Japanese restaurants. Note, however, that there are plenty of places in LA and Manhattan that are better than Ozumo.

Tasted following from menu:

- Dobin mushi

I enjoyed this simple dashi broth with matsutake, prawn, black truffles.

- Dohyo

Tuna tartare basically. Nothing special.

- Hanabi

Hamachi and avocado with jalapeno ponzu sauce. Why the fuck do they want to bastardize fresh fish with jalapeno?

- Gindara

Decent preparation of this nice, flaky fish.

- Hitsuji

Lamb chops, well prepared and tasty. Not sure if the hijiki and sweet potato salad work well tho'.

- Gyu Kakuni

Nice, savory tender beef short ribs. Delicious.

- Assorted sushi

Good stuff. We just had nigiri, and steered clear of the wonky rolls. Cream cheese in sushi? WTFOMG, spare me from culinary abominations like that.
 
The coup de grace of Ozumo has to be the drama of conspicuous consumption unfold before your very eyes like a car crash in slo-mo.

Lots of guys and gals fidgeting with their iPhones and Blackberries pretending to read important e-mail. Web 2.0 guys trying hard to be shabby chic with designer jeans with strategic rips, expensive limited edition t-shirt with ironic imagery, and even more expensive athletic shoes. Upwardly mobile guys and gals that look like their wardrobe is straight from the designer du jour catalog. Girls who obviously want to see and be seen wearing their sexy, but not too sexy to be skanky outfits (o-skanky-desuka?).  Older folks 40+ who want to feel young and relevant...

One great example- a "doctor," probably in his late 50's holding court in the main dining area across from the sushi bar with 2 super-hot 20-sumthin' chicks in dresses that didn't leave much to the imagination. These two chicks were clearly "professionals"...errr escorts I mean. Hahahaha.

All the waitstaff were kissing this "doctor's" ass making him feel like the whale that he was. Naturally, the gals were fawning over him during dinner, as I noted the shopping bags from high-end boutiques on the floor by their feet. Thank you sugar daddy!

I aspire to be like the the good doctor when I grow up! :)
author: Bono B.

description:
Maybe I should write 2 reviews of Ozumos. One based on the restaurant/ bar itself and one based on the catering staff. 

OK, I will start with the good first. Great bar area. Get here early and take over a section of it. This is what being young professionals is about. Great food. Damn good sushi. Really nice staff. Good location.

Now, the bad. I have been through 3 catering managers here. In 3 years. The second gentleman was great. When I ordered lunches, he would deliver them himself, he was upfront about Ozumo's capabilities and he was personable. The most recent manager upset me so bad that my team knows not to ask me to order from Ozumo again.

I called a week in advance and ordered plates for 2 lunches to be delivered at 11:00am. I was well aware that this was a special request since their kitchen doesn't normally open that early, but asked IN ADVANCE if it would be a problem and was assured it would not. I was assured that they would happily deliver one of the orders themselves in time for a meeting that started at 11am. I informed the manager that I would be there at 10:40 to pick up the other order.

I arrived to pick up the second order at 10:30, knowing I had to leave the restaurant by 10:40. I was assured by the manager himself that the orders would be ready shortly. When I was given the trays to BOTH orders at 11:35am, mad wouldn't even begin to describe how I was feeling. I have not ordered from Ozumos since and this incident occurred in Fall, 2007.

Go to the restaurant for a great experience. Otherwise, forget it.
author: Lora C.

description:
Food:  Really fresh sushi (which is all we ordered).  Fortunately I went here on the company tab... it's on the pricey side.  I thought we ordered mirugai nigiri but they brought out sashimi - a bit fishy but the texture was top-notch.

Service:  My server was fantastic, actually - he was attentive yet gave us plenty of space to enjoy our meal (and my friend and I were there for almost 4 hours).  I'm bummed that so many people disliked the service here.
author: Doreen S.

description:
Awesome appetizers during Happy Hour, and cheap drinks!  Bartenders are really nice...making drinks less strong or MORE strong when I asked.  Of course, I asked mine to be more stiff....

Street parking is a pain in the ass (at $0.25 for five minutes).
author: Daniel M.

description:
Is it completely inappropriate to say that staffing the door with a collection of incredibly attractive monochromatic hostesses is an excellent idea and really sets the tone for a visit?  well there, I said it...

Anyone giving this place a bad review should come to Texas and revel in the crap we call "Contemporary Japanese Dining and Sushi".  Unfortunately, and I mean that it in the most sarcastic way possible, I was with a regular that ordered everything.  So I can't really explain what I had other than to say it was all fantastic.
author: gregg h.

description: VERY.....disappointing service at the bar....please change out the female server that was there on Thursday night at the bar..... Totally ruined my evening.... Very mean person blames everything that goes wrong on the kitchen... I'm done going here, I don't need this kind of frustration!!!!
author: Connie R.

description: Rawr I got mauled by some cougars here.  Beware.  One was a doctor and the other a lawyer.  At least Mom would approve.  Great place to drink for the mature set.  Or to go cougar hunting :P.
author: Harry T.

description:
Ozumo has a highly swanky and spacious interior, which got my group immediately excited about our dining experience.  The menu has appealing dishes and the sake list is one of the best I've seen for a restaurant.

Unfortunately, the food was a let down of mediocrity.  Their salmon belly (which I have difficulty finding) was seasoned and cut too small for the price we paid.  The shiromaguro was extremely fishy and should not have been served.  Chocolate mochi as a dessert had too many flavors going on.  The winners: "hanabi" (hamachi with jalapeno) intrigued my taste buds and the special dessert of yam and pumpkin ice cream was an outstanding way to finish.  

It is quite clear your bill ends up going to the decor and rent, not the food.  For half the price I can get a significantly more delicious meal at Gochi in the south bay.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Yum! I had such a fabulous experience at Ozumo. Came on a Sunday night with 4 other girls and sat at one of the bar tables. Ozumo is definitely on the pricey side and their portions are small, but the food was great and I was there for a work dinner so hell, as long as I wasn't paying  it didn't really matter. 
I ordered the Sparkling Geisha to start which was lychee flavored sake and passion fruit puree topped with champagne---- OMG, this drink was so good I could've had 5.....but instead I had 3....hey, I thought that was pretty good self-control. For an appey, we started with the Hanabi ($18) which was slices of Hamachi and avocado in a spicy ponzu sauce- tiny portion, but absolutely delicious. We also started with their Vegetable Tempura ($10) which was pretty standard- I'm not sure how you can really mess up fried vegetables. We ordered a few rolls to share- Spicy Tuna ($9), Shrimp Tempura w/Jalapeno ($9), Yasai-Maki (Veg roll- $8) and the Yokozuna roll ($13). My favorite was the Spicy Tuna- the quality and freshness of the tuna was superb and it was crazy spicy which I loved. The shrimp tempura w/Jalapeno was also great. Our waitress was really nice, but got a little slow at the end. 
Between 5 girls our bill came out to $310 after tax and tip. 
Would definitely love to go back again (on the company card of course...).
author: Shani D.

description: Bert the waiter was amazing !! I never liked yellow tail until today! He was very professional and knowledgable about the menu whatever he says to taste I will taste!! Overall this place is waaaaaaaaay better than the one in oakland it's very fresh and Bert will be sure to please your palates desire.
author: R K.

description: I experienced an unspeakable crime against sea bass here. Even the waitress seemed sorry about it. Out of the blue she told us the next time we wanted a nice dinner we should try Manresa. I would suggest you do the same.
author: Tai N.

description: We visited Ozumo for my birthday dinner. Everything we had was amazing - better even than last time. I had a flight of three sakes, to match our meal of sushi, appetizers and small plates. The meal was pricey but each dish was impeccably prepared and presented. Highly recommended if you are a lover of Japanese cuisine with a Western twist!
author: Karen C.

description:
Food was good but way overpriced, I probably should have picked up on the fact that this is somewhere to pay more to be seen. $16 for a 5 piece roll? Kick in the proverbial sack when the bill came. 

Bartender (Ali I think?) was cool though, definitely helped raise my enjoyment level of the place, but food-wise, we're in a recession people, these prices can't last.
author: Michelle A.

description:
The fish is worth the $- but then the service shoots it down. 

Actually- the service started with a non-friendly and non-smiling bang when we ordered beers and asked to see the sake list for "something simple". That, in our waiters eye, was an $81 bottle of sake. We asked for a bottle of the house sake and were treated with outright disdain. And mind you- we were laughing, friendly, and ready to have a good time at dinner. 

The rest of it? Good food- not Nobu good- but good. 

But seriously- the waiter- a guy with a quasi beard and a non-quasi attitude- should be avoided. 

When he realized the tab was $150 and there was going to be a good tip after all- we got our first half sentence and half smile of the night. Right buddy.
author: Will W.

description: Fantastic!  Service is outstanding, sushi is super fresh, menu is very creative and diverse.  Wine and sake list has great variety.  All around a wonderful experience!
author: Mr. P.

description:
Have to say, I used to love this place, however, dont ask me why, the quality has gone down. 

I am a nigiri lover, and the fish quality is not as good as it used to be. The only thing worth it here is the salmon belly, this one do is like butter. However, the rest of the pieces are not the best (about to say bad!). 

They have some good hot dishes, like the cod,  but otherwise, not a good value for the money you leave at the table (look for a $100/px if you order a mid price sake bottle).

Their sake list is good, but expensive. 

They have a great atmosphere since when you go in they have a cool bar, behind it a small kind of secluded room and at the back a nice open room with bay bridge view. 

Bottom line, I have a list of better sushi places before going back to this one. 

Food: 19;  Service: 24; Decor: 26.
author: Roger N.

description: Just went here for a bite after work, staff is great, food is delicious, gm is walking around making sure everyone is enjoying themselves.
author: Jane Z.

description: Stopped by on a Friday after work. The place was quiet with only a few tables filled. The spicy tuna roll and Japanese skewers are average. Nothing special. Will come back during a weekday for HH.
author: Jenny J.

description:
I love their cucumber cocktails and almost every sushi roll I have tried. The seaweed salad rocks. 
One of my favorite spots for sushi in the city.
author: Liza A.

description: The service and food was great.  The sushi was fresh, and the Albacore Sashimi was fantastic, basically melts in your mouth.  For dessert, find a way to get the mochi, it's really fresh and delicious.  The only problem is they don't sell the mochi alone, so you have to get the fondue which is really great as well.  Final note, really awesome view.
author: Scott R.

description:
there are good and bad things first the good:
Georgeous inside, very trendy 
major bar scene, girls were all dolled up
Our waiter was fantastic, he was patiient with our large group and very helpful explaining the extensive sake list as well as the interesting sushi dishes to the non-sushi eaters at the table.
the salmon nigiri was good, the rice was perfect texture and they put the perfect proportions of rice and fish in all the rolls and nigiri pieces..and no hidden wasabi on the nigiri pieces either!
The bad, all the rolls were either spicy or fried, and they didn't tast very good.  The traditional items of Miso soup or tsukimono - not there.  Very expensive, itty bitty portions. I don't think it is worth the money, next time I will go to the bar though!
author: lauren p.

description: classy venue. delicious and fresh sushi. outstanding drinks/ menu! what more can you ask for?! :)
author: Jennifer K.

description: The food was pretty good (the black cod especially), but the portions are so small. My friends and I were still hungry after spending $30 each here, so we went to In n Out for cheeseburgers, fries, and milkshakes... and only after eating those were we full. We probably could have skipped out on Ozumo and been just as satisfied.
author: Jessica W.

description: Amazing ambiance and views.  Delicious and fresh food, great experience.
author: Briana B.

description:
I love the atmosphere- it's trendy, sexy, smooth...all that jazz. It reminded me of an upscale Vegas joint- totally luxurious. I had a great night until I unintentionally got over-billed by $150! While trying to be nice, they insisted that it was my fault (For future reference- don't trust the prices listed online, i guess they're just for show.)

I was steamed, but I refuse to let all that ruin my amazing night with my husband. We ate delicious, fresh, and creative food, and had a great time, despite paying the equivalent of two roundtrip tickets to New York.
author: Hella M.

description: If you love kobi beef (and let's face it who doesn't), the kobi beef was supreme. Everything else was fairly good, but can be had for less elsewhere. But, let's face it. There are only three reasons why you go here atmosphere, atmosphere, atmosphere. This is the place to go for business lunches and dates, but there are better options if you're just craving good japanese food.
author: John Z.

description:
I have been here for several happy hours and have eaten once.  The place is cool, but filled with a lot of accountants as it is near a few big accounting firms.  Still a great place to go after work.  The food was very good, but nothing in here is cheap.

Went again tonight and we had a blast.  The service was top notch, the food was yummy, the drinks were great and the place was interesting.  I am tempted to go to five stars for this place!
author: Pele N.

description:
The best sushi I have ever had in my life.  

For all the cry-babies whining about how "expensive" it is, ever heard the term "you get what you pay for"?  Duh.  If u want cheap, bland sushi, go to some joint in the Loin with your $12.00.  Ozumo is worth every single penny.

Anyhooo .. Ozumo's food is AMAZING, their staff is very very nice and not overly pushy, and the place itself itself is beautiful.  *if you need a place to "write notes" as one person commented*, go to Starbucks.
author: Sofia G.

description:
I love this place.  The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is because I've never had to pay. I work (worked in about 2 days) in an industry where client dinners still exist.  I'm (was in about 2 days) lucky enough to get to go to restaurants without even thinking about the price tag.  Well, since those days are almost over - changing jobs and career focus, I decided that my reviews must take price into consideration.

So, this place is expensive.  BUT the food is excellent.  I love the salads they put together.  Mix of sweet, salty crunchy and raw is perfect on most of their salad like items.  Their rolls are gone in a flash and their sashimi is so good...smooth and tasty.  I really like sitting in back with a view of the bay bridge.  Upfront, it's a totally different scene...very much akin to the place next door Chaya.
author: cristina t.

description:
Update: I just went to Ozumo again and LOVED it just as much! The Salmon kababs are amazing as well as the Beef with eggplant and spinich. The waiters did not bother us, but if we needed something, they brought it to us quickly.

********************
Ozumo is my favorite sushi place ever!

The atmosphere is really nice, and there is a great view of the bay/bay bridge! The sushi is really fresh and delicious and they have over 50 different types of saki. The spicy tuna rolls and the tuna/avacado rolls are amazing! Besides the high prices, this place would be a great place for a date...especially if he's paying!
author: Elaine S.

description:
This was the venue of a friend's two birthday parties and both times i thought it's a nice place to go back to on a date or as a group. Love the ambiance and the decor.  The food is not the best Japanese in town but definitely decent.  The waitress was one of the most cheerful I've encountered though. 

What bothered me was that they were cheapass at the bar. Hubby likes to sample scotch at various restaurarant and all he got was a few drops with a mountain of ice.  Please....
author: Hadley K.

description:
I've been here a few times, though only for drinks. They get a +1 for an extensive sake menu, and a -1 for a staff that's a bit aloof and impatient. Fine for a diner, not so fine when one is paying $13 a drink. 

On the other hand, I probably would be too if I had to deal with their usual obnoxious ego-inflated clientele.

Nice atmosphere though.
author: Jeffrey F.

description:
Pricy, elegant , but sushi is soo good. They need to work on their meat however. I like the ambiance. There are nice tasting drinks like the sparkling geisha with lychee........

I don't think the dessert was really worth it though.
author: Connie Y.

description:
Hands down the best Japanese restaurant in the city. Innovative sushi dishes, really fresh fish, great menu selection (especially if you have guests that are a little squeamish about sushi - i.e. there are many more cooked options than just teriyaki chicken) and an all-around nice dining experience.

Prices are a little high-end, but the service and atmosphere live up to the final numbers on the check. Not to mention, it's in a pretty badass date location (half a block to gorgeous views of the Bay Bridge and a romantic stroll along the Embarcadero). 

Go there. Eat sushi. Drink sake. Have fun. You'll be happy you did.
author: Kevin K.

description:
I ate in the main dining room and at the sushi bar.  The decor is really nice and spacious with a view of the Bay Bridge.  As we walked in, the bar also seemed pretty chill and a great place to hang out after work. 

Back to dinner...They have a great Japanese menu complete with salads, soups, hot pot items, and grilled items.  They also have a variety of nigiri, sashimi, and rolls.  We tried the yummy seaweed salad that included three types of seaweed laid over mixed greens.  We also enjoyed the agadashi tofu that was prepared perfectly.  I also tried some of the more traditional items like albacore and toro.  Their rolls are pretty creative and all the ingredients are fresh and well prepared.  My only hiccup was the bill at the end of the meal.  A meal here is certainly not cheap.
author: Nina L.

description:
I think this is chill place to hang out for a few drinks after work with some friends.  

They usually have a DJ playing a mix of all kind of jams from old school to new.  This makes for a good vibe while eating sushi and throwing down a few Nigori sakis and Kirin beers.  

The happy hour prices aren't that great, but what really is in the city huh?
author: Ed B.

description:
The two Farraris parked out front tell me this isn't going to be inexpensive, but that's OK as I'm taking my BF out to birthday dinner.  He loves sushi and I wanted to choose a restaurant with the look and feel of something special.  Ozumo delivered.
We were given a table with a water/bridge view and the sushi was delicious.  The sake list was amazing.  
The decor was tasteful modern and there was an understated, hip vibe.
author: Kara H.

description:
I don't mind Ozumo, but the sashimi is consistently underwhelming.


 Pretty good place to stop by for a drink and some rolls.
author: lizok

description:
Love it here!  It's pricey, but what's new with Sushi?  Excellent customer service sets this apart from most.  The servers are very attentive and make educated and excellent suggestions with their extensive (and somewhat overwhelming) Sake list.

Great place to bring out of towners, too.
author: Miranda O.

description:
I really wish I could give this place a stellar review cause I had heard such good things about it from friends.  I'll go into detail in a minute, but if you want the short of my review it goes something like this: pretty killer decor, pretty average service and entirely overpriced for the quality of the sushi.

Actually, haven written that I really don't think I need to go into more detail at all!  If you like spending a lot of money for otherwise average sushi just to be at a trendy eatery, then go for it.  Yes, Marina-folk, I'm talking to you.

Side note: if you do decide to give it a go, the Ozumo roll is your best bet.
author: Amanda K.

description:
My favorite sushi restaurant in the city. Fantastic fish, great service - but beware the stealthy way they try to sell you sake. They hook you with the flights and get you to taste the good stuff, then just casually ask you if you'd like a bottle of something. When this happened to me, I just casually responded "yeah, we'll take a half bottle of that one" without looking at the menu or, more importantly, the prices. Stupid! Stupid! Stupido! When the bill came, and I was full of fish and sake, I wondered if I'd accidentally bought the chef's car from him or something without realizing it. It was so expensive, I think technically I must be a part owner of Ozumo or something.

Oh, and they have taped Japanese lessons playing in the bathrooms, which is cute - but not really a practical way of learning Japanese.
author: John D.

description:
My awesome friend, Kim, took me here for my birthday.  She is very awesome, as are the food and the prices (awesome meaning I am in awe of how much they charge).

Kim and I hadn't seen each other in about 2 years, so we didn't do much people watching, but the view of the bridge was lovely and the restaurant itself is very sleek and classy.  

The service was close to impeccable.  Though our server steered us pretty assertively toward certain dishes, we were not disappointed with those of her recommendations we ordered.

Specifics:

Sake flight:  3 sakes served rather generously.  It was more than enough for us to share but we're not huge drinkers.

Hanabi:  Hamachi and avocado in heavenly sauce that makes one want to lick the plate.  For the record, I did not.  Listen to your server when s/he recommends it.

Two orders of sashimi:  
Toro -- OMG -- this was melt in your mouth magnificence.  We are polite and deferred to each other for the fifth piece.  Kim's awesomeness continued when she let me have it.

Hirame -- excellent, as well.  Not only that, it was sculpted into a flower that was very pretty.  Not too pretty to eat, but pretty nonetheless.

We also had this amazing salmon off the robata grill.  Very simple, grilled in miso, I believe.  

Two rolls:  the Ozumo (unagi with crab and other good stuff) and the Sekiwake (spicy tuna, tempura flakes, salmon and hamachi).  Delicious, both.  

So, we were that kind of full that's not a painful, bloaty, sort of sick-feeling kind of full.  We were happy full.  And we were celebrating my birthday (still, a month later.  I've really milked this one.) so we had a nice green tea ice cream with hot chocolate sauce.

One last awesome for Kim, as she barely cringed at the bill that I could not even pretend to offer to split.  I look forward to coming back when she or anyone else is paying.  It is fabulous.   Let me know if you'd like a charming, witty and oh-so-grateful dinner guest.

[Good, yet dangerous, news:  Ozumo is opening a restaurant in downtown Oakland.  Eek.]
author: Lauren B.

description: I love this place!!! My wife and I live close by and we've been here on several occasions. It is pricey, but worth every penny.
author: Daniel D.

description: This is my favorite "ultra-nice" place to go for sushi for special occasions. We've always had great meals here. The fish is fresh and the kobe beef is yummy. The bartenders make some fun, delicious specialty drinks (I love the Tokyo Glow). The miso cod on the main menu is amazing! Definitely worth trying. So, if you want a place to impress a date or out of town friends, family, add this one to your list. There is a cool bar on the Steurt St side, then there is a small traditional floor seating area in the middle for larger groups, then lots of tables extending back through to Embarcadero St side where the sushi bar is located. Make reservations if going with four or more, especially Thursday - Saturday.
author: Artina M.

description: Went here for lunch on a weekday and was impressed by the large, open atmosphere and friendly greetings of all 20+ staff.  Perhaps, that was because we walked in before the lunch rush.  I only had sushi and thought I'd be blown away by the selection of imported fish, but I wasn't impressed.  The prices they charged for the quantity and size of the rolls was ridiculous!  Our waitress was accommodating and continually checked on us, even as the place got crowded.  I did find the restrooms interesting, for they were playing Japanese tutorials in there, LOL.  Not coming back for the food, maybe to try out a few of there 100's of sakes to choose from!
author: Jeralyn K.

description: I went to Ozumo for my birthday this year! Great atmosphere, excellent cuisine. Wonderful service.
author: Michelle W.

description: We went to Ozumo in the beginning of November, 2010 to celebrate our anniversary. The inside of the restaurant is very nice. We had a great view of the Bay Bridge from our table. We had calamari (good) and seaweed salad for appitizers. Unfortunately the salad was bland. My wife had Mahi-mahi for her main course. It was good but a little bland as well. I had mirin marinated and grilled lamb chops. Probably the best lamb I have ever had. Dessert was phenomenal as well and our server paired it perfectly with a sample of four different sake's. The service was excellent. Our waiter was well educated in the menu and had a great, engaging personality. Ozumo was expensive but worth it for a special occasion.
author: D S.

description:
Last time when I was here I did not like their Japanese style soup too much. Everything is pricey! You even have to pay their Edamame beans (which usually comes free at other also-fancy restaurant)!

But today as we went by Ferry building we decided to give it another try! We sat on the Sushi bar as we did not make reservation. But I like it there more than the regular table as it is more intimate sitting than the regular table when the two people sit across the table!

We ordered Yaki Tako (grilled octopus) that is tangy, chewy while tender! We also ordered their special with beef tongues! It is as good as it can get! 

The yellowtail nigiri and unagi nigiri are very good but 2 pieces of them came at $8 and $7 are again a bit expensive for us. We also had Akebono rolls that have some chopped toro and black Caviar. It is kind of an invention.

For dessert we ordered the choco Chan (flourless chocolate cake with Mochi and green tea ice cream). It is pretty good. 

The atmosphere is nice but I have to say that the waiters are too quick to move every plate from your table every time you finish a plate. It feels like they are in a hurry to bring you a new dish. I wish they are not so attentive.
author: Jasmine C.

description: This place is definitely overpriced but I guess you pay for the trendy, upscale atmosphere. Location is great, especially if you work around the FiDi. Loved the rolls with jalapeño. Creative, innovative sushi options.
author: Lina L.

description: Great space! Good cocktails. Tasty food.
author: Fabian M.

description: This place is one of the top sushi places I've been to! Amazing black cod in miso sauce dish, fresh toro sushi, great appetizer dishes. And a beautiful, trendy upscale environment. Prices are definitely on the high side so difficult to make it a regular haunt, more like a night out!
author: Rajan S.

description: Was at happy hour on 4/19/13 when a breaking alert that the 2nd suspect of the Boston Marathon bombing was captured came across our smart phones.  Asked the waitress if we could change the channel from the A's game to see the breaking news.  Managers response: "Sorry, we're a baseball town."
author: Luke A.

description: i have been back several times since my first Yelp. Have to say I haven't been as excited each time as I was with my first visit. One time, we had a very rude waitress. I like to have suggestions when I eat sushi. I believe the staff knows what is the best that night. She was not helpful, did not suggest items close to what we were eating and two dishes she brought us we just did not like.(ie. we did not order anything that was spicy and one of the dishes she suggested and we ordered was spicy, and she did not even warn us of it while suggesting it)
author: Mary J.

description: I've been here for dinner several times. Love the dim, romantic ambience and professional service. Fresh sashimi always. I also ordered their steak with green beans (forgot the name of the dish), everything was cooked to perfection and til this day, I haven't forgotten the bacon wrapped green beans....it tasted like they smothered the green beans in delicious hot bacon oil. Not for anyone on a diet but great for a special occasion meal! There's always fresh sashimi on the menu too! And delicious mixed drinks. I'm a happy camper!
author: Ree W.

description: My boyfriend and I came here for valentines day. Had some sashimi, was pretty good. But the duck is why I'm writing this review. I had the Kamo (duck) and my boyfriend had the Washu Gyu (ribeye). Both were fantastic, but my duck had me raving about it every night. It was served with the tastiest parsnip puree and homemade pesto - wow. We topped off an already fabulous dinner with the chocolate fondue, and it was just like your regular fondue but the mango they served as part of the dipping foods was so fresh and fantastic. Fabulous and worth the money. Yum!
author: Hanna B.

description: Had a great lunch here today. Great miso soup, wonderful kiwi, strawberry spritzer and really fresh sashimi.
author: lisa m.

description:
I have eaten at this establishments a few times and celebrated one of my birthday's here, and it so happened that Donovan was throwing one of his parties there that night of my birthday, which made the night that much better.

The food here has never disappointed the palate although it is very much on the pricey side.  There is also a fine selection of sake (don't miss trying the Wakatake) to enjoy.  The interior is very chic and provides a good ambiance.  It is a good place to take a date or a business client.
author: Long Duk D.

description:
The key is to either get drunk beforehand or go drink somewhere else afterwards. Drinking is what makes this place so expensive... They have so many types of sake, my head was spinning when we left. And I had just drank green tea...

Their sushi is amazing. Blowfish, shmlowfish... The sushi here is much much better... 

And if you are lucky, you get a view of the bay and the bay bridge.

Enjoy...

Adding more:

Had dinner there again today. Had the lychee/passion fruit/sake drink. Oh my God! I had to tell the waitress not to bring me any more even if I asked for it after gulping two of them in a hurry... Tasty...

And for those UNI lovers, out there! They have an uni risotto. Can you say "rich and tasty"? I was practically licking my chopsticks. 

Now my stomach aches but who cares??? That is why we have mint tea at home :)
author: Oz O.

description:
I really liked the ambiance except for our next-to-the-pillar table. Sushi was really good and well laid out. Our waiter was "extra" knowledgeable and went on and on about the menu, sometimes losing eye-contact and looking away at other guests! I think he's really taken up by the place and wants everyone to know how "great" ozumo is :)

The sake we ordered was really nice and smooth. It's a nice place for a special occasion.
author: Praveen K.

description:
Prepare to go to the poorhouse if you are entertaining clients or friends here and are not on the corporate card!  This could be the most expensive sushi in the entire city.

I took out a table of four... and decided to order 1 order of toro and a side of rice after I let the clients order their dishes.  After my order, everybody elsedecided my order was a good choice and added on Toro sashimi :)

We always play guess the bill at the end for a $1 each.  Person closest to the number wins the pot.  The guesses?  $208, $265, $190, $300.  Remember, this is for lunch folks......  The bill?  $480 pre tip!!!?!

Sake selection is good, but expect a 200% mark up i.e. $20 to $60-70/bottle.  

Unfortunately, the location is good for downtown, and it is really the only decent Japanese restaurant in the area.  

More fun just going there for happy hour after work in the front.
author: Jacob J.

description:
I really try to be positve.  I really do.  Yet, I find I can only write a detailed review when there is something to critique.  

When a restaurant is really good lushing on and on about the food and service just seems indulgent.  The five (or four) stars should speak for itself.  However, a low review has to be justified.

Either that or I just like to complain more than compliment.

To start with the positive, the fish is good.  All the sushi is excellent.  Better than most of the sushi joints in town. 

With Ozumo the problem is definitely the service.   I should have known b/c I checked out the Yelp reviews and saw that it was a problem.  However, I had eaten here before at the sushi bar and didn't have any problems.  So I figured I would give it another shot.  

We order some edemame and sake to start.  The sake is great but the edemame is absent.  Next, the server takes our dinner order and we state we would like the Martini Sashimi appetizer followed by a long list of nigiri and rolls.

The first item to hit our table is the rolls.  Before the edamame, before the appetizer, before the nigiri.  What's up with that?  The rolls come but no one gives us soy sauce.  By the time we flag someone down for the soy sauce, we now have the edamame and the appetizer.

Ten seconds later the nigiri comes out.  We don't even have room for it on the table.  The server at least realized it was impossible to try to get another dish on the table so he decided to take it back and wait.

What a mess.  You pay all this money and expect to have a nice leisurely dinner and they are throwing the food at you every which way like they are rushing you out the door.

Anyhow, if I go back, I'll probably stick with the sushi bar.
author: jeff k.

description:
WoW 
The food was amazing, the service impeccable and the ambiance surpassed my expectations. I highly recommend the happy hour because the bartenders make the experience at the bar OUTSTANDING!!!  
Unlike the previous submission, the air quality was fine.  A fantastic experience all around.
author: chandler s.

description:
This place doesn't get 4 stars only because I thought the bartender was pretty rude and the seating.  More on that in a minute...

The decor is real snazzy, the ambience is nice and the crowd is that yuppy, Financial District/Advertising Agency after-work crowd.  There is a nice bar in the front which makes really good drinks (average strength) and then in the back is where the restaurant bit.  And yes, in the bathroom, they have Japanese language lessons playing.  Interesting.  And the wait staff (serving food, not the bartender) was very nice and the service was excellent.

The food was very good, expensive, but expected for that part of SF.  My favorite was the Garlic-Soy Edamame, edamame that boiled, salted, and then stir-fried (skin on) in a garlic-soy sauce.  Amazing edamame.  The rest of the food was usual, expensive, trendy Japanese fare.  No problems there.

Drinks - I got the green tea martini, which I really enjoyed; and then water and ice tea - nothing to report there.

Gripes: 
Bartender - I ordered the green tea martini for myself and my friend that was with me; a lady heard me ordering it and asks the bartender how that drink is and the bartender says, "Oh, it's not at all my favorite.  I don't recommend it.  Order something else."  In front of me.  In front of the person who ordered the very drink she was trashing.  I've never been a bartender, but I've been in many a bar situation in my adult life, and I didn't think that was very nice of her to do.  There are other ways she could have said it, perhaps, "oh, it's not my favorite, but you should try it... " "it's a unique drink... not everyone likes it".. or something a bit more mild.  You think?

Seating - got there right at 5P, we were on a schedule, so we got our drinks and were seated by 5:30P.  We were seated in the back, away from the rest of the restaurant.  Not really sure how they did their seating, but I wasn't happy with sitting in the back, made me feel like they didn't want to show the general public that they were serving food.

All in all, it was a decent experience, the food is good, but more likely a place I'd take a visiting friend, not somewhere I would go on the regular.
author: Meghana A.

description:
Had dinner with some good friends in the private dining room.  The service was good and the food was excellent.  

Couple of my favorites were the Black Cod (which just melts in your mouth), the Kobe Beef (well you can't really complaint about it when it's prepared properly), and the sesame pudding was delicious.
author: George L.

description:
ALL HYPE!  Overpriced mediocre food! reservation service sucks

I went here for a going away party for a friend.  had 830 pm reservations and didn't get seated till 915 pm. While waiting at the bar the cocky bartender couldn't remember how to make some of their own signature drinks. Suits and Birthday crews fill this place up. The food is of good quality but nothing outstanding.
author: Dominic J.

description:
I can't believe how nit-picky some of the reviewers on here are!  The bench was tight so two stars.  Wah Wahh.  Don't listen to them.  

This place is five stars.  They have it all from the ambiance to the food and service.  I went here on vaentines day and It was outstanding.  The sushi was the best I have ever had.  Beautiful and flavorful.  The sake list is extensive.  I was with four people and we ordered everthing on the menu that was good.  The desserts are also great. We had a chocolate fondue that would blow your mind.
 The service here is 5 star.  Waiter recomendations were off the chain.  Food came very quick even on valentines when the place was packed.  
I will go here many more times.  I absolutely loved it.  Just make a reservation early!
author: Pete L.

description:
I've been here thrice perhaps for lunch and always enjoyed it. Last night took the bf out for a birthday celebration dinner (different menu entirely). This is what we ordered in the order in which it came also.

Sake Flight- Nama Ichiban (Extremely fruity- I would recommend for the girly drink drinkers- try something else if you want more traditional sake fare) 

Sashimi- 5 pcs each: Beni Toro, Hamachi, Maguro, Hotate (everything tasted great except the Salmon Belly- oddly enough, i didn't enjoy that. I would highly recommend the Scallops) only complaint- no ginger slices to cleanse the pallet, I think the wasabi needs more kick! Believe me- i put a lot usually.

Salad: The spinach with sesame dressing (nothing to die for but tasty)

Small Plates: 
Yamabuki (my highlight!) For Uni lovers- gosh, ever wanted to take uni and mix it in a bowl of rice- well they did it for you here, but even better. It's a Uni Risotto- the creaminess i suspect comes from the uni and not cheese!

Futago: Beef over spinach over eggplant over cucumber with teriyaki like sauce. Pretty good! The beef was extremely tender (but I think i was still too focused on the delish-ness of the uni risotto.

Yaki Plates: Grilled Japanese sweet potatoes- deep purple in colour. Yumm... Must search for it at the markets.

Nothing appealing on the dessert menu so we skipped. Yes- it's pricey- but it's a fancy establishment- what do you expect. I would bring anyone here for a treat.

Service: The waitress was good (i did not get one of the pan asian ones that Ozumo is noted for). 4 stars for her too.
author: Len K.

description:
I used to go to Ozumo frequently for their fun happy hour - which unfortunately ends kind of early. I don't go for it that often anymore but I do still really like it. The food is excellent and the ambience is swanky and fabulous. I recently had lunch there and everything was delicious. Make sure to have their handmade gyoza - sooo good!

I hear they are opening a place in Oakland in November too! Cool!
author: sarah k.

description:
This week was my second visit to Ozumo and I can't wait to be able to afford going there for dinner one day.  But the first time I went for lunch with a bunch of people from work and we all got very delicious bento boxes.  And this week I went with a bunch of girlfriends to Ozumo for Happy Hour.  We had dinner reservations at Shanghai 1930 and got there early but it was totally dead.  So we left and went to Ozumo which was much more hopping and it was just a tantalizing two doors down.  We never ate at Shanghai 1930 and ended up spending dinner there and will definitely try to go back again.  I can't wait for it to open in Oakland.
It was beautiful decor.  The wait staff was wonderful and accommodating and overall, highly recommended.
author: Mindy C.

description:
Eh, I want to give this place 4 stars, but b/c of their ridiculously "out of the ball park prices", they get three.

Dinner was great and yes, we enjoyed ourselves tremendously!  We had the iron skillet, salmon sashimi and tuna tartar.  
The food was very good.

The decor is really cool and chic, as most have described.  The bathrooms are clean!  Yay!  The wine list is ok; and the sake list is very good.  Service was excellent and the pours on the wine were "good pours".  I must say, FINALLY....a restaurant that knows how to pour a glass of wine.  I've found many restaurants to be a bit stingy on their pours.  

The major downfall of the evening however, were the prices!  Look, we're not chintzy at all when we go out.  But if we pay, we like to receive something fair in return.  The iron skillet was $35 and it was small.  It had little meat; and more noodles.  We mentioned this to our server and all he said in rebuttal, was, "Yeh, you don't get a lot for the price in SF."  

Eh!  Look now, we've been to quite a lot nice and pricey places in the past and the majority of them offer a portion size = to their asking price.

Here, you won't get that.  What a disappointment.
author: Kat M.

description:
Went here for the first time a few years back for Valentine's Day, spent over $250 for two and was not impressed by the meal at all! 

On the flipside, why do I keep coming back? One answer...the bar.lounge area, it's always a reliable hangout for afterwork drinks with your co-worker or friends. if you want a consistent crowd in a hip and loungey environment. This is one of the places to hit up in the embarcadero area. Of course there's always Americano down the street...but why not make a few stop and make the night interesting :)
author: Susan K.

description: My family and I recently dinned at Ozumo.  The food was not only great but the staff was very friendly.  Mel is just a doll.  The Gyu Bento was amazing, the beef was so fresh and tender it just melts in your mouth.  I enjoyed my experience and look forward to eating there in the future.  I would happily recommend Ozumo anytime.
author: Jenny B.

description:
The boy and I decided to have a nice night out in San Francisco. Everybody always says to have sushi when you're in San Fran, so that's what we did. 

We hated this place. The only reason it is getting two stars is because our waiter really tried to make us feel comfortable when we obviously weren't. This place was pretentious, expensive, and somewhat uninviting. The first thing I wanted to do after I arrived was to leave as fast as possible. I understood that this place was going to be trendy with an expensive atmosphere, but I didn't realize that the sushi wasn't going to match up to the price. 
Our sushi was horrendous! I've had sushi from all over the country and this place is the bottom dweller. My sashimi was awful and didn't taste fresh at all. Very, very upset that I even gave this place a shot.
author: Meghan E.

description:
This review is for the Noodle Time Specials during lunch only.

I went to Ozumos twice within a week.  I have been looking... searching for my noodle place for a while since I got back to the bay area.  the truth is, it is really difficult to find something in SOMA... I wish I was back in the financial district area, but its not really up to me at this point. so i am really glad I found Ozumos.  I LOVED their Sapporo Ramen.  First time I went, the service was really slow and it took FOREVER to get my ramen.  But I patiently waited since my coworker said that it really is worth the wait.  and it was... I eat slow... but in matter of minutes, I was done with all the noodles and realized I was slurping on the soup... Edamame was gone too... I am still craving for the real crab legs in the soup with a bit of butter and picked vegis... noodles cooked to perfection...
Second time I went, we let them know that we were in a hurry.  we had no issues waiting for our ramen then.
they lose a star because it does take them a while for us to get the food but... it really is worth it...
author: Katelyn M.

description: Great place.  Love the food and the service.  The noise from the bar can get a little loud occasionally.
author: David H.

description: I love love love this place! great atmosphere. good service. A little overpriced, so no full stars.
author: Lynn W.

description: Favorite part about my experience here was the company I was with:(.  Don't get me wrong...the sushi was tasty but I just don't feel like the price matched.  We had to wait standing in the crowded bar for 25min even though we had a reservation and the hostess was very cold and short with us.  Our server was very nice but 3 stars is all I can give...my sushi place of choice is still Sushi Groove on Hyde St.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Ozumo is one of the best Japanese restaurants in the city.  Their sushi is a must because the fish is some of the freshest around and the grill items are super tasty too.  I highly recommend getting a sashimi plate and if you like veggies, get the eggplant and sweet potatoes, they are soooooo good.  The service is fantastic - especially if you get Felix!   He had great recommendations and was very personable.
author: Lisa Y.

description:
stylish bar, fast, friendly service and high quality fish....fantastic hamachi and scallops.

plenty of room at each table to hear yourself speak.
author: william b.

description:
Waitress was awful. Didn't bring my wife's drink until midway through meal. 
Half of our sashimi orders were warm. That's not good. 
My son who loves Japanese food wanted to go eat somewhere else after. Huge disappointment. 
Best part? Assistant waiter was great. He should be promoted.
author: Daniel K.

description: Great sushi place.  Had the yellowtail appetizer with a friend and toro sushi.   Service was a bit slow.
author: Michael P.

description: 15 pieces of sashimi... two skewers of chicken hearts.... 1 bottle of junmai daiginjo sake... two beers.... $300.  WORTH IT.
author: Josh F.

description: My husband and I went on our wedding night , we literally stayed next door at the Harbor Court hotel and we had an amazaing experience everyone was so nice. Our waiter name was Felix and he was amazing very kind and sweet. The manager Mel stopped by our table to congradulate us on our marriage. We felt like stars. The atmosphere was elegant and romantic. We never tried sushi but we had these " dynamite rolls" that were to die for omg, it was like tuna and creamc heese wraped in this cheese warm sauce umm umm, mai tai were delecious. We enjoyed ourselves so much we invited 2 of our favorite couples thesaturday night to sit in the lounge area for cocktails and champagne. Thanks Ozumo staff especially Felix and Mel manager!!!!! We will deffinately be back. That was a night to remember 2/25/2011
author: Candy Kane K.

description:
For our second night in San Fran we ended up at Ozumo. My wife's selection since she is Japanese and was looking for a taste of home. Upon entering, we were both amazed by the decor and disappointed - obviously it was quite beautiful, but we knew we were in for Americanized-Japanese food... and our intuitions served correct.

Overall, everything was decent-to-good, and I won't get into each dish since we tried a bit of everything. That said, it just doesn't compare to a place that really knows sushi, or for that matter even my wife's Japanese cooking. Call me spoiled.

In any regards, it probably serves the clientele well, as we saw no other Japanese in the place, and it surely is fun to people watch. A respectable, if not entirely predictable, meal.
author: Ryan A.

description: Pricey but worth it! Best sushi in the bay.
author: Johann B.

description:
The service was personal without being overwhelming. Their suggestions were on point steering clear of traditional sushi towards the small mixed plates. The black cod was perfectly cooked and seasoned; some at our table said better than Nobu. The scallops and mushrooms were fresh and paired well. Our table looked out at the bay bridge. The Masumi Arabashiri Namasaki recommendation was a wonderful accompaniment. 

The desert though tasty did not keep with the progression of the meal and will be passed during our next visit.
author: n m.

description: Outside of this restaurant you'll see Ferrari's lined along the street, the not-so-good-looking men that drive 'em & the botox bitches that luv em.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
1,400 ...  

and yes, that be in Dollars, not Yen. 

Thankfully the person placing the orders for our party of 8 can't do exchange rates (or add, obviously), and besides the vendor paid so I happily give this place five stars and order more sake (hot, if you please).

Ozumo dots the Embarcadero traffic stream next to Boulevard and the interior is classic SoHo Tribeca fusion.  The server will gladly walk you through off-menu options that become steadily less comprehensible with more sake so just wave it through.

Be the center of the universe.  Crash a party.  Wear a tie.  Sit through a boring meeting if you have to.  But whatever you do find a way to check Ozumo... on anothers' dime... it is class.
author: Jim W.

description: bucho roll, tontoro, octopus salad, salmon belly, rice pudding, short ribs, branzini, buritoro, hamachi, scallops/risotto
author: Josh L.

description: I had some of the best food there.  Kobe beef was awesome.  The sushi chef is also fun to chat with.  It does get crowded in the front but there are tables in the back.
author: S F.

description:
For hanging out on Thurs night, Ozumo has alot of action.  

For dinner..  be prepared to pay top $, the last few times its been about $75/person with minimal drinking.

I went once and had toro, which is really quite expensive and the cuts were not very good.  Same problem has happened at FukiSushi in Palo Alto.  A measure of a place's quality and pride would be whether they say they are sold out of toro, or if they sell you 2nd rate toro at full price.

Otherwise the place is a very fancy place to take a date to.  The food is definitely good, but if you're like me you kind of are annoyed by the overly fancy euro-japanese places like this and often just want a 5-star pure Japanese resturant w/o the frills and the fancy wait staff.
author: Doug C.

description:
Very pricey.

Small Portions

Rude & conniving waiters & staff

I'll go for a couple drinks at the bar, but not for a meal! Not worth it.
author: Keith R.

description:
Contemporary Japanese Cuisine with the price tag attached!  The food was good , not spectacular,  as my boyfriend and I were expecting.  We had the sashimi martini apetizer, vegetable robata plate,  and a couple of the special sushi rolls of the day,  After consuming those dishes, we didn't feel the need to order more, not because we were full, but because our food expections lowered.  We just weren't satisfied.  The restaurant decor is nice.  

The bar/lounge area is a nice upscale place for drinks-- nice & modern decor!
author: Cathy P.
Brad P.

description:
Ehh. SO NOT WORTH THE MONEY. $150 for 3. Sushi is good, but I have had better. I have a hard time parting with the $$$ for something so small. 

Sushi Rika, near in the tender nob way better.
author: Sean E.

description:
OK - let it be stated here that Ozumo is hands down the best sushi-ya in San Francisco.  And perhaps in the lower-48.  

It's all about quality at this joint.  When you can get chu-toro at the bar that rivals much of what you'll find at Tsukiji (yeah, the one way, way over there), or even the places that feed Tsukiji for that matter, you've found a place that does sushi right.  When it's located in San Francisco, the land of heavily dyed maguro and phenomenal roles but no actual quality sushi whatsoever, you've found something very special indeed.

Now, I know this joint is a bit pretentious.  And I know it's ridiculously expensive.  But this is truly a place where you will get what you pay for, especially when you compare it to the other offerings out there.  The fish is of just ridiculously high quality.  And, really, that's what the sushi experience should be all about.  Not that they don't do the rest of the classically Japanese menu (or the portions of the menu that  aren't classically Japanese for that matter) well - they do.  But the fish is the best around, by a long shot.  And that, to me, is worth every last dime you spend in this place. 

If you're a role fan, you can get good rolls all over this city (check out Miyabi, Wasabi & Ginger, or Kamekyo for some reasonable bites at reasonable prices).  But if you want good FISH, there's only one place to go.   

Side notes: service is just so-so; bar is too crowded by design, ambiance sucks ass, unless you're wanting something like Sushi Samba Rio - in which case you'll be right at home.  Put this place in a traditional sushi-ya setting and you'd have the best Japanese restaurant outside of Japan.  It's that close...
author: Forrest C.

description:
Love this place, although I do have to say its a bit pricey! Customer service has always been excellent.  I'm not much of a sushi person at all but when i come to this place to dine i always make sure i get the salmon phili cheese roll (forgot what its called).

Great place for a group of friends if you're willing to spend the money.  A group of us got the private dining room and one of my girlfriends actually ended up making out with one of the waiters (thats how much she was impressed with the service).

All in all dining is okay.  Happy hours of course are always crowded so just be sure you get there early enough to grab a seating area in the bar area.
author: Syonora A.

description:
The rolls and nigiri here are pretty good - decently prepared and unquestionably fresh.  The ambience is pleasant, and the waitstaff attentive.   The back room has a great view of the bay. In terms of quality and dining experience, I have no complaints.  

Why only three stars, then?  I view ratings as indicators of value - if the experience is good but nothing special, and the pricing isn't commensurate, I'm not inclined to give very good ratings.  In Ozumo's case, the pricelist reflects their expectations of the clientele - moneyed tech yuppies and lawyers in wingtips.  The formula works for them, given how crowded the place gets, but there's better sushi out there for less money ... even in SF.
author: Susuk L.

description: Food was good. However my two star rating comes from their takeout policy. If you order food to go a 20% automatic gratuity charge is slapped on top of your bill. Don't get me wrong I was going to leave a tip, however 20% is a bit steep on takeout. Didn't like that I had no option on what I felt was the correct amount of gratuity.
author: Laura P.

description: Very cool joint with almost two personalities - swanky bar scene in front, large, bright japanese restaurant in back with great view of bay bridge. Sushi is pretty good to very good, although the selection of rolls seems a little limited. The sake menu is ridiculous - worth the trip alone! They also have some very inventive drinks.  The non sushi items on the menu are generally also very good, and also very unique as well, albeit the whole menu is a little pricey.  We enjoy going there for drinks and small plates (which their menu caters to).
author: Josh B.

description: I was skeptical at first but after dining here I really love this place!  The ambiance is nice, by the water nice window views onto the Embarcadero.  Despite not being able to eat the raw stuff this round, I found plenty of cooked items to taste.  Started off with the edamame which came out piping hot roasted in some garlic sauce which made them extra tasty.  I had the Bucho roll and Ozumo roll which were both fantastic.  The fish and crab were really fresh the rolls were well made (not falling apart).  I loved the extra touch of yuzu aoili on the Bucho roll as well.  Also got the braised pork ribs; they just fell off the bone... so good.  Also got a chance to try the pork cheeks.. this was not my favorite but very fatty and flavorful for those who like that sort of thing.  Lastly for the entrees I tried the Suzuki and the Sake.  The Suzuki is a steamed sea bass over black rice/risotto.  This was superb.  The freshest and least oily sea bass i have every had!  I really loved this dish.  I think a touch of fresh lemon would have really made it stand out though.  The Sake was the salmon with peas/onions etc.  That was good too.  The salmon was well cooked and still juicy on the inside (not try like most places make it..)  But I have to admit that by that time I was pretty full so didn't get to enjoy the salmon as much as I would have.  Overall I would definetly come back once for a special occasion when I can drink the alcohol and eat the raw fish again!  The tuna tartare looked exquisite.
author: Margie C.

description:
yuppy priced sushi
kind service tasty tartare
views made my eyes smile
author: chester R.

description:
Delicious. My husband and I dined at Ozumo for our 10 year anniversary and it was exactly what we were looking for. An upscale, exciting restaurant that offers tasty plates. Our server, Elliot, was great. He took pictures for us, brought out complimentary champagne and dessert, and was extremely friendly. The management was kind and ensured a wonderful experience. 

The food was awesome...we ordered miso soup, futago, the dragon roll, and the Jidori chicken breasts. Food presentation was beautiful. 

We will definitely visit again!
author: Lindsey K.

description: The quality of fish here is pretty good and the sake selection is impressive in size. However, if I wanted to pay $180.00 for ten pieces of nigiri, two glasses of the cheapest sake on the menu, and a bowl of miso,  all for two people, I'd most definitely go elsewhere. I'd highly recommend a place like Sebo, where there is no pretentious air, the waitresses are actually helpful, the chefs are interesting to talk to, and where they truly love creating a meal for you.
author: F H.

description: Freshest suhi, good ambiance, delicious entree and the friendliest staffs. Jessica the "sake master" gave samples/tastings and explained where a particular sake originated, etc... Valet parking is a plus.
author: Cristina T.

description: This is a cute (or should I say kawaii??) bar that is really into creating a Japanese atmosphere (maybe even overly so). My cocktail was called the Giddy Geisha. They were playing shamisen music. The icing on the cake was when I walked into the bathroom and they were playing some type of Rosetta Stone Japanese learning CD. I learned a few new phrases in the ladies' room that evening. Awesome, ne? ^_^V
author: Angela X.

description: This is a review for their happy hour.  I should deduct one star because hh is only from 4-6 and only if I'm home "sick" can I make it.  Happy hour food here is wonderful and tasty and fried.  But I'm mostly giving 5 stars because the Giddy Geisha martini drink is probably my new favorite cocktail! Oh and for the guys - the bartenders are usually pretty darn hot women.
author: Jen C.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here for our anniversary. The place is really really nice..I would give the decor 4 stars, the food is average, but the price is up there. You pay more for the atmostphere/decor, plating, and service here....but the feel isn't too comfortable. If your looking for a upscale dressy up place with creative plating ..this is the place...but make sure you bring your bankroll to fill your stomach!   
I recommend trying this place on your own to decide.....great for couples. Definitely not a place to just pass by though.
author: .I I.

description: Ozumo use to be my spot for a drink and sushi until last night! the service was slow, the food was dreadful. The sushi chef must have discovered wasabi last night, so he/she used it excessively on my nigiri. Frankly speaking, I am not a picky eater, but I had to rush to the restroom and spat my tiger shrimp nigiri out! what a shame, guess I will have to find my new spot!
author: Ching N.

description:
Great place to meet with friends and have a few drinks. It is definitely a hipsters type of ambiance.  The food is very good and the service is good if you can get a table.

I recommend making reservations if you want to have dinner. However, if you just want to go for drinks, it is a good spot to hit.
author: Carlos R.

description:
This place is amazing. I love the atmosphere, the food and the service. There are plenty of options for fish lovers, meat lovers and veggie lovers. 
If you like sake, they have some great sampler options and tons of different kinds to choose from.
author: Jenny L.

description:
The sushi was very good, the service good, and the atmosphere was really fun, and the bar was solid (get the lychee martini!).  Sake flights were a first for us.

For pure sushi, there are better places in the city, but the whole package was excellent and trendy.
author: Jobba J.

description:
5 star food
3 star service
Great fresh sushi. Get the Hanabi. Great mixtures of flavor. Some amazing yellowtail. Good sake flights and info on sake.

Sat down at 9:10 on a Sunday night, door and website say open until 10:30pm. Immediately after seating the waitress informs us the kitchen closes at 10:00. Hmm. But anyway, the menu looks great. When I asked the waitress for suggestions on the appetizers she began a speech, when I interrupted to ask a question about one of the plates she got flustered and seemed irritated. We ordered a sake flight, drinks, soup, 2 appetizers, sushi, and rolls. The drinks and sake came late. We asked for them once when the appetizers arrived and still didn't get them until the sushi came, quite some time later. I would have enjoyed starting my drink and sake before even the soup came. She seemed to have forgotten about one of the rolls we ordered and it came pretty much at the end of the meal.
All in all, the service was amateur. But for sushi this good I wouldn't hesitate going again.
author: Webber B.

description: Um, okay. . . . I just forked over $100 bucks for LUNCH for just my friend and I.  What, no lunch specials!  Whaddup with that?  Okay, I would say that my home girl is completely worth that cost cuz of her bday, but not for sushi.  That literally hurts this peasant's pocket.  We ordered the ozumo roll, which is crab, tuna and eel.  Then we ordered your traditional dragon and spider roll.  Had their so called "world famous" garlic soy edamame (bid deal, whoop a dee doo), and finally a thing of sashimi.  If you blind folded me and told me to taste it, and I didn't see the nice platter, with sauce dripped on the border of the plate.  Or the nice spring lettuce used to nest the sashimi. . . . what do you think I would taste.  Um, hello. . . just sushi.  Even their diluted soy sauce needed help.  Come on ya'll, if you can afford to jack the price on everything else, at least give us quality soy sauce. Ok, so the atmosphere is very sophisticated, service is pretty good, but if you want taste, good service, and better parking too.  I suggest Umi on 18th.  It'll be our little secret.  ; )
author: Janice F.

description: DELICIOUS but overpriced. I came here for a weekday lunch. My friend and I got a spider roll, edamame, and a miso marinated black cod bento box. Everything was amazing. Especially the cod. So tender and tasty. The meal totaled about $40 - a bit much for a lunch that didn't fill either us up. But boy... it WAS good. Very hip and chic spot, too.
author: Natasha P.

description: D and I had dinner here for New Year's Eve. Delicious sushi rolls and lobster special. Sake was outstanding, although guidance through the list was confusing from our waiter. We loved the food and ambiance, but chocked this place up to another bizarre waitstaff experience. Waiter was quiet, shy, confused with specials and prices. We felt like we were helping him figure the menu out. Maybe it was due to the crazy night and crowded restaurant. I would definitely go back in heartbeat, but we've decided to start documenting our weird waiters in a photo book.
author: Megan D.

description: This is one of the busiest and most elegant restaurants in SF.  It is massive and a very impressive operation.  I love the ambiance and layout.  The food of course rocks and the service is generally very good considering how busy the restaurant tends to be.  It is pricey of course, but one of the best places in town.
author: Anna G.

description: I love the decor in this place. Food was good and the waiter was knowledgeable of the menu. Everything I ordered was recommended by him. fresh food very tasteful but, I dont think that Japanese food should be THIS expensive.
author: Trisha C.

description: I have eaten at Ozumo at least 20 times and they consistently deliver a good meal. Make sure you eat in the back room on the Embarcadero side, which is much more pleasant than the front or the middle sections.
author: Josiah H.

description: Pricey but well worth it!! Recommend the dohyo and futago, All the sushi was fantastic, anything from Ozumo will be amazing!
author: K P.

description: This used to be one of my favorite restaurants to visit whenever I'm in San Francisco.  Haven't been to the restaurant in over six years.   Dined there last night and was a bit disappointed.  It still has a great atmosphere--particularly the bar area.  I had great memories of eating rolls whenever I would visit---but the quality was definitely sub-par to my past experience.  Maybe just went on a bad day--but wasn't all that impressed this time.  The scallops we ordered this time was good though.  Might give it one more shot since I'm in San Fran another week---Hopefully, there will be an improvement.
author: John S.

description:
come for the ramen menu at lunch in the front of the restaurant.

i haven't had their sushi for a couple years, but remember it to be pretty good.

service is excellent.
author: Andy P.

description:
Everything was excellent, beginning with Chef Alex's tasting menu full of rhythmic taste, each better than the last.  Beginning with outstanding rosette of halibut then seared scallops topped with foie gras followed by kobe beef topped with the most amazing butter ball whipped with wasbi.  Amazing flavors that build beautifully upon the next!  Just a sample of the many surprises and combinations that enticed us to dine at Ozumo's twice in 10 days.  After just returning from Tokyo in October, I long for the elegance and the taste of true Japanese dining, which is gratefully found at Ozumo's.

Our server, Bertram is outstanding -- request him.  He is brilliant in his knowledge of food, ingredients, and tastes.  Very personable with no attitude and a true sense of pleasure for what he is serving.  He recommended excellent sakes, both the cold, Summer Snow, and the hot, Muko, which kept our company savoring every minute of our luxurious experience.
We will return very soon, again.
author: cinthia h.

description: The black cod was succulent and I would make the trek just for that!  Service was impeccable! Made my birthday surprise evening a very appreciated effort! Would go back! You won't be disappointed.
author: Terry S.

description: Loud, crowded & amazing food -- just what you need some nites!
author: Johnna M.

description: The family and I really loved Ozumo.  The service, food, and ambiance were excellent.  There were 6 of us (including 2 children) and they were kind enough to offer a private dining room since it was a seemingly early dinner on a Sunday and it wasn't that crowded just yet.  When we left, the place was buzzing with a bunch of people.  We really appreciated the kind and thoughtful service.  We have also heard amazing things about their restaurant in Oakland and can't wait to try it.
author: J T.

description: this is an expense account type of sushi place.  the fish is actually pretty good (fresh).  tried salmon, yellowtail, scallop.  the rice is on the dry side and the wasabi variable amounts.  come here for presentation, ambiance, and fresh eats, but not my kind of intimate sushi joint, more of a see and be seen kind of place.
author: Rob C.

description: To be honest....food was like a 4.....the price, very expensive....the lady infront, was very rude!!!!
author: Bella T.

description: I'm changing this review to five stars because I felt bad about the four stars rating I gave originally as I do love this place.  They have five star food and five star service.  I run a business myself and i know how sad it is to receive four stars when you KNOW you offer five star service all the time, every day to everyone who walks through your doors.  Anyone could have made the mistake of taking an order from the kitchen before its time...so I'm upping the star rating.  :)  I'll come back here.
author: Annette V.

description: WORST SERVICE OUT OF ANY RESTAURANT I'VE BEEN TO IN SF!!!  Be prepared to be ignored, to fill up your own wine glasses, and not have your dirty dishes cleared. Wrote a letter to the GM - Mel and didn't even acknowledge the poor service. Will never go back. Food is decent but very, very pricey. I know so many other good Japanese places to go to. If you need a reco, just email me!
author: Josephine H.

description:
Dec 2007 - Saturday night. Great unique drinks using Japanese rice vodka! Sitting at the bar for a pre meal cocktail was the perfect way to suck in the uber cool atmosphere. Great dark decor lots of wood and earth tones.

The sake flight was delicious and really unique. I've never had sake before and the waiter explained it to me over and over again in great detail. BRAVO.

The sushi was melt in your mouth delicious as were the tuna tartar and other appetizers.  The food was perfect the environment was cool/hip but not pretentious, and the entire experience was a delight.
Dinner for 3 with a couple of cocktails each was only $150. Not bad for this kind of quality!
author: Happy C.

description:
me: we went to ozumo
me: sucky japanese place
sean: sounds awesome
me: we asked for still water and 1 girl asked for sparkling
me: they gave everyone sparkling and poured it
me: and we were like whoa whats up
me: so they stopped
me: took a soup order
me: had everyone put up their hands if they want soup
me: cuz it was 11 ppl
me: did that 3 times
me: never brought the soup
me: we ordered 2 vege gyoza
me: never came
me: forgot one of the rolls
me: i loled
sean: that's good service
me: yeah
me: the gratuity was included in the bill
me: good thing for that guy
me: idiot
author: aaron f.

description: I love the decor at Ozumo.  We had lunch here one day.  As a vegetarian, my choices are fairly limited.  I ordered Kare Raisu (basically japanese curry rice complete with spinach,  eggplant, zucchini, over Genmai (brown) rice in light curry sauce) which was good, small in portion, and certainly not  a great deal at $13!
author: Tiffany L.

description: Trendy, scene-y, expensive...all pretty much the kiss of death for me when it comes to sushi.  I just don't need to spend hundreds of dollars on a meal that will leave me wanting.  And this meal left me wanting.  More food and less scene.
author: Emily T.

description: Great place for after-work drinks. People watching, check. Delicious appetizers, check. Fun, fluffy drinks for girls, check. Convenient location and near many other bars/restaurants, check.
author: Han C.

description: Overpriced HH  food; drinks are strong. I got the giddy geisha for happy hour at $7.00.  After 6pm the drinks were $13.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Great bay view from the sushi bar, yummy  rolls and fresh sashimi, friendly service, awesome sake menu!
author: Caroline M.

description: Great food and great, friendly service. Chill ambiance. Could not have been better. We had a sake sampler which was very interesting.
