Had a piece of Cod with Miso glaze which was outrageously good. Sat at the bar and Jake made sure our experience was worth every penny. We'd come back for sure. But prefer the cozy lounge over the brighter and less intimate bayside dining room.
author: Wes S.

description:
i absolutely adore Ozumo!!!

i know Sho Camio (the guy who made the menu - also an Iron Chef in Japan) doesn't work there anymore, but he really knew what was up!!

the food is delectable!!

the sushi is so fresh and they have so many choices!

my fave part of ozumo is the sake...they have more variety and knowledge about sake than any other place i have been in california.

the cooked items are to die for, too...the black cod...MMM!

i am just in love with ozumo...havent been there in a while, tho, bc i live in LA, but it really rocks my world!!

TIP: try the Masume Sanka sake...to DIE for!!

xo-
andrea
author: Anz L.

description:
Pretentious =  1 star 

All the reviews could be useless...cos i woke up this morning realized that if food or restaurant is 5 stars or 1 star has a lot to do with who you go with 

Could be the company i went with most of the time...supplier/vendors have been asked to bring us there countless times.

No one should eat shasimi as full course meal....
author: N N.

description:
Gracie Unni & J's Adventure #3 
(in case you were wondering, i have 2 more reviews after this ... the infamous adventures of my gracie unni & i)...

first of all, i'll be truly honest with you ... i don't remember a damn thing about this darn place because i was drunk, not to the point of being super intoxicated, but just enough to laugh uncontrollably, but i do remember how ozumo def had a nice modern touch, and i wouldnt mind coming back soon, REAL soon.. 

another thing i remember of this place is making numerous restroom visits, literally every 5 seconds ... but overall, it was a very nice place, very nice, but the reason it loses a star is because we wanted to order sushi but they didn't have any ... uh, that's stupid because you should always have sushi... iono...
author: Jennifer S.

description: Love Love Love everything about this venue. The decor and ambiance is gorgeous. Set the mood for an intimate time.  The sashimi was as fresh as can be!!  I also had a lychee drink. Amazing!!! I could probably come here every week or more :)
author: Lola D.

description: I have been going to Ozumo for years and stop by everytime I am in SF. They have reliable good Japanese food in a great setting. Always go with a good group since it's great to order and share. The Tuna and Salmon sashimi are conistently fresh and tasty. The tuna tartare and yaki tako are delicious. Always order one of the hot pots, it's so worth it. Order some items from the robata as well including the short ribs, black cod and eggplant. If you have room you should order the fondue!
author: Helen B.

description: It has a trendy izakaya atmosphere in the bar area and a boring fine dining atmosphere in the dining area. I agree with other reviewers that it feels like 2 different restaurants. Food is pretty good but pricey. I would stay in the bar area, if you're looking for young/hopping vibe.
author: Su K.

description:
This is a difficult review. I've eaten at Ozumo 2 or 3 times and it's good solid food. But what is it that makes me wanting more? (Or less in terms of the cost of a lunch). Is there a pretentiousness in the staff? Not so much. Is the food excellent...it's good (a little cool when you're expecting hot) The portions are good. I don't know. I just don't know. One funny thing...I was eating lunch with an Asian fellow (Chinese American) and on the way in and out the (Caucasian) hostess spoke Japanese. "A for effort ", my friend said,  "but I'm not Japanese." 
Crab cakes were ok..dip was mediocre...Miso soup (do they sell this in a can?), The Hanabi was very good, bill for two was $70.00. Hmmmm?
author: Craig M.

description: It's definitely expensive, but Ozumo holds a special place in my heart...I went on my second date with my boyfriend here. I was nervous, he was suave, the wine went down easy, and the food was incredible. It was the perfect night and it makes me all mushy and nostalgic every time I eat here.
author: Brianne K.

description: Ozumos is the best sushi I've had in the bay area thus far. Everything I've had has been great. Try their daily specials they are out of this world. Sometime you do have to wait a little while to be seated and it can cost more then other sushi places but its so worth it. Also they teach Japanese in the bathrooms! It sounds weird but it's so cool! You have to check this place out. I love it!
author: Derek H.

description: This is my favorite sushi bar in SF - it is expensive, but the sushi and sashimi is excellent, the presentation is creative and the atmosphere is awesome.  I highly recommend sitting in the bar area if you're on a date or want to really have a good time.  The main seating room is blandly decorated and very bright with a nice view of the embarcadero, but the bar is an island style bar area with tables all around and is very dimly lit with great music playing.  I highly recommend this for dates or if you want to grab great sushi with a few people before going out and want an upbeat place with great sushi.
author: J H.

description: There are some nice things to say about Ozumo, but when it comes to food, I'd say it's just OK.  It's definitely a well-designed restaurant, very trendy and modern without being over the top.  Service is always good, and the prices are perhaps on the high side, but as this tends to be an expense account place in terms of business/recruiting, it's not normally my money, and people from out of town tend to enjoy it.  Still, it's got to be said that there are few places in SF that I've been to where the quality of the meal oscillates more.  I'll have a meal or do quick sushi takeout where I say to myself, "I need to make a point of eating here more often--this is great sushi!" (I'm very enthusiastic when I talk to myself about sushi) and then will return two weeks later and feel like I've been robbed in terms of the price:quality ratio.  Can't explain it, but it's what I've observed.
author: Ty D.

description: Finally agreed to dinner with the Boring Lawyer. All he talked about was tort this, contract that and pedophilia case. I wanted to smother him with big piece of raw tuna. Luckily succeeded at ignoring BL in order to watch masterful sushi chef, Ken-Sun, whose skill with his knife on big rolls of sushi was pure pleasure to watch. Bar area is also Hot, Anime playing on overhead screen a good touch, and my favorite was bathroom, with Japanese language tapes on audio.
author: natashka o.

description: Mediocre and very expensive.  The sushi was actually ok but not great, the futogo (basically a gyu tataki) was excellent. The ribeye was over peppered and somewhat dry. We complained about it and the waitress asked - do you want me to call the manager? We are pretty much non confrontational so we just said no we just wanted to let you know. She should have been proactive to take care of it, a manager and asking us basically if we wanted to make a scene certainly wasnt necessary. For $44, the meat was terrible. The atmosphere was great so if you just need some mediocre food but with a great atmosphere it might be ok.
author: anthony c.

description:
i dunno i like this place!  i was surprised that such a foofy restuarant would actually have decent food.  we had:

-the seaweed salad (not your usual slivers of seaweed, but almost full leaves of seaweed!):  very pretty, fresh tasting, but lacked something in the dressing.  perhaps a bit more sweet and tartness would have helped.
-salmon and yellowtail sashimi:  extremely fresh, buttery, melt in your mouth.  very good.  wish the cuts were a big more generous though.
-tempura shrimp roll:  good, but i thought the rice was too packed and slightly soggy.
-hamachi kama (yellowtail collar) - oh the best thing that we ordered!  grilled perfectly with a bit of burnt on the skin, and the meat very tender and juicy.  highly recommended.
-some hamachi salad with ginger and jalepeno?  i didn't care for it, thought the dressing was too strong, but my friend loved it.

the service was also very good.  i had a blonde moment and had booked our opentable.com reservation a day early, but still they were able to get us a bar seat in 5 minutes.

also, weds seems to be the hot night to go - seemingly hip professionals crowd.  good sake mixed drinks too!
author: Josie M.

description: my favorite sushi in all of sf, probably because my friend is a sushi chef there and I got totally spoiled BUT try the lamb and the ahi tuna and ask for the oyster/uni shots - maybe that was a special treat for me. Everything on the menu is delicious and the vibe is on point - nothing but the best.
author: c g.

description:
Great food, very nice decor, attentive service. Ask your waiter for their specials, and be sure you won't be disappointed. Rolls are fantastic, but what sets this restaurant apart is the Japanese cuisine applied to some American ingredients ( eg. New York style meat). I read many people complaining about the price, but I think it is not too much for the quality and the level of the restaurant.
The only flaw: a bit too noisy.
author: Francesca R.

description: I don't even like sushi, but this place made me actually like some of it.  Very good food overall, nice ambiance and good service.
author: Michael P.

description: it was just okay.....I really wanted to like this place but how do you F-up a california roll? Sorry but I think that Yoshi's is better......
author: Annie G.

description:
ok, first of all, i'm don't really like sauces and all that jazz, so that's the only reason why it's missing a star, and maybe because their portions are quite conservative.
i ordered basically almost all the small dishes, but my favourite is definitely the spicy tuna and avocado dip thing with the chips.  The spicy tuna was pretty good and the avocados / guacamole was excellent as well.  another standout dish was their salmon sashimi, which i usually stay clear of, but this time was really good.
also, the maitre d' who seated us was extremely good looking (off topic, i know but man she was gorgeous) and had awesome tattoos.  rest of the food was forgettable, but the maitre d' is alone worth another visit :)
author: Chris L.

description: This hip spot doesn't get enough credit. And still it's always packed. The menu was defined by the Japanese Iron Chef, Shou. And the design is painstakingly trying to balance Japanese concepts and $$$ Dining functionalities. My rose tinted view might be from when Donovan threw his Chill Parties here and going there with my hedge fund friends. How this place really satisfies both palettes is it's finishing touch.
author: Jean W.

description: This is probably my favorite place to go for rolls. It's pretty pricey for what you get, but worth I would go back for a special occasion. If you're looking for a fancier upscale japanese restaurant, this place is two thumbs up for the food and ambiance. My friends and I got three different desserts and they were all amazing. The only thing I'm not too crazy about was the slow service.
author: Tracy L.

description: I really like the sushi here - it's always very fresh.  I've enjoyed the sashimi, nigiri and rolls every time.  Last night I had the shabu shabu and the fondue - both were delicious.   As the waitress anticipated, our neighbors looked on enviously as we dipped our fresh fruit into the chocolate.   The vibe is great too - if you like to see and be seen, there's the darker bar area.  If you like a more zen environment, the main dining area is soothing.  Here are the negatives - the portions aren't that large, and it is expensive (forgot to ask one time when they suggested uni sashimi and that cost a pretty penny).  The bar area can be deafening, largely because of the music.  Service is friendly - the host must have checked in 5 times with us as we were sitting near the host stand - but the food is slow.   Last night, our bucho roll never showed, and the waitress (who was otherwise very friendly) was apologetic but basically said dishes do go missing when they're served by mistake to the wrong table and not rejected, and then suggested that perhaps we might not want to reorder since the sushi was really backed up with several large parties.  Good thing we were no longer hungry.  And another time at the bar I was given someone else's check - which was twice as much as our dinner.  Luckily I looked as my friend did not.  Overall, some issues but I still go back for the quality sushi and variety.
author: Vivian W.

description: The only reason why I didn't give this place 5 stars is because of the price.  Love the food, the atmosphere (anime playing in background, and live DJ's), the service.  But this place will break you if you go too much.  I like hanging out in their lounge.  Good drinks made with good sake.  The bathroom freaked me out at first.  You hear someone speaking japanese.  I was like "uh.... hello?"  Actually, it's a recording that teaches you how to speak basic Japanese.
author: M S.

description: This place is never bad, never great.  I only go there when I am using a corporate credit card.  It is nice, predictable, and everyone will find something they can enjoy.  If you want outstanding sushi...you will need to keep looking.  But the combo of afterwork crowd, expensive food, and nice food will keep this place the same for years.
author: Alex H.

description:
Crap tastic!!!
too expensive and the waitstaff just doesn't give a rat's ass.  seriously, went to the bathroom and the audio in there is playing a "Learn Japanese" tape with sayings like:
Where is my husband?  Where is my child?  Where is the bathroom?  (Been to Japan, never needed to ask for anything in Japanese, I played the round eye card and they loved me, particularly the gal working in the hostess bar who taught me all these naughty words)  At Ozumo, it would have been nice to come out of the tinkler and say DOKO NI WATASHI NO BAKA AHHO waiter IMASU KA (where is my stupid ass waiter)?  The way he crapped on about the place being so great as if he was the SKEVVY(pimp daddy) of the place- whatever,  KIEUSERU(fuck off) and bring me my god damn sake before my sushi!  
TWO WORDS FOR THEIR RICE- UNCLE BEN'S!!!!  And for a Japanese restaurant that says they were rated number one (by mid western tourists ,gutter palates, and SENZURIs- wanks), bad rice is UNFORGIVABLE.
There are hundreds of better places to get your sushi on in San Francisco, HUNDREDS!
author: Aimee L.

description:
i went on a blind date (back in 2003) and he asked me to meet him at ozumo for dinner. unfortunately i was not attracted to him nor did i feel obligated to "put out."  he had every sense in trying so hard. poor guy didn't care enough to check the damn mirror before meeting me! he had a booger dangling in one of his nostrils (oh hello!!). he dressed real nice though. i nicknamed him, 'stockbroker booger'

but i was clearly impressed by the restaurant. service is off the hook! i looooved their sushi rolls, soft shell crab appetizer, and their grilled beef dish. i remember tasting ponzu sauce for the first time and i melted in my seat. my date wished he was the chair, honey! 

i had 3 lychee sake martinis and one grey goose and tonic. luckily i lived in the city so all i needed to do was hail a taxi cab because i was pretty toasty. my date kept on talking about himself. i let him rant about his success stories and accomplishments. all dandy, sugar..leave me alone so i can finish my food! 

a dap and a friendly-"looking at you like a big brother" kind of pat on the back as we bid farewell. i smiled at him with a tummyful of ozumo goodness while seated in the cab. threw a 'peace out' sign as the driver took off. priceless.
author: Mika D.

description:
maybe the haterade is strong in me today, but everytime ive been here i was like wtf? the first time, my buddy was the first folks to throw a party there. was thinking nice decor, i should come back to check out the food. mmmmmm mistake. decent food at holy crap you couldve at least used some ky first prices. went several time more afterwards. nothing to say except, well, shit when do i have nothing to say.... everything is there, nice decor, nice open kitchen thats nearly spotless and ventilation is great, no smoky smell even when youre sitting right next to the robata grill, decent to great wait staff.... but theres no real FEEL, LIFE to the place. its as empty as the 40 something cougar licking her lips at me from across the bar. the food is decent, but really nothing to get too excited about. really, i am fish snob, and ozumo gots nothing on places that cost half as much. 

i like the bar, as that a bar, but then again, im not really a "pretty boy/girl" whose exhistence lies on peoples perception of them, so i guess i dont belong here. i belong with the normal folks... whatever that means.
author: Euge L.

description:
ozumo is definitely on the swanky, cool side.  like most places, eating in the bar area is more interesting than eating in the main dining room.  if you have a party of more than 3-4 then the main dining room is the way to go and if you want to make reservations, then go ahead and reserve a room in the dining room.  the main room is well decorated and pretty nice.  

most nights the bar area will have a DJ spinning something good without it being so loud.  i think last night he was spinning 80's reject tunes like herbie hancock remixes which was kind of funny.   the hamachi appetizer (i think they call is hanabi) is one of the specialties. avocado, hamachi, tomatoes in a ponzu chili sauce.  very cool.  then we went on to one of the many rolls and had some fatty tuna and eel sushi.  everything was very nice, as usual.  with sushi, it's mostly about the ingrediants so ozumo is safe as long as they keep getting the good fish, i think.  but the prepared food, like the hanabi is quite creative as well.  

and of course, you probably want to get a sake if you go to ozumo since they have such a large selection.  

the grades start at junmai, then ginjo, then daiginjo... which refers to the % of the rice that has been polished down prior to make the sake from it.  if you don't know much about sake then just get a junmai or ginjo because the daiginjo will get pricey and you might not be able to tell the difference anyway.  don't get a warm sake.  heating up sake (although a facinating gimmick) is like putting ice in wine.  it destroys much of the flavors and is a trick to mask bad sake.  you would never warm up good sake.  you warm up mediocre sake so that it doesn't taste as bad as it would normally.  when you're at a restaurant, stick to cold sake so you can still appreciate the flavors.  start with a junmai bottle or better yet, ask your server to recommend a sake tasting so you can sample a variety .... maybe an unfiltered sake, a dry one, a sweet one, etc...
author: dan h.

description: Probably the best sushi I have had in SF. Even the California rolls stand out as amazing and the sashimi is as fresh as it gets. Service is good, prices are high - kind of expected. The only thing I wasn't that impressed with were the beignets but the walnut brownie dessert more than made up for that.
author: Shannon F.

description: Wonderful dining experience!  My husband and I enjoyed the chef special selected dinner.  Eight excellent course that run the gamut of their menu.  Huge sake and wine menu with many unique sakes.  The wait staff was excellent and very engaged in the dining experience.  Yes, it is expensive, but well worth the experience in SF!
author: Linda H.

description:
if i were walking past ozumo, i would not go in. my first reaction would be to think, "expensive" and move on. well, that's not totally unfounded, but tonight we had a bit of an advantage.

sitting down at the bar, i realized that the bar staff is not only extremely friendly, but also very attentive. sapporo on tap is definitely a good thing. a great thing. also, knowing the bartender is nothing but an advantage. sake tastings all night long really makes the entire evening more posiitve. we ordered the garlic edamame and the seaweed salad to start. although i've had better tasting seaweed salads at tokyo go go, i did find the japanese plum a plus. the edamame was amazing. not too much garlic, but it definitely was better than any other edamame i've had anywhere else. i was particularly hungry this evening and ordered the yokozuna maki, rock and roll maki, anago nigiri, unagi nigiri, and beni toro nigiri. as you can tell, i love eel. i had never tried seawater eel (anago) and was in for a surprise. it was sooo good.

whoever it was in a previous review that said this was a hipster-ish bar was horribly mistaken. this is a cougar bar if anything. i was getting the eye from a slew of older women as well as a few older guys. i can't see how you can walk in this bar single and walk out alone.

ultimately, if i had the kind of money i spent tonight, every night, i would eat here all the time. this is definitely a rare treat.
author: Jeremiah W.

description:
the restaurant part of the experience was delightful - full of vegetarian friendly tidbits, tasty drinks and wonderful service.

the bar part of the experience was less miserable - full of rudeness, cramped or nonexistent seating and slow service.

so an average of four stars, and a note-to-self not to return without a table reservation.
author: shannon e t.

description:
I love coming to this downtown hotspot...my wallet, not so much.  

Food:  2 stars.  The menu is ridiculously extensive and overwhelming.  I had kept losing track of the items we wanted to order.  Finally we decided on the uni nigiri (sea urchin), sumo roll (hamachi, tuna and shiso over california roll), yokozuna roll (grilled unagi with crab), shacho roll (lobster), sekiwake roll (spicy tuna), dobin mushi teapot, dohyo (tartare of big tuna), futago (grilled Washu beef), unagi (eel) salad, gindara (black cod), shiromi (salt grilled Pacific sea bass), hotate (pan seared sea scallops), and tofu cheesecake for dessert.  The problem with such a large menu is that it can create problems in the kitchen with execution.  Sure enough, the following dishes left a lot to be desired:  sumo roll (boring), sekiwake roll (spicy tuna that wasn't spicy), dobin mushi teapot (glorified miso soup), futago (blandly sweet), unagi salad (no flavor), and tofu cheesecake (as nasty as it sounds).  The saving graces were the dohyo (tasty spin on tuna tartare but they need to include more of those awesome gyoza chips), gindara (black cod marinated in miso and sake makes miso happy!) and hotate (best dish of the night).

Service:  3 stars.  Service here is decent.  I noticed that a restaurant manager was watching our server like a hawk (she must have been a newbie).  I felt scared for her because the manager looked pretty strict.  She made one mistake (she gave the dobin mushi teapot to my friend even though I ordered it) and he jumped all over her for that.  Poor little grasshoppa.

Atmosphere:  5 stars.  The atmosphere is definitely the main reason to come here.  It's alive and kicking, with a beautiful bar in the front and a modern, clean dining space in the rear.  The restaurant definitely features a see-and-be-seen crowd, especially during happy hour.  I love the free Japanese lessons given over the intercom in the restroom.  You can try to stay and learn, although I'm sure people will think you're a freak.

Hits:   Hotate, gindara, dohyo, atmosphere, being hooked on Japanese phonics.

Misses:  Unagi salad, tofu cheesecake, sekiwake roll, extensive menu, getting weird looks while learning Japanese in the restroom.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Blowfish Sushi to Die For, O Chame, Sushi Ran, Sushi Groove South
author: Keith C.

description:
I have hardly considered giving anything 1 or 2 stars, but recently I had the most awful experience at Ozumo.  I had been here before and remember the comfie lounge area, the hip feeling and the great sushi.  

Saturday night, a group of 6 went there for dinner.  Our 9:15 resi ran over so we decided to eat in the bar area.....can I please tell you that all around the service was horrible.  Our cute waitress started off the evening by spilling half my drink on my lap...good times...that is fine, until the next time she came around and was pouring water and the same thing happened...no offer to pay for the drink, just an oops, I'm sorry.  We decided to eat in the bar since our table was running late.....we finally flagged the waitress down to take our order.....after walking to the host stand on several occasions and getting a BS story about the restaurant capacity, how the kitchen was slammed and that they were running behind.  That is all fine and dandy, but we just wanted to order.  I think the two clinchers were after sitting there for an 1 1/2 hrs and only our pregnant friend's food had arrived, The waitress asked how was our meal and could she get us anything else....we hadn't even gotten our food yet!!!....we had a few words and for the first time ever in my history in SF, we left only a 10% tip....the final straw was the annoyed host....after requesting that he call a cab for us....

The only redeeming quality was the DJ spinning old school mixes!
author: Tracy M.

description: My friend took me here for dinner and I was not disappointed. I had the best Spanish mackerel ever. Seriously, no bite. All of the sashimi was very clean, cut thin West coast style. The rolls were OK. We had a rainbow-like roll that was incredible. Also had some CA rolls and Caterpillar which were just OK. But the sashimi was insanely good. Hamachi, yellowtail, salmon, & fatty tuna. I was pounding some Savingnon Blanc which was incredible (New Zealand) and went perfectly with the fish. Excellent service in a very trendy, yuppie environment for a Tuesday night. Cons: Prices are just OK, especially the rolls which are overpriced. I've had better quantity sushi of similar quality but a couple of "best ever" votes makes me confident in a 4 star rating. Go and be merry but have your business partner or friend pick up the tab!!
author: Jonathan H.

description: That's it! You can give me great design, and make a space look nice and inviting, but after the 3rd time of extreme service disappointment, I will never go back. This last attempt had us sitting at damp chairs - waiting around for orders, food and checks (became a 2 hour work lunch!) and overall nothing special to accompany the $40 check for each at the end of the meal!!
author: Amanda P.

description: I come to Ozumo's because the sushi is on the top of the list for best in SF.  They have some pretty unique cocktails that are really tasty and the crowd is good.  Its a great place to visit for an early dinner or a late drink and bite.  I really enjoy the service, sushi and ambiance every time.  The live DJ makes it all that better.
author: Joella A.

description: Their signature cocktail "Giddy Geisha" was fabulous, which is a mix of lychee & passion fruit. Simply amazing. They also have a vast selection of sake. The staff is unbelievably nice. I can't wait to go back and have dinner!
author: Faith V.

description: Definately quality food & great vibe.   Can't go wrong with anything from the sushi bar.  If you get a chance to try the seared duck breast, do it because you won't regret it.  Cool place to chill at the bar for some Japanese beer or sake tasting.
author: Jason A.

description: Best sushi I've had in San Francisco. I found the tako (octopus), uni (urchin), and shrio maguro (albacore) to be especially excellent here. I recommend sitting at the sushi bar and ordering omakase (chef's choice) style (my friend and I ordered $60/person omakase and got an excellent selection of sashimi and sushi, including toro, tako, uni, and abalone among others). The sake is priced slightly higher than I'd like, but what the hell.. splurge a little. Service was friendly and attentive.
author: Sunny Y.

description:
delicious. expect to pay a lot. great service. modern decor.

my favorite - hanabi.
author: Oanh N.

description: Sayonara Ozumo!  Anyone who knows what good Japanese food should taste like won't like this place. The nigiri we had last night was bland and dry.  I couldn't believe the prices they charge for such sub-par food.  I guess they can charge what they do because of the waterfront real estate.  I give it one extra star because I liked the Japanese language tutorials playing in the men's room.  Ja mata...
author: Reality Check S.

description: Come for the happy hour and creative rolls, stay for the shabu shabu and hanabi (imo the best dishes on the menu) and stay even longer for the chocolate fondue with exotic fruits (star fruit, mango, grapefruit, kiwi etc...).  This has become not only my favorite japanese restaurant in the city but one of my overall favorites (along w/ Slanted Door, Mecca, Limon, Oola and a few select others).  If you havent been here - go now, sit at the sushi bar - and ask for a custom roll.
author: D S.

description: Ozumo was really great last night. We sat in the Sake Lounge, which has such a lively atmosphere.  It's first come, first serve, so you never know if you'll get lucky - but we did. Three of us girls, we ordered wine and sake, garlic edamame (SO good), Ozeki, Sekiwake, Maku-Uchi and Hanabi (their rolls and ingredients are listed on their website). Total was around 65$ p/p. Service was fast, efficient and friendly and food was great. Would recommend and will definitely go back. Maybe next time we'll sit in the actual restaurant, which looks very nice as well.
author: Jenn D.

description: Just now when I searched for Ozumo, just thinking of it made me chuckle. Ozumo thinks it's way more than it is, but it does have fine sushi.  The fish is not as good as Sushi Groove, but I don't think people come here for the fish. People come here b/c it's like a less dumb Blowfish experience.  The bar is cool from a design standpoint, but is usually packed, and quite a scene - usually with people not from SF, but surrounding environs.  The dining room is big, loud, and gets hot on a busy night. Like I mentioned, fish is ok and menu is large and varied.  Overall, I think Ozumo tried to recreate Katana in West Hollywood, and failed.  It's a hip, sceney sushi place that's more hip and scene than sushi - and I use hip loosely.
author: Emily M.

description: I admit I only got through the last 20 or so reviews.  However, if you do not sit at the Sushi bar and do not order Omakasi (and I even say only raw fish nothing cooked - except for the Fois Gras tartar) why go there?  Their toro is some of the best ever but yea it is $10 per piece.  Not per order.  Per piece.  Order 10 pieces = $100.  Add another $100 for Saki.  I don't think I have left this place without spending less than $200 a person.  But if you order right, it is worth the money (especally if on an expense account).  :)
author: John G.

description: 5 Stars for the Toro (but it'll cost a month's salary- may be worth it sometimes). It's trendy, hip, with live dj music veering towards house/electronica type of stuff. Nice place to have a girl's night hang for drinks and food. Service has been inconsistent, sometimes good sometimes bad. Chocolate Fondue is excellent!  Like I said, not a place to get stuffed....just enough to appease your taste buds.
author: Maya L.

description: I love Ozumo! I've been on a sushi rampage lately and keep coming back for more. The Japanese vocabulary lessons in the bathroom, plus the fresh rolls and trendy vibe give this place the extra star. Good location for work or evening meals in the FiDi.
author: Shannon M.

description: Food is excellent, not a bargain, but then again you generally get what you pay for in the realm of fresh fish. The Sake Sommelier was a bit of a surprise. Nice young Irish girl...but she pointed us to a nice bottle of Sake with a real enjoyment in sharing her expertise. Our waitress was treating us like tourists, only recommending the most high priced items on the menu. The meal was really wonderful and the quality of the food excellent. The environment was lively and it's always a fun place to have dinner.
author: cynthia d.

description:
the bar used to be our favorite hang out, nice setting, few big tables and couch for large group.
the restaurant at the back is nice too, the sushi are good, fresh..but a bit pricey.
author: Suki S.

description: Been by a couple more times - sushi isn't out of this world, but very solid. Menu is varied. Best thing about this place is the hip buzzing atmosphere.
author: Rob G.

description: Every time I come by here it is always extremely packed.  The crowd was buzzing and a lot going on.  It isn't the easiest place to go if you are trying to have a conversation with a friend.  The sushi was definitely good, but it's very pricey.  Young, hip crowd and is fun if you can afford it.  The decor is very stylish and cool, the service was pretty attentive, but be prepared to stand around for a while if you go during normal dinner times.  I still really like this place because I've always had fun when I came, so I can't give it 3 stars, but it's not worthy of 5 either to me.
author: Tom Y.

description:
it's a nice and elegant ambience made even nicer if you are on a corporate account. 

the lively bar in the front leads to a quiet long sushi bar and elegant dining area.  some small misses are the large tables which are very wide apart so it's hard to talk to the person in front of you.

i live for hamachi, butterfish or fatty tuna.  if you chat it up with the server, they will at times, bring out dishes that are no longer on the menu.  if sushi isn't your thing, the cod, short ribs, and waygu are amazing.

i'm not a conoisseur of sakes but if you let the server know what you like or don't like for flavors, they will guide you in the right direction.

please don't forget to save room for dessert.  they have a mix that will please the conservative to the more adventurous diners.  i personally love the chocolate mochi.

a definite for groups, fun dates, or corporate meals sure to please locals and out of towners.
author: Anh V.

description: I love this place soooo much. Everything about it is perfect. The ambiance, the fish, the presentation... I'm a total fan. My favorite is to have Shiromaguro and  Tako sashimi,  some variation of a salad and  the hanabi as apps and then the black cod (Gindara) for an entree. OMG-- the black cod is to die for. However, I also frequent this establishment just for the sushi/sashimi. It's a hip, lively setting, which reminds you that you're "out-for-the-night," but also manages to have tables in which you can converse with your friends in relative peace. I heart Ozumo.
author: Zoe P.

description: I came here a few months ago for dinner and the food was great. We sat at the bar and had a nice and helpful waitress. You can share dishes with one other person but they are relatively small so you end up ordering a variety of different dishes. Good for the belly but things can definitely add up. Cocktails are good but they can be a bit too sweet. Sake was good. Overall this place is hip and chic with a great ambiance.
author: Adriana G.

description: Yummy, and completely overpriced.  We ended up spending $250 for two people.  If you go, make sure you stuff yourself with celery first.
author: Serena Y.

description: Ok, so I've been going here the last week, and even with the drastic menu changes, irratating SOMA/financial/meeting an escort that your company paid for crowd.. I still keep going back for more. I suggest the Sumo roll, garlic edamame, Hannabi and any of their seasonal Lobster rolls. The leycee martini is great too! Just be prepared to wait and spend half of your rent ( sumo roll $14.00 and lobster anywhere $22 and up)
author: Liz C.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!  GREAT FOOD!  Last time I was here I sat next to Larry King.  hahahha!  The place is trend/hipsterish so be prepared for that type of crowd.  Good place to go w/ a few friends or if you want to impress a date.
author: Adriana G.

description:
How the heck this got best Japanese restaurant in all those articles, I don't know.

Bar area- a little too loud for me, but not horrible. I was pretty casually dressed and didn't feel out of place.

had great seviche with amazing chip made of those tiny baby eels! and my friend had maguro, but it was basically seared ahi that was a little over seared, imho. salad on top was interesting and delicious. 

Here's the strange part- I also got amaebi. Waited and waited for the head half, eventually asked the waiter, and was told "We don't serve the heads since Americans (wtf?) don't eat them usually." I have NEVER had this happen at any sushi restaurant anywhere. To their credit, I jokingly said go ahead and serve me those extras, then, and they did bring out 4 heads instead of 2. 

Overall, the waitstaff was super friendly, smiley, nice. Pacing was very strange. As I mentioned, I got seviche and amaebi and my friend had maguro. The maguro wasn't served until I was almost completely done! Perhaps they assumed we were sharing, but I thought it was pretty clear when we ordered that we were not.

Table was tiny and in the middle dining area. Quieter than the bar, thank goodness, but too brightly lit and felt like we were dining in a hallway.

So, overall, good, but not amazing, and with some strange screw-ups. Bar was too loud and dining area was too bright. Didn't seem CRAZY overpriced to me, but I didn't see the final bill.
author: Erica B.

description:
Finally I had the pleasure to try a sushi place that reminds me of the good old days of working in Tokyo. The only setback? The ridiculous prices!!! I would of given this place 5 stars but when you spend over 100$ bucks a head with only one drink, no dessert and your still hungry that's when you realize that there are far better places to eat sashimi in SF that aren't overly priced.
Our waiter Brandon suggested to my friend and I a nice glass of sake to start the meal off. My friend and I ordered the tuna tataki salad which consists of grilled albacore sashimi over a plate of mixed greens with a very tasty vinaigrette. The salad was perfect, not too much dressing and a very light consistency.
For the main course we decided to order a few of the sashimi dishes that were market price for that evening. We ordered the Konakapachi and the Spanish Mackerel, both 25$ per five small slices of fish. I can't complain, the taste and the freshness was unbelievable!! We added to our list of shashimi the sea urchin and the unagi. I wasn't very fond of the consistency of the urchin. Very slimy taste in your mouth, kinda pasty. We also ordered two of the small plates; the squid and the yellowtail. Both to die for!! 
What topped our night off was meeting eight nice gent's who invited us to their table to eat more food and drink all the sake, wine and champagne we could ask for. We couldn't pass this invite up as my friend and I were still hungry.
I am not sure how often I will be able to dine here but if my wallet could hang  I would be here at least every week. It reminded me so much of the fun nights running around in tokyo, eating nothing but the freshest fish  and being drunk off the many different flavors of sake.
author: Kehaulani K.

description:
Food was pretty good.   The shashimi was fresh and the rolls were VERY good.  Our crab and avocado roll was delish.  The place is a bit pricy, but for a group of 5 girls, we ordered a few drinks and shared the rest.  Our tab was not bad at all.  

I recommend giving this place a try.

BUT, the place feels like a meat market.  But maybe you might be into that sort of thing.
author: D H.
CAT H.

description:
was here for a sake pairing just recently. the dinner itself was hosted by jessica furui, the sake sommelier. learned much about sake complemented by the great japanese food. 

my dinner consisted of maybe 10 or so courses, so here are the standouts

a spicyish fish with jalapeno and avocado
washu beef with japanese eggplant and cucumber
miso black cod

sushi was good -- nothing too stand out 

oh, and pretty people work hereeeeeeee
author: justin t.

description:
This review is specifically for the Noontime Noodles at Ozumo, which is new, although lunch in general for Ozumo is not. FiDiners can now get their noodle on at Ozumo, which is offering five noodle-centric dishes in the lounge area only for $10.95, which includes a side of edamame.

Hot soup and noodle are hard for me to pass up, but since it was another of those unseasonably warm days in San Francisco nearing 80 which were nice at first but are now starting to freak me out, fear of rising ocean levels and all, I ordered the cold Maguro Soba. 

For the price the portion was a bit on the small side, but despite the smaller portion of noodles, I received a generous topping of maguro. And since like most women over 30 I am on a diet, or counting calories, or restricting carbs or anything to fit into those skinny jeans, I thought the amount was satisfying and I didn't leave feeling stuffed. And the noodles are buckwheat, which theoretically should make me feel full longer. Right?

Noontime Noodle Menu:

Nagasaki Chanpon: A "chanpon" mix of pork, shrimp, clams and cabbage in a hot miso broth with Japanese wheat flour noodles)

Hiyashi Chuka: Chilled ramen noodles with pork, cucumber, egg and bean sprouts, with viegar-shoyu sauce, mustard and beni shoga

Sapporo Ramen: Classic "Sapporo style" ramen with a shoyo based soup, thin ramen noodles, crab, charsu pork and buttered corn

Muguro Soba Salada: chilled soba noodles tossed with wasabi dressing, topped with tuna tartare, cucumber and kaiware

Tatsuta Soba Salada: Japanese style fried chicken glazed with sweet soy sauce, served with chilled soba noodles, cabbage and goma dreessing
author: Ls Y.

description:
a nice crowded place on a friday night.  it was awesome to get seated so quickly.  i liked the elegant, modern decor.  the front of the restaurant has a bar where you can order a full menu while seated on comfortable asian pillows.

our waiter had male pms.  the food was very fast.  we started out with a 'seaweed' salad that was something akin to safeway's spring mix.  wine had not yet arrived, although our waiter expressed disdain for merlot.  second was a martini glass filled with sashimi.  pretty good.

we sat for a while before i was able to comandeer some attention from a really nice waiter who recommended the miso glazed black cod which was pretty good.  the three rounds of raw sushi and sashimi were the highlight of the meal, with delectable, perfectly cut fresh fish floating on a perfectly warm bed of rice.  we also had filet which was the second best.

our last course was another martini glass filled with ceviche.  yummy.

dessert, ice cream and warm apples.  nothing wrong with apples.
author: apple r.

description: I went here for a birthday dinner last night with nine people. The food was delicious, well presented and fresh. The service was friendly. Was a bit pricy, at almost $100 per person with drinks, but overall well worth the price! This is the second birthday dinner I have attended here, and I highly recommend it for this sort of celebration!
author: Lisa M.

description: Saturday, 8:30 p.m.: I enjoyed the service here, which made the buck-half I paid for three of us worth it. The Aoba salad and a beef tartar dish were the best of the night's kau kau. My friends also liked the Fuji Apple and Shibuya Sunrise drinks.
author: Keith K.

description:
just got back from a b-day lunch here and while it was a fun lunch, the food isn't on par w/ some of the other gems here in the city.  it's pretty pricey and that's probably due to its location.  my best bud and i started w/ a flight of sake each while we waited for one our friends to roll in.  we both enjoyed the sake's we had there but i unfortunately did not note down the one's i liked.

on to the sushi!  all the sushi was alright, nothing bad but nothing great.  the spicy tuna and spicy scallop were adequate as was the spider roll.  the amberjack sashimi was cool and the ozumo roll was decent.  but the only reason i would go back here is the day the bring in the toro again.  holy mf'ing lord of all that is sushi!  this is my new baseline for toro.  all other toro shall be compared to this and must be either equal or greater for me to speak of its greatness!
author: Swarup B.

description: Trendy yet snooty atmosphere but quite romantic for a date (he/she better be worth taking to here...expect to rake dough for this place) The lighting was intimate...not an ideal place to have a sunday brunch with the family & children. The hostess was unfriendly and pretended that she didnt see us and i was standing right in front of her.n The waitress recited the menu and looked up at the ceiling to remember what she was supposed to say... I guess the chefs here were minimalists because like 6 pieces of sushi were beautifully arranged but cost like $16..way too overpriced but I have to admit that the cod we ordered was very smooth, juicy and very very tasty.
author: Charmian D.

description: This place is right by my office, so it's easy for me to come here for a martini. A bit pricy for a cocktail, but the sushi is delicious and they deliver if you stay in the Harbour Court. The waitresses are good fun as well and even played along with our trick to send our male colleagues an unsuspecting cosmopolitan across the bar.
author: Kristin M.

description:
seriously delicious!! my evening started off in the bar area, which is a great atmosphere. i had the giddy geisha martini - lychee, passion fruit puree, & vodka with a lychee topper so yummy & not too overpriced. 

then we were lucky to be seated in the main dining area, near the chefs. i am not usually a big fan of sake, so i told our waiter this. he brought me 2 different kinds to try & we ended up going with another bottle, but still. great customer service. next was the food. omg soo good.

we had the tuna tartare small plate which melted in your mouth, plus had crispy wonton chips to go with. this was my favorite. we then had the lobster roll, spicy tuna roll with extras, and another custom requested roll. all of the fish was fresh, the rolls werent too huge, & the flavor combinations were amazing. add in some edamame & i was stuffed.

not the forget dessert, we had the chocolate fondue which was the great ending to a great meal, and a great night!!
author: Jessica B.

description:
I've been to Ozumo's a few times and one of the things I really dislike is that the prices are somewhat outrageous, so make sure you have money to throw down to enjoy a great meal and great sake.
My last visit there, I brought my co-workers which was for a work event.  Everyone else was very pleased with the food, service, and ambiance.  The back room is the main restaurant which was spacious and seated several patrons.  The front room is the bar area where you can hang out for just drinks, appetizers or even be seated to dine for a full meal.  The mood of both sides are quite different.  If you are looking for something more hip and upbeat, then ask to sit in the front area.
As for the food, food was delicious, very fresh, presentation was simple and clean and the flavors really melted in your mouth.
Overall, I'll give it four stars, since the service had been up to standars so far that I've come.  But in all truth, this is Not my favorite sushi restaurants.  Definitely worth a visit though.
author: Jenn C.

description: A friend lost his bet to me and took me here for dinner as my price.  We shared an appetizer, each had a good glass of sake, and had the black cod for entree.  The food was very well made, but the portion was quite small.  (and i eat a lot)  I didn't order more food 'cuz i didn't want my friend to spend too much money.
author: Vivian H.

description: Always great energy and a fun crowd. Great for business meetings, dates, or a fun night on the town. The sushi is fresh and consistent. Word of caution: the portions are small so order more when in doubt.
author: Maria C.

description: I've been here about ten times now. The sushi is always fresh and very good, the service has never been an issue, but the place is a little pricey relative to the quality.
author: Brian J.

description:
First thing's first, make sure you are dressed to the nine before entering this trendy sushi hot spot. Casual doesn't exist at this place. 
We love the sushi at Ozumo. Very interesting rolls and and a multitude of specials that keep the menu interesting. However be ready to spend a few dollars. We are big Sake drinkers, but there is no reasonable sake on this menu. The food is excellent, just highly over priced.
author: Melissa P.

description:
learn japanese, eat great sushi. that would be my summation of this place.

for some bizarre reason, the toilets have japanese lesson tapes playing in the background, so if you are bladderally challenged you will have the opportunity to pick up some key phrases that might come in handy. i was hoping to time my fourth visit to the little boys' room with lesson 6, "ordering at a restaurant", but unfortunately my timing was a little off and i had to make do with lesson 7, "buying a train ticket". imagine the surprise on the waiter's face when i fluently asked for a roundtrip to osaka instead of the soft-shell crab.

as for the food, which is really what you should be here for, it is amazing. expensive as a bugger, but fantastic. everything we ordered was perfect, and, as is always the case with sushi, we over-ordered quite significantly, so i have a lot of reference points to base that claim on. the sake was exquisite, but again, pricey. we ordered 2 small bottles of sake, and even asked for recommendations - the first one was $50 and the second $75! that'll teach me to order without checking the price first.

at the end of the night, we were satiated, slightly pickled, $300 poorer but hey, at least i learned that if i am ever stranded in yokohama i know i can make it back to tokyo on the bullet train.
author: Niko V.

description:
this is one of my favorite restaurants in SF... i LOVE fusion asian food. but can i go here often? hells no - way too expensive. only on special occasions. :) 

note: if you're looking for a traditional sushi restaurant, this is not for you. but if you want great ambiance and japanese food with a twist, then i highly recommend it. try the rolls or the fish robata yaki plates (all of them are good). and finish it up with a nice raspberry&mango sorbet... mmmmm

their bar area is nice too if you want to just stop by for a few drinks and small apps... but be warned, it can break the bank.
author: Lucy C.

description: The service is always amazing. I love the sparkling geishas!
author: ERIN M.

description:
The food was decent but way over priced.  The food by itself I would give a slightly higher rating but based on my overall experience, Ozumo got only 2 stars.

My biggest complaint is related to my expectations of what we ordered and the value of what we got. We decided to go with the chef's special, omakase.  For $125 per person we were expecting a pretty good meal.  Sadly it fell far short of our expectations.  When you get a "chef's special" tasting menu from any restaurant you expect the best of what the restaurant and the chef can offer, right?   Well some of the dishes we got seemed pretty pedestrian.  Our sashimi and sushi dish had fish like red snapper and maguro, not exactly what I expected for a chef's special.  Come on, we didn't even get toro!  I asked the waiter about why maguro would be on a chef's special menu and he said that he wondered that himself.   One dish was tempura baby icefish which wasn't bad tasting but was lukewarm and extremely oily.  Some of the dishes we got were good like the parchment steamed salmon in sake and the banana crepes with green tea cream.  Overall just a terrible chef's tasting menu.

I see other reviews and think there must be something more to the restaurant than our experience.  Unfortunately my experience wasn't that good and in San Francisco there are so many restaurants to try that first impressions mean so much.
author: Gordon S.

description:
Definitely the place to go for sushi in San Francisco.  Not exactly for the value-oriented, as they are on the high end of the price spectrum, but as far as a restaurant experience goes, I don't think I've been to anything better.

I considered subtracting a star for them being exorbitantly expensive, but decided against it, as the food, atmosphere, and service are all unbeatable.  It seems wrong to penalize the restaurant for price when the place is flush with good food and good-looking people.  

Good selection of tougher to find menu items, including excellent Kobe beef, toro (although a slightly skimpy cut), ankimo, etc.  I'm never disappointed whenever I go.  

Drinks are mediocre, but they get the job done.    

Keep in mind that truly good food is always expensive.
author: Ryan K.

description: Expensive for the quality.  I would not take a Japanese person here.  I think this a perfect place to take a date who you want to impress and spend alot of money on them.
author: Frank F.

description:
OK ... let's get it out of the way ... Ozumo is expensive. Dinner for two with drinks, before tip ... $250 ... so save your pennies. I would suggest that for you would figure $150-$200 per person in order to have a wide range of food and drink samples. Next time I go I plan on $300 per person and staying one of the nearby hotels. 

And, Oh! ... I happen to accept higher prices at speciality restaurants ... so I don't have to dine with the buffet crowd ... did someone say Todai? 

The food ... ooooooohhhhhhhhyaaaaaaaaaaaa yea! 

Best: Black Cod - buttery texture, unbelievable flavor. 

All sushi very good ... try the Monkfish Froi ... excellent. 

The real treat - sampling the wide range and types of Saki. Wide range of flavors and types - try the cold Saki's, very unusual. 

Service was outstanding. If your expecting everyone to speak Japanese ... oh come on, are you kidding! 

I sat at the Sushi Bar with an outstanding Korean born chef who created our dishes ... executed flawlessly. 

Our waitress was excellent ... she appeared at the exact moment she was needed, and the other staff moved through our table without interrupting our meal in any way. 

The bar ... just like the movies, it's the bar everyone's dressed up in, but we never see for real ... well this is it. 

... and the manager introduced himself and gave me his card ... "... call me and tell me how everything was this evening ..." 

Expensive ... yes! Worth it .... yes! 

PS. I would write more but I'm in line for the crab legs and I want to get a new clean plate so I can also pick up some deserts to complete this round of eating at Todai's (ha ha ... I also like Todai's).
author: Richard M.

description:
The Toyko Glow...need I say more? If perfection can be found in a drink then this is it. It still doesn't beat the infamous Lemon Drop Martini from the Ritz Huntington, but definitely a close second. 
I am still reeling from the delicious vapors of my food, drink, and bejesus....the Red Spider Roll which is a dastardly delectable concoction..
Ozumo fits all tastes, if you are boisterous, then by all means embark on the pleasure cruise at the front of the restaurant...rub elbows with those that see and want to be seen...if you are looking for something more intimate, then sashay into the middle dining room next to the grill-its quieter...and you can stretch out without some middle aged banker making eyes at you....for the more relaxed beer crowd then delve further to the well-lighted cafeteria style enclave at the back of the restaurant...Ozumo fits your needs...if not your wallet but so well worth the expense...after all what is life if not living to the fullest? Highly recommended treat for you and yours.
author: Nickee M.

description:
I crave for this Sushi....I crave for sushi in general but Ozumo is tops for me.  Fresh raw fish, miso, eggs, seaweed, etc...SAKE.  Ozumo hasn't let me down. Yes, the service is erratic, and this kills me.  When a high end Restaurant commands tall prices...I expect excellent service; but this is something that can be worked on.  The foundation has already been laid-Great Elegant Foods.  Yes its high priced, but you get what you pay for with the food, and it makes it worth it.  I like that it is located near the bay, and the design is pleasant.  The use of wood and granite fused with Japanese/Californian vernacular architectural elements is impressive.  I'll venture to say it is my favorite Sushi restaurant in the city and one of the best in the world.  I am getting hungry just thinking about it.
If you are feeling frisky, they also have possibly the best Sake I have ever tasted.  The Black Dragon.  This Sake is no joke, and apparently brewed exclusively for Royalty way back when.  It's Divino.
author: gordon w.

description: This is a tough review to write.......I liked a lot about this place.......the food.........people.......staff...........decor. But the prices are off the charts........so the wonderful taste I had in my mouth.......well, I left with a bad taste after I paid the bill!
author: tom h.

description: One of the best Japanese restaurants in SF - ambiance just like a hip Tokyo restaurant. Food is always top notch - first rate sushi chefs. Quality apparent from use of Bluefin Tuna - the finest. The best sake list in SF - great people watching. Occasionally slightly long wait (15-20min) despite having reservations, but worth the wait. If you're bored with seafood try their Wagyu beef.
author: Aydin S.

description: my sister and best friend dined here last night and it was phenomenal!  We couldnt decide what to order, our waitress made wonderful suggestions!!!  The hanabi was so fresh and tasty!  We also had the uni risotto.... that was to die for!  The sashimi was fresh and sweet!  The ambiance is trendy and the service was superb!  The manager came around numerous times to ensure everything was up to par!  Great service!  Service like that was not expected, I had to ask for the manager's business card!  We asked for Mr. Chow for a good sake recommendation.... he delivered exactly what we wanted!  EXCELLENT service!!!
author: Yukio W.

description: Fun place to come to for drinks.  The bar and the private room are very swanky.  The prices are high, but the food is solid.  Good sushi and lunch items.  The Kaiso seaweed salad was different than what I'm used to, but not bad...just different.
author: Michelle M.

description: Bring money. And an appetite.  Then kiss every other Sushi restaurant good bye because you will only want Ozumo after.  Wagyu beef cubes almost caused a riot at our table when they ran low.  Seared albacore in Ponzu sauce truly redefined flavor to our party.  $500 tab at dinner for two hurt.  But in a good way....
author: Jacob C.

description: Yes, it is good, it's really good, but it ain't as good as that price they're charging. Go when your rich friend who insists on paying wants a nice night out.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Finally had dinner here after all these years.  It is not the BEST place in the city.  But definitely very good.  Standard dare sushi, rolls and teriyaki.

FYI - there are a bunch of hot girls that work there!
author: James B.

description: Always book in advance. Sit at the Sushi bar, and ask the chef to create your meal. Forget the fancy rolls. Order some top shelf sake or Japanese beer. Excellent food. Very expensive.
author: Jeffrey W.

description: I enjoyed my Christmas Eve dinner at Ozumo.  Being one of the only places serving late we stumbled across it on a stroll about downtown.  The food was good but service was a tad slow.  Dessert was awesome, the beignets rocked.  Modern interior, a bit pricey for sushi but for the most part we enjoyed our dinner here.
author: Ikey S.

description:
My fiance and I walked in to get a drink and some rolls before the Giants game.  After we ordered and received our four rolls (for an over-priced $23) and finished our cocktails we asked for our bill.  The waitress looked at the sushi chef and started speaking Japanese, clearly talking about us and how that's all we were ordering.  Let me point out that we were the only ones sitting at the sushi bar, we weren't taking up her table and we were in and out in a matter of 15 min.  We just thought it was pretty classless to do that at such a nice restaurant- a nail salon has more class than our server.

On another note, the sushi rolls were good and the atmosphere was devine!  The bar was going off at 6pm on Friday night...
author: Lisa p.

description: Had no othr choices for an easy dining wait aroun the area and my company was into sushi...had a bubbly at the bar while waiting and  later haqd a table by the sushi bar and had greqat selections of fresh sushi...however our waitressw was not so informing that the sake bottle we chose was a $200 bottle..boy and we should have insisted to replace the spilled drink for the same quality and won't agree for just any replacement if we had known. anyway all sake taste the same for me but that one should be remembered totally and the bubbly for $25 each must be a real nice company i was with...
author: cecille p.

description: Came here for lunch.  Very pricey for not a whole lot of food (quality and quantity).  The waitress only came by to take our order and then to give us the check.  Fish was not as fresh as it should have been.
author: Terry F.

description: Took my wife there for our anniversary.  We had a great table along the Embarcadero with view of the water and the sushi bar.  We enjoyed a fabulous meal of  sushi and sake.  We'd recommend the Ozumo roll, albacore tuna negiri and rice pudding dessert.  Pricey - yes.  Worth it - absolutely!
author: Green B.

description: I was there on Saturday for a birthday party  -- 100 people who knew each other, and me & my two friends.  I have to say that the decor of this place reminds me of EVERY restaurant in Vegas: "look how expensive I am."  We didn't eat there, but the drinks were interesting.  At $7 and $9, not the cheapest, nor the most expensive alcohol beverages possible.
author: Stephan W.

description:
FOOD: enjoyable 4/5

WAITSTAFF:  Had a terrible, pushy, waitress who was clearly trying to hype up the bill

Overall give this place just a 3/5 due to the poor training of waitstaff and the overall cost
author: Bob S.

description:
I just spent $90 for two people (no alcohol...all food) and we both left incredibly disappointed and hungry.

the scallop nigiri was great (but slightly overpriced) but everything else was pretty horrible.

hamichi signature dish....gross.  the fish wasn't fresh.
tried 2 rolls....both were below average.  the rice was overcooked, the rice paper was a little soft/soggy.  the fish (in both rolls) were barely detectable.

spinach appetizer...gross.  i've had better at cheap/crappy japanese joints all throughout the bay area.

can't remember what else we ordered....because most of the dinner was unremarkable.

the interior was really nice though....but the way the building is made, it doesn't take advantage of the great views...you can barely see the bay bridge relative to places like waterbar and epic.

overall, if you don't eat much japanese and can be easily impressed by the ambiance, then this might be an ok place for you.  but if you've ever been to japan....eat a reasonable amount of japanese....or just have a reasonable standard when it comes to food...then you'll think this place is ridiculously overpriced for the lack of quality.  i'm never going back there again.
author: Jay M.

description:
my first visit to Ozumo was last weekend and i totally dig it!~ it's especially awesome if you like super hip places and i hear the happy hour is cool. 

it took us forever to decide what to eat because of the extensive menu. we decided on two sushi rolls and an entree each. the special roll was a shrimp tempura roll which was pretty good... but OMG.. the sumo roll was super yummOLA! i especially loved the shiso on the top because it gave it a really fresh and different taste!

he had the salmon over risotto, which was ok. i had the duck with wasabi mashed potato and it was sooo good! i wish i went with the waitresses recommendation for medium-rare because medium was a little overcooked. still.... sooo good.

the cocktails were pretty good too, but nothing out of the ordinary for a japanese fusion place. 

prices? expected of a place like this. but i thought it was worth it!

i am definitely going back to try out some of the other dishes. next time though with more people so we can order more!
author: Bobbie L.

description: Not much to say that hasn't been said already, but a meal here never disappoints.  Great service and great food.  Some favorites from my last visit: the Grilled Veggies, Tuna Tataki and Summer Snow Nigori Sake.  Yum!
author: Lindsay B.

description: I went here for happy hour with my bf and another friend and for 2 drinks each + ~4 rolls (which were small, not tasty (the rice in the rolls were incredibly dry) and not inventive) cost $140!!! INSANE.  I will not go back there again.
author: Grace M.

description:
ate here twice with my girlfriend.  first time I spent $50 on my dinner alone!  way too pricey for my tastes.  second time we ordered dessert wine while we were waiting to be seated.  the bartender kindly allowed us to sample 2 different wines and we both picked the same one.  we were shocked to find out that a  single glass was $20!  like whoa.

i think for the most part you are paying for the ambience and the location.  I've only gone at night but it is right on the embarcadero overlooking the bay.  

the sushi itself was not spectacular.

what stands out in my mind was the wine - it was pretty good although crazy expensive - it was the Inniskillin Vidal Ice Wine Pearl Niagra.  The garlic edamame was delicious and likewise the Hamachi in the Hanabi dish.

Otherwise I think you can find sushi just as good accross the bay at Angelfish in Alameda.  it may not be as fancy schmancy but the food is just a good.
author: Hello.kitty.kat S.

description: Close to the worst service I have ever had at a restaurant. This was my first and will be my last time to Ozumo. For a very expensive dinner, our sushi and other plates were served within 7 minutes of sitting down. The hot Saki, which we didn't even receive until after the entire meal, had to be sent back twice because it was lukewarm. We also ordered cold saki, and other cocktails which were all served after the meal.  It was a constant battle to get our very rude waiter's attention. We sent our tempura back with the check -- they both came out at the same time. All in all, our entire dining experience (was a birthday dinner as well), lasted exactly 29 minutes. Asking our waiter to "slow down" several times did not register. I have eaten at some of the best sushi restaurants in metropolitan cities around the world, and I have to say that this was the absolute worst. I could not even enjoy the fish, which was fine (nothing outstanding by any means), because the service was atrocious. Please spend your money and 29 minutes elsewhere.
author: Alex D.

description: I had a fabulous sake-filled happy hour here last week.  The sake was really quite nice, and the decor was elegant and simple.  Who knew so many empty bottles lined on a wall could look so good?  I have to come back here to dine and take in the nice view.
author: CAKE E.

description:
The food was awesomely displayed, but I just didn't like the fact that not everyone received their food all at the same time. I had a couple of guest receive their food and everyone else was done with their meal. 
Also there was like 15 of us and no doubt we knew that the bill would be high, but we caught some random things that we didn't even order or get on the bill. Then the waiter gave us such a hard time when we pointed it out to him. Then he tells us that dessert was free since he messed up the bill. So we all order dessert and then he says that the birthday person's dessert cake was free and not everyone else's. Isn't that free for most birthdays?  We were all so irritated and I was so embarrassed, because I was the one who threw the event for my boyfriend's birthday and his friends that I barely was getting to know. I wanted to show his friends a nice place to have a birthday with a nice setting. I felt so bad, because a lot of them were irritated about the random add-on's to the bill, so I just ended up covering the rest of the bill.  I've gone to this place with a smaller amount of people prior to this event and it was nicer, but when it was a larger group, I guess the waiters aren't trained enough to handle the huge amount of people. This place definitely disappointed me that day. Be careful of saying yes to things too, because they don't tell you that it's "extra". I've gone to Ozumo's prior to my embarrassing day, but I only take people there for quick cocktails, I couldn't take anyone here again for business meetings or personal events again.
author: Joanne D.

description: I came here for a friend's birthday on a Saturday night. It was pretty busy. We ordered several dishes to share, I paid $30 to get 3 pieces of sushi and a share of ahi tuna tartare thing they had. No drinks. This place is a complete rip of a new a-hole with the price gauging they do here. Portions were completely tiny, you can say they're hors d'oeuvre sized for their "small plates" menu and their sushis. Food was ok. It's not memorable or anything. And with the price they charge for food, you would think the service would be better, but no, they go together hand in hand. The server becomes completely rude if they don't succeed in trying to oversell you in their overpriced plates. Unless you don't mind paying the big bucks just to sit there and look at their decor, I definitely do not recommend anyone to come here.
author: My C.

description: This is definitely one of the nicer sushi restaurants in the city.  It's on Embarcadero - so it already gets extra points in my book for location. The interior design is very trendy and modern.  The sushi selection is pretty good and so is the sake (which I LOVE).  It's definitely a little pricey - so be prepared to possibly spend a few bills, but still worth a visit :)
author: Cherlyn M.

description: I really like this place.  Its got a modern feel without being cold.  I've had dinner here and remember all of the food was exceptional (although portions were small).  Also, they have a variety including robata - not just your usual sashimi.  More recently I came here for lunch.  If you want a regular table you have to make reservations or drop by and dine at the smaller tables by entrance.  Its also the kind of place you can drop a bill easily just for lunch.  Pricey indeed.
author: Aileen N.

description: The food here is spectacular but the service is really uneven, almost to the point where it's offensive.  I've been three times in the last six months and the time I spent the most money ($600 for dinner for four) we had a crappy table and crappy service all the way through, from delaying our seating (depite a reservation) to being ingored throughout the meal.  We complained and they gave us free water.  Wish they'd fix it, I would go back even more often for the great small plates, sushi and desserts!
author: Margaret F.

description: Wish there was more on the plate to actually taste. I'm willing to pay a grip for cuisine--as long as the food exists. I'd like to, however, give the bar a chance. Have heard great things about their sake list.
author: Mar M.

description:
Was feeling really chilled and burnt out after a 12 hour trip from New York when I arrived looking for a soothing meal at 830 on a Wed. night.

Passed on the drink menu  and went deep into a  good sized glass of Ketel One on the rocks, which was garnished by a couple of huge stuffed olives that seemed to be dried out.  

Waitress was polite and very well spoken,  quite a pleasant suprise.  I
 started with the miso soup with shitake mushrooms.   Well executed.  Followed with the hamachi plated with jalepenio ponzu---buttery slices with a touch of peppery bite.  Delicious.

Accompanied this with a ginza (sp) sake,  light, fruity, refined.  

Then came the sushi.  Uni, tuna, yellow tail,  ....the highlight was the amber jack.

Followed by more sake.

All in all a gracious meal.

There was a lot of activity at the bar in the front of the restaurant.  Lots of 20 somethings drinking,  eating,  and trying to hook up,  all in a low lit atmosphere very conducive to making new friends.   

Back in the day,  I would have nose dived right into that scene and not made it into the dining room beyond!
author: Delicious B.

description: Expensive as hell and the fish isn't even fresh.  Had their toro and ankimo...tasted like both were sitting in the fridge for days.  I make better sushi at home!
author: Selene K.

description:
service is beyond excellent, very lovely, and extremely good looking.  their seaweed salad is beautiful in sight and taste.  

this sounds incredibly generic, but their california rolls are unlike anything i've ever had.  it has your typical ingredients, but they must be very high quality, because it tastes amazing.  their other rolls are also quite tasty.
author: Grace V.

description:
If you want sushi, this place has some of the best quality fish.
Sashimi Tai and Hamachi were stellar.
The chef let me try some Salmon belly that melted in my mouth and I don't normally get salmon.
They have great rolls but some places in SF are gettin very creative so it may not suit everyone's palate who care for more rice than high-quality fish.
The apps and other entree options are awesome but I come for the fish.
Service has improved alot recently so I have started coming back more often.
Weekends used to be packed but not so much anymore which is great since it's not as loud and boisterous as it used to be.
author: Faisal M.

description: Where should I start. Oh, I'm being generous with the 3 stars, how about there! I was joining 3 friends for dinner on a friday evening and I called friday afternoon for a reservation, so I am aware that it would be unlikely I would get anything at a reasonable hour. I was told that they could take us at 9:15. Um that was a little late and I just inquired as to whether there MIGHT be any chance around 8-8:15. Sure! they could take us then. Got there at 8. waited. waited. asked. waited. at about 8:30 we grabbed a table in bar area, ordered a bottle and waited. waited. Oh the table was right next to the hostess stand, so I would like to think they hadn't forgotten us. We were told 3 different times that it would be only a few minutes. At 8:55, starving, we flagged down the waitress and ordered some food. At, 9:15 our food came, and so did the hostess to tell us our table was ready. All I wanted to do was eat and get out. The food is alright, the service was OK, I don't really have problem with the prices (although it is pricey) but for the love of God do not make me wait an hour and 15 minutes for Ok service,alright,expensive food. If you can't take my party at 8 , just tell me. I'm a grown up.
author: Ann K.

description: Oh my..best sushi/japanese food i have ever had. Really inventive, beautiful atmosphere, friendly staff, the place was great. I took my boyfriend there for his birthday last year and it was romantic and fun, we got a sake taster and had some amazing food. Expensive but worth it for a night out.
author: Nicole S.

description: The fish here is so fresh it melts in your mouth... I love this place. The sushi chefs seem to always come up with a great special roll or two that are worth trying, and if there is something else you have in mind they are open to requests. Ozumo requires a little more $$$ to dine at than many, but when you are looking for a great place to take out of towner's or that special someone it is worth it. Just make sure you plan ahead if you want to dine during peak times, they do get packed.
author: Kelly J.

description: I am shocked that this place doesn't have 5 stars across the board! I just had lunch there and had an excellent experience. We did have to wait at the front for a bit, but it was nothing to complain about. Once seated our service was excellent! The food came out in a timely manner and everything was amazing. We shared the spinach salad, the rainbow roll, dragon roll, and spicy tuna roll. My taste buds where in heaven! Best sushi I have ever had! I will most certainly be returning.
author: Lisa K.

description: Great place to grab a drink or bring a date! Once you walk in, you can feel the energy from the bar and the food is fabulous...pricey yes but worth it! You might want to make a reservation, but then again, people watching at the bar is great here :)
author: Betty H.

description:
I have been to this place three times. It is nice, but way over priced. Still, I returned after the first time cuz I thought the high price could be justified by the ambiance and service. I was WRONG!
Second time around, I got some serious attitude. Assumed it was the one person I was dealing with, so went back a third time, and I will never go back, even though it is 2 blocks from my office. These people have the attitude of " we dont' need you business at all", so there is no service, and they don't treat you well. They act as if they are doing you a favor by giving you table or a drink at the bar. Food is OK, even though too expensive for what it is.
author: M K.

description: I took my family to Ozumo this last Saturday and it was fabulous!  We had such a good time.  Everything was absolutely perfect.  Mike, our server, was incredible, as well as his supporting staff!  Mike listened and staggered the food perfectly!  Chef Alex created delicious specials, the gindara was superb.  Christine was elegant and thoughtful.  And then there's Mel, my parents are still talking about his hospitality and how he made everyone feel so special.  Thank you!
author: Kiimberly B.

description:
Its just OK. 
nothing to Bragg about , nice ambiance , the sushi was average at best. 
go to sushi zone its much better.
author: shirly b.

description: Everything about this restaurant is perfect. The ambiance, the food, drinks, service, everything! The best sushi in the city hands down. I would eat here everyday if I could. Perfect place for a date as well-its fun and happening and after dinner you can always go and sit at the bar.
author: Leily M.

description: I'm not a huge fan of sushi, but this place is really good!  I went there when my boss would give me my reviews, hence the reason why I never paid a dime.  Its very pricy; even for lunch, but if you got the dough to spend (or expense), I say rock it, yo!
author: Tom D.

description: Nice looking place.  Lunch for two cost $150!  We made the mistake of asking the sushi chef to make us whatever he thought was best.  It was tasty, fresh and presented well, but not really what I would have ordered.  The Sea Urchin was challenging, especially with a hangover.   Had dinner a while ago which was excellent and fun.  I will definitely go back.
author: Brad Z.
