description: Pretty good sushi, nice sake selection, we did a sake flight (or three) and it really made me appreciate sake more than ever. Food was good but not the best sushi I've had. Made up for it with the atmosphere.
author: Dana R.

description: I have been here for lunch several times. It's a great place to entertain out of town business clients who don't get a chance to eat good sushi as often as us SF folk do. Bottom line, good food, decent service, but PRICEY.
author: Michael V.

description: I love this place & today - the service was excellent!  (which is not typical of Ozumo... but maybe the staff is working hard for their last minute Holiday tips).  Either way - had a great lunch today.  Toro, Hamachi, Unagi, Live Scallops, Ebi, Rainbow Roll... all of it & more... it all melted in my mouth!  Absolutely delish!  Great dining experience.  As always (sans service).
author: Natalie P.

description: The bar at Ozumo is rocking!  The food's not cheap but what do you expect?  It is good and there are great options for sushi and sashimi and of course more sake than us Gia-gin can ever hope to understand!  I have been there several times and the bartender (Cody) is a great guy, fun and entertaining!  He definitely makes me want to come back, and eat at the bar rather than in the dining room.
author: Trip H.

description: This place has great sushi and I love sushi, but it is over priced.  This place gets 4 stars for the food, minus 1 star for price.  Sushi is fresh and delicious.  Atmosphere is spectacular.  Request a seat near the window and you can have a great view of the bridge and water.  Go for happy hour (forget the exact timing before 6 maybe?) and order the bar food.  The bar food is much cheaper than their lunch and dinner menus.  Otherwise, it's not worth going.
author: Dbear T.

description: If you like sushi and a hip spot by the financial district you should try this restaurant. I recommend the garlic edamame and black cod. The rolls are a hit or miss. The bar is great! Ask for Aaron the bartender.
author: Loren T.

description: Went there for a nice dinner date. Dress to impress status. It's absolutely amazing food. Probably one of the best sushi places I have gone to in San Francisco It's a cool spot and will definitely leave a lasting impression. Dinner menu is absolutely amazing and the sake is legit. Great location as well
author: Mish M.

description: Great place for HH drinks, to catch up w/ friends or meet up with a date.  They recently expanded the sake selection and the service is good, when not crowded.  Only drawback is the bar closing on the early side during the week.  Check what time they close before heading over for a session.
author: Jenny K.

description: A little bit trendy trendy but Ozumo has great sushi and views of the Bay Bridge. The sashimi is very fresh and the specialty rolls are extremely creative. Ozumo is pricey, but all the good sushi places are.
author: Jen L.

description: GREAT PLACE ATMOSPHERE!!!   but seriously over-price.   Only would recommend for special occassions,business events,  taking friends as a tourist to have a heart of  SF for a Chill Night will be great!!!  Be Prepare $$$$$.   Their appetizer r good for small bites.
author: evelyn y.

description:
We dine at Blow Fish and Ebisu regularly but it is always a treat to go to Ozumo.  You are paying a bit more for the view and atmosphere but why would you go there unless you wanted that anyway?

We ate there Saturday night....we got a reservation last minute on Friday and when we arrived a few minutes late they were not the slightest bit testy about it.  When I made the reservation they asked if there was anything we would be celebrating?  I said no, we just got married two months ago and are all celebrated out.  The gentlemen on the phone congratulated us and said he would be glad to find a nice table for us.

Once seated the server was funny without being bothersome.  Our food was great.  But the nicest part was when we went to order desert they had sent one on the house to congratulate us. :) Nice touch.  So yes it can be pricey for Japanese food however, it was a nice time and you get what you pay for.
author: Meagan S.

description:
This place is OK - if you're looking for a place with a hip yuppie buzz and overpriced fusion-y Japanese food then this is the place for you.  If you want some truly great Japanese food go elsewhere - Kabuto in the Richmond would provide much more bang for your buck if you're looking for creative offerings.  Sushi House has better special rolls.

The good: modern decor with cavernous main dining room and cool front bar; great for people-watching; shacho lobster roll was truly tasty; sea bass dish

The bad: $5 miso soup (you gotta be kidding me) among other overpriced items, unflavorful special rolls.

Interesting: Japanese lessons while you pee; attentive service but not the kind that makes you feel comfortable
author: Irene W.

description: "Ramen is really good; sushi is good, but expensive. Love the mochi dessert"
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I love the ambience here very trendy and upscale The food here is very pricey and pretty good. The thing that stood out the most for me was the scallop --very juicy and cooked just right-- and the seared ahi tuna. I don't remembered the other two dishes we had. The service is really good because we came here on a Saturday afternoon so there was not a lot of patrons. With the price I pay here I rather go to Zushi Puzzle and eat whatever Roger has for that day.
author: Allison H.

description: I love Ozumo- It is high quality gourmet sushi- but it is very very expensive. I went there for lunch during the week, the place was packed, and it is a huge space. Mostly Business types doing important business type lunches. We sat by the window- the views were amazing. We had the special roll which was amazing and few others and 2 glasses of wine each. The bill was easily over $125 total... but totally worth it! A great place to wow someone from out of town.
author: Sarah C.

description: Wow this place is amazing. Started off at the bar (happy hour merlot is gross, but never met a merlot i got along with). We then moved to the sushi bar and had a great view of the water off the embarcadero watching the sun set. The shacho sushi roll (lobster, mango, jalapeno goodness wrapped in rice paper) is to DIE for, the most delicate flavorful roll I've ever had. The ozumo roll was delish as well. We sampled a few gingo sake's which were delightful, the unfiltered milky ones were the best. I would def ask for recommendations though because their sake menu is HUGE. Fun place, a little pricey, but an excellent date place or for taking someone from out of town.
author: Jordan V.

description: Good food and fun strong cocktails.  Don't drink too many though if you are on a work lunch, they sneak up on you!
author: Lauren B.

description: FUCK this place, after waiting soo many hrs to be seated, we finnally was given a menu, after soo long after receiving the menu, we finally got our orders taken. the service is crap. way over priced, no different from my local sushi bar. i can't lie though, the place is really nice, but what made me give this place a 1 star is because the food is way over priced, 2 skinny people eating, bad service and our bill still came out to be $90+. can i hear a bull shit?
author: David T.

description: Great saki (sampler and hot saki) and service. Salad and sushi were fresh and the (baked/broiled?) yellowfish was okay (tender but taste was not extraordinary, probably slightly salted with some squeezed lemon juice). I loved that when you go into the restroom, you hear Japanese-speaking lessons (almost surreal and somewhat humorous). Nice, dark aura in the front (nice for stealing smooches if you're anti-pda!) though the back bar/restaurant has a sleek design and lighting. On the pricier scale, and somewhat a scene to be seen.
author: Audrey L.

description:
i loved this place and ate here almost every other week for a while. the sake selection was impressive and the sushi is always fresh. i was hooked on the oysters appetizer, small plates, and the lobster entree. it's pricey and maybe a little too salty for some people's palate but oh so warm and yummy in my tummy.

the bar area is very hip and a dj will provide dinning music on some nights. the dinning area has a large sushi bar and is open w/ a view of the bridge.
author: Runt T.

description: Today (Thursday) we went to lunch for a's bday.  We had a noon reservation, and were seated right away. It wasn't even busy. Ozumo is a lot bigger than it looks from the front, you just keep walking back and it's a big room. It looks nice, and our party was seated by a window that overlooked the water and bridge and embarcadero. Our waiter was attentive, but in an annoying way. I don't know how to describe it, but very fake, which sounds silly because waiters don't generally know you so they are all, to some extent fake, but that's all I can say to describe it. Everyone who brought over the food was very meticulous, even making sure the bento boxes were facing the right direction. So overall the service was good. Prices were expensive. I'd eaten sushi the night before, so I got the lunch ramen. It was $15ish and not bad. There was pork, egg and crab, and the pork was very fatty. I couldn't eat half of it because it was just white/clear fat. Ew. It came with edamame and a small salad, which was tasty. Actually the whole table ordered edamame for appetizers, and it was warm and salty and tasty. My soup was ok but not anything special. Two people had bento boxes, which were very pretty, and they liked them. They ran $18-maybe $22. The other 3 people had sushi. The sushi was pretty, and they seemed to enjoy it ok, but not a lot, and it was small servings. The green tea served with the meal was very good, and in cute tea pots. Overall, lunch for 7 people came out to over $200, which is more than I'd like to spend on lunch.  And if I do spend that much on lunch, I want it to be spectacular. This wasn't spectacular, it was average. By all means, check it out, since a lot of people gush over this place, but I don't see the need to try it again.
author: Merredith L.

description: solid food.  Went here on a business lunch (thank god because no way would I pay these prices on my own) and it was good.  Really nothing special.   Decor and such are nice but with the plethora of sushi joins in this fine city I really cant imagine spending too much time here because of hte cost
author: Robert U.

description: With 500+ reviews...i'm not going to say much except the kobe beef is frackin awesome!
author: Lily L.

description: Great ambience for both food and drinks. Love the decor! Great drinks and good hangout place for drinks on the weekends too. Love the chocolate fondue with seasonal fruits!
author: Yan M.

description: Some of the most unique and tasty Japanese food I've had in the Bay Area but it comes with a nice price tag though.  Worth going if you have a lot of extra cash just laying around. Try the Hamachin Kama (grilled yellowtail collar).
author: Jeannie L.

description: Great Sake selection, and very interesting menu. A bit overpriced, and extremely noisy. Hard to hold a conversation. Nice atmosphere at the bar.
author: Fred S.

description: Absolutely the most delicious sushi I have ever had. Fresh fish in tasty unique combinations. The tuna tartare is incredible - on top of a bed of chopped avocado, wasabi, cucumber. Seating by the windows affords beautiful views of the bay bridge. Service is attentive. Overall fantastic - my favorite spot to impress visitors of the SF sushi scene.
author: George S.

description: I guess the bar is fun if you enjoy white guys looking for Japanese chicks.  As for the restaurant, the food is okay, but the room is not comfortable.  Like other places in this neighborhood, it's high volume / rapid turnover and it shows.
author: Ron O.

description: I always cringe when I hear of a "contemporary" take on asian food.  My theory is that they charge 2x for fusion style food b/c you have to pay for food from two countries.  This place was good.  Nice ambience, Cool layout, Good bar.  I was too busy trying to not reach across the table and strangle my client who drank too much of the truth serum known as Sake.  I would be in a better mood if I didn't have to reach for the check.  Investor, whereever you are, this will be negotiated into your purchase price.  muhahahahahaha
author: Scott Y.

description: Quite the trendy spot for after works drinks and asian appetizers.  It's fancy, the decor is nice, you might see some lookers, but why do I need to pay $10 for a california roll?   You're definitely not heading there for the food.  Sushi is way overpriced and frankly not all that special.  Stick with your local bamboo sushi house with the fresh stuff.  Don't expect friendly service either--they aren't very attentive. If you want to meet for a drink in nice ambience then this might be good for one before heading elsewhere.
author: Ross W.

description: Good variety of drinks, neat ambiance. I only went for happy hour but the food that was being served around me looked amazing!
author: Lisa H.

description: Ozumo is one of my favorite places...  It is expensive - especially cause it is so hard to resist the specials the servers recommend.  I came her with a group of 4, we had a couple bottles of wine and it was well over $100 per person.   The black cod dish is freaking amazing.  The sushi is fabulously fresh, tasty with excellent presentation.  How about the atmosphere?  I prefer the bar area, I'm a big fan of the dim lighting, modern Asian decor, lotsa "pretty people" and comfy chairs to lounge in.  The dining room is a bit too bright in my opinion.  Definitely a place to go for special occasions.
author: Sheila D.

description: Their sake drinks are excellent.  The lounge has a very sophisticated look - makes a very good happy hour place.
author: Ayumi I.

description: The sashimi is great here, but it's really expensive. And it often feels like I'm at a club (cause there are lots of well dressed people drinking and walking around), even though I'm just having dinner. I recommend that if you're celebrating someone's birthday and you have lots of $$ and a big group, you come here. Otherwise, there are probably more intimate, affordable places to have quality sushi.
author: ting b.

description: I've had lunch here three times in the past couple of months and the first two visits were absolute perfection. Delicious food and excellent service. The third visit, yesterday, was the opposite. I treated a close friend to lunch after describing Ozumo as my "new favorite restaurant." I gave that endorsement as someone who lived in Japan for three years. After we were seated, I felt as if I was in the wrong restaurant. The food was poorly prepared and the service was sloppy. Here are a few highlights: The beef in the gyu bento was tough and overcooked. The waitress forgot/lost our appetizer, so we had to ask a second time. I always order a glass of umeshu, which is Japanese for plum wine, but this time none of the waitresses knew what that word meant. I did get my plum wine, but it shouldn't have been so difficult. At the end of the meal, I asked for the desert menu, which never arrived. In the end, I was embarrassed both by and for Ozumo yesterday, and I probably won't risk another visit.
author: Mia B.

description: sushi doesn't get better than this. worth the hype, and worth the wait. great service, fresh fish, and an amazing ambiance. we need more places like ozumo in the city!
author: Roujin M.

description: My colleague and I both got food poisoning. The most expensive bad experience I've had in San Francisco
author: B U.

description:
pluses:

the food is great, they have lots of different types of delicious sake, the place is very beautiful, and we were able to walk in and get a seat immediately (granted it was a sunday night).

minuses:

it's not what i would call "cheap" (though cheap sushi is a conundrum of its own), the service was a little bit slow, and some of the more complicated rolls (the ones with asparagus) were kind of like too many guitar solos at once, but in the taste department.

equals:

I'd go back for sure, but it's not a new favorite.
author: Manlio L.

description: Never had a bad time here.  For some reason I feel like I can always walk right up to the bar and sit down and get a drink, I dig that.  And randomly, one happy hour afternoon, the bartender asked me if I was Jim R, which I am, b/c he thought I looked like my brother who he knew and hadn't seen in years.  That was trippy.
author: jimbo r.

description: By far the best sushi I have ever had. I come have lunch here at least once a month and always order the garlic edamame bowl and Rock 'N Roll. Inside the restrooms they have this really cool speaker that teaches you Japanese and upon entering the staff even greets you in Japanese!
author: Gabby H.

description: I was visiting from Chicago and I told my friend that I wanted fantastic food so he recommended Ozumo.  The food was amazing!  I wanted to try all different types of sushi and everything was sooo good.  I just wish I had a bigger stomach.  If I go back to SF again, Ozumos is definitely on my places to eat list.
author: An A.

description: I really enjoy the sushi here.  Very fresh.  Lots of choices, both sashimi and rolls.  Really, really delicious sushi.  The cocktails are great as well.  It is a pretty expensive place, so I don't frequent it as much as I would like to!  The vibe is definitely a little flashy, which I'm sure factors into the steep price.  However, if you want good quality sushi, some tasty drinks, and a fun night out, Ozumo is a great place!
author: Lauren H.

description: Love this place! Food is pricey yeah, but it's also very fresh and delicious. If you enjoy trendy upscale dining then you will love this place. We ate in the lounge area where you immediately walk into. Very cool lounge dance music playing and hip modern decor. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable. In fact the recommendation was totally satisfying. Food was never disappointing. I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Stefanie M.

description: Great food, but the service was not. The waitress was a bit too pushy about what she thought we should order. We were the first ones at the sushi bar and ordered our food and it came slowly.....one dish at a time over a 2 hour period. Others came and went around us. We sat around waiting too long for each dish.
author: Leslie W.

description: Haven't been here for a few years....But, I used to work for the Hotel connected to Ozumo and I thought this place was great! Owners are hands on, Jeremy was dope! Quality of food is A+ and staff was very friendly...can't beat the location either! It is definitely time for a visit! It's been years..let's see if it's still the same vibe or better! (:
author: Fannie R.

description: Sushi is extremely good, but overpriced.  There is plenty of non-sushi food on the menu, none of which I have tried.  I find the overly trendy atmosphere somewhat annoying, but the staff are very nice and I like the interior design.
author: Russel S.

description: This place reminds me of some of the hip sushi joints I've been to in London and New York.  Unless it's Nobu, these hip joints leave something to be desired when it comes to the food.  Being a sushi junkie this place doesn't make the cut for freshness and creativity in their sushi menu.  The ambiance is great and gets 4.5 stars, but better sushi can be gotten elsewhere in the city.  Also, I didn't really appreciate the constant upselling from bottled water to getting the toro at "market price" instead of our selections.
author: Mamoon H.

description: de-lish.  I love the communal table -- making the impromptu sushi meal totally feasible.  Dishes are innovative and exciting, some more so than others. Of course -- this all comes at a price -- bring your expense account!
author: Heather C.

description: ok after first reviewing Ozumo in 2006, I take it all back. Yes...I do. Maybe because it's changed, or I have ordered better food, but I've been numerous times in the last few months and really enjoyed it here - maybe also because I really haven't had to pay for my food too (that always helps). I came Saturday night and sat at the bar. Got a seat right away, although sitting on a long bench is sorta hard to get in and out of. The redsox game was playing and I had two giddy geisha martini's. They were really really good. Mind you, I had gone to FallFest earlier in the day and drank so much wine that I passed out and had a hangover at 5pm, by the time I got to Ozumo at 9, I felt much much better. The giddy geishas hit the spot and no more hangover! I was hungry and ordered the dragon roll which was really good. Ozumo is my new friend and I will be back again and again.
author: Natalie S.

description: Beautiful setting and the best sushi in town..of course a bit spendy but worth the splurge once in a while.  Happy hour is actually really good there...good selection of rolls and small plates and the happy hour wines are decent. If you like lychees, you must try the lychee martini.  It's 8am and I'm already craving one!
author: Tanger T.

description: Beautiful restaurant, great service, fun bar scene, and perfect spot for Bday events. The sushi is WAY over priced for the quality that you are getting, and way overrated. You are definitely paying for the ambiance and not the food at this place. But yet... I always go back.... but only cause I like the scene not the food ;)
author: Marina K.

description: Lucky enough to eat here when some old coworkers and boss were in town.  Otherwise I would not have gone on my own due to prices.  Service was very good, waiters were knowledgeable.  We ordered sushi, tempura, sashimi, and veggie dishes.  Not that great for the crazy prices you pay.  The decor was cool, their sake display was impressive.  One thing that bothered me was the Japanese language lesson tapes they play in the bathrooms instead of music.  Kind of creepy.
author: Emiko M.

description: This is one of the places I go when the meal is on the ol expense account. Sashimi is very fresh, rolls are ok, impressive sake menu and tea. Service is just ok.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Excellent food and extremely trendy decour.  However, it is way, way, way overpriced.  Worth it only for a special occassion or for drinks and appetizers at the very cool, and sometimes very crowded, bar.
author: Jason S.

description: This is one of my favorite spots for sashimi in Fidi.  They always have a great selection of fresh sashimi flown in from all over.  If you come for dinner try the robata grill veggie sampler dish, it's yummy!  Their sake list is top rate.
author: Amber L.

description:
I took my wife and one of her friends here for a birthday dinner. We drove down from Sacramento. The traffic was so bad, I almost turned the car around in Berkeley and started back home.  
    Once we finally got there, they were cool about us being late for our reservation. We sat at the sushi bar and the first thing I noticed about this place was their outstanding service. Our waitress was very, very nice and explained the specials in great detail. I like when sushi bars have that few special fresh items that I can try. Ozumo did not disappoint . Several different , unique items.   One great thing here, they have Stella Artois on tap. Love it!!.  The sake selection looked great, but expensive.  Full bar also available. We ordered some Miso and some edamame.   Time to start ordering sushi.   First thing I always order at a sushi place is the tako sashimi.  You can really tell the quality of sushi by this dish. Tako should be cooked so still rare in the middle.   It was cooked perfectly here.   Next came some aji nigiri and some suzuki nigiri.  No one here can argue that the fish is not fresh.  probably some of the best quality of fish I have found any where.   We finished our meal with several other nigiris and the girls had some rolls.   The outstanding service kept going throughout the meal.   I do have a few problems with ozumo.  It's just way to pricey.  They tack on a couple extra bucks to each nigiri, but that really adds up in the end.  This was my largest sushi bill ever, and I've run up a pretty good tab at other places with much more return for my buck.   But it was very good.   The Japanese lessons blaring through speakers in the bathroom must go.  We're not at Buca di beppo after all.  Get rid of that and you'll be doing much better.
author: Todd S.

description: There's nothing I can't add here that hasn't already been stated in the prior 600+ reviews. Three different types of dining options: the scenester-esque front bar, the main dining room, or the private dining areas. The food everywhere is fantastic and  eye-pleasing, although quite pricey. Great place to go if you're on an expense account. :-)
author: Suepattra M.

description: Good food and great vibe.  Learn some Japanese while using the loo.
author: Shiho F.

description: Good fresh food.  One of those ultra hip and cool places that makes you feel hip just being there.  The bartender was really friendly and funny and took good care of us.  But the real reason why this place has a special place in my heart is b/c I met  mayor gorgeous there.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Funny review from the ex-worker!  The owners may be creepy and the food may suck, but it's still a beautiful bar.  Great chilled sakes by the glass.
author: Melanie C.

description: Too bad the happy hour prices are jacked up even higher. Now I'll only visit when it's on the expense account.
author: Rene D.

description: If you like to pay for atmosphere, then I'd give this place a 4-star.  For sushi, it gets a 3-star.  It's good, but I've had fresher fish than what they serve here.  Not too mention that paying a premium for so-so sushi is a not a treasured past-time of mine.  Great place for meeting up for drinks; a little noisy and busy for intimate affairs.
author: JeFF T.

description:
4 stars.  this place is delicious, but i'm not sure how i feel about "contemporary japanese cuisine" (hence -1 star).  i seem to enjoy regular ol' japanese more.  the kind with no frills, and at places where i can get really great sashimi and sushi and such for less money (like pink godzilla in capitola and definitely kamakura in alameda).  4 stars because of the fine upscale-dining ambiance and open-space decor, the wide selection of sake, and the GREAT SERVICE.  both times i've dined there, the waiters have been really attentive/on top of their game.

i highly recommend the washu gyu (a proscuitto-like beef plate), the hot pot sukiyaki (although the beef was a bit on the dry side), and any of their rolls (a lot of them come with asparagus! -- isn't that awesome?).

check out their online menu at ozuma.com for pricing.  i was going to rate this place $$$, but it really depends what you get.  they have starters in the $ range, and other dishes like the washu gyu in the $$$, but if you order a lot (especially since this place serves small portions), you could end up handing over $$$$.
author: Michelle W.

description:
I've been here several times and mostly for the ambiance and the bar scene.  Hard to get a table without reservations.  Most times we sit in the bar area, but once in the main dining room (quieter) with a beautiful view of the Bay Bridge.  

Now about the food...meh, it was alright.  Have definitely had better.  The quality of the fish is great, but the flavors are lacking.  Steak tartare was so bland and the meat seemed minced rather than cubed into small pieces.  The rolls I've tried have also been mediocre.  Stick to plain old sashimi and I guess you'll be okay.  On the up-side, the drinks were great.  Be prepared to leave your wallet here coz it ain't cheap!
author: Mel R.

description: The food is really good here but it's slightly expensive. We were a party of 10 and the waiter we got was somewhat slow and out of it......but I guess it's the luck of the draw who you get. The waiter kept on messing up our order... I think he was only able to handle one thing at a time...drink orders...then appetizers...then entrees.  He would disappear for gaps of time, so when the hostess came by, she offered to take our orders, immediately after which she handed off her notepad to our waiter, who couldn't read her handwriting, so we had to re-order our dishes (~12!) again!  He ended up missing a number of items (as well as forgetting additional orders we made later) and mistakenly ordering our lamb rare instead of medium (at $42/entree, no less!).  So frustrating!
author: Ro H.

description: The interior is beautiful-- modern and minimalist. Good drinks, good sushi, although I agree with the other reviews that this place is on the pricey side.
author: shoba d.

description: This place is definitely gorgeous. Good job on decorating. LIKE SERIOUSLY. our waiter was EVER SO NICE. i really couldn't decide which sushi roll to get and everyone at the table had already ordered and I was still being so picky. and he even knelt down to help me narrow my choices. SO SWEET. (i'd be frustrated with me) the sushi came pretty fast (probably because we got there at 9:45 and the kitchen was closing really soon). a little disappointed with the size of the roll. it really didn't fill you up. would have ordered another but kitchen was closing. in the end, the waiter found out it was one of our girl's birthday and came out with fondue! it was so cute. that's the best "restaurant birthday treat" we ever got! probably won't come back for a long time but our time there was enjoyable.
author: Amy X.

description: Went here for lunch last week.  Downgraded my review due entirely to rude service, not food quality. Of course the overpriced sushi was expected.  But, the unexpected part was how rude our waiter was.  He had such attitude, pretty much ignored our table and just gave off all around bad vibes.  Maybe it's because we didn't order a TON of food, so he saw his tip dwindling.  Still, the level of service at a place like Ozumo should not depend on quantity you are ordering.  I've come here many times and was incredibly dissapointed by the lunch service experience.  We even spoke to the hostess, who was genuinely apologetic. But, it'll be a while b/f I head back here.
author: Caroline I.

description: By far the most decadent Sushi restaurant I've ever had the pleasure of sampling!  The seafood is fresh, amazing service and the ambiance delightful! A little pricey to frequent often but so worth it.
author: S W.

description: The first time I stepped into Ozumo, I was so intimidated that I promptly left the restaurant after being seated and given a menu. What an embarrassment. You see, my original intention was to eat a simple bento box lunch (a bento box is a traditional Japanese lunch that is like a box/tray divided into various compartments, each holding a different dish). Bento lunches are nice because their little complete meals for cheap. But cheap was not something I saw when I glanced at the menu, so not wanting to pay $25 for a lunch, I took off.  But I came back. This review represents three different experiences I had at Ozumo: happy hour with appetizers, sushi lunch, and cooked entree dinner.  Read more on The Ballyhoo: http://www.ballyhoo.us/restaurants/review.cfm?review=103
author: Baochi N.

description: Okay, love the sushi for happy hour, but we had the worst waitress.  We had a huge group, so granted she may have been a bit busy.  However, when you have a large group in for happy hour, I would think they would come by and do a "last call" for the sushi.  We ending up spending over $400 there, but the service was def. NOT worth it.  This is the second time I've had less-than-stellar service there, so I'm not sure i'll go back.
author: kerry l.

description: Yes, it's a bit pretentious. Yes, it's sometimes got a cool DJ playing ambient tunes too loud, and it always has an upscale atmosphere--- both in the bar and in the main dining rooms. Yes, it's fun for people watching and has some great sushi happy hours. And yes, it's sometimes overpriced. But why hold that against this place? I always end up having a great time, and the sushi is ALWAYS first rate.
author: Risa F.

description:
love this place... some of the best sushi in SF and a great vibe to go along with it.

a bit expense, but what sushi isn't.

nice music in the bar...
author: Scott K.

description: Fresh fish, but it's pretty pricey for what you end up getting.  Good bar with my favorite Hangar One vodkas.
author: Mitzi C.

description: If you want to impress a date, Ozumo's is a place to take him or her.  A bit on the pricier side, but there is great sushi and a nice view of the Bay Bridge at night.  Definitely request a seat by the window.  The artistic decor is open and spacious and hip and trendy.  After dinner, you can hang out by the bar in the front or take a walk outside by the water.
author: Angie K.

description: This place is really expensive.  Luckily, I got my mom to take us out.  Thank goodness she enjoys shelling out money for good food.  And the food was good.  Not orgasmically so, but still good.  The ambiance is great too, and the windows look out over the bay bridge.  I wasn't drinking when I went, but if I go back I'm definitely going to try a sake flight.
author: Sara M.

description:
i thought the food here was great.  i can see why it's one of san francisco's top 100 restaurants.  the restaurant part in the back was really nice.  when we first got there, i was kind of turned off by the bar portion that was really trendy looking but noisy.  the serve their full menu at the bar, but if you're spending that much money, i'd recommend sitting in the restaurant where you can actually hear your company.  

don't expect any "real" japanese food here.  the only authentics i saw were the yakiniku and shabu shabu.  i was curious how those would be done, but i went with the gandara when the waiter said it was the best -- a choice i did not regret.

the hamachi appetizer was wonderful.  the yuzu roll was just OK.  we also ordered a dragon roll, and it had the thickest cut of unagi and the fattest shrimp tempura. --well worth the $15.  all of their seafood was very fresh.  you can tell by the texture and the fact it wasn't fishy tasting at all.  overall, i'd say this is comparable to blowfish in terms of ambiance (ozumo is less club feeling) and price, but i'd choose ozumo any day over blowfish because you get more for your money in terms of taste and premium quality seafood.

the service on the other hand wasn't so great, not bad, but not what i'd expect when you drop $110 for dinner for two.  our waiter kind of breezed us through the entire meal (it could be because we were about 30 minutes late to our reservation, but they still seated us promptly).

dessert? not sure if they had any. our waiter just brought us the bill without asking us if we wanted any.
author: Waynele Y.

description: Ate here for lunch. so it was quite bright. Very cool, laid back atmosphere. Nice view of the bay. Had the most expensive bento box that I ever paid for but it was quite tasty. Nothing great nothing special, just a nice view, $13 valet service, and very big bill in the end.
author: Jose S.

description: Okay I loved my dinner becasue i had the best seat in the house overlooking the bay bridge, and had some really good food.  Yes the food is expensive, and no i didn't pay so that could affect my experience, but it was overall pretty lovely.  The staff was great, the ambiance was all hip and cool, but there are cooler places for sure.  However if you can eat here, and get that view, do it ASAP.
author: Rachel P.

description: I'm generally weary of chi-chi places in the financial, mainly because I spend enough time there mon-fri, 9-5 that I don't want to go back after hours, not to mention, I'm all too familiar with the corporate expense account guys and people of that ilk and, therefore, I generally avoid places they might frequent like the plague, but I was so wowed by my meal at Ozumo last night, the sake, and the service! We ( the bf, the bff and I) sat at the bar and were taken care of by Josh, the fabulous bar manager and  the excellent staff. Josh made recommendations from the menu that he thought we might like and then went out of his way to ensure that we had the perfect sakes to pair with our assorted dinner items. We  started with garlic aioli edamame and the Horenso no goma-ae (blanched organic spinach salad), moved on to the Kabocha soup (with pine nuts) and Dobin Mushi Tea Pot soup (Matsutake Mushrooms, Black Truffles, and Black Tiger Prawns in  a clear Dashi broth), had the Bucho, Spicy Scallop and California rolls, then had the Futago (grilled Washu Beef with Eggplant) and the Doyo (Tuna Tartare with Tofu) before finishing with the dark Chocolate fondue for dessert. All excellent!  Also excellent and hilarious in only the way awkward failed-pick up attempts can be, was the moment where this douche-bag from Michigan (in what else but a striped shirt, of course) came over to hit on my bff with a line straight out of The Pick Up Artist tv show.  Even funnier was hearing the two poor super cute servers muttering and complaining under their breaths to the bartenders about the douche-bag from Michigan and his freakishly tall friend hitting on them as well.  We left feeling completely full, delighted, and super impressed with the service.  Not to mention, I think I'm in love with Sake...move over Sparkling wine...there's a new man in Dee's life!
author: Dee I.

description: It's pricey, for sure, but the decor is fabulous. The food is unique, and the view is great (if you sit by the windows).
author: Angela C.

description: Been here several times with my gf. Beautiful decor and ambience. Food is very good, but expensive for what you get. If you are looking for a highclass sushi place, then this is the place, if you want to get full without blowing 2 bills, then its not happening here.
author: John Z.

description:
Went to rediscover what it feels like to get off work at a humanly hour and experience "happy hour". I miss working market hours sometimes. 

In any case, i think we missed happy hour but stayed for dinner.

Got a couple of sakes, that Sparkling Geisha, couple rolls, steak tartare, and seafood hot pot.

I guess the best way to sum up how i'm feeling is if i went to watch Fast and Furious or Die Hard and criticized the movie for lacking substance in the plot, complex character development, or sheer intellect. I

In other words, the food here sucks, but i've got to be kidding myself if i was trying to get exquisite food here. Sake was fine, the Geisha could be made at home.... rolls - awful, and the seafood hot pot was more like a hot cup. Tiny. Where's the pot?? That wasn't the sample of the much larger pot that's coming? Yuck. And the steak tartare... i think i'll leave that experience in Paris from now on. Price does not match food quality. Service, on the other hand, was fine.

I would drop 150 large ones 99 out of 100 times at Koo over Ozumo's... which means to prove this point i will have to go to Koo 98 more times and not go back to Ozumo's during that stretch.

Someone out there is a lucky girl.
author: Steven L.

description:
Swank, hip, trendy, expensive sushi restaurant. A great spot for special occasions. 

The scene reminded me of a club or lounge. Music was playing, the place was dimly lit, and the waitresses are young and attractive. The crowd was mixed but mostly well dressed business professionals with their corp cards. 

Food was phenomenal. I do think it was the freshest fish I've ever had. The menu was unique and refreshing. They didn't have the standard boring list of ubiquitous sushi rolls, but instead had unique rolls I've never had before. 

Only downside to all this is the price. I ran up a bill north of $100 for myself alone without any trouble. If you can stomach that or are on an expense account - I strongly recommend this spot.
author: B B.

description: I thought the sushi was good quality, slightly better than SF neighborhood sushi in freshness but not on par with very high end sushi place. Wait staff and front staff were both great and very attentive. No attitude just service. I didn't pay the bill, so value-for-money doesn't factor into my review. If you're downtown near embarcadero I don't know of any other sushi place of similar quality...
author: Jack S.

description: I lile the bar at this place and the food is good to but a little on the $$$ side. I went there about two weeks ago and it was still a great place to visit.
author: Sergio G.

description: Fish is spectacular, the service is decent, and on occasion you can even get seated right away.
author: Max L.

description: By far the best Janapanese in SF!  Watch out, because once you taste this sushi...the little dive on the corner won't satisfy the sushi urge.  Excellent Lyche martinis as well!
author: Sarah D.

description: Very good but kind of pricey.  They have great fondue.  The sushi presentation is excellent.  After 10pm the restaurant turns into a lounge.  During the summer, the windowed wall can open up toward the street to get more air (they did this when I was there one night...it was so hot...)
author: Sonya T.

description: Friday night scene after work... the place is packed.  Lots of good looking types with a bar menu of sushi (yum!).  Great place to meet friends who work around that street.  A little tough to get the attention of the bartenders because it will so packed.
author: Annabel G.

description: I've had lunch there a few times, dinner once, and happy hour a bunch of times. Food has been good to outstanding. Happy Hour is great!
author: Dana B.

description: The atmosphere is nice, the sake is great but the food is mediocre and overpriced.  The sushi definitely isn't authentic and isn't creative enough to pass as good fusion.  If you go, try the sake flights - 3 tastings of sake, grouped by various themes.  The place gets crowded easily so if you go on a saturday night, I'd suggest eating somewhere else and coming here for drinks.
author: M P.

description: This is a great place to go for happy hour. Their interior design is very modern and metro. I love the vibe. Their dinner menu is alright. Their dinner menu is very yummy. The portions are small. Come if you are a light eatter. I feel that I can get better priced Japanese elsewhere.
author: Helen L.

description: I put on a fund raiser here one time and it went very well. The staff was friendly and although loud, the space was fun. The food is decadent and delish. The furniture and walls are nice to look at too
author: Roxane S.

description: Excellent spot, with great Japanese food bordering on the Asian fushion side.  Their sushi is amazing, and they've got a great selection and diversity on the menu.  Good mellow atmosphere, tons of saki.
author: Evan A.

description:
it's not the best japanese place in the city, but it certainly ain't bad.

start your meal with the onikor...o..shi...(uhmmmm) daiginjo.  translation: "demon slayer" sake.  light, super smooth, tastes like the way flowers smell. (it's descriptions like that that reinforce why i don't write for a living.)

next, on to small plates: the uni risotto is EXCELLENT.  creamy and gooey like uni, but perfectly cooked to maintain the consistency of rice in every bite.  the carpaccio was excellent, as was the grilled vegetable plate.  we also tried the kunamoto oysters - a platter of 6 yielded 3 fishy tasting ones, and 3 perfect, fresh oysters.  odd.

(by the way, i know i'm butchering all sorts of spelling.  bear with me here.)

signature dish is the blackened cod.  fish was not meant to be so buttery.  i'd stick with fish all the way through, including the sushi, over the meat dishes.  last night's specials were hawaiian yellowtail belly and salmon belly, both fantastic.  however some of my other faves, like ankimo (monkfish liver) were merely so-so.  

service wasn't terrible but not great.  our server seemed as nervous as your prom date - maybe it was her first night on the job?  try to sit in the main dining room where the sushi bar is - the seating near the kitchen gets positively sauna-esque.

in reality, i'd give it 3.5 stars.  but last night i was sitting across from a tina fey clone - i'm not particular to older women, but being smart, talented, and funny go a long, long way in my book.
author: brian w.

description: I don't care if the food is awesome (according to my fiance) but a 2.5 hour wait for dinner on a Wednesday night (a raining Wed. night I might add) is soo not worth it.  Nice restaurant and all, but I like to enjoy the atmosphere with food please.  It's very hip, trendy  and swanky...but took my umbrella, sneaker wearing and school bag (which had good money in it) elsewhere!
author: Helen C.

description: Ozumo, Omazing! This is the best sushi I have ever had- so fresh and so yummy! This place is a bit pricey, but it's great for a special occasion. The staff was really well educated on the food and sake and major plus!
author: Alison W.

description: Ozumo's is a stable in my life and the girls and I meet up here about once a week.  Jesse and his staff always take care of us and I LOVE the Chocolate Fondue!  Yes, fondue!  =)
author: Suz L.

description: Not impressed. Walked in and although we were seated promptly, and the service was decent, we left feeling hungry and somewhat lacking in good food. I know it is sushi, but I expected something special. All the fish, and I mean all the fish, was "fishy". Not exactly fresh. Even the oysters tasted off. The wine and sake selection was great, but not worth the cash to fork out for it. The bar was definitely the place to be, with a Dj and good loungie,  relaxing environment, but I dont think I will be back. Not worth the money or the time.
author: Sara A.

description:
I've been coming here for 6 years and always know to expect a great meal and experience.   It starts with the fact that the Valet is $10 and the guy working there is actually very pleasant.   
The bar area is always full of beautiful people; some fully dressed and some wearing some scanty outfits in the cold weather.  It's a good mix of people every time.
I booked it through opentable.com and got a great table overlooking the view of the water.   I love the Geisha Martini (lychee) and my friend enjoyed the Cosmo.   Yesterday, we had a great waitress who was very laid back and personable.   Love the soy garlic edamame, which we couldn't finish.   Had fantastic hamachi, maguro and toro nigiri and a spicy tuna roll.  The black cod has always been a favorite and yesterday we discovered a new small plate beef with garlic mushroom and soy miso Japanese eggplant.  It was all absolutely amazing.   A memorable meal.
My friend and I were catching up so they let us have our own pace.  But a couple of times, they kept wanting to clear our dishes when we were just too busy chatting.   They need to wait for the customer to request help instead of interrupting the conversation over and over.  
As everyone else mentions, Ozumo is a place where you need to expect to pay a large bill at the end of the meal.  But it's always worth it.
author: Ayelet B.

description: My lovely ladies took me here last weekend for the dinner portion of my bachelorette party. The only reason why I held off on the 4th star in my rating is our waiter was a complete ditz. It was as if his mind was not on Planet Earth. He kept wandering away before he finished telling us specials, and he swore that EVERYTHING ON THE MENU was the most delicious thing ever. Aside from the service, the food and sake were tasty. They accommodated us even though we were half an hour late. Definitely order their dessert sushi because the caramel sauce is to die for. I almost tried licking the plate clean but settled for wiping off the sauce w/ my finger.
author: Christine T.

description: This is the best Sushi Restaurant in San Francisco. The fish itself is the freshest I have tasted in my life. The price compares to eatting the best of something you can find so come prepared, the food is worth it. I often eat lunch here at the Sushi bar, and theres just no better lunch than when your eatting Ozumo. I live to eat Sushi and this place is the best I have experienced. Get in there to try it for yourself! The menu is amazing, the key is to go with a large group and order a different dish for each person and then let everyone try a little bit of everything. I highly recommend the black cod!
author: Michael G.

description:
I don't get a chance to go for sushi too often so when I do so I have a hard time comparing places.  Last week I made it out to a place here in Sacramento for lunch and had a very good experience so it was a good comparison to make to Ozumo.  Unfortunately, this trip to Ozumo opened my eyes to a lot of the other complaints people had.

Again we had a Saturday night reservation and were seated promptly and on time.  The bar was less crowded and the atmosphere more relaxed however our waiter was horrible.  My wife is a vegetarian and he was making recommendations all night about fish dishes trying to convince her to try them because they're so good.  He also tried to convince our friend who doesn't like aioli to get the aioli on the roll because it adds a "decadance and richness."  Um, no, she doesn't like aioli dummy.  In addition he messed up two nigiri orders however the thing our friends found odd was that he took the plates away.  Are they throwing away the plated sushi or re-serving it to someone else?

We ordered some rolls and my wife substituted some veggies for fish in the Shacho and (I don't remember) however she picked the two rolls that come with less than 6-8 pieces (4 and 5 respectively).  The menu doesn't state that these rolls have less than the "standard" number of pieces.  Again, the waiter tried to play cool and state "well, they're larger rolls so they have fewer pieces."  Unfortunately for him they were the two smallest diameter rolls we ordered all night.

As for the nigiri the pieces of fish served are small however the rice is good, which I hadn't noticed until someone was discussing it last week.  That by no means makes up for the price to fish portion ratio.  Also the Saba was really odd - it was pickled or something nasty.  I usually enjoy Saba because it has a bit of a "fish" taste to it however this tasted almost like the jar of herring people eat for New Years or something.

I need to go rate the place I went to here in Sac (once I remember the name) because compared to Ozumo it was hands down better.  I'm going to give Ozumo a low rating because the waiter was thoroughly annoying, the price/portion was poor and the saba was just not right.  I won't be going back again.
author: Dave S.

description: The bar is a great place to sit and eat if you can't get a table, but you will miss the view!
author: Carson H.

description: We usually go here for happy hour every now and then.  Pretty good service, drinks, and food.  I like their kobe beef and spider rolls.  Wash them down with a glass of sapporo and I'm a happy buzzed man!
author: Jeff H.

description:
Food and Appearance: Four Stars!
Service and Ambiance: One star...see why below

I was looking for a nice place to take my fiancee for our six year anniversary. I booked a reservation at Chenery Park, but we were staying at the Intercontinental and Ozumo was highly recommended by the Hotel staff. So, I went to Ozumo. I wish I would have went to Chenery Park. The initial ambiance of Ozumo creates a very "traditional Japanese" feel with a sense of refinement and sophistication. There are big sake bottles stacked up over the bar and the lounge benches on the sides looked quite comfortable wth big pillows and very nice wood tables. So the background was awesome; five stars there. When I called Ozumo, they said the first seats available were at 9:45pm, however it is first come first served, so I was encouraged to hurry so that I could have a table. When I arrived I was greated by a very polite host and waitress. To my great dismay, they told me that there were no more tables but I could sit in that well-appointed and comfortable looking lounge area. I thought, "not bad" this looks better than a boring table.  

FOOD:  The food was actually quite good. The Burikama (yellow-tail collar) was outstanding. I've heard this is considered the "fillet-mignon of fish." The maguro tataki salad was also a delicious combination of tuna and salad with a ponzu dressing that danced around my tongue. The sushi wasn't the greatest, but nevertheless it was tasty. 

SERVICE: 
The waitress was very attentive to most of my needs. She would frequently check with me to make sure everything was well and did a very fine job. My first complaint is that we were seated close to the door, so it was very drafty. The doorman didn't do much to help by holding the door open for an eternity when he thought he saw people headed towards the restaurant. Now to the not-so-fun part. This is why the review is only a one-star: 

Now, you would think, that an upscale place like this would control the customers and not let them get too rowdy. WRONG!!!! About ten minutes into the meal, the party of four next to me started causing a huge ruckus. They obviously had about ten drinks too many and were throwing the F-bomb around like it was going out of style. They were posing for pictures, calling each other names, shouting to each other as if there was loud background noise, and making it very unpleasant for me and my dining partner. The party next to me was about a drunk mess. They were about a stone's throw away from expelling their dinner on the table and passing out on the floor.  To the waitress:  I had a simple request: Can you please find me a seat anywhere away form these clowns? She told me the only seats available would be more noisy? Really? So you're telling me that your restaurant is full of noisy jerks? I'm paying for a $100 dinner, but I'm supposed to put up with this foolishness? Sorry, but if that is the way your restaurant is run, then I'm never coming back and I'm telling everyone that I know to avoid your restaurant! 

There are much better places to go where one can dine without having to be cold through most of the dinner and try to hold a conversation over the drunken yelling of belligerent fools.
author: Nick C.

description: Quite honestly I've had better sushi...and it doesn't really seem to be worth the price.  I wouldn't choose to come here if I had to pay...but my work paid for lunch so I guess I can't really complain.  One thing I will note is how odd it was that they served us water in small cocktail glasses with fat tall straws, but as we were about to leave and asked for more water, the waiter brought tall (regular water) glasses and no straw...odd...
author: Alvina W.

description: I've had dinner here several times now and have never had to wait, most likely because I dine late night (around 9pm). Though the prices are high, the food is worth it! Contemporary Japanese a stone's throw from the water so you can walk along the Embarcadero afterwards with the Bay Bridge twinkling at night, hopefully with a halo of light through the famous SF Fog. Don't miss the Dayboat Scallops with mushroom risotto or the tender Kobe Beef served with fresh wasabi, making all the difference. If you like sashimi, I've tried a variety and all have been top quality and freshness. Happy eating!
author: Sabi M.

description: Ozumo is a great place for an important dinner. The bar is pretty good, too. The food is superb and beautifully presented. The tablesetting is nice, the restaurant in general is very attractive. Ozumo will always be one of my go-to sure-thing meals. It's not for everyday dining, necessarily. But that's okay. I'm just glad to know I can count on Ozumo for consistently good food.
author: Karen Z.

description: Okay, So, I am from L.A. and am well versed in "High End" sushi restaurants which cater to a young crowd who like sushi and good cocktails. I will admit this place has a good bartender who made me a good old fashion, but the food was sub par, the service was disgraceful and I frankly could have had a sushi dinner that came with better food and service for about half the price or less. This place is trying to be like Katsuya or Koi or Matsuhisa in LA (all three of which I have eaten at), and Ozumo frankly does not have the cuisine or service to get them to that level. Good for a Cocktail and snacks if you want go to a stylish joint, but skip Dinner.
author: Thomas E.

description: Going off the Zagat guide this was the only place on the Sunday night of Labor day weekend we got a table. The sushi was so fresh it melted in our mouths. One of the things I really liked was being seated at the sushi bar we had a chance to chat with the sushi chef. It was almost like having our own personal sushi chef! He was great.. from Korea and even hammed it up for us. The sashimi was wonderful and blew our previously favorite sushi place in Chi-town out of the water.
author: Pooja S.

description: Expensive but very good food.  Only issue: it was an unusually hot day in SF and they would not turn on air conditioning.
author: I R.

description: Was there last week on Wednesday night. Very busy. The staff seemed pissed off that we were in a large group (with a reservation).  The food was good but the service sucked. Overall good experience.
author: Duncan A.

description:
Executive Summary: food = delicious, service = too bad to overlook for the cost, value = poor

I'll say that the food here is quite good. I like sushi, and they do some creative & interesting things (one of the very nice, friendly sushi chefs gave us some type of fish-peanut butter-strawberry piece that was actually fantastic). The appetizers are delicious as well. However, the service is terrible. My girlfriend and I had reservations for an early dinner (5:30) before a show and arrived promptly. The hostess looked us both up & down (we were dressed fairly well, but not in formal wear) and told the waitress to seat us at "station 8", or something like that. In an empty restaurant with big windows, sweeping views of the bay and about 4 other couples dining, they sat us in the back, near the bathrooms and a service station. After sitting, I asked the waiter if we could move tables, and he said "I doubt it. We have lots of reservations tonight. Would you like me to get the manager?". It was 5:30, the place was empty and  _we_ had reservations. I asked to see the manager, and when he came out, he asked what the problem was and said he'll "see what he can do." 5 minutes later they moved us to a marginally better table on the back wall, right next to one of the other 4 couples dining. As we ate, I noticed they consistently seated the older, affluent-looking couples in the prime spots, and stuffed all the younger couples in the same row of tables, all spaced very closely to each other.

So, my review is obviously biased by my distaste for the pretentious staff, but there are far better sushi places in SF that treat you well and don't charge as much. That said, if you're in a suit and have money to burn, the sushi is pretty good.
author: Todd S.

description:
We had a table reserved but we took a seat at the bar for a drink, first. The place was definitely happening, even though it was just another middle of the week night... The crowd was mostly young and trendy and definitely enjoying their food and drinks while a DJ was spinning some good chill-out music in the background. 
Our bartender was Evans, whose cool attitude and passionate way of talking about the menu and about the sake he was pouring immediately won us over.  When the hostess came to seat us, we did not hesitate to tell her that we won't need the table any more...  
Evans' knowledge about various sakes and their pairings with food was absolutely amazing! We did not only have dinner but a total eye-opening experience as we worked our way through the courses masterfully introduced and explained to us. 
Sushi rolls? Forget sushi rolls!... You can have that anywhere ...The menu was incredibly extensive and fresh and Evans suggested  dishes that were pleasant surprises, from the delicious Hanabi (ginger does wonders!), to the Tiger Prawns and many others, whose name I am going to have to go back and try to remember next time...Because there will definitely be a next time !
By the time the delicious Pineapple Maki dessert came, we had travelled all over the Japanese cuisine map and had tasted sakes from various regions. With Evans as our guide, the great music in the background and surrounded by other people who were obviously enjoying the food as much as we did, I can definitely say that Ozumo was one of the best Japanese culinary experiences we have had in San Francisco. 
I do recommend geting the sake pairing with food- the staff there will be able to suggest the right match for the food you choose. If, like us, you want to be pleasantly surprised, you can either ask for Evans or, I am sure, any of the servers or bartenders- they will guide you and suggest dishes that will suit your taste and mood.
author: Le Big Mac A.

description:
good for happy hour thurs or fri but the food isn't that great and is a bit overpriced.

ozumo is a lively place and a good place to take a biz client after a moscone conference. the waitresses are attractive

GOOD
shireomaguro, hamachi, aji nigiri
lychee martinis
beer on tap and good sake variety
cougars! and mini cougars abound!


BAD
crowded bar area 
food is decent, not great
sushi not all that fresh
tempura ebi, ikakoromo wasnt all that fresh either
author: Bobby B.

description:
*happy hour review only* 
good place to people watch indoors, a little less crowded than americano, very friendly happy hour wait-staff.  seating is a bit scarce, but we always manage to find a table.  the prices are a bit stiff, but then again it is an "upscale" financial district happy hour venue, so its to be expected.  

great atmosphere and great friendly staff keeps me coming back when i'm in this kind of happy hour mood.
author: Jason J.

description: Only the freshest of fish will make it to your table while eating at Ozumo.  The seafood literally melts in your mouth, including the calamari which is easy to screw up.  Definitely make reservations!!  The service and food is great and the bill will reflect that.  :]
author: Michael H.

description: sorry, wanted to like this place, but the only thing that was good were those garlic edamames!?  the food is passable, but the rolls were bad, flavors weren't right, food was sorta boring....
author: Monster E.

description: Tokyo design firm Super Potato created the right spot for cocktails and sushi.
author: E C.

description: Trendy, expensive, very good sushi.  Probably among the top 5 sushi places for the actual quality.
author: J D.

description: Goodness...I paid $28 for a Spicy tuna roll! :( It was good; however, the cost was ridiculous. Dining in SF automatically signs you up to pay for the employee health plan that the city offers to its employees. Great decor and service though!
author: B ..

description: With all of the great reviews out there, I was disappointed.  I didn't think the food was that great especially for what it costs and the service was mediocre.  It's not worth the wait and the prices.
author: Amanda H.

description: Great food, but the service was meh. I think we actually ended up getting at least half of our dishes/drinks comp'ed because it took so long, so it kinda evened out, but it wasn't exactly what I was looking for. Being hospitable is great, but it's even better if there's nothing wrong in the first place.
author: Jessica T.

description: Pretty damn good sushi in a beautiful, if somewhat austere, space. Eat at the bar up front or get a private room.
author: Not M.

description: Great food, great service. Try the hanabi salad and, of course, the chocolate fondue
author: Nellie L.

description: Good for drinks in a nice ambience (excellent lychee drinks) with your friends.  Bad for meeting people unless you like girls who wear too much make up and guys who look like cheeseballs in suits.  Kinda how I feel about San Diego.
author: Dana C.

description:
me to a certain soon to be ex -  "wanna meet there in 15 for dinner?"
a certain soon to be ex to me - "yea! but george made me drink rum all day at the baseball game and then he bought me three post game dirty martinis and a guinness, i have to walk it off before i get on my motorcycle, lets meet in 30."

ok, i should have known dinner was doomed.

after he "accidentally" blew out the candle, refused to read the menu while instead repeatedly blurting out various made-up names of made-up sushi rolls he said he wanted, knocked at least two glasses off the table, and spilled his whole bown of miso soup, i gained much respect for the waitress and almost understood why his mother was so crazy.

Aside from that, the sushi, ceviche, sashimi, seaweed salad and miso soup were good, but not great.  Nice presentation, though.  Less emphasis was on the straight japanese style/simplicity, and more was on the fusion style japanese.  Good place if your going with people who don't all want raw fish - they had a lot of other options.

If I were rating ambiance and service, this place would have 5 stars, hands down.  The bathroom was nice and i actually liked the japanese language tapes playing instead of music.  The interior was large, roomy,nicely lit (or nicely darkened), well decorated with very chic design.   

But the food, it was more presentation than anything.  And the prices were extreme for the quality.  I could only justify it by thinking we were paying for the ambiance and service.  With that "justification", it still only comes out with 3 stars.  (Albeit, my certain soon to be ex seemed more impressed, but i'm writing it off as due to his beer goggles and the "after-ballpark-hot-dog" impression.)

My advice - go for drinks at the bar if you want a cool space to hang in.  Save your apetite for a post-drink meal elsewhere.
author: Today Y.

description: Food is greatttt.  Drinks are strong.  Nice atmosphere.  I don't like the setup of the bar too much.  But anyway, if you like sushi, I definitely recommend this place!
author: Labonee M.

description: no this is not your everyday sushi joint, that you can just go to on a whim. But if you have some paper, or a special event, get rad here. the fish is very fresh, presentation is beautiful, and the ambiance is very nice
author: Lauren V.

description: Expensive sushi! Service was pretty good. Sushi itself was excellent, but if you're going here, I sure hope someone else is paying for it, otherwise you're in for a heart attack. They also have an extensive selection of sakes to choose from. Depending on where you sit, you can get an excellent view of the ocean. So if you're treating your honey to a fancy anniversary dinner or something, I suggest requesting a window seat. Parking's kind of difficult to find, but I believe there is valet, and a couple of lots if you don't want the hassle of searching.
author: kimberly l.

description: The atmosphere is very cool... the bar especially.  And the place is HUGE!  I couldn't believe it when we were walked through to the back dining room.  I have to say though, there isn't a point to sitting at the sushi bar other than not having to look your date in the eyes.  Our waitress was extremely nice and friendly and led a 20 minute explanation of sake and its proceses.  A little over excited but wo don't know anything about it so it worked out ok.  I would say the sushi itself is average and pretty expensive.  I'd rather eat at Blowfish to be honest!
author: Alexis J.

description:
3.5 stars.

Food is certainly good, but you pay for what you get.

Quality sushi, and check out the Washa Gyu if you want something a bit more...beefy.

Seating between the bar and the back restaurant area can feel a bit awkward.
author: Brian S.

description: Ozumo is THE epitome of a high-end sushi restaurant. Nothing is overlooked. Be ready to spend ... but it's more than worth it.
author: Tim B.

description: The food here is great. From their small plates to the freshness of their sushi.  Also gotta love the flights of sake. The service was also exceptional. Sure its a bit pricey, but then again, if you are complaining about that, what the hell are you eating out for in the first place?  Cook yourself, it's cheaper.  Get it together people, this place is hella good!
author: Michael W.

description: One of my fave spots for sushi in the city and not as spendy as you'd expect. The DJ spins decent stuff and the bar has a cool crowd although on week days there are a lot of business-types.
author: LeeAnn G.

description: The fish is fresh! The rolls are creative! It's amazing!
author: Christopher L.

description: Overall the food was good, but I was disappointed by the seaweed salad which lacked the tanginess and sweetness that I'm used. It was pretty bland. Dishes come out at different times, which I also didn't like...some people in our table were done with their food while others hadn't gotten their appetizers. But I do recommend the yellowtail collar.
author: Katrina R.

description: Love the bar, love the food.  The hosts need an attitude adjustment.  I've been with parties that have dropped some big dollars in this place, and generally like the bartenders and staff.  I just don't need some stuck up menu holder thumbing their nose in the air.  The sushi's pretty good, but a bit overpriced.
author: Harold B.

description: maybe i am now a sushi snob. this place isn't horrible but it is just overrated! the food is not as great as it seems and too expensive for what you get...not going back
author: tipp v.

description:
Let me begin by saying i created a yelp account strictly to be able to relay how disgusted and disappointed i was in my experience at Ozumo.  I came in last Saturday and sat at the bar by myself, it took the bartender a solid twenty minutes to finally acknowledge i was there and what she lacked in service it seemed as though she thought she made up for in sex appeal by squinting at me and making overtly sexual jokes that to be frank made me uncomfortable and a little uneasy.  To ad insult to injury  i ordered the most simple drink ( absolute and soda) in hopes it was delivered fast and went down smooth..to my dismay ANGELA decided she would rather serve me a gin and tonic! 
i wanted a vodka soda from what was supposed to be a fine dining Japanese restaurant not a gin and tonic from a brothel.
all in all i can promise you i will NEVER return..there are plenty of other restaurant's i would be happy to give my business to and likewise would be happy to have me
author: michael L.

description: Great setting, very cool bar and wonderful unagi, but the server....AWFUL!!  She's lucky I didn't really care since it was a Monday and the drink didn't really need to be flowing. I haven't in awhile seen such unfriendly, slow and unaccommodating service.
author: Natalie E.

description: Best happy hour sushi in the city!  Amazing rolls (dragon and spicey tuna to name a few) and a fun, chill atmosphere.  Sometimes their glasses of wine aren't filled quite as high as they should be!
author: Stephanie P.

description: a little pricey, but the environment and delicious little bursts of flavor is definately worth it.  Honestly, I go there for the music, the people and the great cocktails.
author: Grace K.

description: Yeah its expensive, but the sushi is great.  The bartenders could work a little harder to curb their attitude in the lounge, but the service by the waitstaff in the restaurant make up for what they lack.  I don't recall her name, but there's a gringa waitress there that speaks perfect japanese.  Her diction alone made me order way more unfiltered sake than I should have ;-)  I asked our sushi chef to make us an original special creation at the end of our meal.  He did this amazing  magic with some toro, sea salt, a blowtorch and a lemon.  Totally worth the price of admission and probably illegal in most places -- that's all I'm sayin.
author: abdullah s.

description: Unfortunately, this place did not live up to the hype. Obviously a magnet for the happy hour FiDi crowd (black jackets and striped shirts--oh my)...and the drinks are decent. Yet, the food was a great disappoint--unrealistically small portions--and items on the menu that could no longer be had...a major faux pas in my book. I did think the sushi was good. This place was saved by the drinks (great sake selection) and the service (very nice people).
author: sshawzam s.

description:
I want to give this place a 3.5 stars since I think the sushi is stellar (always ask for the Omakase -- the sushi chef has yet to disappoint when asked to choose and make his favorite sushi)...but the bar scene is a mess -- and for some reason, it's become more and more obnoxious.

So yes, to food...nyet to the peeps...unless you like that sort of stuff...
author: Hannah H.

description: First, a great sake selection.  Second, a trendy looking bar with great seating.  Third, fresh fish.  Don't drink too much or your wallet will thin like a forty year old's receding hair line, but the sushi here is great.   This is great place to meet friends, go on a date or just try various sakes.
author: Asit P.

description:
We had a business lunch at Ozumo with a modest-sized group of  five people.  The service was horrendous.  Once our order was taken, the wait staff disappeared for 30 minutes.  The food delivery was awkward. Rather than everyone receiving their food at the same time, the plates came out over a 15 to 20 minute period.  We then had to get up and ask for the check, and then had to get up again to get someone to take the check.  

Given the negative service experience, the food was difficult to remember and did not stand out as being overly spectacular or overly poor.

This spot seems to shine for cocktails but leaves something to be desired for dining.
author: Rick R.

description: Admittedly, I'm not a huge sushi/sashimi eater, but after dining at Ozumo, I think that may change. The restaurant is pretty trendy and loud, but the food is damn good and the service was stellar. We had a couple of dishes which our server pointed out were the house specialties, and they were delicious. We ordered sashimi which was extremely fresh and a few sushi rolls which were the best I've ever had in the Bay Area, so far. The restaurant also has an extensive sake list, and our server was extremely knowledgeable about the sakes and offered up very good recommendations. I would definitely dine at Ozumo again, and next time, I'll try the robata which I've heard is also very good.
author: Fern D.

description: 2.5 stars to be exact. Ate at Ozumo's on valentines day of last year. They had a set menu so we didn't try anything on their regular menu. The atmosphere and decor was very nice and spacious. Service was good and knowledgeable wait staff. The food on the other hand was just OK. The so called Kobe beef they served was not tender and over cooked. Tasted more like a choice steak. Nothing memorable about the other dishes. All you heard from my table was "Can you pass the salt please".
author: HUNG L.

description: We went here last week Thursday night for drinks as my friend was in town.  I thought it had a really great mix of people.
author: X Y.

description:
As far as sushi goes, I don't know how one can really screw it up.  It's a simple cut of fish, some rice, and something to wrap it all up in.  Good job Ozumo, you passed the test.

Being an avid enjoyer of sushi, I thought everything tasted great.  I was here with a few clients, and it's a great place to hold a power lunch.  I don't know if I would necessarily come back for dinner, but then again, I haven't been here for dinner yet.

From the moment I walked inside I felt taken care of.  The girls at the front desk had my reservation in the system, and they happily took the flowers I had brought for my clients and held them behind the counter.  I only mention this because it made me feel like less of a wuss after carrying the flowers for the past six blocks.

I think I had exclusively raw cuts of everything, from the appetizers to the cut rolls, and everything was fresh and lacking the "fish smell" you sometimes find with a bad sushi restaurant.  The sake was great, and the restaurant had a very interesting architectural vibe to the interior, which I am sure would have both amused and enthralled me had I been downing more of that lovely fermented rice.

All in all, I give the place 3.5 stars, but I'll round them up to 4 stars for both their reputation and their willingness to hold my flowers up front.  Food was nothing extraordinary, but I bet this would be a neat place to get hammered.
author: Jason B.

description:
Been here on three occasions--once for New Years Eve, once on a date, and once for an office outing.  Had fun each time, but don't believe that was due to the food.  On all three occasions, the people or person I was with were more focused on the unbelievable sake selection.  Tried food on each occasion, but nothing memorable (yes, this could be b/c of alcohol, but give me some credit), so I would have to say that the food wasn't great.    

It's got a nice shi shi vibe with excellent service.  Don't think I'll be back for the food, or for that matter if I have to pay for myself.  To this day, still don't know the range of prices to expect.  It is a great space for celebrations.  In particular, the view of the fireworks on New Years left a lasting impression.
author: Ji-yon Y.

description: Ozumo is, like, THE spot to have cocktails with co-workers and clients and such.  They have a yummy little happy hour menu.  I had lunch there recently.  I ordered some kind of udon or ramen soup.  I loved the noodles.  My soup contained lots of crab, which was nice.  I would recommend Ozumo to anyone who has never been there.
author: Kandi K.

description:
happened along two consecutive nights over a short stay in san francisco.  the company you are with is the most important, but ambiance and hospitality drives it all the way.

kudos to the manager, who made the final night the absolute best.

the food is just something, as well as this particular sake.

for as much as i can remember of the night, definitely a location that i will revisit everytime i'm in town.
author: charles y.

description: Nice ambiance, but disappointed in the sometimes unfriendly service - Pity, this place could be much better with a more positive & welcoming attitude from some of the staff (this may be specific to this specific waitress though)
author: M S.

description: Ozumo is a great restaurant in my humble opinion.  When you first walk in, you see the bar, which is esthetically pleasing.  As you walk further into the restaurant, there you find the sushi bar and more tables.  This restaurant is spacious and nice.  There is a view of the water, which can be romantic I suppose.  The first time I went here, I ordered hamachi sashimi, which was very delicious!  It was a really good grade of fish, and it melted in my mouth.  The seaweed salad is good too.
